boundaries_comment: Ludlow-Taylor desperately needs a new principal if the school is going to capture in-bounds families and reach its capacity. Barring that, I'd rather be rezone for Peabody or granted proximity admission preference to School-Within-School at Goding.
Oyster has capacity problems as it is; will admission by right require investment to prevent this from becoming another lottery situation?
feederpatterns_comment: If this area doesn't feed into Wilson, or a hypothetical Western located in Georgetown, you're going to have a massive exodus of parents to the suburbs. We don't feel comfortable with Cardozo.
eschoicesets_comment: This would be more compelling if (say) Hearst was turned into a French bilingual school.
mschoicesets_comment: My concern is the impact of losing access to Oyster's elementary program on participating in Oyster-Adams MS.
msproximity_comment: We don't feel like Columbia Heights is a part of our community. Francis-Stevens would be more compelling.
hslottery_comment: Again, without guaranteed access to Wilson or a hypothetical Western, this area will lose confidence in DCPS.

boundaries_comment: This is incorrect.  Our current elementary school is Francis-Stevens/Marie Reed (dual-assigned) and we would change to Oyster.  We are, however, elated.  We strongly support this change as I always found it strange how close we are to Oyster without being in-boundary.  While we were considering moving, we would likely stay in our current home to attend Oyster.
feederpatterns_comment: Again, has our current school incorrect.  We do not support feeding into Cardozo.  However, as an overall change to the system that included rezoning for Oyster, this may make sense.  Our neighborhood has many small kids but not as many high school aged children.
eschoicesets_comment: The system seems to have either our address or the boundaries wrong.

boundaries_comment: Our son goes to JO Wilson, not our neighborhood school
feederpatterns_comment: I'm not happy with our in-bound options, so we will do the lottery
eschoicesets_comment: I like this idea generally, but it would depend on which charter is in our choice set.
mschoicesets_comment: Depends on how the new school is set up.
msproximity_comment: Obviously, this coding is incorrect. YSC only serves children incarcerated there.
hslottery_comment: The more we can mix up school attendance, and therefore decrease racial and economic segregation, the better.
setasides_comment: I'm not sure how this would work in reality. I have trouble visualizing it as a solution.

boundaries_comment: Tubman is only two short blocks away, whereas Park View was 7 blocks away, and across busy Georgia Ave.
feederpatterns_comment: Middle School in DC is pretty universally terrible at the moment and Carzdozo has a bad rep. I don't think the idea of my children attending either of these schools, but I'm hopeful that they will improve by the time my child is old enough to attend. Both schools are relatively convenient and close by.
eschoicesets_comment: I could live with this, but I'd much rather have guaranteed access to my neighborhood school.
mschoicesets_comment: Not really sure this will solve the middle school problem... Reserve judgment until this proposal is fleshed out better.
msproximity_comment: Again, not sure what this would accomplish, but not kneejerk against it. Some sort of choice seems like a positive thing.
hslottery_comment: Eliminating guaranteed access would create a ridiculous rat-race for spaces at the top schools, disincentivize improvements at the worst schools, and force some children (and their parents) to commute across the city to go to school.
setasides_comment: Don't really understand how this would affect me.

feederpatterns_comment: Replacing Deal with Hardy is very bad for the neighborhood.  Not only is it much more difficult to access Hardy from Cleveland Park, but Hardy is a much lower performing school than Deal.

boundaries_comment: my kids do not currently attend Tyler, nor will they ever attend there.  The percentage of in-boundary students at Tyler is very low.
feederpatterns_comment: Jefferson is difficult to reach via bike, foot or via public transportation

It's too confusing currently that our children would go to Stuart Hobson if they graduate from JO Wilson, but go to Walker-Jones if they start DCPS at middle school.  This proposal sounds much better and more consistent.
eschoicesets_comment: I'd prefer that we have a consistent home elementary school, but I can see how this would be a useful change and all of these schools are still reasonably close to our house.
mschoicesets_comment: I'm okay with my children's middle school options being further away than their elementary school options.  We'd be happy with just having Stuart Hobson as our choice as it is now.
msproximity_comment: We don't have any other relationship with Wheatley or the elementary schools that feed into it, so this doesn't seem like a positive change.
hslottery_comment: Our children shouldn't have to potentially trek all the way across DC for school.  A citywide lottery with local preference points (if it can't be a guarantee) would be acceptable.
setasides_comment: This seems like a reasonable change.

boundaries_comment: I have to cross two major commercial thoroughfares to access this school by foot - New York Ave NW and NJ Ave NW. These intersections are extremely dangerous to pedestrians and I do not feel safe walking them with my children. Further, I am concerned about the PK-8th grade campus model, as it has not been proven effective elsewhere in the city. There is significant crime in Walker Jones' immediate neighborhood, and metal detectors at the elementary school.
feederpatterns_comment: As stated above, the PS3-8 model is not one that is working. I think all families should have a stand-alone middle school option through DCPS. I would love for my kids to attend Dunbar, which is two blocks from my house. However, until and unless Dunbar offers an outstanding education and can challenge proficient students, it will not be an option for us. I would love to see a test-in academy model at Dunbar.
eschoicesets_comment: A theoretical charter option is not a real option for people to select. Who knows what that school could look like. I fail to see how this choice set option actually improves any of the schools (or student experiences) within the choice set. Selfishly, I would be happy to have an in-bounds preference at Thomson, which is vastly superior to my in boundary Walker Jones. But what of the 65% of kids in boundary for Thomson who currently attend that school, which maintains a significant waiting list.
mschoicesets_comment: As stated above, the PS3-8 model is not one that is working. I think all families should have a stand-alone middle school option through DCPS.
msproximity_comment: Neither of these are acceptable options to our family at this time. The proximity preference does not solve this problem. I suggest a re-opened test-in Shaw middle school.
hslottery_comment: I should think this is a good idea because my in-boundary option is not good. But you do not solve the problem by redistributing the small number of acceptable school seats.
setasides_comment: Again, you are not improving anything here. You are simply moving the problems around and creating pressures on the high performing schools, which DCPS should be striving to replicate, not dismantle. It is a laudable goal for all schools to have 10-20% of seats for students assigned to low performing schools. But you are talking about a miniscule number of overall seats compared to the number of children assigned to low performing schools.

boundaries_comment:
This makes me extremely angry. I bought my house with the intention of sending my child to Barnard - which is safely walkable from our home. Under no circumstance will my child EVER attend LaSalle. If these boundary changes take effect we will leave DCPS in favor of charters, enroll our child in private school or move out of DC entirely. 

LaSalle is not only far away from my house, it is completely disjointed from our lives. We NEVER go over to that neighborhood for ANYTHING. Let alone to educate our child. Absolutely no way. Never.
feederpatterns_comment: We need a quality middle school. Period.
eschoicesets_comment: There is no way that my child will EVER attend any of those schools. She will go to Barnard (if our boundaries are maintained) or she will go to a charter school or private school. Or we will move out of DC entirely.
mschoicesets_comment: Possible. But probably not.
msproximity_comment:
Mamie D Lee is a special needs school. This makes no sense at all. 

As stated above, there is absolutely NOT A CHANCE IN THE WORLD that my child will ever attend LaSalle. Never. That school is so far away from my house and completely disjointed from our lives. We NEVER go over to that neighborhood for ANYTHING. Let alone to educate our child.
hslottery_comment: I think this is a terrible idea. But if the boundaries DO in fact change, then i hope it takes effect. the new boundaries are WORSE than this idea.
setasides_comment: don't change the boundaries and i won't NEED a set-aside. DON'T CHANGE THE BOUNDARIES.

boundaries_comment: Although our family would continue to go to Murch, I believe the southern boundary change would negatively impact neighborhood schools.   Children should have the right to attend walkable neighborhood schools.  This change would cause children who live closer to Murch than our family does to attend a school they would likely have to be driven too.
eschoicesets_comment: I believe in neighborhood schools.  While all the schools in my choice set are great DCPS elementary schools, I prefer the predictability of one assigned neighborhood elementary school.
mschoicesets_comment: Hardy Middle School is a considerable distance from our home.  Deal is a few blocks away.  We chose our home, in part, because of its proximity to schools.  Commuting for families is difficult enough as it is. I am opposed to families being asked to do this unless they are commuting to a school by choice for a specialty program.
hslottery_comment: I believe in neighborhood schools and oppose a citywide lottery.  High school students should not be forced to commute to school unless their families are seeking a specialized program like the arts program at Duke Ellington.

boundaries_comment: We're not crazy about this but we could live with this.
eschoicesets_comment: Not knowing what school my child would go to is a problem.  In addition, one of these schools is walking distance and the other two are considerably farther away which would create a hardship for my family.
mschoicesets_comment: This proposal would assign my kid from a high-performing school to a low-performing school.
msproximity_comment: One school is walking distance from my house and very good, the other is a drive/bus and lower-performing.  I do not like being reassigned from a good school to a lower performing school.
hslottery_comment: This is a terrible idea.  It would be utter insanity to create total uncertainty for parents and students who may wind up going to a lousy school far, far away from their home.  This option is the nuclear option that would force us to sell our house and move out of DC.

boundaries_comment: Maury is already overcapacity in-bounds for the 3 and 4 year old program. Expanding the boundaries will only make this worse.

No one should be forced to attend a lower performing school. Murch was our school when we bought our home, and began building our life in DC.  Changing that will force us to change our life plan, including possibly looking into a new home and building a life somewhere other than DC.
feederpatterns_comment: We prefer the current plan: Murch, to Deal, to Wilson.  Those were the boundaries when we bought our home, and began building our life in DC.  Changing that will force us to change our life plan, including possibly looking into a new home and building a life somewhere other than DC.
eschoicesets_comment: The term "choice set" is misleading.  It is a lottery.  We will not live with this level of uncertainty about our children's education.  Additionally, we should not be forced to attend schools that are quite a distance from our home, when there are three (Hearst, Murch, Janney) within walking distance.  We moved here because we value having a walkable lifestyle.  If DC does not value neighborhoods, and families being able to have walkable lifestyles, and instead forces us to drive, putting more cars on the road during rush hour, we will consider moving to elsewhere.
mschoicesets_comment: The term "choice set" is misleading.  It is a lottery. Deal is a much better school.  We will not stay in a place where we have this level of uncertainty of our children's education.  We will not stay where there is a game being played over whether our child can attend the good junior high that is a few blocks away.
msproximity_comment: Oyster Adams is ten times the distance than Deal. We moved here because we value having a walkable lifestyle.  If DC does not value neighborhoods, and families being able to have walkable lifestyles, and instead forces us to drive, putting more cars on the road during rush hour, we will consider moving elsewhere.
hslottery_comment: A lottery is a game.  It is gambling.  Treating our children like a game is unacceptable.  We will not live a place with this level of uncertainty about our children's education. We are so close to Wilson that their football games in the fall interfere with our child's bedtime.  We should be guaranteed to go to a school this close.  This is not Cambridge; people in DC can just move a couple miles to Maryland and have guaranteed access to good schools.  We do not have to stay in DC and live with this plan.  Lotteries, as opposed to neighborhood schools, will put more cars on the road and more people on public transportation during an already heavily-congested rush hour.  It will add a lot of time to parents' and children's commutes, decreasing the quality of life for families, and taking away quality time that could be spent at home, cooking or playing.
setasides_comment: This does not help most students in low-performing schools.  I am shocked so much energy is going into trying to assist a few students from low-performing schools instead of putting energy into improving low-performing schools, and thus actually helping ALL students at low-performing schools have access to quality education.  Where is the plan for improving low-performing schools?

boundaries_comment: Makes sense for us to feed into Cooke as we are closer.  But, the principal there has no interest in parent outreach and engagement and believes that even a monthly newsletter is too much to ask.  She attended maybe 3 PTA meetings in the entire 4 years I was there.
feederpatterns_comment: Doesn't really affect us - our kids go to Bancroft.  But, it's silly for Cooke to feed into CHEC because it is not bilingual.  Also, this would be a death knell for Cooke because no one in the middle class set wants to send their kids to CHEC or Cardozo EC.  Deputy mayor for educationhosted a meeting at The CHEC campus to talk about boundary changes and the principal didn't even show up.  If she were interested in reaching out to middle class parents she would be at these meetings.  Cooke should feed into Deal.
eschoicesets_comment: Our kids go to Bancroft now.  I like that we would get a choice set for that school.
msproximity_comment: Doesn't seem to make sense - CHEC is closer to our house.  And, my kids will be bilingual, but if my kids weren't bilingual than Adams would make no sense either.
hslottery_comment: I hate that idea - this only makes the current problem worse.
setasides_comment: that seems like a good idea

boundaries_comment: We are very happy at Lafayette.  Thanks to both our local community, families and D.C. for long-standing partnership that makes this school great.
feederpatterns_comment: The primary factor in where we purchased a home was to attend Lafayette, Deal and Wilson.
eschoicesets_comment: These are all 3 great schools and comparable in terms of quality.  However, I don't see a particular upside for using choice sets in this neighborhood.  The downsides are considerable: traffic and loss of a local neighborhood ES.  There are many working families in NW (2-income households) and every morning and evening counts in terms of crunch time on the road and quality time to spend with family.  We walk to Lafayette or carpool with our neighbors.  That goes away with the other options. And what about siblings?  One to Lafayette and one somewhere else? This is an interesting academic exercise, but it makes NO practical sense.
mschoicesets_comment: This feels like we are all lab-rats in a strange experiment.
msproximity_comment: We will not attend Brightwood EC under any circumstances.  It is several bridges too far for our family, both in terms of education and transportation.

boundaries_comment: I would like J.O. Wilson to be utilized more by the local neighbors. It would be great for the neighborhood to embrace the school and send their kids there.
feederpatterns_comment: Stuart Hobson looks ok as a middle school but I don't we will go to Eastern HS unless the reading and math test scores greatly improve.
eschoicesets_comment: I don't think this choice set is much different than being matched with my neighborhood school and getting proximity preference to the others. I do not like the idea that I don't know which school my child would go to. I (and my neighbors) started volunteering at our inbound when our kids were babies. I would be very upset if the inbound changed. As new parents, I definitely would not invest time or energy into a neighborhood school if I could end up at a different school. Terrible idea.
mschoicesets_comment: Again, I do not like knowing which school my child would attend.
msproximity_comment: I do not like not knowing which school my child would attend.
hslottery_comment: I do not like knowing where my child would go to school. I would end up waiting for the lottery with a back-up plan. If I didn't get my PLANNED choice, I'd have to go with plan B to ensure that I have a known back-up plan.
setasides_comment: I think any plan that helps students in low-performing schools "get out" and have a better chance is a good idea. 10%-20% seems reasonable.

eschoicesets_comment: Both the current boundaries and the proposed boundaries zone my kids to elementary schools that I am not very enthusiastic about but might be able to live with (BMPV and Tubman).  This choice set would eliminate any predictability about where my kids would go, thus diminishing my ability to invest in improving the neighborhood school.  It would also introduce the possibility that my kids would end up at Raymond, where I would not consider enrolling them.
mschoicesets_comment: In principle, a new middle school is desperately needed in my area.  But without any details, I find it hard to support this plan.
msproximity_comment: Raymond is terrible.  West is far away.  Both are education campuses, rather than stand-alone middle schools, and therefore lack the number of students necessary to support a rich array of offerings.
hslottery_comment: Although I would not consider Cardozo for my kids right now, I also strongly dislike the idea of stripping away all predictability about where my kids would go to high school if they remain in DCPS.
setasides_comment: It's important to think about how to distribute quality education more equitably.  But I think that an even greater priority should be to create more opportunities for everyone to obtain a high-quality education at a predictable school without having to travel half-way across the city.

eschoicesets_comment: This is the worst scenario because as a parent you lose the stability of knowing you can attend your neighborhood school and there will still be winners and losers. Plus, this removes any escape hatch at all for children who end up in choice options where all the options are sub par or lowish quality.
mschoicesets_comment: I am pleased they are considering putting a middle school is Ward 4, however since it doesn't exists and no resources are dedicated to it, it's hard to know what the ultimate quality of the school will be. However I think having the middle schools focus on things like STEM or Dual Language is a great option.
hslottery_comment: Since the high school we are currently zoned to attend is sub-par with truly terrible literacy and math proficiency rates and is very under enrolled, I'd welcome more options if they were actual options not just shuttling across town to attend a different sub-par low performing school.
setasides_comment: I think set asides provide a good option as an escape hatch for some people, but they don't address the overall quality issue, which is my true area of concern.

boundaries_comment: Both of my children were born while I have lived in this house (2002 and 2009) and neither has attended Ludlow Taylor.
eschoicesets_comment: I have sent both children to SWS. Would not consider straight Montessori and JO Wilson and Miner are farther from my house than Peabody. Ludlow Taylor is only starting to become a decent school.
mschoicesets_comment: Hine and Jefferson are not acceptable and are much farther away then Stuart.
msproximity_comment: Wheatley is completely unacceptable and has dangerous roads to navigate for a middle schooler.k
setasides_comment: We need a test in middle and high school, rather than trying to avoid bad schools.

boundaries_comment: We're currently in-boundary for Powell and are joining with other parents excited about attending next year for PK4, so upset to hear that we'd be re-zoned. It seems strange that Bruce Monroe's boundary includes so much land where no one lives (Soldier's Home and Wash Hosp Ctr) and almost none of the area where so many Hispanic families live.  I think dual language Spanish is an important and desirable offering, but we're equidistant between two dual-language schools and would would like another option where it's not a primary focus.
feederpatterns_comment: The missing Middle School is of greatest concern and I don't know anyone who's satisfied with education campuses.  We want a stand alone middle school.  Dealing with kids at that age is tough enough without muddling the effort with lower or higher grades.   Much of the DME proposals would be easier to consider if we could envision what that school would be.  Perhaps a dual language program exists within that middle school to accept students from the two dual-language ES.  There's not much that makes sense for this area past 5th grade and that's a huge problem for those of us who want to maintain parental involvement in neighborhood schools past Kindergarten and 1st grade.
eschoicesets_comment: Again, two dual-language schools within one choice set does not make a lot of sense.  Also, nothing in the choice set looks good to me without predictability at the MS and HS levels.
mschoicesets_comment: It's difficult to see the appeal without a middle school to consider.  I like the idea of choice for special programming, but how could I know that the programming I want is in my choice set?
msproximity_comment: Very much dislike education campuses.  Very, very, very much.  I want my future 11 year old to feel that he's progressed from the realm of pre-schoolers but not yet concerned with the realm of high schoolers.
hslottery_comment: Hard to sell this as a replacement for proximity access to high schools.  I can see city-wide lottery to specialty programming as an option, but everyone should have right to their neighborhood school.  I wish this proposal would get taken off the table - it's become a real distraction for those of us who want (NEED) quality neighborhood schools.
setasides_comment: Considering that we'd be competing with all the other low-performing schools, this doesn't hold much appeal. I'd rather see effort going into improving our local school, which would be first on my list if it had more to offer.

boundaries_comment: Powell has devoted significant effort in outreach to our neighborhood and we have just started getting neighborhood support for Powell. It is a bad time to derail those efforts and will disappoint neighbors who just moved in with plans to attend Powell.
feederpatterns_comment: We are currently inbound for Deal and Wilson. Replacing those options with West and Roosevelt is a non-starter. Everyone will leave DCPS rather than attend those schools.
eschoicesets_comment: None of those schools are attractive options. Our closest school, Powell, is left out.
mschoicesets_comment: We are currently inbounds for Deal. Who knows if "New School" will ever get built and one option does not provide much choice (particularly a mythical option).
msproximity_comment: Again, we are currently inbounds for Deal. The drop off from Deal to an EC is significant and not reasonable or acceptable.
hslottery_comment: Predictability is important and this idea eliminates predictability.
setasides_comment: This is a good idea.

boundaries_comment: We are very unhappy with the possibility of losing Barnard as our neighborhood school. Our daughter will be entering PK3 in Fall of 2015, and we were very happy that she would have neighborhood preference there. I DO NOT WANT my 3 year old going to school with 8th graders.
feederpatterns_comment: I'm not yet focused on middle and high school options yet - and I feel that there is a lot of time for schools to improve between now and when we need them, so I'm more open to possible changes.
eschoicesets_comment: I am a big believer in neighborhood schools, particularly at the elementary school level, and I really feel something is lost by not preserving that. Not to mention that the over-reliance on the lottery brings a lot of uncertainty and stress to the process.
mschoicesets_comment: Not as worried about this at the middle school level, but again, I am not a fan of the uncertainty that this enters into the system. It's hard to get families and neighborhoods to invest in particular schools, when you don't know where you will be going.
hslottery_comment: The lottery is so stressful for families. I don't want to make this the only way a child can go to school. Every family should know that their child has a guaranteed spot in a neighborhood school through graduation.

feederpatterns_comment: CHEC makes no sense to feed to, since Cooke is not a dual language school. It is a MAJOR DISAPPOINTMENT to be removed from Wilson and sent to Cardozo. We would move before sending our child there.
eschoicesets_comment: I actually think that this has a real potential to improve neighborhood schools east of Rock Creek Park. I think it's a good idea worth exploring.
mschoicesets_comment: It's hard to evaluate this without knowing what schools will be in the set. I certainly agree that each person should be able to attend a stand-alone middle-school (or a choice set of several stand-alone middle schools), rather than the education campuses that permeate DC right now.
msproximity_comment: This would only work if the choice includes at least one stand-alone middle school (not an EC).
hslottery_comment: I expect that the complete lack of certainty here would encourage many people--my family included--to seek out charters and/or move to the 'burbs.
setasides_comment: Those who are in-boundary for a failing school should definitely get a preference in the out-of-boundary lottery. The 10% set-aside actually seems low to me. Ideally, DCPS would improve the failing schools so the set-asides weren't necessary, but frankly I don't think this can be done with current DCPS leadership, so the set-asides seem like the fairest way to give people a choice outside of their failing school. In general, those in failing schools should receive lottery seats before those in achieving schools, whether through a set-aside or a general out-of-boundary slot.

eschoicesets_comment: I would prefer to know exactly where my child would go.
mschoicesets_comment: Deal or nothing.
msproximity_comment: West is too far away. Want to know where my child would go. No lottery.
hslottery_comment: No lottery. We would move out of DC without access to great schools.
setasides_comment: Percentage seems a little high and higher performing schools should not be over crowded but concept has merit.

boundaries_comment: Right now my kids walk 4 blocks to Murch. Hearst is too far to walk plus dangerous because there are not enough traffic lights and safe places to cross. I would have to drive them to school every day. This is a very bad idea.
feederpatterns_comment: Hearst is a lower-performing school than Murch. I have concerns about that. But at least it still feeds into Deal and Wilson.
eschoicesets_comment: Who thought up the word "choice set" - George Orwell? This is more like a shell game where you think you have a choice but they shove you where they want you. In our case, away from a school we can walk to to something very far away for young kids. What a bad idea!
mschoicesets_comment: See above. This is "3 card monty" not a "choice." Deal is acceptable for us. Hardy is not. My friend sent her son to Hardy for half a year and fled because he was learning nothing. You won't make Hardy better by trying to scam families with "choice sets" - you will have just have 2 Hardys because people like us will go to Catholic school. On the other hand, if you made Hardy better by hiring a new principal and great new teachers and pushed academic excellence and safety (now Hardy is full of fights and kids who leave as "below basic" as when they entered) then my family would consider Hardy. But only as a real choice not a fake forced choice.
msproximity_comment: Again, Deal is the only choice for us. That is why we moved to our neighborhood.
hslottery_comment: Lottery is the worst idea ever. Who thought that up? Wilson would not be Wilson without the families from the Wilson neighborhood who go there. It is the only functioning (and diverse) non-test HS in the city. Lottery won't give equal access to Wilson, it will Dunbar-ize every non-test high school in the city.
setasides_comment: I think the "set asides" idea translates as "Kaya Henderson and Abigail Smith have not been able to improve low performing schools, so they are trying to create a bigger escape hatch." If I were in one of those neighborhoods with low performing schools I would want to escape, too. I don't mind kids from other neighborhoods going to Lafayette and Murch and Janney and Deal and Wilson. That is part of what makes those schools diverse and successful now. But are "set asides" a long term plan for success in DCPS as a system? If I did my job like Smith and Henderson do theirs I would be fired! Instead of working to make low performing schools better they are just trying to cram everyone into the few schools that work. And these schools work because of great teachers, principals, and involved families. Kicking neighborhood families out of their neighborhood schools to make room for 20% more out of neighborhood kids will not solve the basic problems in DCPS and will instead create new problems.

feederpatterns_comment: I have no problem with setting aside some portion of space for out of boundary students, but I believe the school should maintain strict discipline standards, and children who will not meet those standards should not be allowed to remain and disrupt education for others. DCPS needs to focus intense resources on fixing the culture in all schools - and different schools will require different remedies - not simply sending kids cross town.
hslottery_comment: Fastest way to tank housing values, for families with school kids and those without who just live in the District. Families need predictability. Simply bussing a kid crosstown isn't going to improve educational outcome (thought it might worsen it for others as people pull their kids from DCPS). Better to focus effort on fixing all schools, and the unique problems each one faces.
setasides_comment: Not necessarily opposed to this, but again, if all kids had a good performing school, this would be less of an issue.

boundaries_comment: I'm delighted that the boundaries will remain the same for our neighborhood school.  We moved specifically to be able to walk to a high quality local school with our children, and we're excited to be part of a dynamic school community.
We think this is fantastic news, and reflects the reality that Harvard St. is firmly rooted in Mt. Pleasant.
feederpatterns_comment: This proposed feeder pattern would make it possible for us to stay in our home for the long-term.

boundaries_comment: My children don't attend Tyler (nor will they) but as a nearby neighbor, the streets cannot handle the large volume of children arriving by car from all over the city. Frankly, the boundary is somewhat meaningless for the Spanish Immersion program that seeks students from across the city.
feederpatterns_comment: Very few in-boundary Tyler students have the means to transport to SW for middle school. Eliot-Hine is walkable. Jefferson is not.
eschoicesets_comment: I don't think in-boundary Brent families will ever select Friendship PCS.  If it intends to diversify the student bodies of the three schools, I don't think this will happen.

boundaries_comment: It's hard to know without knowing what Van Ness' boundary will be.  Reserving out of bounds spots at better-performing schools for kids who live in-bounds for low-performing-schools would give me a better chance of getting into a school with higher scores than Amidon, but I worry about what that will do for the kids left behind at Amidon and other schools like it.
feederpatterns_comment: You have cut off one of the most diverse neighborhoods in Wilson's boundary.  This causes civil rights concerns.  Also, it makes me less willing to try Jefferson (which seems to be doing great and has a great principal!) because I'd want to get into a school that feeds into Wilson or a high-performing charter high school.
eschoicesets_comment:
I didn't realize that Eagle had decided to join this choice set.  Is that accurate?  I don't know much about the school, but when I've checked its website it seems to keep getting hacked by ads for generic cialis.  That's not encouraging.  There's no demographic or performance data on the myschools DC website for the NJ Ave. campus.  I wouldn't want to be forced to travel to their other campus.  Also, it only goes to Grade 3. Would its charter expand, or would kids be reassigned after that?  

So basically I'd have a raffle where the "prizes" are my current low-performing school, a charter with no information that only goes to 3rd grade, and Van Ness--which doesn't yet exist and won't serve upper grades at first.  NOT AN IMPROVEMENT.
msproximity_comment: Jefferson is a lot more convenient, but they perform about equally well.
hslottery_comment:
Assigning SW to Eastern should NOT be considered a done deal!  People in 20024 and 20003 don't contribute much to Wilson's overcrowding.  People who get into Hearst and other Wilson-feeding schools out of boundary at age 3 and now feel they have a right to go to Wilson 15 years from now (and send younger siblings 20 years from now) are causing the problem.  Putting SW and Near SE in Eastern makes both schools less diverse and risks the US Dept. of Education finding a civil rights violation.  

I don't like a city-wide lottery, because I don't trust many middle and high schoolers to travel in safe and non-disruptive ways, and frankly I doubt that some kids' parents will even enter them in the lottery, and then what do you do in September when they just show up at the closest school?  

I also don't believe DCPS will sustain high-quality opportunities at schools with mostly underperforming kids.  They either won't offer things like AP classes, lots of sports teams, a school newspaper, science research, etc. or they'll water them down by filling the classes with 75% kids who are well below grade level and keep the 25% who could actually benefit from the class from learning.
setasides_comment:
It'll help the kids who win the lottery and get to go elsewhere (who are also the ones with parents who can do research, enter the online lottery, and get the kids across town...ie, the ones who will likely be more successful anyway, and whose parents will be more involved in whatever school their kids attend) and hurt the kids who are left behind.

It's kind of the same thing as the current destination school rule: it drains off kids whose parents get them into Deal or Hardy feeder schools, reducing test scores and the size of the student body (and thus funding and opportunities) at places like Amidon, especially in the upper grades.

boundaries_comment: It would be positive to update the boundary for Hearst such that it could truly become a neighborhood school. The current boundaries for Hearst make no sense since a majority of the area is parkland, commercial property, embassies or UDC/ Howard law.
feederpatterns_comment: Having a straight forward, school-of-right feeder pattern is very important to our family.

boundaries_comment: Maury ES is already over capacity and all pre-school and pre-k, inbounds, families are not accepted. IF the Maury ES boundary expands, the school's planned expansion needs to be put back on track especially if set-asides are also considered.
feederpatterns_comment: We need to develop stronger feeder patterns in the District, ensuring programs are aligned and students don't slip through the cracks.
eschoicesets_comment: I believe the proposal included Maury, Miner and Payne not Peabody/Watkins.  Please check the data.
mschoicesets_comment: Great options, though the real issue is that both Eliot-Hine and Jefferson are dramatically under-enrolled.  Until the schools expand the programming that is needed to attract students is not available through the DCPS budget.  We're in a catch-22 and the solution - building better neighborhood schools - is not being discussed.
msproximity_comment: The options should not be the geographic closest but the closest within the same HS feeder pattern to better promote programmatic continuity and vertical alignment within a neighborhood.
hslottery_comment: We need strong matter of right neighborhood / comprehensive high schools. Proposals to make all high school assignments via lottery is a non-starter and my family would leave DCPS if this proposal moves forward.
setasides_comment: Great way to promote diversity in our schools.  Though we need to look at school capacity and make a determination about what % of out of bounds children should be admitted at neighborhood schools vs destination schools (ie, larger elementary schools on transit lines that could accommodate larger out of bounds percentages).

boundaries_comment:
Both Murch and Janney elementary schools are incredibly overcrowded and would become more so under current boundaries.  It simply makes sense to shift the boundaries to a school with some capacity, namely Hearst.  Of course, no current Murch or Janney families should have to switch, and the transition could happen with little interruption of current enrollment.

As an alternative, the boundaries of Murch and Janney could be perserved close to their physical locations, and the boundary of Hearst expanded east of Connecticut (Murch) or west of Wisconsin (Janney).
hslottery_comment: A truly bad idea.  Large amounts of uncertainty would undermine the investments of time, energy, and money that many parents have made in their local schools across the city.
setasides_comment: Seems like a reasonable proposal, but would have to be balanced against school capacity and the right of in-boundary families to attend their own school.  Would make most sense if the set asides only applied to the first grade at a school.

feederpatterns_comment: Oyster Adams currently has DC CAS proficiency rates around (or over, I believe) 80%.  Cardozo has proficiency rates around 20%.  Our child -- a sixth grader at Adams --- will not attend Cardozo, nor with any of the other kids in his peer group, made up of high achieving kids from a wide variety of economic and cultural backgrounds.  Cardozo is an absolutely unacceptable choice for Oyster Adams parents.  If that change is made, the ONLY result will be do dramatically drive down results at Adams and hurt the most vulnerable kids at Adams, since the only kids who will still attend will be in-boundary kids without options.
eschoicesets_comment: When we moved to DC in 2009, we chose our house based 100% on the school that was available.  We visited schools in Arlington, DC and Maryland before we ever looked at a single house.   The same goes for everyone we know.  Our neighbors tell us that 20 years ago, our neighborhood was very different.  It has changed dramatically for the better as families have moved in and committed to living in the city and sending their kids to the schools.  Removing the ability for families who are committed to public school to move into an area with certainty about where their kids will attend school will reverse that progress.
mschoicesets_comment: When we moved to DC in 2009, we chose our house based 100% on the school that was available.  We visited schools in Arlington, DC and Maryland before we ever looked at a single house.   The same goes for everyone we know.  Our neighbors tell us that 20 years ago, our neighborhood was very different.  It has changed dramatically for the better as families have moved in and committed to living in the city and sending their kids to the schools.  Removing the ability for families who are committed to public school to move into an area with certainty about where their kids will attend school will reverse that progress.
msproximity_comment: We would not send our child to Francis Stevens.  No one with options is going to buy a house or lease an apartment where their kids can either go to a school with proficiency rates in the 80s or the 40s and no certainty about which.   People require certainly.
hslottery_comment: Our child -- a sixth grader at Adams --- will not attend Cardozo, nor with any of the other kids in his peer group, made up of high achieving kids from a wide variety of economic and cultural backgrounds.  Cardozo is an absolutely unacceptable choice for Oyster Adams parents.  Likewise, a city lottery where our child would potentially re-live the 1970s social experiment of busing is absolutely unacceptable.  We would move out of DC, as would most folks we know who have options --- the exact folks that the DME is hoping to redistribute around the district in order to improve failing schools.  Whoever came up with this idea seems utterly out of touch with the realities that drive the success of high-performing DC schools.  No parents of high-performing kids who have the option will stay in DC if their only option is a citywide lottery.  The kids that the DME hope to distribute in this social experiment will leave, and the city will be left will all failing schools.
setasides_comment: This seems like potentially a good idea, but in any case our child will never attend Cardozo, and we would not gamble on set asides.  We will move --- either to the Wilson boundary if scenario B is adopted or out of DC if the lottery or choice set options are adopted.

boundaries_comment: Families that will be rezoned should be grandfathered into the current school to avoid disrupting the child.
eschoicesets_comment: This is a horrible idea
msproximity_comment: why not assign the closest school
hslottery_comment: this would be a mess for the city
setasides_comment: This is a great idea to give some students the opportunity to go to a better school than their local school but the real issue is that many neighborhood schools are not that great and this needs to be fixed.  The idea to save a proportion of seats for low performing schools is only a bandaide and only will help a few students.

eschoicesets_comment:
It's not clear to me how this relates to the current system of lottery. If we don't like our choice set options, what do we do? Does the out of boundary lottery still exist?

What's more, we are enrolled in Capitol Hill Montessori, which has a very specific educational philosophy. Putting a Montessori school in a choice set makes no sense to me. That school currently operates as a city-wide lottery rather than a neighborhood school. Some have suggested that there should be proximity preference, which I support, but I do not support putting that school into a choice set because then people who wouldn't choose a Montessori education get assigned to the school. That seems like a disaster. The same proposal suggests that SWS (which needs a new name) would be in the same choice set as CHMSL: DCPS is suggesting that students randomly be assigned a Montessori or Reggio Emilio education rather than a traditional one? Perhaps these are district anomalies, but both schools need a student body with parents dedicated to the educational philosophy, not simply living nearby.
mschoicesets_comment: Again, having schools specialize - which seems positive - and then random assignments seems contrary. If I have a child interested in language, I don't want her randomly assigned to a school focused on math and science, and vice versa. Some sort of hybrid might make sense - like proximity preference to the 3 closest middle schools if you don't want your feeder or neighborhood school.
hslottery_comment: Why? How does this improve our schools in any way?
setasides_comment: How is this different than what already happens, functionally? Students from low performing schools want out so they apply for lottery spots. Are you suggesting that schools like Wilson would be forced to have 20% out of boundary students from low performing schools? What does enrollment look like now? Where does that leave neighborhood students?

boundaries_comment: So grateful we're in an autonomous school, because this process has made me lose what little confidence I've had in DCPS et al.  Just where did the advisory committee get authority to propose redistributing wealth in the city via school "choice sets?"
feederpatterns_comment: It better remain the same, or I'm moving to VA - I'm not going to continue to pay DC taxes only to be gerrymandered to lesser, non-neighborhood school.
eschoicesets_comment: Who the hell thought that redistributing students around upper NW would be a good idea?  Most people with kids bought homes based on walkability to neighborhood schools, and the communities that engendered, as well as their commutes and other factors.
mschoicesets_comment:
I don't give a flying fig about "special focus" middle school - I care about my child being able to walk to our local neighborhood school where all of his friends will be going.  Why would you think it is good idea for jr. high and high school students, whose circadian cycles have them rising later in the morning, to have longer school commutes?
And did anyone bother to think about kids from two homes?  There a number of families with one parent living in Maryland or east of Rock Creek Park, which means an even longer commutes for these kids when coming from their other homes.
msproximity_comment: I need a guarantee right to our current feeder schools, or I'm done with D.C.
hslottery_comment: Why do you think that redistributing the few good seats is going to improve education across the city?  That has backfired in cities like San Fransisco and Cambridge, where families that don't get into the few choice schools simply leave.
setasides_comment: There you go redistributing wealth again.  Has anyone thought through how this will work in the schools in upper NW that are already overcrowded?

feederpatterns_comment: let kids stay at k-8 and improve the quality.  keep families together and provide teachers and administrators who make choices about curriculum, instruction and school climate that are based on decent understanding of child development.
setasides_comment: quit fooling around in admin offices and get the real work done in schools

feederpatterns_comment: I think this feeder pattern language is misleading. As I have heard, Burroughs will feed to the new Brookland MS in 2014-2015, not to "Brookland EC at Bunker Hill".
eschoicesets_comment: I don't believe the choice sets are a good idea in any form or configuration. Improve all schools, don't just slice the pie differently. Charters should remain outside of the neighborhood system and I do not believe in neighborhood preference for charters.
mschoicesets_comment: This should be renamed Brookland MS.
msproximity_comment: This is a silly choice because both Burroughs and Brookland ES will feed to Brookland MS.
hslottery_comment: Citywide lottery for HS creates more traffic problems and would increase truancy exponentially.  Again, improve all schools and don't just slice the pie in different ways.

boundaries_comment: I have been engaged with my current boundary school long before we had a child believing that this is the way to make neighborhoods and neighborhood schools better. Now we have a child who will be starting school in 2015. I have no faith in Cleveland ES and will likely have to find a charter school, win the lottery and then drive my kid to and from school every day.  Or leave the city.
mschoicesets_comment: A new school?
hslottery_comment: I would never in a million years send my child to Cardozo. So maybe a lottery is better??  Really, we need better highschools. It's total BS that only students of wealthy parents who can afford the real estate west of rock creek get a good high school education at Wilson.
setasides_comment: Again, we just need better schools in general. Taking kids out of low performing schools just screws everyone over. Need to make all the schools better.

boundaries_comment: This doesn't make any sense, Peabody is the feeder to Watkins in the Cluster. Changing my school fr
hslottery_comment: I want my kids to have a tie to the neighborhood and want them tone able to walk to school with their siblings to the same school.

feederpatterns_comment: Continuing to Deal as previously planned with the original feeder pattern is ideal.
msproximity_comment: My child is in an out of bounds elementary school (Hearst) and I would like him to continue on to middle school with his current classmates.  I am currently in bounds for this middle school (Deal) but neither of these middle schools would be destinations for most of my child's current classmates who would likely go on to Deal themselves.

feederpatterns_comment: This does not account for the parenthetical in the DME plans that said Shepherd could feed to the new north middle school and, presumably, to Coolidge ("Explore Option: Feeder rights to North Middle School, once established").  My rating would change considerably were the parenthetical to become the mandatory feeder pattern.

eschoicesets_comment: Wheatley and Browne are both a mess. It would be a choice, but a terrible one.  Between a rock and a hard place.

boundaries_comment: The way this explained doesn't make sense. Changing my primary school to Watkins from Peabody doesn't make sense since Peabody is the feeder school to Watkins. I assume this plan would keep me in the Cluster (both schools) regardless of the semantics of my "primary" boundary school.
eschoicesets_comment: I like being primarily assigned to the Cluster first.
mschoicesets_comment: Again, I like Stuart Hobson the best and would like it to remain my primary boundary school.
hslottery_comment: The worst idea. Kids should be able to walk to their school with their siblings. No parent wants to drive around the whole city to drop off kids in 4 different places. Stupid idea all around!

eschoicesets_comment: I don't like the idea at all.  We moved out of one school's boundaries into the other because it offered a better option for our daughter entering K.  If we hadn't had that option, we might have left DC.  I think, too, that there is a massive undervaluing of the sense of community families and children get when they and the other children around them attend the same school, can walk there, get to know neighbors, etc.  It's not just a numbers game, it's a way to build strong communities.
mschoicesets_comment: A choice set for middle school would bother me a lot less.  The kids are older, schools are bigger, and many kids are ready for greater differentiation at that point.
hslottery_comment: Boo - terrible idea.  Look at San Francisco.  No one goes to public school if they can afford private.  That is NOT the kind of educational disparity we want here in DC!
setasides_comment: Interesting idea - would need to learn more about.

eschoicesets_comment: Powell makes sense. The others do not.
mschoicesets_comment: Looking forward to the new school,

boundaries_comment: The test scores at this school are horrendous.  We all need quality neighborhood public school options.
feederpatterns_comment: Again, this set of neighborhood schools needs a lot of improvement. Improve our neighborhood schools!
eschoicesets_comment: None of these choices are acceptable.  All of these schools have very low test scores.
mschoicesets_comment: I have only heard of one of the three choices, but I am not hopeful that these school are any better than the elementary school choices.
msproximity_comment: My middle school choice is neither of these. Stuart Hobson middle school is my preference.
hslottery_comment: Not acceptable. Very low test scores and low graduation and college acceptance rate.
setasides_comment: This is a good option for those of us in-bounds for low performing schools. This is a band-aid though, ideally we would fix the low performing schools so that everyone has access to a good neighborhood public school.

boundaries_comment: If a neighborhood school isn't thriving, shouldn't families have a better chance to go someplace else?
We've been at Brent for 7 years and 3 children...will be 9 total. Happy to hear that my house within eyesight of the school will still be in bounds.
feederpatterns_comment: Our children will be attending a charter or private middle and high school, starting with our oldest who will leave Brent a year early to attend Basis DC next Fall.
msproximity_comment: Stuart Hobson can not accommodate all the Hill kids who desire to go there.

boundaries_comment: This is a safe and very walkable boundary for Brent. I don't agree that capacity issues will be a concern (or at least it is too soon to tell). I SY13-14 bump of PreS applicants established capacity fears, but the SY14-15 applicant figures were down significantly and should calm those fears.
feederpatterns_comment: I give it credit for being a predictable, neighborhood pattern - an idea I fully support. The programs are not in the middle/high schools yet to get young families excited about the post-elementary options.
eschoicesets_comment: Choice sets are a bad idea. Elementary kids need the safest, most-walkable commutes to school. Another 4-8 blocks for a young child is too much. Additionally, many schools on Capitol Hill are getting significant involvement from families whose children are not yet school aged because they see it as likely to be their only option and they want it to get better. Those families will have no incentive to start becoming part of the school community early if there's no guarantee they'll get that school or if there's a better, more established school in the choice set they want (in this case it will be Brent for everyone). I do not support choice sets for elementary school students and believe this will crush any progress at neighborhood elementary schools.
mschoicesets_comment: I don't love the idea of choice sets, period, but I can be more open to it at the middle school level if the schools have diversified programming that provide actual choice for parents and students. Middle school students can withstand a bit more of a commute and these choices are all in relatively close proximity. I don't love the idea, but I'm not 100% opposed to it in this case.
msproximity_comment: Pretty much my same thoughts as middle school choice sets. I don't love the idea, but I can be more open to choice at the middle school level if the schools have diversified programming that provide actual choice for parents and students. Middle school students can withstand a bit more of a commute and these choices are all in relatively close proximity. I don't love the idea, but I'm not 100% opposed to it in this case.
hslottery_comment: I don't like the idea of a citywide lottery. Continue to improve programming at the neighborhood high school level, but grow the number of specialized and application only high schools - and keep those citywide. Choice means picking the programs/situations that are best for your child. That could be a specialized program, or it could be the most convenient school. Provide that choice. Do not force people into a citywide golden ticket system.
setasides_comment: I do not support the idea of set asides for low-performing schools. First, what is being done to address why that school is low performing? If it's lack of parent involvement, why bring that lack of parental involvement to a high-performing school? Second, what happens to the kids who aren't lucky enough to lottery out? Will that school get closed and those kids reassigned to another low-performing school? This is another bad idea.

boundaries_comment: I like the current feeder pattern.

feederpatterns_comment: Taking away access to cross-boundary pattern with Deal MS is a non-starter.  West as a middle school is not an equal or better option to West.
mschoicesets_comment: Ward 4 needs its own middle school!
msproximity_comment: Education Campuses do not work.  They do not have similar nor equitable enrichment programming, such as bilingual immersion programs.

boundaries_comment: As a family in the Brent school boundary we are happy with the boundary as is given the excellent quality of the school.
feederpatterns_comment: Brent Elementary students are not going to Jefferson because the quality is poor. This feeder pattern does not function (the excellent visualization tool shows this).
eschoicesets_comment: To do this, all schools must be of equivalent standard. People move to neighborhoods to guarantee themselves access to a particular schools. If this certainty does not exist, demand for housing will decrease in the areas with the better schools until the quality of all schools is equivalent.
mschoicesets_comment: To do this, all schools must be of equivalent standard. People move to neighborhoods to guarantee themselves access to a particular schools. If this certainty does not exist, demand for housing will decrease in the areas with the better schools until the quality of all schools is equivalent.
msproximity_comment: For Brent families, feeding into Stuart Hobson (not Eliot Hine) is significantly more preferable to Jefferson. It is also closer to the Brent catchment area.
hslottery_comment: The quality varies to significantly that this would discourage families from moving to or staying in the District.

boundaries_comment: I believe in walking to schools. This proposal will cause people who walk to a school two blocks away to have to drive to school. The houses in the rezoned area are in the same neighborhood, ANC 3F06, that the Murch school building is in, so the rezoning breaks up the Murch neighborhood. It is a real neighborhood with block parties and group trick-or-treating and picnics in the park. The overcrowding does need to be addressed, but this method ignores the value of walkable neighborhood schools. I am also unsure what this will do to the demographics at Murch, but I suspect the elimination of so many apartment buildings may make the school less diverse in several respects. There are other options, like rezoning Murch's Ward 4 families to Lafayette, which is simultaneously losing enrollment and, like Hearst, is being renovated to add space; or rezoning areas that already have to drive to drive a little farther. Murch itself is in dire need of renovation and expansion and this will happen soon and that should be considered.
feederpatterns_comment: Feeder patterns are essential to creating and continuing high performing peer groups. It allows the MS and HS to plan because they know the achievement levels of the incoming students. It is also socially important, which we know from experience -- disrupting friendships and peer groups should only be done with great care for the individual child's ability to adapt. While I am in favor of keeping the feeder patterns, and I am in favor of making room for OOB students at risk, I am concerned that inflexible set asides will perpetuate overcrowding and prevent the principals from planning and managing class sizes.
eschoicesets_comment: This makes no sense at all. It is a solution in search of a problem with these schools. There is not enough room to list all the reasons this is a bad idea, but causing drivers of 2000 elementary school students to criss-cross Ward 3 to trade seats at three, good, crowded schools that nearly everyone walks to now -- ugh. It seems like whoever drafted this has no knowledge of these neighborhoods or schools at all. Other cities that use choice sets seem to also retain the boundary school of right, with choice sets as the next option. That would work.
mschoicesets_comment: My kids can walk to Deal in under two minutes. Driving to/from Georgetown twice a day is not a viable alternative. The only way to get there for all families coming from Ward 3 is to drive on Wisconsin Ave., which is already a jammed up mess. No one should be in favor of adding more traffic to that road. We chose our home because it allowed us to walk to the metro for work and to walk to good schools from nursery through high school. We are not in favor of changing that. Walkability and academic excellence are our priorities. Given options, we would not drive to a magnet or great private school, and we would not walk to a dysfunctional school. We chose to live where we can walk to great schools. See also below.
msproximity_comment: Again, my children can walk to Deal in under two minutes - we can see it from our porch; West, which I'd never even heard of until this survey, would require driving, and so we would not prefer that. We already made a choice. We chose our house to allow us to metro to work and walk to good schools. My husband was bussed across the city for a magnet middle school and will not subject our children to the same commute -- not even for a magnet, which West is not. West is also preK-8 so it would feel like moving to another elementary school and being the new kids in someone else's school. Also Deal is supposed to be the best MS, and we aren't sold on Deal yet; but we would not choose to drive farther for a worse school. If Deal were not available, we'd likely choose a walkable private school with high academic standards instead, as there are several to choose from. This would be a financial strain, but our children require the highest level of academic challenge available and a peer group on par with them. These needs are not negotiable, and we will not leave it to chance. See also above. Is this for real? Everyone would choose Deal and everyone who "lost" would have to go to West, no matter how close to Deal they live. This is not a real choice and it would destroy property values, which would decimate the tax base.
hslottery_comment: No. High school is too important to gamble away in a lottery. We will do everything in our power to ensure that our children are exceedingly well prepared for college. We will make a move as early as necessary to ensure that our children get a high school education appropriate to their substantial academic potential. Again, we're not sold on Wilson yet given the AP test scores, although we are leaning toward it, and we like what we are hearing -- there is still some convincing to do over the next four years. But if even Wilson is not a guarantee - and if the academic ability of the peer set is determined by chance/lottery -- forget it. Feeder patterns are important for academic planning. We can walk to Wilson, we swim there, we participate in fundraisers and listen to the marching band. My kids already think of it as their high school. If they can't go there, it will be a real shame. We will have to make a move soon to ensure their high school educations are not left to a last minute lottery chance and a peer group picked out of a computer's hat. FWIW, we do not consider charter schools for the same reasons -- random peer group and distance. We gave DCPS a chance because we saw these three schools doing well and improving, and we prefer public school. Friends and family thought we were crazy -- it's beginning to feel like they were right. If changes like this happen -- joke's on us; we were duped.
setasides_comment: In theory, this is a nobel sounding idea that I like, but it does not seem to be thought out well enough to be viable yet. Not only have they not decided how to determine which schools are low performing, but they also have not determined which schools must set aside seats and at which point they must concede that there are no available seats to set aside. If too rigid, this will lead to overcrowding and/or displacing families who purchased homes based on neighborhood schools. Building space is finite. Also, for the most at risk students, class size is vitally important and a large crowded school may not be a helpful alternative, no matter how well some of the other kids in that school may happen to score on standardized tests. Most importantly, this proposal fails to improve the low performing schools, which should be the goal. That said, this is most likely to improve outcomes for children if they are placed in the new school in PreK, so they benefit from the full ES experience at the high performing school. They also should be given transportation to reduce truancy and the burden of commuting for their parents/guardians. These are just some of the important details that have not been defined. So at best, it is premature to opine on this vague plan, except to say this better not be their only idea for "improving" the low performing schools, because obviously it does not do that.

boundaries_comment: My child currently attends Barnard and we love it. It is an easy 2 1/2 block walk, the school facility is very good, the teaching staff is good and I really like the school leadership. Truesdale would be several long blocks further, it is an older facility and, worst of all, it is an Education Campus, which is a school model I strongly dislike. The playground at Truesdale has always attracted groups of teenagers which has disuaded us from spending playtime on that campus. I do NOT like the vibe at Truesdale...it needs to be made into either an elementary school or a middle school...but not both.
feederpatterns_comment: It is absurd that our family does not have access to ANY viable middle school options. A failing education campus is out of the question. It is a crime that Ward 4 has been allowed to languish as long as it has. Create a top-notch middle school NOW that has application-only programs for advanced students. Quit making everyone try so desperately to flee to the other side of the park. Give us something to be proud of and a school we can dedicate our time and energy to. We would be very happy with Roosevelt if it actually provided programs for advanced students, offered terrific college counseling and didn't devote so much energy to remediation and truancy issues.
eschoicesets_comment: I want to see data that shows that choice sets work. And please define what "work" means, because I don't think they will result in higher scores or greater racial or socioeconomic diversity. Stop trying to figure out ways divvy up the same amount of decent school seats and instead, work on making the undesirable schools more so.
mschoicesets_comment: I only selected "strongly like" because giving Ward 4 a new middle school is an absolute must. Please get rid of the education campus model. But to be clear, I do not like "choice sets" at all...besides, according to the DME proposal our choice set is a choice set of one....that's not much choice...
msproximity_comment: I will not send my children to an education campus. That model has not proven to be successful and budget numbers show that middle school children on these campuses do not receive the classes, electives, resources, and extracurriculars that they deserve and I demand for my children.
hslottery_comment: They only reason this is being considered is because of Wilson and its overcrowding. Making people lose a lottery is not the way to achieve success in DCPS. Creating more viable options EotP is what is needed to woe people away from Wilson. Please use carrots and not sticks.
setasides_comment: I think the set-asides are well intentioned, but would be nearly impossible to implement honestly without corruption and cheating. Plus, there is no definition yet for "low-performing school" so without that knowledge (along with other details like, at what point in the year will schools be given their labels so that families know whether they have a shot at a set-aside seat) it's difficult to have an educated opinion. I don't think labeling a school as low performing and then giving some children an escape valve is smart policy. So the other kids get stuck on a sinking ship? And in one of the proposals it actually blames new boundaries on OOB kids who would get set aside seats. Please, please rewrite boundaries based on the populations in those neighborhoods, not based on a need to reserve set asides. That will only breed contempt and resentment for OOB families (I should know...my older child attends a WotP school as an OOB student)

msproximity_comment: Not sure why the closest isn't Takoma EC.

boundaries_comment: Not actually a change.
feederpatterns_comment: I have very little hope that Stuart Hobson and/or Eastern will improve sufficiently to make them a realistic option for my children.
eschoicesets_comment: I think this is a terrible idea which is likely to drag the higher performing schools down to the level of the lower-performing schools.  My children currently attend an out-of-boundary school, and we feel very fortunate to have had this opportunity through the current lottery system.
hslottery_comment: I dislike this because it gives people fewer choices, under the guise of offering more.  Again, I am unlikely to send my children to DCPS public schools, but I think this is likely to destroy the very few bright spots in the system.  People who are currently guaranteed to attned one of the few good high schools will opt-out of the system, rather than roll the dice.
setasides_comment: I dislike this option because the high-performing schools are already crowded.  We will have to eliminate spaces for people who are inbounds, or we will have even more crowded schools.

boundaries_comment: The new boundary for Burleith's neighborhood elementary school seems reasonable, geographically, but I would be against it if it would mean losing Wilson as a neighborhood high school.  Until DCPS gives strong, clear assurances that the neighborhood High School for Burleith is Wilson, I don't think there will be an overall favorable opinion of the proposed change.
feederpatterns_comment: As I read the DCPS proposals, DCPS seems to be sending a signal that the neighborhood high school for Burleith "could" change.  That creates a lot of fear in the Burleith neighborhood.  Only if there is a strong, clear assurance that Wilson will remain the neighborhood high school, would I support the boundary change.
eschoicesets_comment: I see no benefit to choice sets for Burleith parents.  I want one designated neighborhood elementary school for my children.  That is how children build relationships throughout their public school years, and how strong communities of families are built.  Choice sets would cause damage to development of childhood friendships and networks of families in the community.  Therefore, I am against it as a proposal.
mschoicesets_comment: As stated above, choice sets are not a wise idea.  There should be only one neighborhood school.  Although Deal is currently considered a "better" school than Hardy, I do not believe many Burleith parents would accept this proposal merely because it would give them a chance at a "better" school.  Principled allegiance to the status quo should prevail when choice sets, in practice, would cause damage to local communities.
msproximity_comment: As stated above, choice sets are an unwise policy because they would cause damage to neighborhood communities.  Although Oyster is currently considered a "better" school than Hardy, I do not believe many Burleith parents would accept this proposal merely because it would give them a chance at a "better" school.  Most Burleith parents will understand that the effect of choice sets would limit the likelihood that students and their families will remain in contact with one another throughout their public school years.
hslottery_comment: I am astonished that a citywide lottery is even mentioned as a proposal.  I fail to see any benefit to such a policy.  Families with the means to leave the city would leave if not lucky enough to get into a quality charter school or an application-only school like Walls, Banneker, or McKinley.  The effect would be to dramatically lower the quality of any DCPS school that is currently considered desirable.  It would also affect the real estate market in a negative way.
setasides_comment: I am in favor of giving preferences to "at-risk" students, but not at the expense of overcrowding some schools that are already overcrowded.  First, it should be acknowledged that "at-risk" kids are the ones who need assistance -- and setting aside seats for kids from "low-performing schools" is not an accurate, effective way of helping that group (because not every child from that location is "at-risk."  Instead, the object of the policy should be income-based rather than location-based.  Second, reserving a specific ceiling or floor of seats puts pressure on overcrowded schools.  Instead, preferences for admission should be given only to the extent that there are available seats at any school.  In sum:  the mechanism of the policy should be changed in order to be effective.  As currently written, it would probably do more harm than good.

boundaries_comment: I am pleased that we would still be at Stoddert, though I am skeptical that the proposed boundary change will have any meaningful impact on the crowded conditions at the school.
feederpatterns_comment: Here too, I am pleased that we will stay on a certain path, but it is disruptions like the proposed changes and other things that still impede progress at Hardy.  I think the school is on the right track but right now what it needs is for everyone -- the DME, the City Council, the Chancellor, DCPS -- to get out of the way, stop tinkering and just let Hardy focus on being a school and educating our kids.
eschoicesets_comment: These are all fine schools and reasonable choices, but has the potential for us to go from a school that is a block away to having to drive my kids to school every day.  Not awful, but not idea either.
mschoicesets_comment: Again, these are both fine choices from a quality point of view.  But from a kid's point of view, they want to go where their friends are going.  That, as much as anything, I believe can impact a child's experience at school.  If they are unhappy because they are away from their friends, that is what they will focus on, not lessons.
msproximity_comment: The idea of sending my kids to Oyster, while a fine school, presents a number of factors that make it a less than ideal situation.  At this point at least, it is difficult to tell if my kids have any proficiency, aptitude, or even interestn in a foreign language.  Until that can be determined, it makes no sense for us to even consider Oyster.
hslottery_comment: Potentially I could wind up sending my children to Anacostia for high school.  Without rendering an opinion on the school, the idea of having to cross town and cross the river to get to school makes no sense.  What's worse, a lottery will dilute the quality of high-performing schools and send kids to low-performing schools, resulting in less than stimulating environment for these kids as well as artificially tweaking test scores in the low performing school.  All this really does is put a cheap veneer on the schools to make it look like they are improving without doing any real work to make that happen.  A lottery would be simply enable avoiding focusing on quality.
setasides_comment: The devil is in the details.  20% is much too high, so I wold wait to see what the numbers look like before making a final determination.  In general, set-asides are a fine idea, but once a kid is out of the low performing school, he/she will stay in that feeder pattern all the way through high school.  Here too, there runs the risk of impacting another student who could really thrive and putting them in an environment where they will simply wither on the vine.  An approach like this only works if some kind of system is set up so that once the low-performing school has reached a certain achievement level, that kids are routed back into their neighborhood school.

boundaries_comment: About time!
feederpatterns_comment: I like matching MS boundaries to the feeder ES.  It helps make that 6th-grade transition easier if a student is likely to be going to the same school as all of her friends from 5th grade.
eschoicesets_comment: Then what's the point of boundaries?
mschoicesets_comment: Then what's the point of boundaries?
msproximity_comment: Oh, come on.  I am not making my child walk across I-395 to get to school.  DCPS does know that middle school students can't drive, right?
hslottery_comment: High school students are still children.  It's unfair to expect any of them to endure an adult commute.  For instance, I might like the academic reputation of Wilson HS, but it's a 45-minute train ride each way from our home on Capitol Hill.  It shouldn't even be an option for my daughter.
setasides_comment: This just gives DCPS an excuse to not fix the low-performing schools.  And what about those "borderline" schools that meet standards some years but not others?  Those poor kids would keep getting transferred to a different school each year.

feederpatterns_comment: Currently these choices are not acceptable.  I am a native resident of DC educated in DCPS (Eaton, Deal, Banneker).  I grew up in Columbia Heights and Petworth and I went to Eaton as an OOB student.  The schools East of Rock Creek Park have always been subpar to the schools West of the Park.  My parents chose to send me to a school that was very far away in order to get the best education.  I too will do the same for my children even if it means paying for private school, which I currently do for my three-year old.  Still, I think that DCPS needs improvement and while I think it's great to have a stand-alone middle school in Ward 5, I think making sure that the children get programs that are on par to West of the park schools is key.  If the programming is improved, then I am more likely to send my children to DCPS.
