eschoicesets_comment: I am actually in favor of choice sets because I think it will allow parents some options besides just a bad neighborhood school.  If my neighborhood school is unacceptable then I have no where to go.  However, if choice sets could include at least one school that has solid test scores, and solid programming then the choices are not so bleak.
mschoicesets_comment: Currently, Brookland@Bunker Hill is an education campus and not a true middle school so I'm somewhat confused by the proposed set.  Now if it was turned into a middle school that was given a specific focus that was vertically integrated with the elementary high schools, then I would turn my frown upside down into a smile.
msproximity_comment: Again, these are both education campuses which I wholly dislike.  See comment above.
hslottery_comment: I actually don't care about this issue and my plan is to send my children to my alma mater - Banneker which I know will adequately prepare them for high school.
setasides_comment: I agree with set-asides.  I have thought long and hard about the school situation. I had signed out for the Community forums, but I did not want to face ascerbic crowds hell bent on lashing out at the DME.   From my experience DCPS has been quite content to let African-American, Black, and Hispanic students and their families fend for themselves.  If these families, valued education they could either use the out-of-boundary process (as my parents used) or escape to privates and now charter schools. Those without the knowledge simply languished away.  This pattern could have continued on except white middle class people started moving to traditional minority neighborhoods.  Now we have a situation where neighborhoods that used to be all black or brown are mixed but the schools don't reflect this shift.  While it's all very nice to say that we should focus on improving schools first, that is not the reality.  Changes to both areas need to start at once.  I would like thank the DME for trying to bring some level of fairness and opportunity to a sector of the community that has been dismissed.  I would also like to comment on how sad it makes me to realize that even after the civil rights struggle, because I am African-American, my views and values only matter because white people have chosen to move into my neighborhood.  Finally, for all those in Ward 3 who are rending their garments and gnashing their teeth over choice sets and citywide lotteries;  I am disappointed that they do not realize the legacy left by centuries of institutionalized racism (starting with slavery but including Jim Crow) has produced a state of separate but unequal education in this city.  I do think that the proposals by the DME Abigail Smith lead us away from educating children in racial isolation, which was at the very hart of Brown v Board of Education.

feederpatterns_comment: Not a good option until Jefferson is improved
eschoicesets_comment: I bought my home in part because in was in Brent ES district. Would be very unhappy if this was lost.
All good schools, but I'd like to keep my child with their neighbors, plus the other schools are not walkable.
msproximity_comment: I think it would be hard to start in a bilingual school in 6th grade.
hslottery_comment: Should this happen we would undoubtedly leave DC public schools, either by going to private or moving out of the district all together.

boundaries_comment: This takes my family out of the boundary for Powell ES, which is what we currently have as our neighborhood school of right and which is performing well. Barnard ES is closer to our home, but we have concerns about overall performance as compared to Powell ES.
feederpatterns_comment: The middle school option is not there. A new strong comprehensive middle school option needs to be put in place in our neighborhood area. Also, Roosevelt HS would need to be transformed to be a comprehensive high school.
eschoicesets_comment: This should include Powell ES for our address, which is closer than Brightwood, Truesdell and West.
mschoicesets_comment: There needs to be citywide investment in comprehensive middle schools.
msproximity_comment: This is not an equitable option when compared to what other areas of the city have as their choices.
hslottery_comment: Strong comprehensive schools for all neighborhoods is what we need. Not a citywide lottery for a very limited number of strong schools.
setasides_comment: set-asides should be to ensure socioeconomic equity and equitable access to high-quality schools. "low-performing" measures are not adequate for determining set-asides.

boundaries_comment: I hope that they haven't changed this boundary to push neighbors out so that there is more space for out of boundary students.
feederpatterns_comment: This feeder pattern makes sense geographically for our neighborhood.
eschoicesets_comment: How does this solve any problems?  Keep neighborhood kids together in order to strengthen community support for neighborhood schools.  Giving families a choice of three schools doesn't improve the schools.
hslottery_comment: Please do not implement this policy.  I will have no reason to continue living in the District if I have can have no expectation about where my children will go to high school.
setasides_comment: This policy leaves a lot of questions.  Where do all of the children who live in the neighborhood fit in the school if 20% of the space is "set aside" for students who don't live in the neighborhood?

boundaries_comment: It would be great to attend the closer school that didn't require crossing busy Benning.  We could walk to our neighborhood school.
feederpatterns_comment: Once again, a much safer route to school especially once they are walking on their own.
eschoicesets_comment: Some are pretty far away for an elementary school.
mschoicesets_comment: All the middle schools need improvement.
msproximity_comment: Both middle schools need serious improvement.
hslottery_comment: I would be sad to see the concept of a neighborhood school be removed even if it wasn't until high school.  There are already plenty of choices with the charters that have sprung up over the years.
setasides_comment: Don't know enough about this plan.

boundaries_comment: We live in the neighborhood because we can walk to our neighborhood school, as do many other families on ours and adjacent streets. Murch is .5 mile from us. Hearst, on the other hand, is 1 mile away.
eschoicesets_comment: The proposed choice set for our area would give us the option of schools 1 mile, 1.5 miles and 2 miles away, while shutting my neighbors out of our closest school. This would add traffic to the roads and create a hardship for the many families in my area who choose to live without a car - some because they can't afford one.

boundaries_comment: Maury's already overcrowded.
mschoicesets_comment: I like this option of having some choices among the middle schools.
hslottery_comment: I'm not in favor of Eastern right now. I like the idea of a city-wide lottery.

boundaries_comment: It's crazy to have this appendage comprising the small triangle southwest of Maryland Avenue, a major artery of the Capitol Hill NE community, be in the same elementary school boundary as families approximately one mile away by Union Station.
Marie Reed was on our list of schools we would've lotteried for, but we are IB and planning to go to Garrison and would like to stay there.
eschoicesets_comment: This choice set is bad for us. We live closest to Garrison. And choice sets are just bad policy. It doesn't guarantee anything - everything is up for grabs. There is no predictability. There SHOULD be access to walkable good schools - why is that so hard? Why are we mixing stuff up to send everyone all over town rather than focusing on how to make good schools better, and okay schools good.
msproximity_comment: This isn't awful but we have no idea what the quality of either of those schools will be by the time our child is ready for MS and we'd like the option to lottery into somewhere else (another DCPS middle school or a charter).
hslottery_comment: This is another ridiculous proposal. It gives the appearance of assistance while actually causing havoc for parents all over town. Again, stick with simple obvious things you can fix. Don't upend the entire system.
setasides_comment: Just don't understand enough about this to comment.

boundaries_comment: In general the boundary seems to make sense, however, moving families across Wisconsin to other elementary schools seems a bit arbitrary especially as they are within such close walking distance to Janney.
feederpatterns_comment: This pattern makes complete sense based on the concept of right of access to neighborhood schools
eschoicesets_comment: "Choice set" is a misnomer as this is essentially a mini-lottery.  There is no choice.
mschoicesets_comment: Again, this is not a choice set as you dont get to "chose" which of the schools your child will attend, instead this is open to chance.
msproximity_comment: See above
hslottery_comment: Lottery for education would do nothing to improve education, but instead completely randomize the entire process.  Evidence in other cities has shown that this results in:  1) fleeing of families that are able out of the city, 2) lack of local neighborhood investment in the school system as almost no one has a local stake in their school, 3) negative economic impact on the city by losing tax dollars by the families that have left.  This idea is an non-starter, and is not a proven method of increasing quality of education for any child.
setasides_comment: Until the DCPS puts an effort into improving schools in all neighborhoods, there should be a large amount of set asides for out of bounds students to have the opportunity to attend a high quality school.  Limitations on space need to have out of the box solutions.  This might include buying more local property (e.g. St Ann's school near Janney), trailers on school grounds, etc.  The problem of inequity in educational opportunities will not be solved by any random lottery system. Improving schools will only come from systematic, logical and proven approaches that include both city support (e.g recruitment of high quality teachers) as well as local parental involvement.

feederpatterns_comment: I am really not a fan of the Education Campus model. I assume that once Brookland Middle School opens, Noyes will feed there.
eschoicesets_comment: I don't like the choice set model.
mschoicesets_comment: I don't like the choice set model.
msproximity_comment: I am ok with the idea of having a choice of 2 middle schools, but do not like education campuses. I would need a stand-alone middle school.

eschoicesets_comment: No much sense. All 3 are great schools. Would just add commuting time and traffic conjestion.
mschoicesets_comment: Thought Deal is currently a better school than Hardy, we are all for neighborhhod schools, have been working with DCPS and Hardy's Principal on improving Hardy's offering and are happy to send our kid to Hardy next year.  We need school choice and predictability, not school chances.
msproximity_comment: We are all for neighborhhod schools, have been working with DCPS and Hardy's Principal on improving Hardy's offering and are happy to send our kid to Hardy next year.  We need school choice and predictability, not school chances.
hslottery_comment: This proposal is unacceptable. We would opt-out of DCPS, would go to provate schools, and will put all our best efforts to vote out whomever dares to introduce such a nonsense proposal.
setasides_comment: You need to improve neighborhood schools everywhere, instead of granting families chances for a better education on the other side of town. Do your job, I am happy to give you my money to do so.

boundaries_comment: We walk the 8 blocks to Burroughs frequently yet do not even have proximity preference. Both Bunker Hill and Burroughs are underenrolled with very little inbound participation. I would rather see the two schools combined in the hopes of it transforming into a true neighborhood school in future years.  At present, Brookland is oddly divided between these two and Noyes.
feederpatterns_comment: Based on its poor performance, I would not send my child to Dunbar. The issue is ensuring quality.
eschoicesets_comment: I need more information on the inclusion of a charter....it reads like a convenient filler at the moment. For this particular set, I'm also curious to know more aboutwhat wowould be the specialty offering (Burroughs' label of STEM seems weak presently).
mschoicesets_comment: Again it's an issue of quality.
hslottery_comment: We would stand to benefit from this because our zoned option is of such poor quality. That said, I don't support this.
setasides_comment: We first need to know what is considered low performing.

boundaries_comment: I would never send my children to a PS3 to 8 DCPS school. These kind of schools simply cannot offer the same programming that a stand-alone middle school can.
feederpatterns_comment: I like the idea of a new middle school in Ward 4 but am not thrilled about Roosevelt.
eschoicesets_comment: Two of these options are better than my neighborhood school, but I disagree with the choice set idea in general. It's a real bummer that I don't feel comfortable sending my kids to a school that is two blocks away. A true neighborhood school would be ideal.
mschoicesets_comment: I like the idea of a specific focus but would hope for a test-in or gifted option.
msproximity_comment: I have no interest in sending my kids to an education campus. They simply cannot offer the kind of programming (various foreign languages, accelerated math) that schools like Alice Deal Provide. I would rather go charter (and I have been teaching in DCPS for 11 years so I would love to support the system) than send my kid to an EC.
hslottery_comment: Why not just try to improve ALL of the high schools and offer the same programming as Wilson rather than send folks all over the city? And I would never send my kids to Roosevelt if it stays like it is now.
setasides_comment: Unfortunately, the schools that would receive those students are already overcrowded and adding 10-20% to the student population would likely increase class sizes and put a strain on resources.

boundaries_comment: The school is not overcrowded and the families being cut out are some of those that live closest to the school and walk.  It does not seem necessarily and unfairly cuts some families out of Janney.
eschoicesets_comment: There is no evidence this will improve schools and there is reason to think this will lead to less investment in rising public schools.  This appears to be rearranging deck chairs on the titanic to redistribute a limited number of high quality seats.  Where is the plan to improve schools so that there are more high quality seats?  Also, using choice sets where the existing schools are high quality appears to be a waste of resources with no actual benefits.  It will reduce certainty and walkabout without addressing any identified need or purpose.
mschoicesets_comment: I disagree that choice sets will benefit the schools.  I have two good middle school options, the best non charter public options in the city so I expect my family will be fine.  What is being done to improve other middle schools and how will the uncertainty help?  What the city needs to focus on is how it can provide additional high quality middle school options, which includes ensuring a prepared cohort of students to get parent buy in to send their children.  DCPS needs tracking for middle school to take advantage of the momentum that rising elementary schools are creating.
msproximity_comment: This is barely different than middle school choice sets except it cuts out some current families from quality options they now have as a right based on geography without establishing quality middle schools in those neighborhoods.
hslottery_comment: Uncertainty without sufficient quality programs will not improve dcps, again where is the programmatic plan and evidence?  Plan another high quality comprehensive high school with proficiency qualifications and quality programming outside of Wilson that families currently IB for Wilson and families in other parts of the city would like their kids to attend.  In kids minimum proficiency requirements to target a prepared demographic.
setasides_comment: I like the idea of set asides depending on how it is used and implemented.  My support depends on whether the percentages are cumulative in that they account for OOB children that come up through feeders or additive in that at each level the school does not count children that were accepted into the feeder from OOB as part of the set aside for the new school.  This should not be used to displace children that have an in boundary right to a school or to reduce boundaries.

feederpatterns_comment: Happy with EH and Eastern as options. I, however, think Miner needs significant change.
eschoicesets_comment: I do not agree with choice sets. The lack of predictability would be even worse than it is now. It may allow for a chance at a school other than Miner ( if we choose not to go there) but there would still be such a hierarchy within these choices. Choice sets would also disband any community based schools that are starting to be created here.
msproximity_comment: More middle school options are great.

feederpatterns_comment: This is INSANE and unacceptable until their is a viable/comprable option to Deal that is up and running.  West is a K-8 campus and is NOT a middle school.  For over 40 years we have been in the Deal boundary this is utterly insane.  The Education Campus at West was not put together with any community inpit in fat West should be a PS-5 and then go to Deal.  When a stand alone option exists that is closer than 3 miles (which is not far--a Metro bus literally stops in front of my house to take kids to Deal) then you can think about changing boundaries.  There is not even a stand alone middle school around let alone one that is proficient!
eschoicesets_comment: AWFUL unacceptable idea all schools are low performing --no choice in that.
mschoicesets_comment: How is this even an option--there are no choices let alone one neighborhood middle school.
msproximity_comment: These are education campuses NOT middle schools and are low performing!  Unacceptable a non-starter.  Not an option for 16th Street Heights and Crestwood.  This is INSANE.
hslottery_comment: ridiculous and unacceptable until there are multiple high proficient schools with transportation options.
setasides_comment: If this ever came to be would need WAY more set asides.  Like 40%.

boundaries_comment: Underperforming school. Not appropriate to require children to attend until DCPS makes all schools like those in Georgetown.
feederpatterns_comment: Underperforming school. Not appropriate to require children to attend until DCPS makes all schools like those in Georgetown.  Eliminating choices for parents is an abomination.  Eliot Hine has a fight every day in the cafeteria and a 30% suspension rate of some of the violators of school rules.  The school is dark, windows like prisons and metal detectors at the door. This is a disgusting situation that has not been addressed with budget increases for four years straight.
eschoicesets_comment: Every school should be like Peabody or Maury.  So not appropriate to gamble with my childs education. Fix it!
mschoicesets_comment: Not appropriate to require children to attend until DCPS makes all schools like those in Georgetown.  Eliminating choices for parents is an abomination.
msproximity_comment: Underperforming school. Not appropriate to require children to attend until DCPS makes all schools like those in Georgetown.  Eliminating choices for parents is an abomination.  Eliot Hine has a fight every day in the cafeteria and a 30% suspension rate
hslottery_comment: 30% of the students drop out. My child would be in rooms where 30% of the class is rude, disruptive and has no interested in learning.  Not the best situation. Have you folks looked at DC Latin over the last 10 years and thought about copying a success story that so many want to attend?
setasides_comment:
One City one School System. Sorry. Make them all great the children deserve nothing less. Thank you for the survey. It was impossible to attend these open house discussions and deemed foolish by most parents as no proposals were on the table though we all knew you have your plan in place. Put resources to work at DCPS Central Office getting interns from the many colleges in the schools. Make the hallways and bathrooms safe from bullying, fear and intimidation. Hire competent Principals that are true leaders and change makers. Hire teachers that are willing to work the extra time putting together programs, art and music and science projects that spur intellectual curiosity. 

Don't  waste money expanding failing schools like Logan Montessori into a Middle School. People leave the school in droves due to bullying that is not stopped, failed leadership and poor test scores.  There are so many parents who leave due to the cronyism; hiring of the lead teachers unqualified friends.  I suppose the principal and lead teacher have talked their way out of these massive failings. A sad waste of opportunity.   Thank you

boundaries_comment: My kids can now walk 2 blocks to Murch. Why would you shift them to Hearst? We moved to our apartment for Murch, to walk to school and metro. We don't have a car. How are we going to get the kids to school and work?
feederpatterns_comment: We moved here for Deal and Wilson but Hearst is not convenient by foot.
eschoicesets_comment: Hearst is already far away. You mean would might have to go all the way to Eaton or Oyster? This does not make sense. We are only a short walk from Murch.
mschoicesets_comment: Hardy has a poor reputation. Their scores are much lower than Deal. This is not a choice. This is win or lose.
msproximity_comment: Deal is very close to our apartment. That is why we moved here. Why would you make children travel far when there is a good school they can see from their window?
hslottery_comment: People like my family live in this neighborhood for a good public school. If they can't know that they will go to their neighborhood school (that they helped to build up) then they will leave the public school system. This is a very bad idea.
setasides_comment: Nothing wrong with allowing families to transfer their students to a better school - that is good. But will that mean that some people from the neighborhood can no longer go to their neighborhood school? If so, that would be wrong.

A city wide lottery for HS would dismantle any progress that has been made in the last 5-10 years. Even after being DCPS parents for the last 10 years, we would walk away from all the hard work that we put into our neighborhood schools. We would opt out of DCPS in favor of a predictable future for our children who are excellent students as judged by the DCCAS and their DCPS report cards. The city wide lottery is the epitome of absurdity.

boundaries_comment: Powell worked hard to get our neighborhood residents to feel good about the school. It worked -- I was ready to send my child to Powell, but under this proposal we would no longer be in-boundary for Powell.
feederpatterns_comment: Our current boundary is for Deal for MS and Wilson for HS. VERY VERY VERY upset that we were drawn out of our MS and HS and redrawn into an education campus that doesn't come close to what Deal offers and a HS that is failing and unsafe.
eschoicesets_comment: None of these schools are as promising as Powell.
mschoicesets_comment: What new school? We should have access to a school that is equal or better than Deal.
msproximity_comment: Education campuses are failures -- I've spoke to many families who repeatedly express how they don't meet the needs of the upper grade students. Neither of these options comes close to Deal.
hslottery_comment: Families need predictability and security. This doesn't allow it. I also cannot envision the traffic nightmare it would create.
setasides_comment: I'm not sure how I feel about it, but it does make sense for students in failing schools to have access to other schools. I would need more details.

eschoicesets_comment: This choice is complete crap.  No parents I know in Shepherd Park would consider those other schools in the choice set.  Many people choose private here, and even more would choose private rather than enroll their children in such subpar public schools as these.
mschoicesets_comment: We would likely choose to put our child in private rather then send her to Hardy, unless it has a complete turnaround.
msproximity_comment: Horrible.  Definitely not send our child to either of these options.
hslottery_comment:
We would look into private, specialty public or charter instead of a non-Wilson option. 

We would also strongly consider selling our house, leaving the District, and moving elsewhere for better school choices.
setasides_comment:
I applaud the intention here--if it is indeed to improve access to quality education for poor children--but it is shortsighted.  The rapid pace of gentrification, what may be deemed a low performing school now may not be in just a few short years.  So not only do they have to operationalize their definition of low performing schools, but they have to figure out how they are going to update it as needed in the future.  

Furthermore, even if it is not the intention, the effect of set-asides is that it will make many DC families leave DC while the rest will be left to fight over the few good seats.  It also will worsen traffic,  environmental pollution, neighborhood cohesion, and overall quality-of-life for the parents who are forced to schlep their families all over the city. 

DC's goal should be to improve neighborhood schools.  DC should hire a team of economists, social scientists, etc. to study how best to address this admittedly difficult task.  If this can be done, all of DC would win--both those who have children and those who don't, for the reasons I cited above (traffic congestion etc.). Improving neighborhood schools may also go a long way to addressing other problems of scale that DC has to pay for the long run, like families on welfare/using social services, incarcerated individuals etc. if schools are improved in some of the least served neighborhoods.

boundaries_comment: I'm not sure Hearst can handle additional students or will out if boundary students just lose spots?
eschoicesets_comment: Those are all great schools to choose from!
hslottery_comment: There is ONLY one good high school in the district. There are no other choices unless one chooses to move out of DC.

boundaries_comment: Amidon is a chronically underperforming school.  And it is on the other side of South Capitol street (a dangerous commute to school on foot)
feederpatterns_comment: We were formerly zoned for Wilson.

boundaries_comment: This upsets me although my understanding is that my kids would most likely be grandfathered into Murch. If the question of the security of having my kids feed to Deal is taken away, I would consider moving. As I understand it, Hearst currently feeds to Deal, but I am unclear if this will change. Regardless, it's an absurd idea to move kids from my block, a short walk to school (Murch and Deal) to a school that would require that their parents drive them most mornings. We are a one car family and rely on public transportation, so this is doubly absurd and unworkable for us.
feederpatterns_comment: Happy to stay with Deal and Wilson, but the Hearst zone makes no sense for our street.
eschoicesets_comment: We moved to this neighborhood and this street so our kids could walk to school. Murch and Janney are significantly closer than Hearst and better for transportation. It's why we live where we do.
mschoicesets_comment: We moved here specifically for the Murch/Deal/Wilson trajectory. Taking this away would make us seriously consider leaving DC.
msproximity_comment: Again, we want Deal. Also, our kids don't speak Spanish and as much as I would live for them to have a second language I don't think that tossing them into a bilingual program that late in the game would be good for their academic confidence.
hslottery_comment: Absolutely not. We would seriously consider leaving DC.

boundaries_comment: Makes sense for all of mt p to feed bancroft
feederpatterns_comment: Only negative is that you have to participate in bilingual program to attend Bancroft.  We have one child for whom bilingual ed would NOT be a good choice.  What then?
msproximity_comment: Makes no sense.  Raymond is horrible academically and far from mt p.  Would never send my child there even if there was decent transportation available to it (which there currently is not).  Oyster only works if you want to stay with bi-lingual program.
hslottery_comment: No choice sets!  Lack of predictability will drive families from DCPS.  Our family will not participate in DCPS if we cannot have predictability for MS and HS.  We will stay charter.  DC only has one quasi-performing general, i.e., non-application, DCPS HS---and that is Wilson.  There is NO way that I would consider sending any of my children to CHEC (less than 50% proficient), or to Cardozo or Coolidge (less than 35% proficient).  Instead of all lottery---focus on replicating another Deal/Wilson feeder pattern by creating an application or DC-CAS proficiency required MS and HS East of the Park----perhaps by using a rebuilt McFarland and renovated Roosevelt.
setasides_comment: Stop re-slicing the "pie" of the few performing schools and focus on how to make the "pie" of quality education bigger overall.  Focus on expanding services proven to be effective in improving educational outcomes for lower SES learners (expanded afterschool and saturday tutoring, more social services, smaller classes, more teacher aides).

msproximity_comment: Feeder patterns to "in-boundary" schools should remain. Specifically, Hearst to Deal.
hslottery_comment: Students "in-boundary" should be guaranteed a spot. Feeding patterns should remain, specifically Deal to Wilson.
setasides_comment: I think it is good for students in low performing areas to have access to better performing areas, but not at the expense or risk of "in-boundary" students to have access to the high performing schools in their area.

boundaries_comment: Make the school larger, there won't be that many more ES children in that part of burleith. It is full of georgetown grad students or group homes right out of college.
feederpatterns_comment: This feeder pattern is perfect. One factor missing in this feeder picture is the charter and private schools that pull kids at 4 th grade. In 2013-14 Stoddert ES dropped to only one 5 th grade classroom after years of 2 classrooms to feed into MS
eschoicesets_comment: All great schools. Walking to school is the number one factor in this decision. Our home is spitting distance to Stoddert ES. Would not be able to walk to either Mann or Key with young children from our address.
mschoicesets_comment: We feed to hardy ms at present, this plan would allow us to feed to deal. Love that option. Not sure how much bigger deal can get before imploding.
msproximity_comment: Current neighborhood MS aged students go to charters, private, or very few feed into Hardy MS
hslottery_comment: All kids should have a great education. Wilson HS is only so big, and has already hit a maximum size. If Wilson HS were not our school of right, based on current feeder pattern, connected to address, we would move. The decision to buy property in 1998 was for access to quality schools. If this feeder pattern changes, montgomery county here we come.
setasides_comment: Set asides is a pipe dream. Program does not work at the end of the day. In boundary children belong in neighborhood school.

boundaries_comment: It does make sense to increase Hearst's boundaries given how overcrowded some of the neighboring schools are, and because Hearst could fit in more in boundary students.  However, I do have sympathy with families who were in very close walking distance to Murch and now may have to go much further to Hearst.  I wonder if instead they could move some of the other boundaries (e.g., move north on the east side of CT Ave), so families who would probably drive to either school will drive to Hearst instead of driving to Murch.
feederpatterns_comment: I think clear feeder patterns are crucial, for continuity of peer groups and instruction for the kids, and for certainty for their parents.
eschoicesets_comment: It makes no sense to make kids who live very close to one of these schools travel farther to go to one of the others (especially since arguably all 3 are of similar quality).  Perhaps choice sets would make sense in other parts of town, but I do not think they make sense up here in upper NW.  They would diminish the feeling of neighborhood schools and reduce families' and neighbors' commitment to their local school.
mschoicesets_comment: Same issue as above; families and neighborhoods want certainty, and especially from a small school like Hearst I want to know that all of my children's classmates (or most of them) will be going to the same school together.  In addition, we bought our house in particular so the kids could walk to all 3 schools (elementary, middle, and high), and this sort of model would dramatically reduce the potential walkability (which is one of the factors that the DME claims is important).
msproximity_comment: Same comment and issue as above; families and neighborhoods want certainty, and especially from a small school like Hearst I want to know that all of my children's classmates (or most of them) will be going to the same school together.  In addition, we bought our house in particular so the kids could walk to all 3 schools (elementary, middle, and high), and this sort of model would dramatically reduce the potential walkability (which is one of the factors that the DME claims is important).
hslottery_comment:
Same issue as above; families and neighborhoods want certainty, and especially from a small school like Hearst I want to know that all of my children's classmates (or most of them) will be going to the same school together.  In addition, we bought our house in particular so the kids could walk to all 3 schools (elementary, middle, and high), and this sort of model would dramatically reduce the potential walkability (which is one of the factors that the DME claims is important).

As another parent stated at one of the meetings, I want 100% certainty regarding which school my children will attend; 95% is not good enough.  And to retain and motivate families to stay and be invested in the school system families need that certainty regarding where their children will go.

(NEvermind the transportation nightmares if there was a citywide lottery with kids having to travel far to get to school).
setasides_comment: I think these set asides are a great idea.

hslottery_comment: This is where the whole thing fails.  There's no way a city like DC, where the majority of the public high schools are of terrible quality (not to mention run-down and dangerous in some cases), can assign high schools based on a citywide lottery and expect to keep middle-class and affluent families in the system.  Frankly, even poor families would suffer under this system in many cases, as the city is big enough that students might be assigned to schools they can't afford to get to (remember, there's no city-wide school bus program) or can't reliably attend without major logistic challenges for their families.  This is a complete and total nonstarter, as far as I'm concerned.

eschoicesets_comment: People make really significant decisions about where they live and work based on which school their child would have access to. Introducing this level of uncertainty would be a serious problem.
mschoicesets_comment: Guaranteed access to one specific school based on home address is the most important factor for me (regardless of which school that is). Predictability is key.
setasides_comment: I don't think set-asides are a good idea. And I don't think any schools should ever deny access to in-boundary students in order to make room for out of boundary students (despite the fact that I am an out-of-boundary parent).

msproximity_comment: I don't own a car and should not have to find a way to shuttle my child across Rock Creek Park.

boundaries_comment: I am neutral on the expansion of the boundary, however DCPS where will the additional students go? Maury does not have the space for additional students and as I understand it the promised money to do the next phase of the building has been pushed back another year.Where's the logic?
feederpatterns_comment: We really want our children to remain in DCPS and frankly have viewed Stuart Hobson as a safe option for our rising 4th grader. We have visited Eliot Hines and while we think it's moving in the right direction at this point I would not enroll him there. We are a well educated family and believe Middle School is too important to take a risk on a school that is more concerned with students safety than students learning. If DCPS goes this route and wants to retain high SES families, they need to incorporate at least two years of transition where families who live in changing school boundaries retain the right to automatically enroll in their current feeder school.

boundaries_comment: We can see Murch from our house but would have to drive to Hearst.  Seems like a ridiculous change and not walking friendly.
eschoicesets_comment: All of those schools are far away from our house.  Murch is 2 blocks away.  How is this environmentally friendly, community friendly or convenient?
mschoicesets_comment: We are two blocks from Deal.
msproximity_comment: Look at the map.
They are not middle schools. An Educational Campus is not an equivalent middle school. How can kids who go to a traditional elementary school feed into anything but a middle school?
setasides_comment: DCPS really needs to fix failing schools. People want good schools in their neighborhoods. It is appalling to me that DCPS with all their money and employees cannot fix the failing schools!

boundaries_comment: Assuming current Burlieth residents could stay at Stoddert, reducing our boundary is a reasonable plan for slowing the growth at our overcrowded school.  Hyde-Addison is a different school, but also a good school that people would be happy to attend.
eschoicesets_comment: Choice sets for ES in the NW don't make sense- they won't help with overcrowding and they would reduce walkability and neighborhood cohesion.
mschoicesets_comment: Choice sets reduce the incentive to work to improve your destination school as you don't know that you'll be there.  Improving schools is about a long-term commitment.
hslottery_comment: Again, a lottery introduces way too much uncertainty for families that are committed to the public school system.
setasides_comment: I think operationalizing this in a way that does not disrupt the management/planning of "receiving" schools will be challenging.

boundaries_comment: I'm indifferent as I have lotteried out of my district to a somewhat better school.
feederpatterns_comment: Deal and Wilson are the schools I would hope we were fed towards as the elementary school we've lotteried into feeds to those schools as well.
eschoicesets_comment: All of these schools are terrible.  the only way to get positive feedback on this approach from this household is if one of the choice  schools was a school that was succeeding.  Offering 3 choices of elementary schools in schools that are all failing is not a choice.
mschoicesets_comment: Not thrilled that I could lose out on going to deal for a subpar school like Hardy.
msproximity_comment: Again, choices are good as long as the schools are prospering.  Clearly everyone would choose the school that is succeeding so clearly everyone who doesn't get into the succeeding school will be unhappy with being pushed to the "2nd" best school.  How is it determined who gets in where?
hslottery_comment: Does this mean my children would potentially have to travel down to Cap Hill to attend school when we live so far NW that we're almost in MD?  how would this make sense?  I certainly don't want to battle nightmarish in-bound traffic to get to school.  I clearly am missing something with this "idea".

msproximity_comment: Oyster has specific language requirements. If your child does not meet these, then they are not eligible. So, there may not actually be choice of 2 schools for Mt Pleasant under this scenario.

boundaries_comment: We are currently zoned for Powell ES and we are VERY upset to potentially be zoned out of this school.  We were very much looking forward to the dual language education our children would receive there.
eschoicesets_comment: We are currently zoned for Powell ES and am VERY upset that not only are we potentially being zoned out of Powell, but am incredulous that Powell would not even be one one of the schools in our  proposed choice set!
mschoicesets_comment: While I think that a new middle school is critical, it is hard to comment on whether a currently non-existant school would be a place that we would want to send our children.
msproximity_comment: As they currently are, we would not send our children to either of these schools.
hslottery_comment: Again, as with the middle schools, without significant improvements in many areas, this is not a school to which we would send our children.
setasides_comment: The number of parents that would want to send their children to a school "setting aside" seats would far, far outnumber the available seats.  Ultimately this is an option that we leave a lot of children without a viable option for a quality education.

boundaries_comment: There are many middle class families, westbound, that are excited about being inbound for Powell. With most of them (including a few current Powell families) being cut out, this creates a negative impact on the growing racial and economic diversity Powell had began to see. As confidence in the school grows, people are willing to stay past the early childhood grades. Scores, parental involvement, and community interest are on the upswing and we don't want to lose that momentum.
feederpatterns_comment: I love the idea of having a new middle school as long as it allows my children to continue receiving dual language instruction.
eschoicesets_comment: I would not be happy about not being able to walk three blocks to Powell. I also dislike the possibility that my youngest child (not yet in school) could be placed in a separate school than his siblings. I am a dedicated Powell parent and I am not willing, nor do I have any desire to divide my attention between two schools.
mschoicesets_comment: I would love a new middle school as longas it is a place where my children can continue dual language instruction.
msproximity_comment: We are not interested in an education campus, especially not Raymond. We want to continue with dual language at the middle school level and neither of those schools provide that.
hslottery_comment: This will give us a shot a decent high school. Roosevelt is unacceptable for us.
setasides_comment: This would give a shot at a decent high school.

boundaries_comment: We purchased our house with the intention of walking our children to Lafayette. We would almost certainly move out of DC if we could no longer count on a walkable neighborhood school.
feederpatterns_comment: These are the closest schools to our house, and we moved to our current residence based on the understanding that these would be our schools.
eschoicesets_comment: We recognize that these are all good schools, but the inconvenience of having to get our children to either Janney or Murch would be significant for no net gain.
mschoicesets_comment: Hardy is more than four miles from our house, which is ill-served by public transportation. This would mean adding a significant drive in rush-hour traffic for our children, added to our own commutes.
msproximity_comment: This would be the best way to spur us to move to Maryland. Brightwood EC is very difficult to reach by public transportation, and we would have to go well out of our way to drive there twice a day. Just as importantly, we moved to our current house with the understanding that our children would go to Deal.
hslottery_comment: We would leave DC- this is not the kind of uncertainty that we want for our children's education.
setasides_comment: We would need more information for evaluate this proposal.

feederpatterns_comment: What is this "New MS"?

boundaries_comment: Education campuses do not work. Powell Elementary administrators and parents have been reaching out to Crestwood neighbors to support the school and now families with young children will be excluded from Powell. As a side note, the boundary includes a significant portion of Rock Creek Park that has no housing.
feederpatterns_comment: This is wrong. This is NOT our current feeder pattern. Our current "feeder" pattern is Powell Elementary, Deal Middle School and Wilson High School. The Current feeder pattern put forth here is actually the proposed feeder pattern. We will not accept a proposal that doesn't provide equal or better schools for our children. Education campuses (K-8) are not working and are unacceptable. Roosevelt High School does not exist at this time and it was very low performing.
eschoicesets_comment: Not acceptable.
mschoicesets_comment: This school does not exist.
msproximity_comment: Nope.
hslottery_comment: The school choice needs to be equal or better to our current school for which we bought our home for access. This is not acceptable.
setasides_comment: Define "low performing." This is already done for Title 1 schools.

feederpatterns_comment: Hell no, not my kids!

boundaries_comment: Moving the boundary so that families who now walk 2-3 blocks to school would have to travel up to a mile to school is hard to understand--particularly when so many people affected by the boundary change live in apartment buildings and are less likely to have cars, making the school commute even more difficult.
feederpatterns_comment: These are all great schools, all walkable from our house.
eschoicesets_comment: This approach does nothing to change the distribution of students by socioeconomic status in most of the city. At best it creates uncertainty, at worst it could force families to travel farther to a school of similar quality.
mschoicesets_comment: I would be more inclined to support this approach if the "special focus" piece were better defined and put in place and established for a few years before implementation. Without that, it feels like a crapshoot that is unlikely to have a significant impact on school quality.
msproximity_comment: It's the difference between a 7 minute walk and a 30+ minute commute by bus or car. Huge change in quality of life.
hslottery_comment: Forcing teenagers to travel across the city for school forces earlier wake-up times (bad for learning) and longer times in transit. Understanding that many kids in the city do this currently, I don't see how making all kids do it is a better solution than providing all kids good neighborhood schools.
setasides_comment: The only way this proposal could be better is if there were also an economic component--this should be reserved for families with the fewest resources/options at their disposal.

boundaries_comment: Living close by a quality neighborhood elementary school was a priority for our family.
feederpatterns_comment: We cut out of up and coming sww@fs and Wilson for a not yet existing MS and under performing Cardozo. Hopefully these schools will be great in the future, but currently we would need to find other options. Prefer some choice at MS level eg two closest schools model.
eschoicesets_comment: This is OK but Hyde is a long way away. Why not include Marie Reed in this set?
mschoicesets_comment: A new school at the old shaw site would be great. But I will get excited about it when there are some real plans.
msproximity_comment: Ok with sww@fs.
hslottery_comment: City needs more attractive MS and HS seats. Redoing the school assignment for MS and HS should be phased in together with new MS and HS offerings.
setasides_comment: Problem remains there is only one decent general admission HS I the city.

boundaries_comment: Maury is already quickly growing in its current boundary. We recently needed to add pod classrooms to accommodate the expanding enrollment.
feederpatterns_comment: Feeder patterns do not need to be so strict. A one-to-many relationship between elementary and middle schools seems like a reasonable solution to control enrollment growth.
eschoicesets_comment: I would need to understand more about this. For example, would it only apply to new students? Would currently enrolled students be able to stay in their current school?
mschoicesets_comment: Same comment as above.
setasides_comment: This seems like it would help keep schools balanced.

boundaries_comment: Although my home school is Stoddert, my son attends Hearst Elementary school as an OOB student. We hope that he will be able to stay there regardless of whatever changes will occur with the boundaries. When we sent him there, we were told that he would be able to stay and continue through the Hearst feeder pattern to Deal and Wilson. It is very important to our family that DC does not change the rights of current students to continue to attend the school they are already at and to continue on to the same middle and high school as their peers. Also, I have a younger child who is not yet in elementary school. It is also important to my family that my younger child be able to attend the same school as his older sibling - it would be too difficult on us as a family to manage multiple school drop offs and pick-ups. The fact that grandfathering current students has not been discussed is of great concern to me. We love Hearst and have already made it our community. We don't want to have to leave.
eschoicesets_comment: Choice sets are a bad idea because they create too much uncertainty to parents.
mschoicesets_comment: This is also a bad idea. I will not stay in DC if middle school feeder patterns are not guaranteed. I don't like the uncertainty and would rather go somewhere where I know what schools my children will be attending.
hslottery_comment: This is a horrific idea. It would pull the high achieving students from DC public schools because parents want to know where there kids will be going. If you leave that up to chance, anyone with the ability to do so, will find a better option for their kids, be it private or charters or moving to MD or VA. This is what I would do. I want to stay in the city and raise my kids in the city but if I have to go through the lottery again, I would rather just move to the suburbs where I have a known quantity.
setasides_comment: I don't know enough about this to know how it would work in reality. I would need to know more before being able to say whether I support it or not.
I am comfortable with this if it provides students at underperforming schools with options.

boundaries_comment: I greatly prefer the idea of shifting boundaries to fit school capacity rather than upending the entire current system. That said, changing school boundaries is hard because it requires such careful quantitative analysis. With all the focus on potential major policy shifts, it seems the long, careful analysis of population and trends done by many school districts may not have been done here. The boundaries for Murch need to be reduced, but the currently proposed shift is not well planned to balance walkability and the capacity of the nearby schools of Murch, Janney, Lafayette, Hearst, and Eaton. This points, in part, to the problems created by the lack of long-term integrated planning for facilities. While Hearst is being renovated for a capacity of 325, some surrounding schools will require a capacity of greater than 750 or more.
feederpatterns_comment: These schools are all within three blocks of one another. For the current in-boundary residents of Murch, walkability is a primary reasons for living in the community. Many residents, including my family, have selected the area primarily because of the walkability of the area. My family lives across the street from Deal and two blocks from Wilson. We have dealt for decades with numerous community issues due to the large number of students flowing through neighborhood daily, but we have tolerated issues and supported the schools because of assumption that our children would benefit from the convenience of attending those schools one day. It is unlikely that our tolerance of these issues would be so high if our children were not guaranteed attendance at those schools.
eschoicesets_comment:
While all of these schools are quality schools, this proposal provides "choice" at the potential expense of the choice of schools my family has already consciously made. We strongly prefer walking to school for a variety of reasons. It is healthier, better for the environment, and more economically feasible. Moreover, being close to our school provides us with more quality family time and a less hectic lifestyle, which is a primary value for us. 

One major concern with Policy Example A is that it would require one of these schools to shift its programs to become a specialty school. This seems like a waste of the city's resources to alter a successful school when so many schools are under-performing. Furthermore, many families (including mine) value traditional, non-specialized schools, particularly at the elementary level. The schools in this choice set are all at, or over, capacity. Many residents who have chosen in the past to attend these schools could be forced to "choose" a speciality school under this plan.
mschoicesets_comment:
While both of these schools are quality schools, this proposal provides "choice" at the expense of the choice of schools my family has already consciously made. We strongly prefer walking to school for a variety of reasons. It is healthier, better for the environment, and more economically feasible. Moreover, being close to our school provides us with more quality family time and a less hectic lifestyle, which is a primary value for us. 

One of these schools (Deal) is across the street from our home. Predictability is essential for us. We live where we do because we have sacrificed and structured our lives to be able to do so. For our family, finding out in the spring that our children would attend a school in the fall that requires driving (there is no reasonable and reliable public transportation option to Hardy for a sixth grader, in our opinion) would significant alterations to our lives. It takes more than six months to find a new job that pays enough to afford a second car, child care, and/or the flexible schedule that would allow us to accommodate the shift to a school that is not walkable. Rather than take that chance, and deal with a scramble to accommodate the potential of being assigned to Hardy, we would have to plan for other, more dependable, solutions long term. Any of those solutions would be a significant shift in our family dynamics and lifestyle, which is unsettling. As DC natives, we are incredibly discouraged to consider the change.

Finally, our family has dealt for decades with serious traffic and other concerns due to living in such close proximity to the largest middle school in the city. We tolerate these issues and support the school because our family would benefit from our children attending a quality school close to our home. Without the certainty of that, it will be difficult to be so tolerant. Neighborhoods support their schools, but only if they are neighborhood schools. Shifting that dynamic has greater consequences than just who attends the school at any given time.
msproximity_comment:
Just like the other proposals for choice sets, This proposal provides "choice" at the expense of the choice of schools my family has already consciously made. We strongly prefer walking to school for a variety of reasons. It is healthier, better for the environment, and more economically feasible. Moreover, being close to our school provides us with more quality family time and a less hectic lifestyle, which is a primary value for us. 

One of these schools (Deal) is across the street from our home. Predictability is essential for us. We live where we do because we have sacrificed and structured our lives to be able to do so. For our family, finding out in the spring that our children would attend a school in the fall that requires driving (there is no reasonable and reliable public transportation option to Hardy for a sixth grader, in our opinion) would significant alterations to our lives. It takes more than six months to find a new job that pays enough to afford a second car, child care, and/or the flexible schedule that would allow us to accommodate the shift to a school that is not walkable. Rather than take that chance, and deal with a scramble to accommodate the potential of being assigned to Hardy, we would have to plan for other, more dependable, solutions long term. Any of those solutions would be a significant shift in our family dynamics and lifestyle, which is unsettling. As DC natives, we are incredibly discouraged to consider the change.

Finally, our family has dealt for decades with serious traffic and other concerns due to living in such close proximity to the largest middle school in the city. We tolerate these issues and support the school because our family would benefit from our children attending a quality school close to our home. Without the certainty of that, it will be difficult to be so tolerant. Neighborhoods support their schools, but only if they are neighborhood schools. Shifting that dynamic has greater consequences than just who attends the school at any given time.
hslottery_comment: My family has a strong preference for predictability and walkability. A city-wide lottery would ensure neither and may force us out of DC public schools. Members of our family are alumni of DCPS and we would strongly prefer to continue to attend DCPS. But a system in which a computer decides what school children attend can never take into account the wide variety of factors, and the weight of each of those factors, that families use to determine what school their child should attend. This policy creates too many unknowns and does not give families enough time between the lottery and enrollment to work out the details of how to make their lives work in a way that also works for their children's schooling. I do not see the value of this proposal for improving education. It, frankly, seems like an attempt to avoid the hard choices required by government when shifting boundaries and the difficult process of building good schools throughout the city. Instead of places that onus on government and the school system, it shifts even greater burdens to families.
setasides_comment: The proposal for set asides has several potential strengths. It could strengthen neighborhood schools that already improving by encouraging communities to further invest in those schools. It preserves what is working at schools that are already high-performing. And it gives motivated families at low-performing schools greater options. As always, the difficulty is in defining the details and there are very few details provided at this point.

boundaries_comment: Expanding the boundary of O-A is going to have huge unintended consequences. For one, way more that 80 kids will go from the new boundary. Not only will people in the boundary who are currently sending their kids to private or charter schools switch to O-A, but many more people will move to the new area to get into O-A. Furthermore, the basis of the O-A bilingual program is that 50% of the kids are Spanish dominant and 50% are English dominant.  To maintain that balance, the school needs to take in a lot of OOB kids, which they won't be able to do with the expanded boundary.
feederpatterns_comment: Sending the Oyster-Adams kids to Cardozo would kill the nascent middle school program at O-A. It's a small number that go to Wilson, so it wouldn't affect overcrowding.  The effect will be to send families to charter and other options for middle school, so as to ensure placement in a high-performing high school.
eschoicesets_comment: Being able to walk to school is HUGE IMHO. All the latest health research says that having activity built into your day, like a twice daily walk, make a big difference. But also, it builds community. Now that my kids are old enough to walk to school by themselves, it is great for their independence (and my work schedule!)  We could walk to Eaton, but Hearst is too far.
mschoicesets_comment: I don't think having 7th and 8th graders specialize is a good idea.  they don't know enough about themselves and their learning styles yet.
msproximity_comment: Since middle schoolers can take transit, I think the walking part is not as essential, and this might be a good way to create interest in middle schools beyond the already overcrowded Deal MS.
hslottery_comment: A TERRIBLE TERRIBLE IDEA.  Seriously, WHY would we be sending kids across the city to go to school.  As a transportation planner I shudder at the traffic and coordination problems this would create.
setasides_comment: Its a good idea, but how are you going to provide extra seats at the already-overcrowded schools?

feederpatterns_comment: This feeder pattern is why we live where we do.
eschoicesets_comment: Significant reason we live where we do is access to Hearst; expect to be grandfathered to stay where we are.
mschoicesets_comment: Do not want a choice set; commute to Hardy is a deal-breaker for us and we would move.
msproximity_comment: If we were assigned to Oyster-Adams middle school we would leave the District for a school in a MD county.
hslottery_comment: A significant contributing factor to where we own a house is access to Wilson.
setasides_comment: Would work for a school like Hearst that already welcomes out-of-boundary students.

boundaries_comment:
The boundary change doesn't seem to consider school walkability.  The suggested change would double the distance we would have to walk to school. The result would essentially put most of us affected in cars.  It would also require us to cross Reno Road which is a fairly busy commuter lane.  I would think we would look at moving some of the people already driving to Murch to Lafayette which appears to have a projected drop-off in population and has similar performance ratings to Murch.

In addition to walkability, has there been any consideration of impact to home values.  I know that when we purchased our home well over a decade ago, the ability to easily walk to Murch, Deal and Wilson were all key considerations.  

The change also seems somewhat arbitrary and unbalanced.  Is it really based on a detailed assessment of demographics and will it really relieve crowding at Murch - especially considering the renovation and possible expansion of Murch?   How come it adds areas from Janney?  

This map is pretty misleading.  About one-third of it is Rock Creek Park.  How many Murch students actually live in the park???

Also, as I understand it, Hearst, even with the renovation, is almost at capacity when OOB students are included.  Considering renovations at Janney, Hearst, Deal, Wilson, etc have so badly missed the mark on target population projections,  what confidence do we have that we are accurately projecting the impact of this border change?  Especially considering the fluidity of the portions of the school population that reside in the large apartment buildings on CT?
eschoicesets_comment:
School "choice" set, in reality seems to be just a localized lottery that introduces uncertainty and some really significant impact to us if the new Murch boundary changes to move us into the Hearst "choice" set.  If the Murch boundary change goes forward as proposed, then under this "choice" set, we may end up at Eaton or Oyster Adams - both of them much further walking distances than Hearst and way further than Murch.  While Hearst would still feed into Deal, Eaton, according to Plan B, would feed into Hardy MS.  Aside from the fact that Oyster Adams is PS-8 (a pretty significant difference itself), OA feeds into Cardoza according to Plan B.  

I don't want "choice" sets because I don't think they are really choices.  I certainly don't want lottery sets that are this divergent in location, schools they feed and population grade spans.
mschoicesets_comment: As mentioned in elementary school "choice" set comments, school "choice" set, in reality seems to be just a localized lottery that introduces uncertainty and just ends up increasing transportation issues.  Deal MS is 13 min and 0.7 miles from my home.  Hardy is 52 min and 2.6 miles away.  We bought our home because we know that our location would allow our children to easily walk to school with their friends.   This proposed localized lottery puts that in jeopardy.
msproximity_comment: According to Google Maps - Deal is 0.7 mile and 13 min walk from my home.  Oyster Adams is 2.1 mile and 44 min walk from my home.  Going to Oyster Adams doesn't make much sense to me.  Again, we bought our house so our children could walk to Deal not Oyster Adams.  These school "choice" plans are just localized lotteries.  They are not really school choice.  I think the primary results would be greater uncertainty, anxiety and more people in cars.
hslottery_comment:
A citywide lottery for high schools is a non-starter.  It totally removes critical predictability.  If we can't predict where are children, by boundary rights, will go to school, then we would need to consider leaving DCPS and possibly the District.   It would undermine parent engagement in local schools and add a significant level of uncertainty into the housing market and real estate prices.  

Again, I think we are just putting people in cars to shuffle kids around the District.

I've seen some of the comparisons to other cities that have implemented this.  San Francisco, which seems to be the most comparable, appears to be rethinking this.  It also seems like there are many very frustrated and disappointed parents and students there.
setasides_comment:
I understand the desire to establish specific set asides.  However, I do not think they should be implemented to the detriment of in boundary students.  My concern is that the boundaries of overcrowded, currently performing schools would have to be collapsed even further to achieve these proposed set asides.  I understand that every parent wants the best education and environment for their children.  However, I think if we start pushing children into lower performing schools to meet these types of quotas, then we will just see people start to leave DCPS and the District.  

I guess the question I have is, "Why are we planning to have low-performing schools in the first place?"  I understand that we have them now.  However, it appears that under current policies, we already have a significant number of OOB students in DCPS.  By implementing permanent set aside percentages for lower performing schools, aren't we saying that we expect low-performing schools going forward?   This is counter to every quality improvement program I have ever seen.  The focus should be on improving the low-performance schools as rapidly as possible, not pushing kids further from the homes.

boundaries_comment: The school is already struggling with the growing size of classes due to an increase in neighborhood kids attending the school.  Extending the boundary will require a (physical) addition to the school.
eschoicesets_comment: I am happy with my in-boundary choice, but I understand the theory behind this "choice set."
mschoicesets_comment: At this time, I am concerned about Eliot Hine but have heard good things about Stuart Hobson and would like the option to chose between those two schools.
msproximity_comment: At this time, I am hesitant to send my child to Eliot Hine and would not consider sending my child to Wheatley.

boundaries_comment: Why not fix the irregular shape?
feederpatterns_comment: Your information is misleading.  My inbounds middle/high schools are now FS/SWW and Wilson.  New proposed boundaries are horrible,  We will move.
eschoicesets_comment: I want the neighborhood ES.
mschoicesets_comment: Hah.  A "choice set" with only one choice as an unbuilt school.  Kafkaesque.
msproximity_comment: Your information is incorrect.  Oyster-Adams is FAR closer to me than Cardoza.  But, oh yeah, we can't go there unless we speak spanish.  Oops.  And then there will be no space at FS/SWW b/c their 6th grade is the same size as their 6th grade, so again no "choice."  Stuck at Cardoza.
hslottery_comment: If you are going to take me out of Wilson and put me in Cardoza, I prefer the lottery.  I'm not going to Cardoza in any case.
setasides_comment: Sure - If you are going to make Cardoza my high school, you might as well give me a chance to get out.  I'm not going there in any case.  Probably moot, though, becasue I will have already moved to Maryland.

eschoicesets_comment: If choice sets are going to be forced upon parents, shouldn't the choices make geographic sense? What about a set of Amidon, Brent, the future Van Ness and Tyler? Why force parents to travel so far from their homes? Especially in the case of Van Ness which is 1 block from my house, why would I want to travel so far to a charter school across the river? This is a terrible idea. The choice set idea might work if all schools were equal, and some had exceptional programming. This is just not the reality in DC.
msproximity_comment: Again, why would I want to travel so far?

eschoicesets_comment: Brent and Tyler are high-performing schools that I'd love to send my kids to - Friendship, not so much. I wouldn't want that option.
msproximity_comment: Their performance levels don't meet my expectations.

eschoicesets_comment: I think that choice set for this address should include Peabody, not Tyler
mschoicesets_comment: Our middle schools need a major overhaul.  There is no good choice set.
msproximity_comment: There is no good middle school option.
hslottery_comment: Geographically this makes sense.  In reality, however, there is no decent high school option.
setasides_comment: Hello?  Fix the low performing schools.

boundaries_comment: That's fine. None of my options are very good, so changing the boundaries in my neighborhood doesn't matter too much.
feederpatterns_comment: I thought the Brookland ECs would be broken up when the new middle school is built. I sure hope that happens. Neither of those high schools is an option for my family, so again, sadly, the feeder pattern does not matter to me.
eschoicesets_comment: Don't add more uncertainty into this process, please. Make the schools better. Consolidate and think about providing some buses!
mschoicesets_comment: I think every middle school should be strong. Then have some specialty tracks. I hate the idea of forcing kids into a STEM or immersion program if that's not what the family wants. I guess this is coming from calls for magnet programs and looking at what's working at charters. That concept clashes with the concept of "neighborhood schools", which need to serve everyone in the neighborhood. Differentiation and specialization need to happen within every school, not vary from school to school, unless it is a magnet or charter that draws from across the city.
msproximity_comment: There are not enough good options now to not guarantee spots in the few good options there are.
hslottery_comment: This is the worst of all the ideas. Instead, make more, better, smaller high schools to give individual attention. Follow the Thurgood Marshall model. Look at what PG County is trying.
setasides_comment: until all schools are improved this seems like the only way to help improve access to quality education, especially for middle and high school.

boundaries_comment: Seems like this has no functional change, so no objection. Generally cool with current boundary -- maybe its too big compared to Maury or Brent in the other corners of this boundary. Makes it harder to build community, perhaps. But I don't want to split the 2 schools.
feederpatterns_comment: My kids are in preschool. Barring changes in our jobs, I expect to send them to Watkins and Stuart Hobson. But HS is too high stakes to not consider choices at that time (both of the parents in our household went to a magnet high school with gifted and AP classes, one a specialized STEM HS).
eschoicesets_comment: I'm OK with this, but it relies on having interesting, quality program choices at the three schools. If it's just everyone vying for the better school of the three, what's the point? I'd rather stick with Watkins and work on improving it. Otherwise, seems like the high SES, inbound families will stack Maury (current perceived as better) until it's full up to the defined percentage, then to some extent Watkins (next), then abandon Payne. Has to be cool offerings to draw inbound families. I want to increase inbound participation and community involvement; I think neighborhood elementary schools are the best way to improve schools. Then, the allocated seats to out-of-bound kids will also be better.
mschoicesets_comment: This is tough. I have my doubts about DCPS following through on quality MS programs. Sure, I'd love a great STEM MS. But if it doesn't materialize, I'd prefer a feeder pattern that kept more neighborhood kids in the school. I have no interest in driving my kid to middle school across the city for a charter or Deal or Hardy though.
msproximity_comment: I like this, given that the last middle school shake up in Ward 6 did not appear to result in more Ward 6 kids showing up in the middle schools. If DCPS isn't going to follow through with quality programs proposed in the other MS option above, give parents the choice for whatever they think is the slightly better school. Maybe they'll buy in and improve the schools.
hslottery_comment: I'd rather have test-in options (including STEM, e.g. T.J. or Stuyvesant) at HS than a neighborhood option. Programs are more important to me than neighborhood at that age. Kids can get themselves to school out of the neighborhood, and friendships are also less neighborhood dependent at that age. If I was looking at HS now for my kids, I would be looking at SWW, and would prefer an even more rigorous option.
setasides_comment: Not exactly sure how this would work. Given that only schools west of the park and Brent are full, it'll annoy them at the ES level. By HS, again, if the set aside got my kid into a rigorous program, I'd be happy. But, at that age, I would absolutely be considering private, charter or moving if my kid didn't have a quality option in DCPS. I don't say this to be threatening (I'm packing up my ball and going home!), just being honest about what I think our family would do.

eschoicesets_comment: My current address gives an option to attend the School Without Walls at Francis Stevens or Thompson Elementary. It seems like a proposed choice set doesn't allow the School Without Walls at Francis Stevens Elementary.

feederpatterns_comment: Unless there are substantial improvements at Cardozo, we would like to maintain our current zoned middle and high schools.  We are in-bounds for SWWFS for middle school and Wilson for high school.  A new middle school could be great, but we would need more details.  Meanwhile, SWWFS may need Ross students in order to
eschoicesets_comment: I don't think choice sets are a good idea for elementary school.  It is very important to us to be in the same school as other children in the neighborhood.  Also, Ross is just a block from our house, so I would consider

boundaries_comment: Support the boundary expansion, moved to this neighborhood to be in bounds for the school and this would give our family more in bounds apartment options.
feederpatterns_comment: Don't support changing to Cardozo
eschoicesets_comment: These were our top three schools picks anyway and I would support having only a few choices that include our in bounds school (especially if that means we have a better chance of getting into one of our neighborhood schools for preschool).

boundaries_comment: In the triangle formed by Nebraska Ave., Van Ness St., and Wisconsin Ave. there is currently 1 student enrolled in Janney. Moving this small section to Hearst will not help with over crowding. It also doubles the walking distance to school, forces students to cross Wisconsin Ave. and cuts this triangle off from the rest of AU Park - the neighborhood with which it is most connected. In the 14 years we have lived here there have never been more than 4 (maybe 5) students at Janney at any one time. Again - this would NOT relieve the overcrowding at Janney.
eschoicesets_comment: This would compromise the community feel of neighborhoods which is so attractive to residents. It also creates a level of uncertainty which I believe would lead residents to consider private school or moving out ad the district all together.
mschoicesets_comment: See comment about elementary choice sets
hslottery_comment: This would lead to great uncertainty about where you child would end up going. I think this would deter people from moving to the area. It would also result in Parents considering private school or even moving out of the district entirely.

eschoicesets_comment: I strongly disagree with this proposal.  Predictability and a walk-able neighborhood are very important to my family.  I would likely leave the District if this proposal were to be implemented.
mschoicesets_comment: Again, predictability is very important to me.  In addition, I believe that middle school is an incredibly important time, especially for girls.  I would absolutely not be comfortable with any uncertainty with respect to middle school choice.  I would leave the District if this proposal is implemented.
msproximity_comment: Again, predictability is very important to me.  In addition, I believe that middle school is an incredibly important time, especially for girls.  I would absolutely not be comfortable with any uncertainty with respect to middle school choice.  I would leave the District if this proposal is implemented.
hslottery_comment: I am strongly opposed to this proposal.  I would absolutely leave the District if this proposal is implemented.

boundaries_comment: Great news!!!
Pleased to be in-bounds for the school closest  to our home.
feederpatterns_comment: Looking forward to a revamped MacFarland-- Dual Language preferred.
eschoicesets_comment: I don't want to leave my child's in-bound school to chance.
mschoicesets_comment: Yes to new middle school.
msproximity_comment: Only if the choice set included the new middle school.
hslottery_comment: Really bad idea. I think that the OOB set asides are a good idea for every school to ensure that there is a chance to attend the school that is best suited to a student, regardless of location, however, communities put effort into building schools that are the best for them. A city wide lottery for schools would disinsentivitize community involvement in making local schools great.
