This said, schools in communities that are struggling should get extra support from the city.
setasides_comment: The city should work to improve low performing schools, not enable some lucky students to avoid them. Extra resources need to be given to low performing schools so that every student across the city has access to excellent neighborhood education.

boundaries_comment: West is too far, not walkable, and therefore not a safe option for children in my neighborhood.  Furthermore, those in my neighborhood have already started to invest considerably in Powell's revitalization. Also, including Crestwood in Powell's boundaries brings a higher SES element that provides a good mix to the school.
feederpatterns_comment: Crestwood feeds to Deal and Wilson by right.  That is why we purchased our home in our neighborhood and paid a premium.  We would never support sending our children to CHEC or West and Roosevelt. Neither school has programming that makes it a viable alternative to Deal and Wilson.
eschoicesets_comment: The schools in the choice sets are too far; also, certainty in elementary choices is absolutely necessary so a choice set lottery is unacceptable.  Parents need to know ahead of time which is their zoned elementary school so that they can take a vested interest even BEFORE their children enter the school, as has happened with Powell, for instance.  Even private school parents often support their in boundary public school for the sake of community.  Taking the certainty away removes non-public school parents' incentives to support the community school.
msproximity_comment: See comments re: certainty.
hslottery_comment: See comments re: certainty.
setasides_comment: Students at a school in this 10-20% might face discrimination or exclusion because they are seen as "set aside" students; this takes the burden off the administration from actually improving the schools.  Until "low performing" is defined, very difficult to support this proposal or understand what it means.

msproximity_comment: Really want Oyster as a choice please
hslottery_comment: Totally against lottery

boundaries_comment: We moved here partly because of Ross, so we're happy that the new boundary proposal does not impact our right to attend Ross.
feederpatterns_comment: We currently have (and would take advantage of) the right to attend a decent/improving middle school (SWW@Francis-Stevens) and a very good high school (Wilson).  If our only option was to send our child to Cardozo after elementary school, we would inevitably move (or try to lottery into an OOB or charter school - although we strongly prefer to have our child go to a neighborhood school because we believe in fostering a strong local community - plus a long commute is a deal-breaker) because Cardozo is of much less caliber than our current zoned schools (and a much longer commute).  I can't comment on the proposed option of a "new middle school" because there's no information about the location or programming of the school or how DCPS would ensure it would be a high quality school.
mschoicesets_comment: This is not a choice set if there is only one middle school.  It's difficult to comment on this proposal without any information about the proposed new middle school.
msproximity_comment: We currently have (and would take advantage of) the right to attend SWW@FS.  We would not send our child to Cardozo EC - it's too long of a commute and not good enough quality.  Interesting that this proposal does not include the new middle school (does DCPS already know the location?).

boundaries_comment: Glad I'd stay at Janney but can't fathom why families that live just blocks from school would no longer be zoned for it.

feederpatterns_comment: I would prefer Hardy to Francis Stevens
eschoicesets_comment: Hyde Addison would be preferable to Francis Stevens; Ross would be equivalent in my mind
mschoicesets_comment: Oyster-Adams would be OK; Francis Stevens as it currently exists would be an unacceptable Middle School to me
hslottery_comment: I much prefer Wilson to Cardozo
setasides_comment: If my only option was Francis-Stevens and then Cardozo I would apply for set-aside slot at Wilson (or a Charter Middle/High School)

eschoicesets_comment:
Neighborhood schools are crucial for many reasons. 

First, neighborhood schools are easily accessible and in many cases, walkable or bikable. In my case, traveling to Murch and Lafayette would be significantly more difficult because they would require a car and traveling across many congested roadways.  My child would be in a car for more time per day, and we would spend more money on gasoline and probably have to buy a second car.  The added car travel that this plan would create would not only congest our roads but result in more pollution, too. 

Second, many individuals zoned for a particular neighborhood school bought their home precisely because they wanted to send their child to that neighborhood school. The "choice set" approach turns that on its head.

Third, the "choice set" would result in many children having to be bused to schools far from where they live, all while they have a school right nearby their homes. This makes no sense.

Fourth, because of all the concerns above, the "choice set" approach would result in many families leaving Washington, DC for Maryland so that their children can attend a neighborhood school. This would adversely affect property values, property tax revenues for the city, and also destabilize many of the neighborhoods that have seen reinvestment in the past 15 years.
mschoicesets_comment: For the same reasons articulated with respect to elementary schools, choice sets are an awful idea. Among other things, my son should not have to go commute all the way to Hardy when he lives nearby Deal.
msproximity_comment: This plan would potentially have my son traveling an incredibly long distance to middle school, when Deal Middle School is right near our neighborhood.  An eleven year old should not have to travel more than a half hour per day to go to school. This proposal would create more traffic, pollution, and would waste the time of both parents and children. Moreover, we should never be put in a position to have to send our child to a bilingual school if we do not think that is best for him.
hslottery_comment:
This would be a terrible approach, for many reasons. First, Wilson High School is easily accessible for us by walking, biking, or public transportation. Any other high school in the city would be very far away and force us to have to drive our son to school. This would require a car and traveling across many congested roadways.  My child would be in a car for more time per day, and we would spend more money on gasoline and probably have to buy a second car.  The added car travel that this plan would create would not only congest our roads but result in more pollution, too. 

Second, we bouht out home precisely because we want to send our son to Wilson HS when he gets older. This approach turns that on its head.

Third, because of all the concerns above, this approach would result in many families leaving Washington, DC for Maryland so that their children can attend a neighborhood school. This would harm the DC schools and would also adversely affect property values and property tax revenues. Finally, it would also destabilize many of the neighborhoods that have seen reinvestment in the past 15 years.
setasides_comment: This could be a good idea, but it would depend on how it is implemented.

boundaries_comment: We bought this house (paying more than we can really afford) last summer in order to send out kids to Janney.  VERY glad that we can still send our kids there.
feederpatterns_comment: Again, we bought the house IN ORDER to have this school set going forward and because we are big believers in neighborhood schools - paying more than we can really afford.  VERY glad that our feeder pattern stays the same.
eschoicesets_comment: Think this is a terrible idea.  We bought our house so our kids could walk to school, so that we would have the sense of community that a neighborhood school brings, and so that we could finally end our (currently) heinous commutes.  This just adds uncertainty and confusion and eliminates many of the advantages of buying where we did.
mschoicesets_comment: Think this is a terrible idea.  We bought our house so our kids could go to Deal and would be close by.  This just adds uncertainty and confusion and eliminates many of the advantages of buying where we did.
hslottery_comment: Terrible, terrible idea.  We bought in order to be part of the Wilson school system and do not want to have the uncertainty about HS, or to force our kids on a long commute.  We would probably move or pull out of the DC schools if this were to happen.
setasides_comment: I am all in favor of moving kids out of low performing schools into better schools.  Think that is good for everyone.  Just think there has to be a way to do so without also forcing kids out of high-performing school districts into lower performing schools.   If that means money for new classrooms in the high performing schools to increase capacity, let's find a way to make that happen!

eschoicesets_comment: I live half a block from Ross- I would be very annoyed if my child had to travel a few miles to get to school rather than crossing the street. Seems ridiculous.
msproximity_comment: Seems more reasonable to have a choice/travel for MS and HS than elementary.
hslottery_comment: Unsure about this...
setasides_comment: You really need to improve all schools- that should be the bottom line.

eschoicesets_comment: Good idea.  We go to a charter that is moving to our neighborhood but would love to have more neighborhood kids so it would feel more like a neighborhood school.
hslottery_comment: This school has a horrific performance record.  I would never send my children here.
setasides_comment: This is a good plan but obviously won't help everyone who is a assigned to a low performing school.  So awesome happy face if we get a set aside at Wilson but what about all the rest of the kids?

hslottery_comment:
This plan is awful. I will move out of DC if you pursue this plan and so will many of my neighbors. This plan has been tried and failed in
places like SF.
setasides_comment:
The answer here is not to move students around and force them
To commute in one of the most gridlocked cities in the country. That will chew up their young lives. It is to fix the underperforming schools. Period. We all want to help make his happen.

boundaries_comment: i'd do anything to get my child into Ross Elementary School, right at Dupont Circle. I wish they could move Ross into Francis-Stevens. There's probably room.
feederpatterns_comment: Cardozo is a mess. We'll move and go to Deal, unless they can improve Hardy, and F-S kids can go to Hardy.
eschoicesets_comment: YES!
hslottery_comment: Unless they can create a high school with similar offerings to ALice Deal, we'll go private or move to Bethesda for BCC High School.
setasides_comment: The key is to be able to isolate or expel violent or disruptive kids. At Francis-Stevens, it took YEARS to remove a child in 3rd grade who attacked the littlest kids (pre-schoolers). This was under a previous administration, but I don't know if things have changed. I don't care where the kids come from if we can quickly isolate or expel or re-assign violent children.

boundaries_comment: Neighborhood schools in my opinion is one of the most important things for a community.  The schools serves to connect the neighborhood.  It also encourages the community to invest both time and other resources to the school.  One problem affecting DC is the lottery system in general.  If  the lottery system was never implemented and we just had neighborhood schools it would have encouraged more community involvement and would have lead to stronger schools.  With that said I can not support at this point relocated any student to a school that is lower performing than their current choices.  DC must make the investment to improve schools and then evaluate redistricting.
feederpatterns_comment: The negative review is based strictly on the choice to have Eaton feed Hardy.  I am not opposed to having Eaton feed Hardy; however, I am opposed to making the change prior to Hardy being equal to or greater to deal from an academic stand point.  I do not think sending kids to lower performing schools should ever be considered.
eschoicesets_comment: This provides way to much unpredictability and is a horrible idea.  This will lead to a flight from DC.
msproximity_comment: This provides way to much unpredictability and is a horrible idea.  This will lead to a flight from DC.
hslottery_comment: This provides way to much unpredictability and is a horrible idea.  This will lead to a flight from DC.
setasides_comment: I think the focus of the committee should be on improving schools not reshuffling the current situation or choosing winner and losers.  If every school were a good option this wouldn't be and issue.  Time for DC to make a significant investment in the education system.

boundaries_comment: We currently attend Eaton.
feederpatterns_comment: We are happy to go to deal but very sad to see that most of our Eaton friends would be sent elsewhere.
eschoicesets_comment: This idea I like. Good choices are good choices.
mschoicesets_comment: I like this idea too but would want to see an improvement in the middle schools before this change occurred.
hslottery_comment: I like this idea in theory but the district has to improve high schools across the city first before implementing a lottery system. You will drive all of the NW families away if you take away their option to attend Wilson.

boundaries_comment: The change is welcome but Ross is so close in proximity that it seems unfortunate to have to travel so far.  The boundary looks
eschoicesets_comment: It seems as though Ross is closer in proximity but not even on our list.

boundaries_comment: The boundary is a natural neighborhood boundary, so that makes sense. One hopes this expansion will naturally result in capacity planning for Bancroft...
feederpatterns_comment: Deal and Wilson are currently better schools than CHEC, but there are looming capacity problems at Deal and Wilson. Ultimately DCPS needs to commit to improving CHEC (and other middle schools and high schools), and maybe building a few more, too. Shuffling feeder patterns without improving the schools is a zero-sum game.
eschoicesets_comment: We have a 1 year-old and are strongly considering purchasing our home in Mt. Pleasant based on the possibility of being able to send her to Bancroft. Sending our daughter to a poor performing school is not an option, and we would move out of the District if we could not have predictability on this issue. The same thinking applies to DC's middle schools, but that's farther off in the future and hopefully DCPS will make improvements there.
mschoicesets_comment: Middle school is the most concerning aspect of DCPS for our family, regardless of the proposals. If Deal becomes overcrowded, it won't be able to maintain its level of excellence. On the other hand, we simply won't send our daughter to a less-than-excellent school. It's disappointing that the proposals have nothing in them to address the need for continued investment in schools. Removing predictability seems to remove the ability of parents to invest in their schools and plan for the future.
msproximity_comment: Neither CHEC or Raymond EC are currently good enough schools for our daughter. They'd need to improve substantially for us to consider them.
hslottery_comment: This might be the dumbest idea in the history of public education. Every student deserves access to a good school, and that's the core problem DCPS needs to address. Throwing the lives of families into chaos, and commuting, is not going to improve schools. In fact, it will make the schools worse, as families with greater means withdraw from DCPS for private schools or for the suburbs.
setasides_comment: This would obviously require capacity planning, but every child deserves access to a good school.

boundaries_comment: We would be re-assigned to a school that is over 10 blocks away when Langley is less than 2.  I think Bloomingdale should be kept in one zone and not split.

Our address currently feeds into both Deal and Wilson, and we would be enormously angry and upset if our children were removed from their current feeder pattern. Moving children from higher performing schools to much, much lower performing schools is outrageous.  This proposal is also removing largely African American neighborhoods from Deal and Wilson, and this is a civil right violation.

feederpatterns_comment: Stuart Hobson has a better reputation, but I think it's a better solution to have everyone feeding to the same MS.
eschoicesets_comment: Dislike!! This would disrupt progress in neighborhood schools. The school that needs the most improvement in this set, Payne, would not benefit from this arrangement either.  Payne will improve if parents make a long-term investment and are locked in to that specific school, which is what happened with Maury and Brent.  The so-called "choice set" would destabilize things and not allow parents to focus on their neighborhood schools.
mschoicesets_comment: Double dislike!!! Parents need to be able to make a long-term, locked-in commitment to specific neighborhood schools.  ANything else would destroy progress in neighborhood schools, and prevent progress in schools.
msproximity_comment: How is this different from choice sets?  I don't see a difference.
hslottery_comment: Distributing schools by lottery is a horrible thing and a very sad commentary on the state of public policy in this country.  Access to appropriate education should be a goal for everyone, not something distributed by lottery and chance!  We need to preserve and protect progress where it exists (ie Wilson), create innovative new options (Charters, advanced tracks at neighborhood schools), and implement ACTUAL programs to help distadvantaged students, not just cast their fates on the whim of a lottery system!  Again, this is a horrible, sad, idea!!!!
setasides_comment: This is a good idea to help low-income students.

hslottery_comment: This is the worst idea. I would hate for my kids having to commute 2 hours a day to a far away high school having to use public transit that is not ready for this kind of operation. I would strongly consider moving out of state

feederpatterns_comment: I always thought Hobart Street should be included with the rest of Mt. Pleasant.
eschoicesets_comment: I just don't care much for the choice set concept as it breaks up any neighborhood cohesion or continuity.
msproximity_comment: Terrible choices!
hslottery_comment: I would prefer to know from pre-k which middle and high school my child would attend.
setasides_comment: Doesn't this already exist in some form?

boundaries_comment:
That doesn't make sense!!! I walk my kids to school 4 blocks away, I refuse the idea of driving or crossing major roads!!! 
We moved to this neighborhood to attend Murch, if we knew we wouldn't move there and as a matter of fact we will consider move out of the city of these changes take place.

hslottery_comment: Totally against this. You should be able to send your child to close to your home.

boundaries_comment: Pls fix poor performing schools before you adjust any school boundaries.
eschoicesets_comment: Parents need predictability or they will leave the city. Parents want to invest in their neighborhood school they know their child will attend.
mschoicesets_comment: Parents need predictability or they will leave the city. Parents want to invest in their neighborhood school they know their child will attend.

boundaries_comment: Eaton is a great school.
feederpatterns_comment: Hardy is promising.  Given the number of children coming through other Wilson feeder schools, I think it is highly irresponsible to say that Wilson can accommodate rising Deal and Hardy students in the next 3-4 years.  There is no concrete option on the table for Hardy families to feel comfortable that they will go to Wilson or get lumped into a relatively inferior performing school.  This is where Eaton families are extremely upset with the shift to Hardy and where Hardy families are justifiably worried about the reliability of Wilson.  My fear (this keeps me up at night) is that no accommodations will be made for a new needed high school and Hardy will be dumped into a terrible high school very far from where we live.
eschoicesets_comment: This is nonsense for upper NW elementary schools.  Please don't waste my tax dollars on such trash.
mschoicesets_comment: Again, nonsense for our area.  Please spend our resources wisely.
msproximity_comment: Seems like another waste of resources to determine this.
hslottery_comment: If this is being seriously considered, I will go grab my picket sign and stand outside of your office.  This is HIGHLY IRRESPONSIBLE in terms of maintaining residents in the city.  Please wake up and stop wasting our time and worry.  Take this option out now.
setasides_comment: There is no concrete way to implement this.  Good luck with the lawsuits.

boundaries_comment: I fully support the new boundary proposal!

feederpatterns_comment: This might be fine if the problems with Hardy MS are resolved and this school performs at the same level as Deal MS.  If there continues to be leadership turnover and other challenges, then I would want the current option of enrolling at Deal MS to remain.
eschoicesets_comment: Students should always have the ability to attend their neighborhood elementary school.  The issue underlying this entire debate is that a number of city elementary schools are underperforming.  Address that issue.  Shuffling the students around to avoid underperforming neighborhood schools is sweeping the problem under the rug.
mschoicesets_comment: I would want the option to choose which MS to send my child.  Hopefully both would be high performing so the issue would be moot.
hslottery_comment: This is the worst possible idea.  I bought my house in my neighborhood because of the school options available at the time.  Should this proposal be implemented, I would likely look to send my child to a private school or move out of the city in order to attend a school that is both closer and higher performing.  This solution will not improve overall performance in high schools across the city.  Instead it will balance the performance.  It could also have a substantial negative impact to the real estate values in parts of the city that attract families wanting their children to attend the best public schools available.  The issue is really about improving performance in underperforming schools.  Address that and you don't need to shuffle kids across the city.
setasides_comment: Improve those schools and you eliminate this need.

eschoicesets_comment: We should be able to go to the school that is WALKING distance to our house and not have to change schools to which we already are assigned.

We should be able to go to the school that is in WALKING distance to our house and to which we currently are assigned.  We purchased our house based on these factors.  Any changes would force us to either go to private school or move to Montgomery County, Maryland.
mschoicesets_comment: We should be able to go to the school that is in WALKING distance to our house and to which we currently are assigned.  We purchased our house based on these factors.  Any changes would force us to either go to private school or move to Montgomery County, Maryland. .
msproximity_comment: We should be able to go to the school that is in WALKING distance to our house and to which we currently are assigned.  We purchased our house based on these factors.  Any changes would force us to either go to private school or move to Montgomery County, Maryland.
hslottery_comment: We should be able to go to the school that is in WALKING distance to our house and to which we currently are assigned.  We purchased our house based on these factors.  Any changes would force us to either go to private school or move to Montgomery County, Maryland.

eschoicesets_comment: I much prefer the current approach which guarantees access to a neighborhood school based on where you live.
mschoicesets_comment: I much prefer the current approach which guarantees the right to attend your local school.
msproximity_comment: I much prefer the existing system which guarantees the right to attend your local neighborhood school.
hslottery_comment: I strongly oppose switching to a lottery system.
setasides_comment: I like the idea of allowing out-of-boundary opportunities but would need to learn more about set-asides and whether they would displace neighborhood children.

feederpatterns_comment: My children have attended John Eaton Elementary because we used to live in Columbia Heights before we moved to AU Park. We love John Eaton school and have stayed there even though we could go to Janney. John Eaton currently has the choice of feeder middle school (Deal or Hardy). Rather than remove that choice, I propose giving that choice to all elementary schools that feed into Deal. This would provide  more opportunities for families to choose Hardy as it improves and even now is preferred by musically gifted students and students who prefer smaller schools for example. It would be psychologically smarter to work with Eaton to embrace Hardy over next months and years while maintaining their right to attend Deal. To remove the Deal option from them will not give you happy partners to work with and violates the principal that changes would not give students a worse option than they have in the current feeder pattern.
eschoicesets_comment: Particularly where all the schools in a choice set are pretty equal, it makes more practical sense to stick to the neighborhood school model.... go to school where you live.
mschoicesets_comment: It would be preferable to be able to attend the middle school that is less than a mile from home.
msproximity_comment: Again, we would prefer a guaranteed access to the school less than a mile away.
hslottery_comment: I do not think this approach will improve schools across the city. Furthermore it will compromise the success of the good schools. Keep neighborhood schools and invest in giving families and underserved schools the resources they need to succeed. Remove the $$ per head requirement and give as much money is needed to improve schools regardless of their numbers.
setasides_comment: Maybe as a transitional measure... set asides would be good to ensure diversity and interconnectedness... alongside radical school improvement that if successful would reduce the need for set asides.

boundaries_comment: My child already attends a great elementary school out of boundary that the whole family loves. We hope that our toddler would be able to attend the same school. There are reasons why certain schools have low enrollment or excess capacity.
feederpatterns_comment: I am very concerned with this feeder pattern. Right now my child's school (which we got her in through the lottery) feeds into great middle and high-schools (Deal and Wilson).
mschoicesets_comment: As long as none of the focuses are the arts,  it won't kill us. This type of focus is currently why  many parents of students don't want to send their children to Hardy.
msproximity_comment: I don't care for either choice as we are happy with our current school situation.

feederpatterns_comment: We would be very happy to be zoned for Eastern instead of Dunbar. For middle school, Jefferson would be slightly less preferred than Eliot-Hine. What Brent (and the Hill) needs is to feed into Stuart-Hobson! If we were guaranteed a feeder spot at Stuart Hobson, we would not even do the charter lottery in between 4th and 5th. We'd happily send our child to Hobson knowing that many of her current school peers would follow suit.
eschoicesets_comment: I don't see how this would work as intended. Families who are currently zoned for Brent who get Tyler or Friendship will not stick around. Our family, for example, would move or pursue private school options. A choice set would only work if all the choices were roughly equivalent. They aren't. This scenario can only bring Brent down while doing little to lift up the others. We might not stay at Brent even if we were assigned it under this scenario; I don't see how it could maintain its current excellence.
mschoicesets_comment: We would prefer a feed by right into Stuart Hobson, but this option would be, I suppose, better than just feeding into Jefferson or Eliot-Hine. As with the elementary school option, though, we strongly prefer traditional boundaries and feeds rather than choice sets.
msproximity_comment: This would be our second choice after a straight feeder into Stuart-Hobson.
hslottery_comment: I'm not sure how this would work. In general we prefer traditional boundaries and a neighborhood school, and fear the uncertainty of a lottery.
setasides_comment: We would love to see Brent, our child's current elementary school, with more socioeconomic diversity, and would wholly support increased access to high-performing schools like Brent. This seems like a MUCH better way to achieve that goal and maintain high-quality schools than the proposed choice sets.

feederpatterns_comment:
Cardozo is not an acceptable alternative to Wilson.  This part of the proposal should be taken off the table immediately.

The expansion of the boundary would upset the language balance of the program unless coupled with an physical expansion of both campuses.
eschoicesets_comment: While Eaton is a wonderful school, and Hearst is fast improving, neither have bilingual programs and would not be acceptable alternatives for our family
hslottery_comment: This proposal would be so disruptive and destabilizing to the system as to drive a significant number of families away from DCPS and, in many cases, force them to move out of the District.  The loss of these families would set the progress of DCPS back 20 or more years, and result in a significant reduction in D.C. tax revenues, thereby undermining the revitalization of the city itself.

boundaries_comment:
Harvard Street seems the natural boundary and would put us in the same boundary as the rest of Mt Pleasant.

This would allow our kids to go to school with other kids in our neighborhood.  After trying different options -- HD Cooke, a charter, and now Hearst -- we have found that consistency of connection over time and having our kids able to attend the same school as other kids in our neighborhood has value beyond what we had anticipated.
feederpatterns_comment: Fixed feeder patterns create student cohorts which are as important as academics to a students success. It also encourages programmatic links between primary and secondary schools and parental investment in schools.  Also, we moved our children to Hearst from a charter school we loved in order to gain access to Deal after also trying Cooke elementary.  We have learned from this experience that consistent and secure feeder patterns are essential to the well-being of parents and kids alike.
eschoicesets_comment: Choice sets are disruptive to families and neighborhoods and weaken links between kids, schools and neighborhoods. Choices include two low-performing schools and one mid-performing bi-lingual school. Assigned schools should be comprehensive and not specialized.
mschoicesets_comment: Choice sets are disruptive to families and neighborhoods and weaken links between kids, schools and neighborhoods.
msproximity_comment: Choice sets are disruptive to families and neighborhoods and weaken links between kids, schools and neighborhoods.
hslottery_comment: Lotteries turn education into a gamble and a game that you win or lose. Not a good message for our children.
setasides_comment: In my experience the only option that works for kids assigned to low-performing schools, especially those who are low-income, are Out of Boundary spots in better schools, which is what a set-aside would be, and charters, which are not being discussed here. I feel strongly about this option because I know many highly motivated, lower-income families at Hearst who drive their kids from Anacostia and other wards everyday because their in-boundary, assigned school is terrible and dangerous. In 50 years of trying, it hasnt changed. But what has changed and is very hopeful are charters and those OOB families who get access to better schools through set-asides.

boundaries_comment: Brookland is divided up into three under-enrolled and (with the exception of John Burroughs) under-performing elementary schools. The proposal is to continue this. Why not give us all access to a single school (presumably Burroughs) or at least reduce to two, so that they have a fighting chance at improvement rather than continuing to dilute the student pool and resources.
feederpatterns_comment: This information is incorrect. There is a new Brookland Middle School being built, which will be our middle school feeder as of the 15-16 SY. While I am happy to see the end of PS3-8 "education campuses", I question the amount of resources being poured into a brand new middle school that is likely to be under-enrolled and under-performing, just like it's feeder elementary schools are.
eschoicesets_comment: I'm tired of the word "lottery" being used to describe my child's access to a decent education. Giving me a choice of 3 medicore schools instead of 1 is still not a choice I want.
mschoicesets_comment: Again, this information is outdated. There is a new middle school being built in Brookland, thus I am not able to comment.
msproximity_comment: There is a new Brookland middle school being built.
hslottery_comment: Enough with the lotteries. Focus on strengthening neighborhood schools. Ensure that all students, regardless of what their zipcode is or whether they "win the lottery" have access to a good high school education. Giving the entire city access to Wilson feels like a cop out--since everyone "could" get into Wilson, we don't have to focus on improving Dunbar, Roosevelt, etc.
setasides_comment: Again, enough with the lotteries, enough with trying to rectify low-performing schools by providing parents a way to opt out. FIX THE SCHOOLS. #chanceisnotchoice

feederpatterns_comment: My child will not go to Hardy!
eschoicesets_comment: No lottery. My child is in Eaton and will stay in Eaton.
mschoicesets_comment: No lottery. My child will go only to Deal and never to Hardy.
hslottery_comment: No lottery!

boundaries_comment: sounds like Janney is overcrowded and tightening the boundaries could help that.
eschoicesets_comment: walkability to an elementary school is a critical element of creating a neighborhood school. we bought our house 3 blocks away from Janney ES so we could walk/ride bikes and use public transportation.

feederpatterns_comment: To bring my kids to and from Hardy would mean traveling with significant traffic further from our home than Deal. For me, that means my younger son would have to also wake earlier and spend 40 minutes taking his brother to school before he goes to school every morning. I chose Eaton with the understanding that my kids could then go to Deal and I would like to still have that option. I want my kids who live close to Deal to have preference over the many students coming from all over the city to attend Deal.
msproximity_comment: I don't think students who have not attended a bilingual elementary school should be placed Ina bilingual middle school.
hslottery_comment: Home dare bought and paid a significant premium for the high school they will be guaranteed access to. To institute a city wide lottery could diminish my home value and more importantly not guarantee access to a great high school for my kids.

feederpatterns_comment: I believe in neighborhood school feeder patterns- that is how you build a sense of community and get families to stay in the city.  People want certainty.
hslottery_comment: I am proponent of neighborhood schools and if every high school is lottery people are going to stop caring about their neighborhood schools and feeder schools.  People like certainty.  If I know my children are going to Eastern, I will be more likely to get involved now (my children are young).
setasides_comment: How about working to improve the school instead of pulling students out??

feederpatterns_comment: I won't be using the middle or high school options outlined here. While we still don't know where we will go, it will not be Dunbar. Whether DCPS arranges to give us choice in the system or not, we will be making another choice.

I want my youngest son to be able to go to Deal, like his older brothers did.

If part of the neighborhood (those who are grandfathered in) goes to Deal and another part of the neighborhood goes to Hardy, will the city run two bus routes for neighborhood kids, one bus route to Deal and another bus route to Hardy?
eschoicesets_comment:
I might WANT to send my child to a bilingual school, but I don't want the city to force me to do so.

Also, our in-boundary school is Eaton.  Why would I want a choice set and lottery that could require me to send my child to a school that isn't as good as Eaton?
mschoicesets_comment: I bought my house in Cleveland Park knowing that it would feed into Deal.  Don't now take away my ability to send my children to Deal!  Make Hardy attractive enough that people WANT to send their children there, don't force people to send their children there.  Hardy and Deal will always be very different, even once Hardy is a good school.  Some people will want a smaller school like Hardy for their child.
msproximity_comment:
I HATE it!  Both Hardy and Oyster are inferior to my current middle school - Deal.
Don't FORCE me to send my child there.  Make those schools better so that I WANT to send my child there (for the smaller size or the language program, for example).
hslottery_comment: I bought my house to be in-boundaries for Wilson.  I do NOT want to send my child to a different high school.  In fact, I won't.  If the lottery assigned my child any school other than Wilson, I would move out of the city or send my child to a private/parochial/charter school.
setasides_comment:
There's not enough space in the good schools to create set-asides.
IMPROVE THE EXISTING SCHOOLS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

eschoicesets_comment: Will create more trouble with transport logistics. Also will break up the neighborhood feel that the kids who live in close proximity to each other enjoy. They can walk to their friends house for play dates and don't have to waste time in traffic
mschoicesets_comment: Again makes no sense to take away from the current feeding pattern. What will happen is the good schools will become less high performing and the bad schools will remain bad. What is the point of this overhaul.
hslottery_comment: Just plain terrible. Leave the school boundaries alone. Work on building new schools and on bring failing schools up to par. Bussing has never worked in the past why will it work now. If I

boundaries_comment: I am delighted that my address would be zoned for Cleveland as would the northern half of Bloomingdale. However, due to the baby boom specifically in Bloomingdale, I question whether Cleveland is large enough to accommodate that large a change through all of elementary school.
feederpatterns_comment: A new middle school would be created to serve my neighborhood? Where? What elementary school would feed it?
eschoicesets_comment: Choice sets are a TERRIBLE idea, because they would prevent any individual neighborhood to focus on improving ONE school. Therefore, poor schools would continue to languish as parents drive their children across town to charter/private schools, or worse, continue to move out of the District.
msproximity_comment: This would be better than choice sets, but problematic for historically underserved neighborhoods.
hslottery_comment: My children are very young, so I don't know enough about DC HSs to comment v
setasides_comment: Little improves, unless high-income and highly motivated parents are forced to improve things. Allowing them to flee bad schools perpetuates the problems.

eschoicesets_comment: Doesn't make sense to have choice sets where driving is necessary when one can walk to the neighborhood school.
mschoicesets_comment: Doesn't make sense to feed into a middle school that is miles away when one can walk or short bike to one just a few blocks away, which would be appropriate for a middle school age student.
msproximity_comment: Again, doesn't make sense to have students/parents driving to different locations when we purchased a home that is walkable to the local elementary.
hslottery_comment: Doesn't make sense to have students traveling all over the District when people purchase homes near the local educational facilities. The solution is to make all of the schools viable for District families. Changing the terms at this juncture is a stupid proposal. What does make sense is having magnet and specialized schools (such as vocational and performing arts) at central locations that are metro accessible.
setasides_comment: I guess this is a good thing, but hard to know. Would in-boundary students be bumped at high demand schools for the set-aside seats? If so, that doesn't seem very fair to the in-boundary families.

feederpatterns_comment: Unhappy with Hardy - we bought our house for Deal and Wilson, and Hardy is not close to the level of quality of Deal.
eschoicesets_comment: If we don't know our ES, we won't stay in DC.
mschoicesets_comment: If both schools are equally good this would be fine, but it's far from clear that Hardy can be quickly brought to the level of Deal.
msproximity_comment: We bought for Deal and Wilson. Taking away a guaranteed slot will make us leave DC.
hslottery_comment: If DC goes ahead with this idiotic plan, and kids can be sent across the city to under-performing schools, there will be a mass exodus of taxpayers from DC. And no family will ever buy in the city again, unless they know they can afford private school.
setasides_comment: There's no way to set aside 20% of slots in at-capacity schools without kicking out in-bound kids. Building more schools in NW might alleviate this problem, but that will take years.

feederpatterns_comment: Cardozo is not an acceptable option for Oyster-Adams middle school students at this time. A small group of O-A students is being singled out to be sent to a low performing high school. As the parent of a child entering middle school, I am faced with this possibility in three years, and there is no way Cardozo can turn around that quickly.
eschoicesets_comment: Elementary choice sets make no sense in this part of Ward 3. All of the schools are overcrowded, and there is no sense in just shuffling students around. There needs to be more of an effort to make these neighborhood schools.
mschoicesets_comment: There has to be another option for middle school in our boundary. My child is remaining at Adams for middle school, but students shouldn't be forced to remain at a bilingual school.
msproximity_comment: Offering only Adams or CHEC as options will weaken Oyster-Adams overall. Many in-boundary parents will not want to send their children to Oyster for elementary if those are the only middle schools in the choice set.
hslottery_comment: Potentially sending students from one side of the city to another makes no sense. Work on strengthening each school so not everyone is fighting to get into Wilson, and don't make kids take three buses to get from Upper NW to Anacostia.

address: 42XX MARTIN LUTHER KING JR AVENUE SW

boundaries_comment: Browne is across a major road and is not walkable from my home.  Maury is walkable from our house.

feederpatterns_comment: We bought our house in large part because we knew our children would feed to Deal and then Wilson.  To change this not only upsets our intended educational plans, but also devalues our property.  Please do not make these changes.

boundaries_comment: It's crazy that homes across the street from Payne are guaranteed access to Peabody (15 blocks away), while parents with school-aged children flee our arbitrary box to better school territory 3 blocks north or south. If we're stuck with traditional boundaries, at least expand them to bring new blood into low-enrollment schools -- folks will complain, but adding Barney Circle to Payne's territory could bring in an abrupt flood of new, energized neighborhood based parents to dilute the high-maintenance, low-participation concentration of homeless shelter families vs. the current trickle of neighborhood families who cycle in, get disillusioned and leave. Choice sets are better, of course.
feederpatterns_comment: I can't say I'm thrilled with those choices, but it's better than the "two closest" options from my perspective.
eschoicesets_comment: This fantastic and fair alternative to the current boundaries which distort everything from real estate values to neighborhood demographics, without the terrible commute and logistical challenges of a city-wide lottery. Obviously there will be winners and losers, but families with means will have an incentive to work on making all neighborhood schools better rather than just moving across a boundary line. Meanwhile challenging populations of students -- from the homeless shelter or a housing project, will be spread out among several schools with high achieving peers and teachers who can help them improve, rather than concentrating them in a few schools like Payne and Tyler that lack the resources and ambition to shift expectations.
mschoicesets_comment: Obviously there will still be winners and losers as in the case of elementary, but at least conscious boundaries will allow a concerted neighborhood commitment to a set of schools and avoid the risk of untenable commutes such as across Anacostia river bridges in the case of "closest two."
msproximity_comment: Ignoring the benefits of neighborhood cohesion and geographic barriers risks disaster. Fair or not, if presented a choice between a school east or west of the Anacostia, 95% of families will choose west, and I suspect 95% of Capitol Hill families assigned to schools east of the river, will instead find a private alternative or leave the city altogether. East of the river schools will continue to decline as spots go unfilled.
hslottery_comment: There are real benefits to a neighborhood committed to improving its schools. When families live within walking distance, their kids can play together while parents conspire to make the school better. I experienced this firsthand when I was part of a group of parents committed to improve Payne. As those kids found one way or another to escape Payne, that neighborhood cohesion fell apart. Besides, driving kids to schools all across town would worsen traffic and waste countless hours of childhood in transit.
setasides_comment: Not quite sure how this would work. Seems risky unless you dramatically expand capacity at high performing high schools.

boundaries_comment: The neighborhood has not bought into Brookland @ Bunker Hill. See low-boundary participation. So I am unhappy to remain within its boundaries.
feederpatterns_comment:
Why was our high school re-assigned from Coolidge to Dunbar? Take us out of a bad high school and give us an even worse one -- that's my perception anyway. 

And I think our middle school would be Brookland MS to open in a year, right? Not Brookland at Bunker Hill. Surely after the $50 MM DCPS has poured into BMS, there will no longer be a Brookland Ed Camps. At least that's what I heard at many community mtgs.
eschoicesets_comment: This limits my choices (vs current lottery) and at the same time, increases uncertainty, and decreases motivation to invest in one's in-boundary school. And how am I supposed to know whether I like a choice set that includes an unnamed "charter school" in it? I presume that only a less popular charter school (i.e., one with trouble filling its classes) would be enticed to join this system, not a Tier 1 or Popular school.
mschoicesets_comment: Wouldn't our Middle School choices be the new Brookland MS and McKinley for STEM? That is what I heard at many community mtgs. Has all that work gone out the window?
msproximity_comment: These are not real middle schools (they are ECs). DCPS had committed to changing these to standalone middle schools in Ward 5 (the new BMS and the new McKinley).
hslottery_comment: Since I would never consider Dunbar for my child, I like this. But people with guaranteed access to Wilson right now will not like it.
setasides_comment: They need to do this for non-discrimination reasons.

eschoicesets_comment: I believe this would weaken the DCPS system further than it already is.

boundaries_comment: This makes no sense why moving our line from Janney to Hearst alleviates crowding at Murch.  Why would you move a family two blocks from the school in which families walk to school and then get on the metro and force them to drive to a school outside of their neighborhood and then have them have to drive to their work.  There is no reasonable rationale for this.
feederpatterns_comment: Makes no sense at all.
msproximity_comment: Seriously how can this make sense as the closet school.  We will move to Maryland before we put our children in a school outside of our neighborhood.
hslottery_comment: This is just a gimmick to keep people from paying attention to redrawing the boarders. So instead of strength inc good schools and looking for ways to improve struggling schools we will destroy the whole system?

boundaries_comment: My family lives at 17th and D NE, yet we are currently zoned for Browne EC, which is much further than Maury ES and requires a dangerous walk across Benning Road. Maury ES is more connected to our neighborhood and would provide a safer and shorter commute to school for children in our area.
feederpatterns_comment: Maury and Eliot-Hine are much closer to our home than Browne EC.
eschoicesets_comment: This set of elementary schools is much better aligned with our neighborhood than Browne EC.

boundaries_comment: I would like to point out that all of the suggestions below appear to be an attempt to make parents of children at under-performing schools feel better because they may be able to send their children to better schools, even if it means spending tremendous time commuting.  However, these proposals are unfair to the children already in successful schools, as the suggestions appear to be that some or all of them should be moved to schools not as good as those they currently attend and plan to attend.  None of these proposals suggests any options to remedy the underlying problem in DCPS -- the overwhelming majority of the schools are not acceptable.  Rather than attempting to shift children around the city so some "disenfranchised" children are given the opportunity to attend better schools, at the expense of an equal number of other children who would be removed from successful programs, why not offer a plan to fix the failing schools?
feederpatterns_comment: We are currently zoned for Deal with an option for Hardy.  Forcing familes from Eaton to "select" Hardy despite its significantly lower ratings is unfair.  The schools that are failing should be fixed, rather than trying to force children from successful schools to unsuccessful schools.  If Hardy were a viable option, more parents from Eaton would historically have selected it, but because it has a bad track record, we do not choose to send our children there.  Of course, allowing our children to attend Wilson is excellent, as that was the pattern we selected when buying a house in our neighborhood.
eschoicesets_comment: Families need consistency and the ability to plan.  Advising us that our children will attend one of three schools is a non-starter and lacks any thought or reasoning.
mschoicesets_comment: Families need consistency and the ability to plan.  Advising us that our children will attend one of two schools is a non-starter and lacks any thought or reasoning.  Further, only one of these schools is as good as the school our children currently attend -- Eaton, meaning the change could send our children from a series of good schools to a good school followed by a marginal school.
msproximity_comment: Again, families need consistency and the ability to plan.  Advising us that our children will attend one of two schools does not allow for planning.
hslottery_comment: This is the worst proposal so far.  Not only does it eliminate the potential for planning, and add the possibility that a family could have children in school in entirely different neighborhoods making transport impossible, but there are currently no other viable high schools in the district.  Removing our current right to go to Wilson, a strong consideration when we bought our house, would force us to leave DCPS.  Removing Wilson is unacceptable unless the replacement school can be guarantreed to be as good, which it cannot.
setasides_comment: It is unfair that some children cannot get a good education through DCPS due to low quality schools.  While as a temporary solution, allowing these students to move to other schools seems reasonable, the real issue is the number of under-performing schools.  Any real fix must deal with these schools, not simply shift students to the few successful schools.

mschoicesets_comment: I would like the choice of othee public middle schools in the city. We need more specialty focused middle schools.
hslottery_comment: If you do get in the desired high schools through the lottery, where would my children go?
setasides_comment: what about kids that are not zoned for low performing school....can they get easy access to public school through set-asides

feederpatterns_comment: The policy example does not guarantee Wilson HS. It notes that if there is no room at Wilson, Hardy will feed into a new school, but does not give specifics on where that new school would be or if it would be funded. It would not be acceptable to go to any existing high school other than Wilson because that would put an award elementary school student into a failing high school. Plus, my address is closer to Wilson than half of the students who would be attending in this scenario.
eschoicesets_comment: This seems like a waste of resources just for pushing children around from one school to another without any tangible benefit.
hslottery_comment: This would ruin local elementary schools as parents cannot wait until 8th grade to figure out if public schools will work for them.

eschoicesets_comment: Bancroft is minimally acceptable, academically. Cooke and Reed are unacceptable.
msproximity_comment: These schools do not meet basic requirements for academic achievement, safety and diversity.
hslottery_comment: We'll be pleased to have access to Wilson and displeased if we do not.

address: 42XX MARTIN LUTHER KING JR AVENUE SW

boundaries_comment: I agree that no change should be made to my elementary school designation.
feederpatterns_comment: It is unacceptable to change a feeder pattern and route students to a lower quality/lower performing school than the one they are currently attending or are in a pattern to attend.  The proposed change is NOT equitable.  If DCPS is attempting to change the feeder/boundary pattern then it must be equitable for all students including those who are currently attending good schools.  You can look at the proficiency levels of Hardy and Deal and see a stunning difference.  If DCPS would like to route Eaton ES students elsewhere then a school of equal or better quality must be offered.
eschoicesets_comment: Simply put - choice sets create more instability in an already unstable system.
msproximity_comment: While Deal is a viable option, Oyster Adams is not.  If students from Eaton ES were sent to Oyster they would have significant challenges entering a Spanish bi-lingual school after only being exposed to Chinese language classes from K-5.  This plan simply would not work.
hslottery_comment: Again, this option would further destabilize an already fragile system.  One very important consideration in education is the time that it takes to get to and from school each day.  This can be a very limiting factor and a deterrent for many families.  Routing children all over the city is extremely inefficient.
setasides_comment:
This appears to be a half baked idea, not dissimilar to many of the ideas that have come out of this study.  What seems to be missing in all of the proposals is a solid plan to provide each neighborhood with a good school.  THAT is what this city really needs.  Children do not need to be routed all over the city to be educated.  DCPS cannot fix societal issues.  What DCPS can do is work to provide stable, good schools in each neighborhood.  You began with the question "How will this affect your family?"  My family will likely leave DCPS, as will many of our friends.  I do believe that DCPS could witness an overall decline in the number of invested families who are currently working hard to improve their neighborhood schools.  I personally volunteer at my children's school at least 10 hours a week and many weeks significantly more.  I will not hesitate to remove my children if they are rerouted to a lesser quality school and will take the energy and support that I currently invest in DCPS to the private sector.  That is how my family will be affected.  Has DCPS stopped to think about how it will be affected if they implement inequitable changes?  I would welcome a response.

Sincerely,
Melody Molinoff
m.a.molinoff@gmail.com

boundaries_comment:
Takoma Education Campus should end at 5th grade, and there should be a middle school for 6th to 8th.
Coolidge is an underenrolled, unsafe school and I would never send my children there.
feederpatterns_comment: A new middle school would be good.  Coolidge is no good.
eschoicesets_comment: Shepherd might be worth considering.  I hate the idea of choice sets for elementary as it destabilizes neighborhoods.
mschoicesets_comment: My children will never attend an "education campus" for middle school.   Close them all.
msproximity_comment: Close all education campuses and create real grade 6 to 8 middle schools.
hslottery_comment: Although Coolidge is terrible and my children will never attend, so we could benefit from a city wide lottery, I think this idea destabilizes an already fragile DCPS and should not go forward.
setasides_comment: Seems like a reasonable idea.  I think that to claim a set aside seat, the school should be low-performing and the family should be low income.

eschoicesets_comment: It depends on the charter school.

boundaries_comment: Geographically, Miner ES is not the closest school to our home, nor is it in the direction I need to travel to get to work after dropping my kids off at school.  Our kids are enrolled at Maury ES, which is, in fact, a little closer to our home, more convenient for work, and within the 6 years that we've had a child enrolled there, has blossomed into a school of choice for the neighborhood.
feederpatterns_comment: While there is certainly room for improvement for the middle and high school in our feeder pattern, we've seen a number of recent steps that suggest that both schools are on an upward trajectory.  Assuming that there are no big upsets in commitment to the IB programs or drastic changes in leadership, we expect both of these to be our default school choices as our students move up through the grade levels.
eschoicesets_comment: Again, the school closest to our home (Maury ES) is not listed in the Proposed Choice Set.  Within a one-block radius of our home, there are 7 other families sending their kids to Maury ES, which is the closest school to where we live.  Proximity to Maury has been a strong driver in our participation in school events and involvement in the PTA and other efforts to improve what we strongly feel is our neighborhood school.
mschoicesets_comment: Eliot Hine and Jefferson both share the feeder pattern into Eastern HS, but Stuart Hobson does not.  Should it?  I think it would strengthen Eastern's student pool to draw from Stuart Hobson, and geographically it seems to make sense as well.  That said, both Eliot Hine and Jefferson are currently IB Middle Years candidate schools; Stuart Hobson is not.  The Proposed Choice Sets need to have enough baseline similarities to deliver students who are equally prepared for the destination high school.  Would Stuart Hobson become an IB school as well?
msproximity_comment: The language "one of the two closest schools" is problematic - if this proposal is not based on the two closest schools, how are the two schools selected?  Why, for example, is Wheatley listed and not Stuart Hobson?  Looking at a map, both are nearly equidistant, but to get to Stuart Hobson, my student would merely walk 7.5 blocks in a straight shot along E Street NE, whereas to get to Wheatley, she'd have to walk 8.5 blocks and cross Maryland Avenue and Florida Avenue to get to the schoool.  Again, Eliot Hine (our current feeder school) is an IB candidate school but neither Wheatley nor Stuart Hobson is; I don't consider the two schools to be equivalent.
hslottery_comment: I think truncating the feeder pattern prior to high school is a move in the wrong direction - as it stands now, you know which is your neighborhood school so there has to be a conscious decision to OPT OUT of that school and enter the lottery.  Middle school enrollment is definitely affected by the feeder pattern into high school.  Right now, there is interest in our elementary school community in trying to get families to realistically consider our feeder middle school, which has plenty of room to grow in terms of becoming a stronger academic school.  Families who commit to the feeder pattern are, essentially, saying that they are investing in their neighborhood schools.  By imposing a mandatory high school lottery, students will scatter across the city - and family investment in neighborhood schools will suffer.  This proposal is essentially saying you have to OPT IN to attend your neighborhood school, which I think is more detrimental to the overall quality of the school system.
setasides_comment: At which school would my student get a "set aside" spot?  And how would sibling preference factor into things?  I find this policy problematic because it seems like the district is resigning itself to the fact that some schools are low-performing and supporting the diversion of students who might otherwise attend instead of trying to attract and retain students who might help build the school up.  If the ultimate goal of the school system is to try to bring every school up to a high standard of performance, this policy is misguided.  What happens to the 80-90% of the students at low-performing schools who aren't lucky enough to get a "set aside" spot?  If those students are from families with other options (willingness to enroll in charter or private schools, moving out of the area entirely), this could ultimately make it even harder for those low-performing schools to improve.  Public education to me means equal access to a quality education, not tiered options that ensure that only some lucky students get access to a "high-performing" school.  This option strikes me as neither viable nor taking a long-term view of the challenges of improving our public school system.

boundaries_comment: But, we would not go to West.  My children are currently enrolled at a higher performing DCPS elementary school in another part of the City.
feederpatterns_comment: The loss of our feeder pattern to Deal would be devastating to our family.  We would leave DC if this happens.
eschoicesets_comment: None of these schools are high performing enough yet.  Again, our family would leave DC before sending our kids to low performing schools.
mschoicesets_comment:
Deal:  Again, our family purchased our home b/c the address allows our children to feed to Deal.

New MS:  if a new middle school included a high quality curriculum (Int'l Bacc?), top quality teachers, innovative/visionary leadership and state-of-the art facilities, then we would consider going to that school instead of Deal.  But, we would need these assurances up front.
msproximity_comment: The City told us our address goes to Deal, we want Deal.
hslottery_comment:
Terrible idea and devastating to families, the local economy and the environment.

We need predictability.  
We need assurances that our 2nd and 3rd child will follow our first child.

It would be wholly irresponsible and dangerous to move children and families all over the City.  The loss of productivity will hurt our economy.  The increased traffic will hurt the environment.
setasides_comment: If the City is going to carve out seats and move kids across the City to those seats, why not select kids who qualify for a "Gifted and Talented" program and move them across the City.  If we are moving kids to a better school, let's allow all kids to move to a better school--even high performing kids and kids who are not in a low performing environment.

feederpatterns_comment: Those of us at Eaton right now should have the continued choice to go to Deal. Please don't take this away from us.
eschoicesets_comment: terrible idea. you would have uncertainty, traffic issues, and unhappy families.

boundaries_comment: We love Lafayette and are grateful to the community, families and D.C.P.S. for working together to make it such a great school.  This is why we purchased our home here 2 years ago.
feederpatterns_comment: We strongly advocate for this policy.  This feeder pattern is why we purchased our home here 2 years ago.
eschoicesets_comment: All three of these schools are of equal quality and the neighborhoods are safe, so from that perspective this policy is okay.  But I don't really see the upside for this neighborhood and I see plenty of downsides.  First, we walk to Lafayette or carpool with neighbors: these are the kind of special everyday things that really contribute to the quality of life in our neighborhood and make a sense of community.  It also helps us as a family meet all the obligations we have.  Most families in NW are 2-income family houses. Finding extra time to spend with our children every day is a huge priority.  I feel like this choice set idea would be pretty disruptive from a transportation, traffic and just personal inconvenience perspective.  What's the point?  Also: what about sibling preference?  Seems kind of like an overcorrection in our neighborhood.
mschoicesets_comment: I don't really see the upside of this approach for this neighborhood and I see plenty of downsides (transportation, unnecessary commute headaches). The reason I didn't put this in the "really hate it" category is because from a broader perspective I get why this would help Hardy.  I get it.
msproximity_comment: ThIs is the most offensive of all of the proposals to me.  We absolutely will not attend Brightwood.  It is a poorer quality school, the neighborhood is not as safe, the commute is not reasonable and we will absolutely not consider it.  We made a life-changing investment in our first home purchase to attend Lafayette, Deal and Wilson.  Please don't make fools out of us.  DC must be a good bet for young families.  Brightwood is off the table for us.
hslottery_comment: I am more open to this for high school than elementary or junior high, but I still think this is unreasonable and unfeasible.  A self-inflicted wound.
setasides_comment: I do not support mandatory setasides for elementary schools. I am supportive of mandatory setasides for Middle and high school.

boundaries_comment: The rest of Mt. Pleasant is zoned for Bancroft.  On Hobart, our kids are zoned for a school primarily attended by Adams Morgan families.  We'd love to attend and support what we consider our Mt. Pleasant community school.

feederpatterns_comment: Currently we can feed into deal which has more students at grade level proficiency than Hardy. There is no way my child is going to Hardy middle school

boundaries_comment: Rudolph has been closed for several years and we are currently zoned for Truesdell.
This is a terrible idea which ruins the integrity and walkability of our neighborhood. We live 2 blocks from Murch but a mile from Hearst. We will leave DC if this happens.
feederpatterns_comment: Hearst ES is not part of our neighborhood. We live 2 blocks from Murch. The rest of the feeder makes sense (Deal,Wilson).
eschoicesets_comment: This is also terrible in terms of neighborhood integrity and walkability. Furthermore, predictability is critical to attract and retain families in DC. We will leave DC if this happens.
mschoicesets_comment: This is also terrible in terms of neighborhood integrity and walkability. Furthermore, predictability is critical to attract and retain families in DC. We will leave DC if this happens.
msproximity_comment: This is also terrible in terms of neighborhood integrity and walkability. Furthermore, predictability is critical to attract and retain families in DC. We will leave DC if this happens.
hslottery_comment: This is also terrible in terms of neighborhood integrity and walkability. Furthermore, predictability is critical to attract and retain families in DC. We will leave DC if this happens.
setasides_comment: As long as neighborhood schools stay intact this might be ok.

boundaries_comment: I live on Hobart Street and we would love to send our son (2 years old) to Bancroft. Please, please adopt the changes!
feederpatterns_comment: I live on Hobart Street and we would love to send our son (2 years old) to Bancroft, Deal, and Wilson. Please, please adopt the changes!
msproximity_comment: We would like for our son to attend Deal Middle School.
hslottery_comment: We would like our son to attend Wilson High School.

setasides_comment: Don't make already crowded schools even more crowded just to add diversity!  Leave these schools as they are now.

boundaries_comment: It makes my commute to pick up and drop off my kids from school untenable - this is not a "neighborhood" option for our house.
feederpatterns_comment: WE currently are zoned for both Deal and Wilson which have much better academic success rates.  You're offering us a poorer choice of school.
eschoicesets_comment: Powell should be included in our choice set.

boundaries_comment: We are planning to send our preschooler to Burroughs EC and would it to be part of the proposed school boundary. Also I feel the proposed boundary lines should extend more to the east including the area between South Dakota and 18th street, north to Taylor Street crossing Michigan up to S. Dakota, and west only up to the railroad track and south until Rhode Island. These seem to be the neighborhoods most involved in Brookland interests via the events, listserve, and clubs. Therefore, it seems these would be where school boundaries naturally lie.
feederpatterns_comment: I would like more choices for better schools. I would also like the new middle school to be part of our proposed feeder pattern.
eschoicesets_comment: I'm not excited about the schools in my choice set at all, but I think this might be a good system with other more popular choice sets.
mschoicesets_comment: A purposeful and long term view of our middle schools is greatly desirable and needed.
msproximity_comment: I would like the new Brookland Middle school to be part of my choice set. Also, I am not satisfied with the two in my set.

boundaries_comment: The proposed, blue boundary makes REALLY GOOD SENSE for the way the neighborhoods and population centers exist in the Adams Morgan / Mt. Pleasant / Columbia Heights neighborhoods. The proposed, blue boundary allows true neighborhood schools to exist in a rational and fair manner. YES PLEASE to new, blue boundary proposals!
feederpatterns_comment: YES! The new, proposed feeder pattern is a fantastic new plan: please do implement the Bancroft / Deal / Wilson feeder plan !!
eschoicesets_comment: Mad scrambles for lottery places is insane: it divides communities and pushes families out of the District.
mschoicesets_comment: Choices lead to jockeying for the currently "favored" school - thereby creating a brain drain from one to the benefit of the other. Assigning schools is better, as proposed in Plan B.
msproximity_comment: No. Not at all interested in these two schools nor in being fed to them.
hslottery_comment: Again, forcing people to enroll their children based on lottery winnings is insane.
setasides_comment: Sounds like needless loophole.

boundaries_comment: This would allow me to stay in Mt. Pleasant, rather than contemplating a move out of the neighborhood I love and to a different part of the city or MD.  I have four kids and need free, quality options for school.
feederpatterns_comment: I like the predictability of knowing where my children will go to school all the way through.  This predictability is normal outside of DC (and in DC currently).

mschoicesets_comment: Why does my proposed choice set not include my zoned middle school?

feederpatterns_comment: These middle and high schools have a long way to go.
eschoicesets_comment: I'm torn. The reality is that everyone is going to try and get into Bancroft. On one hand, distributing students throughout the area would help those schools, how are the schools prepared for this? Likely to be wide range of abilities in each classroom. Teacher will need much support to handle.
mschoicesets_comment: It's needed.
msproximity_comment: Do not like these options. Would leave DC if this were our only choice.
hslottery_comment: Not everyone can afford to purchase or rent near a high-performing school. But, how feasible is it for students to trek across the city daily? You have to be a pretty motivated kid to make this happen. What about the kids who are not? Or parents without cars?
setasides_comment: I do not understand what "set-asides" are. What are they setting aside? Seats? For whom? This needs much more explanation than has been conveyed to parents.

mschoicesets_comment: Why is there 1 middle school in the choice set for this address and it isn't even the assigned middle school?

boundaries_comment: Payne is not a viable option for our children, who are several years above grade-level in upper elementary grades.  The program is not geared to serve the needs of most children in the surrounding neighborhood.
feederpatterns_comment: Again, those schools are not currently positioned to serve the needs of our family.  Virtually none of the above-grade-level children in the immediate neighborhood considers those schools a viable option.  Our children are instead at a charter and OOB at a DCPS middle school in Ward 3.
eschoicesets_comment: Including Payne in this choice set means that the families who have been working very hard to strengthen and support Maury and Peabody would have a good chance of being assigned instead to a school that is either weaker (Watkins) or not an option at all (Payne).  You destabilize the currently stable and improving options on the Hill without measurable benefit for the other schools.

feederpatterns_comment: Though we are out of boundary in a Ward 1 school, because of the disparate funding and opportunities available in the pk-8th grade schools in DCPS (which keep all of the kids in these programs from even applying to schools like Schools Without Walls or Banneker) we would definitely not send out child there.  And Dunbar is horrible, and has a recent track record of trying to push out "bad" kids without trying to engage them while similarly not serving "good" kids at a level that prepares them for college or work beyond graduation - a volatile and unsustainable combination.  Teir graduation rate when looking at the size of the 9th grade class v. who graduates in 12th is abysmal. We would not send our child to that school.
eschoicesets_comment: Not a bad choice set, but not really sustainable as some of those schools cross over Rhode Island Ave.  Currently, both Noyes and Burroughs are available to our kids, both schools are walkable and Burroughs has a bus line that runs close so that our kids could easily get to the schools and get home from them.  However, there is no good way to get to Langdon or Langley from our house without crossing major intersections - not ideal.
mschoicesets_comment: Again, the pre-k through 8th model is a terrible model for kids as currently structured and funded.  These schools do not have the funding for language, science and arts in the same way that dedicated middle schools do, so they enter high school behind their peers (and it's my understanding that they are not able to gain admission to some of the best high schools in DC simply because they were not provided the opportunity to have the classes required).
msproximity_comment: Again, the pre-k through 8th model is a terrible model for kids as currently structured and funded.  These schools do not have the funding for language, science and arts in the same way that dedicated middle schools do, so they enter high school behind their peers (and it's my understanding that they are not able to gain admission to some of the best high schools in DC simply because they were not provided the opportunity to have the classes required).
hslottery_comment: Dunbar is terrrible and we wouldn't send our child there.  However, having a lottery like this without preferences makes it difficult to invest in a close-in school, adds to travel time for kids (which takes away from homework and extracurricular time) and does not appear to be sustainable for the less popular neighborhood schools (like Dunbar, unfortunately).
setasides_comment: Though we take advantage of the out of boundary lottery, I do recognize that the brain drain on struggling schools is significant.  So it feels hypocritical, but I am worried about stripping the cream of the crop within DCPS (though at some level, the charters are already doing this, so perhaps that is not a citywide priority).

boundaries_comment: Not sure why it makes more sense to reduce the boundary that is closest to the school rather than the northern boundary, which is much farther away.

feederpatterns_comment: Hobart is in Mount Pleasant, not Adams Morgan.  Assigning it to Bancroft will shorten school commutes and keep our neighborhood intact.
setasides_comment: The system is already complicated enough.  If kids are not allowed to attend in-boundary schools in their neighborhood, young families will continue to flee to the burbs and to private schools.  DC schools will never fare well without a core of students from middle class families committed to their neighborhood through home ownership and civic involvement.  The wrong policies will create a DC bereft of a middle class, with a disengaged elite in private schools and failing schools for everyone else.

boundaries_comment: What is the plan for Van Ness? This is the only school within walking distance to our home, and the only one the possibility of being an option.
feederpatterns_comment: Feeding kids from one failing school to another, there is no way we'll be part of this pattern.
eschoicesets_comment: Depends what the "New School" is.
msproximity_comment: There is no way either of these schools are an option.
