hslottery_comment: We live in Navy Yard, and there is pretty much no way we would send our son to any of the schools in our area.
setasides_comment: This is too much of a risk.  We are planning to leave the District.

boundaries_comment: I would like my kids to attend a dual-language Spanish/English school, in that respect I would like to have them go to Powell. However, I understand that Barnard does have a Spanish program, if not as robust.
feederpatterns_comment: Roosevelt is much closer to my home and I hope that my kids can attend high school there once it is fully modernized. Currently, the facilities are in terrible shape and that is needs to be addressed for the current student body. I assume the middle schools will be MacFarland again once Roosevelt's modernization is complete - which I like.
eschoicesets_comment: Why wouldn't Powell be in that set? Or Parkview? It seems like you'd try to make the choice sets offer diversity in focus and programming not just location. Also, I am opposed to choice sets and believe in neighborhood schools.
msproximity_comment: I want guaranteed access
hslottery_comment: I'm happy with roosevelt, but am not happy with a citywide lottery. I want a neighborhood school by right.
setasides_comment: I'm not sure I understand the definition exactly, but what I think I understand is that there will remain possible for out-of-boundary kids to attend high performing schools, but that the out of boundary seats will be limited to 10 - 20% of the in-boundary school population. That seems reasonable to me under a system of neighborhood schools, however it would be useful to know what the current % of out of boundary seats there are at higher performing DCPS schools. This would help inform my opinion.
I don't understand the part that says "the high school you would or would not have access to is Wilson"

feederpatterns_comment: The schools in these boundaries still perform so poorly that this is a reason to play lottery or move.  A city-wide lottery or other ways to get our kids acceptable public schooling would convince us to stay in the city, where we would like to stay.
eschoicesets_comment: None of these schools performs at an acceptable level yet.
mschoicesets_comment: hard to comment at this level of abstraction
msproximity_comment: neither school performs at an acceptable level at this stage
hslottery_comment: lottery would definintely be better than the status quo and would help overcome some of the challenges of the up and coming schools in other neighborhoods that the existing feeding patterns hold.

boundaries_comment: I'm on the PTA at Powell. We are putting our blood sweat and tears into that school and I would like my younger children to be able to go there. I don't understand how moving the southern Powell border accomplishes anything.
feederpatterns_comment: Why on earth would I be happy about getting zoned to a worse elementary school, middle school AND high school? There is nothing good about this. What's the basis for it?
eschoicesets_comment: These schools are not anywhere near as good as the elementary schools north of us -- Barnard, West, etc. Some of those should be in our choice set I would think.
mschoicesets_comment: I AM hoping there will be a new middle school created. Hopefully a bilingual one that can take advantage of the success Powell is having.
msproximity_comment: Neither of these schools is very good.
hslottery_comment: It just seems like we're all going to be driving in a thousand different directions every morning
setasides_comment: I'd rather have a good neighborhood school than a set aside.

eschoicesets_comment: Oyster Adams Bilingual School is a much closer elementary school than Bancroft or Marie Reed.

feederpatterns_comment: Dunbar is a terrible boundary for Brookland.

boundaries_comment: School will gain more students as people buy in-bounds specifically for Maury.  Result will be overcrowding.
eschoicesets_comment: Some of these schools are too far away.

boundaries_comment: Harvard Street seems the natural boundary and would put us in the same boundary as the rest of Mt Pleasant.
feederpatterns_comment: Fixed feeder patterns create student cohorts which are as important as academics to a students success.  It also encourages programmatic links between primary and secondary schools and parental investment in schools.  Choice sets are disruptive to families and neighborhoods.
eschoicesets_comment: Choice sets are disruptive to families and neighborhoods and weaken links between kids, schools and neighborhoods.  Choices include two low-performing schools and one mid-performing bi-lingual school.  Assigned schools should be comprehensive and not specialized.
mschoicesets_comment: Choice sets are disruptive to families and neighborhoods and weaken links between kids, schools and neighborhoods.
msproximity_comment: Choice sets are disruptive to families and neighborhoods and weaken links between kids, schools and neighborhoods.
hslottery_comment: Lotteries turn education into a gamble and a game that you win or lose.  Not a good message for our children.

boundaries_comment: Not impressed with WEST and will not be sending our children there unless major changes occur but our zoning has not changed. We participated in various lotteries (common public/charter and individual charter) and applied to private schools.
feederpatterns_comment: We knew we would have to make alternate arrangements for elementary school but strongly oppose the end to cross-park rights to DEAL and Wilson High School. We bought in Crestwood with a young family due to that situation. Otherwise we likely would have bought in a different area of DC or very likely in Virginia. The new proposed schools do not match up to our existing in boundary schools of Deal and Wilson. It affects education options AND property values. Stances on these issues will affect our voting results. Also, it devalues the charter school options as they do not "feed" into Deal and Wilson. We were happy to send our children to charter elementary schools with the expectation of our traditional access to Deal for middle and Wilson for High school. Now all of our preparations/work need to be adjusted for our children's education.
eschoicesets_comment: Options for local schools allow parents to make better choices for their children. Many of Crestwood families, however, have established roots at Powell and now are being zoned out of Powell.  Would really like to see Powell as one of the choices for Crestwood.
mschoicesets_comment: Not equal to DEAL. If we are rezoned we do not want to be downgraded in education options for children. It is a major reason people buy homes pay the high level of taxes we pay in our area.
msproximity_comment: Choice is better than no choice but still a major downgrade for us
hslottery_comment: Downgrade from Wilson. Maybe an option for children to "test in" like at School Without Walls. We wanted our children to be zoned for Wilson, which again has traditionally been the zoning for Crestwood.
setasides_comment: I think it's nice to have some options for students assinged to low performing schools but many families pay the prices and taxes they do for the access to the schools they thought we were zoned for, which is now changing.

boundaries_comment: Although my child would remain in boundary at Janney, I feel it is unfair to the families of children who would be forced to change schools with the new boundary assignment given that many of these families chose the location of their home based on their neighborhood school.
feederpatterns_comment: I think current feeder patterns should remain the same
eschoicesets_comment: I feel strongly that student should be guaranteed admittance to their neighborhood school
mschoicesets_comment: I feel strongly that student should be guaranteed admittance to their neighborhood school
msproximity_comment: I feel students should be guaranteed admittance to their closest neighborhood school
hslottery_comment: I feel strongly that students should be guaranteed admittance to their closest neighborhood high school
setasides_comment: The focus should be on how to improve ALL schools so that this would not be necessary.  I think it would be nice to set aside seats for students assigned to low-performing schools, but that is very unfair to the 80% of students who would not be moved to a high performing school.  Again...improve ALL schools so ALL children can attend a successful school.

boundaries_comment: I'm concerned about the level of education that will be provided at Payne.
eschoicesets_comment: Maybe this will help some underperforming schools to have a community of children and parents that want to have the best neighborhood school possible.

boundaries_comment: Sorry for the families who will be zoned out of Janney against their will.
feederpatterns_comment: No change is the best for our family personally.
eschoicesets_comment: Walking to school is a major draw for us. Living in neighborhood with school friends is what we dream of for our preschooler.
mschoicesets_comment: Deal is better than Hardy. Why would I like a plan that jeopardizes my child's ability to WALK to the BETTER school?
msproximity_comment: How could my child suddenly join a bilingual program in middle school?? That's absurd. And again, our preference is for walking to Deal and going there with her neighborhood friends.
hslottery_comment: That would create a hot mess. Everybody commuting, no predictability, no neighborhood cohesion. This is such a terrible idea I have a hard time taking it seriously.
setasides_comment: I don't have a dog in that fight. But it's hard to weigh the benefit to those individuals against the risk of siphoning off good students and jeopardizing community cohesion.

feederpatterns_comment: Keep Deal as option for Eaton. We are much closer to Deal, and it's a better school.

boundaries_comment: They go to OOB school now and the change will make no difference.  They are both under performing schools that need more attention before they are considered viable options.
eschoicesets_comment: I like the current OOB lottery process better.  I would not consider any of the schools in the choice set and would make me consider moving out of DC if those were the only options.
mschoicesets_comment: I would move first before sending my kids there.  We need more options in Ward 4.  Reopen McFarland.

boundaries_comment: Makes sense to make the Bancroft boundary match the neighborhood boundary.
feederpatterns_comment:
This proposal doesn't make sense. Bancroft currently feeds into both CHEC and Deal/Wilson.
But I am very concerned that we will lose access to Deal, so I like this proposed feeder pattern.
eschoicesets_comment: I want to keep the current setup where kids in our neighborhood have one elementary choice, Bancroft.
mschoicesets_comment: This is a good choice set, but since Bancroft is a dual language school, its graduates should also have Oyster Adams Middle School as a choice.
msproximity_comment: Please keep us in the Deal boundary!
hslottery_comment: Lottery only high schools are a bad idea.

boundaries_comment: Our neighborhood is Mt Pleasant, and I would like for my kids to be able to attend school with other kids from the neighborhood.
feederpatterns_comment: I would like to be in the Bancroft/ Deal/ Wilson group.
eschoicesets_comment: Bancroft, please.
mschoicesets_comment: Deal, please.
msproximity_comment: Deal, please.
hslottery_comment: I want predictability.

feederpatterns_comment: Neither HS is desirable, but Dunbar is still a disaster and I would move before I sent my kids there. Look at those depressing  attendance and graduation rates!
hslottery_comment: As I said, I will move out of DC before I send my kids to Dunbar. It might improve in the future, but I have 3 MS students and there's no way you can turn Dunbar around in my timeframe.

This is an outrageous proposal that would lower property values in our neighborhood and the decrease the quality of education at Wilson. I chose to buy my house based on the school guarantees. Without those guarantees our family would definitely move across the border to Bethesda to the Whitman school district.
setasides_comment: Quotas are fine to correct historical discrimination. However, in this instance, low performing students have not been discriminated against due to race, gender or sexual orientation, so set asides are inappropriate here.

boundaries_comment: This is a no-brainer. Hobart Street & the south side of Irving are and have always been part of the Mt. P community. The only reason that these family homes do not feed into Bancroft can only be zip code laziness, a decision that has been lost in time.  This should be fixed and the community should be preserved.
feederpatterns_comment: It makes sense to keep the community and children together. Hobart & the south of Irving should be part of the Bancroft feeder. Keep communities, families and friends together. It is why we live in the neighborhood.
eschoicesets_comment: The idea of a choice set is interesting. If this were connected to community based weights, then there may be something there.  The overriding concern, however, is that this disregards the reason one move into a neighborhood and chooses to invest in DC.
mschoicesets_comment: Same as above. The concern is that the instability would undermine a reason to stay in DC.  At some point, people with resources say "F*$% it"  I'm moving to MD or Va.  THAT would be the WORST result and one that this may likely produce.
msproximity_comment: Choice sets can be disruptive to families and neighborhoods.
hslottery_comment: The politics seem impossible. Why would I stay in the city if there was no sense of stability for my children and their friends. If there were many good schools, then maybe - but that is not the case. How about recruiting and paying our teachers better than anyone in the nation. Double down on IMPACT and be the envy of a new generation of teachers.
setasides_comment: Economic integration is what we are getting at.  This makes some sense.

boundaries_comment: I like the school that I am in.  There are 2 other schools that are closer to me that I could walk to.
feederpatterns_comment: I prefer the feeder system as opposed to the lottery system for predictability.
eschoicesets_comment: I can only walk to one of these schools.  I live in dc for an urban experience. I do not want to have to drive my children to school
mschoicesets_comment: I live 4 blocks from deal and 3 miles from hardy.   I live in the city to have an urban life.  Driving to school is not something I choose to do.  We walk to school every single day, it is probably the biggest reason that I am an engaged parent. I talk to the other parents, my kids teacher, my kids friends.  I am engaged because I am living 5 blocks from the school.  I work full time but if I can volunteer for something I do because I can get to the school in less than 5 minutes.
msproximity_comment: Oyster is too far.  I live near deal.
hslottery_comment: This is ridiculous.  I do not understand how this will enrich schools.

mschoicesets_comment: silly to go past deal to get to hardy
hslottery_comment: Beauty of AU Park is local schools.  Do not want to take my child across town in rush hour.
setasides_comment: Janney is already overcrowded.

boundaries_comment: We live next to Adams Middle School and have always been upset that our son couldn't go there for middle school.  This way he would be able to attend the closest middle school.
Rather go to SWS
feederpatterns_comment: Better than the current one which makes no sense
eschoicesets_comment: Would love to go to SWS
mschoicesets_comment: They still need to improve

feederpatterns_comment: We purchased our home based on the Deal/Wilson feeder pattern. This proposed rezoning abuses the trust we placed in the City when we opted to move to DC.
Although preserving the status quo is good for me personally, I don't understand how this proposal addresses overcrowding at Deal and Wilson.
eschoicesets_comment: While I would only have logistical problems with sending my children to Janney or Murch (as opposed to concerns about the quality of the schools), it's not clear how this choice set would benefit any students, families or schools. The downsides would be considerable - inability to carpool & share childcare with neighbors, inability for neighbors to walk or bike to school together, and decreased cohesiveness within neighborhoods.
mschoicesets_comment: It would take a middle schooler approximately one hour on two buses to reach Hardy Middle School from my home via public transportation.
msproximity_comment: Is "closest" middle school being measured as the crow flies or with any reference to driving distance, let alone travel via public transportation? Deal Middle School is a 2.7 mile drive from my home while Brightwood EC is a 3 mile drive and Takoma EC is a 3.9 mile drive (or a 2.5 mile walk through Rock Creek Park).  A bus ride from my home to either Brightwood or Takoma involves two transfers and takes at least an hour, while a bus ride to Deal takes 28 minutes on a single bus.
hslottery_comment: I am honestly not sure that I will send my children to a DCPS high school in any event, so I am not one of those people who bought my home with the expectation of sending my kids to Wilson, etc., but this proposal greatly concerns me because the utter lack of predictability around high school placement seems likely to drive many people away from DCPS at the high school level.
setasides_comment: I support the idea of out-of-boundary seats being set aside for students assigned to low-performing schools. I am concerned about how a specific quota (10-20%) would impact overcrowding at high-performing schools, assuming in-boundary families retain a right to attend their neighborhood elementary schools and feeders, and I do not understand how overcrowding is addressed by this proposal.

boundaries_comment: We're two blocks from Powell, a school (allegedly) on the move. West is much further away, and doesn't benefit from the active, committed core of pre-S/K parents trying to turn Powell around.
feederpatterns_comment: None of these middle or high school options are remotely acceptable, which is why we'll be taking our $300k annual income -- and hefty DC taxes -- to the suburbs when the time comes. Wish we didn't have to!
eschoicesets_comment: Not in this lifetime

feederpatterns_comment: Currently Hardy is not the same quality as Mann and Wilson causing most in our area to move to charters or private schools after elementary.  Please ensure boundary realignment favors improving local use of Hardy
eschoicesets_comment: This would make it so more kids would have to be driven to school.  Traffic is already a mess at the schools even with any walking.
mschoicesets_comment: Of course access to Deal is better than only having Hardy as a choice, however fixing Hardy is the solution rather than jumbling up who goes where
msproximity_comment: This would be ok but should not be necessary
hslottery_comment: Crazy idea.  This is a big city with a lot of traffic.  This approach guarantees that people would have to move if they didn't get into close school or have long commutes.  Terrible choice given the limited options for high schools. Fix the High Schools that are failing and keep people in the closest school.  This approach perpetuates the issue of failing schools by not addressing it and trying to appease the parents in those areas while penalizing those in the areas where schools are ok.  Nobody wins
setasides_comment: This is a much more reasonable approach, however charter schools help address this issue already.  Fix the low performing schools as the best option

boundaries_comment: Murch overcrowding can be relieved by a long overdue modernization and if that doesn't completely solve the problem, it would make far more sense to shift the northern boundaries which are much further away from Murch into Lafayette, which is projected to have a decline in their elementary school age children over the next few years.
eschoicesets_comment: Murch and Janney are both 4 blocks from our home, but all of the proposed choice sets are significantly further away.  Additionally, would want to know how the choice sets would impact our middle school and HS feeder pattern.
msproximity_comment: We need certainty in our middle school.
hslottery_comment: This is a terrible idea which would significantly disrupt every DCPS family and will completely disincentivize families from actively working to improve their local schools.

eschoicesets_comment: We are a one car family. If we could not get Janney (our current school), Murch would be an doable, but less desirable, option (with some difficulty),  but Lafayette would not as we need school to be near a Metro.
mschoicesets_comment: We would prefer our child walk to school, but taking a bus to Hardy might be an option, especially if DCPS provides a bus from the Metro that is not used by public (based on my own experience, I think the current Metro buses on this route are crowded and sometimes unreliable).
hslottery_comment: I think this will be a logistical and traffic nightmare.

eschoicesets_comment: We purchased our home in area specifically so that our child would have the in bound right to attend Janney.
mschoicesets_comment: We purchased our home specifically for the right for our child to attend Janney, Deal and Wilson HS.
msproximity_comment: We purchased our home with great attention to the school boundaries and the in place feeder system. The purchase price of our home and current property value reflect that. DC enjoys the high taxes from our property values--at sale and in annual real estate tax payments. There has been a significant amount of neighborhood investment--parent contributions and involvement--that have made the schools in our pyramid what they are today. We would be very disappointed to have that pattern change. The answer to underperforming schools in other areas of the District is a deeper outreach and investment for early childhood and families at risk--essentially from birth, to help with adequate, safe child care, support and education for mothers and fathers, AND  greater investment in PS-3 and PK-4. There is no use more important for the City's budget surplus.
hslottery_comment: A city wide lottery for high school would encourage more middle class families to move to the suburbs, or to re-consider private schools. Improving elementary schools with neighborhood and family commitment is a first step that will ideally eventually lead to improved middle and high school with an engaged parent and neighbor community. However, based on scores today, and the underlying reasons for our home purchase in the Wilson district, we would be very unhappy with a Citywide lottery for high school.
setasides_comment: I am not opposed to set asides for OOB students, so long as in bound students are guaranteed spaces.

boundaries_comment: It's pretty simple. People buy houses in neighborhoods with good schools. Schools that have bad education have low capacity so people look elsewhere. I should not have to pay the price in a. Home value. B. my child's education because the city can't fix the education at that school in another boundary. Focus on the teachers, the parent involvement and then people will flock to that school and the neighborhood. It's like the city has lost it's screws.

eschoicesets_comment: I'd prefer Tubman to either HD Cooke or Marie Reed. Those are too far to be practical for us. But overall, I dislike the choice sets model.
hslottery_comment: Citywide lottery is an awful idea. The uncertainty. The commute. There's nothing good about it.

boundaries_comment: I am happy with my neighborhood school -- even though it is a struggling school (one of the lowest 40 in the city. Even though my children are not yet school-age, they and I spend a lot of time at the school and know it well. I am glad to read that when Van Ness opens it will assume part of the original Bowen boundary. This is as it should be, because assigning the students from the original Bowen boundary all to Amidon would result in two segregated schools -- with Amidon as the poor, black school, and Van Ness as the white, middle-class school. Therefore, I think it is ESSENTIAL, for the success of both schools that their boundaries share the areas that are made up primarily of public housing so that neither school faces the challenge of educating an overwhelmingly disadvantaged population, so that the resulting boundaries are as inclusive and diverse as possible.
feederpatterns_comment: This proposed feeder pattern would eliminate my kids' right to attend Wilson High. My objection is as much to that fact as it is to the broader problem I have with assgned high schools. I believe that there should be a city-wide lottery for high schools.
eschoicesets_comment: I would prefer to have the predictability that goes along with having a single assigned elementary school. I don't have children currently enrolled at Amidon (they're still too young), but I'm devoting much of my time to helping the school, and I believe it is important for people to have a commitment mechanism to their neighborhood schools.
mschoicesets_comment: Once again, I believe that elementary and middle schools should be assigned and neighborhood-based.
msproximity_comment: THIS MAP IS AMAZING!
hslottery_comment: I would be strongly in favor of a citywide lottery for high school.  Barring that, I would want to retain my children's current access to Wilson (not Eastern).
setasides_comment: I think this is an intelligent approach, though I probably would not avail myself of it (even though I assume Amidon would fall into the category of a low-performing school no matter what rubric they decide to use). I prefer to have my child at a school where I know the teachers, staff, and parents, and where my kids will be safe. I know that this is not how everyone thinks, though, and I respect the right of students who otherwise would have to attend failing schools to be given priority seats in a better performing school. I think this also creates more of a commitment mechanism for people whose schools may be "borderline" -- just the kind of investment that is needed for these schools to turn the corner.

boundaries_comment: Happy for my location, but worried about increased traffic on already-crowded streets around here with those cut out of the current boundary suddenly forced into driving to Hearst.  If DCPS wants to do this, they need to get school buses to transport the children newly-assigned to a school that is no longer in walking distance.  Schools are part of a community, and traffic is already a problem in this community, not to mention for the entire planet (see: warming, global).
feederpatterns_comment: Good but how does this deal with overcrowding at these schools?  Furthermore, what about those who are stuck in a feeder pattern that feeds to a subpar school?  All children in the district deserve quality neighborhood schools.  What are your plans to improve schools all over the city, and make neighborhood schools more attractive for everybody?
eschoicesets_comment: This is a ridiculous proposal for Ward 3 elementary schools; they are all equal in terms of quality.  This would only cause undue confusion, logistical difficulty, and a disruption to community relationships that are determined by neighborhood.  Not to mention creating more traffic on already-crowded city streets during rush hour.
mschoicesets_comment: It would be ridiculous to commute to Hardy when I can see Deal from my house.  A waste of time and energy, as well as worsening traffic.  Also, a death knell for the neighborhood character of Deal that is an important factor in its continuing improvement.  I would leave DCPS in that case.
msproximity_comment: This is better than the proposed choice sets because Oyster is a better school, but the problems remain.  Difficulty in commuting, worsening traffic.  Also, not sure that Spanish immersion is right for my children.
hslottery_comment: Where to begin on the absolutely unacceptable nature of this proposal?  So poorly thought out, so purely ideological --  frankly, it's insulting to comment on it at all.  Not an option for my family AT ALL.  Will leave DCPS and most likely the District itself if this passes.
setasides_comment: I think that set-asides are valuable for children in failing schools and for bringing diversity to other parts of the city.  But it isn't fair to displace IB children to do so.  DCPS either needs to build another school in NW to execute this, or plan their renovations of current schools appropriately.  More significant however, is that this plan does not address the children left behind in failing or mediocre schools.  DCPS needs to address why those schools are in dire straits and intervene in a targeted manner to improve neighborhood schools for all.

boundaries_comment: We purchased our home 2 years ago based on the reputation of the neighborhood PUBLIC school. To take such a right away would upset our family. While our daughter isn't even eligible for the PK3 lottery until next year, we are already connected with the local school community.
feederpatterns_comment: Francis-Stevens is a diverse, progressive school moving in a positive direction. We want a rigorous middle school curriculum for our daughter such as IB or Pre-AP. Francis-Stevens is doing just that, which will elevate the caliber of education at the middle school level.
eschoicesets_comment: I understand that Hyde-Addison and Ross are seeing an increasing number of in-boundary students. If this is true, we may end up at Francis-Stevens because both schools have limited capacity. We live 2 blocks from Ross ES.  It would seem that proximity to the publicly run elementary school district should be the deciding factor as to whom gets what placement. Both Hyde-Addison amd Francis-Stevens would be acceptable choices to our family.
mschoicesets_comment: I see the opportunity for a new middle school as positive for the students in Neighborhood Cluster 6. The parents from the feeder schools should tell DCPS the type of curriculum they wish to see at the school and DCPS should work with the families to help create a vibrant middle school option that has Honors classes/tracks for high-performing students who may not get into a special focus school.
msproximity_comment: The discrepancy between these two options is HUGE. We would move if our daughter were assigned Cardozo. francis-Stevens would enable our daughter a good shot at getting into application-only high school, notably SWW.
hslottery_comment: A city-wide lottery is a BAD idea. I think DCPS needs  to invest in application-only special focus schools in each ward of the city as well as make certain there are is a regional public high school that has an honors-focused track (IB or AP) so that families would have an automatic, rigorous high school option by right as well as one or two special focus, application-only schools to choose from if their child has a particular talent. Such opportunities would retain middle to upper middle class families in the DCPS system.
setasides_comment: My concern with set- asides at the high school level is

boundaries_comment: We strongly believe elementary kids should live within walking distance of a school.
feederpatterns_comment: Ideally, we will live within walking distance or easy commuting distance of all schools.
eschoicesets_comment: Elementary students must live within walking distance of their school.
mschoicesets_comment: Strongly prefer to live within walking or easy commuting distance to school.
msproximity_comment: Strongly prefer to live within walking or easy commuting distance.

boundaries_comment: Would like to be re zoned for Peabody or SWS because they are better and closer.
feederpatterns_comment: Right now there does not exist a non test in DCPS high school I would even think of sending my kids to.
eschoicesets_comment: These choice sets would improve my life if they did not restrict access to Logan and SWS based on income, which I would expect DCPS would eventually do to try to avoid the inevitable flip in these schools as the neighborhood gentrified.
mschoicesets_comment: Stuart Hobson is directly across the street. I would be horrified to have to travel to a much worse school across the city. The mere mention of this idea is making me plan to take a spot at a DCI feeder.
msproximity_comment: No way.
hslottery_comment: This would mean absolutely no hope the middle class families would ever commit to eastern.
setasides_comment: So easy to game this. Very bad idea.
I prefer the city wide lottery proposal over the set-aside proposal for high school.

boundaries_comment: My family lives a block away from Van Ness Elementary School.  We should have the right to attend Van Ness Elementary School when it reopens in 2015.  Also, we are physically located closer to Brent Elementary School than we are to Amidon-Bowen Elementary school, so I see no reason why we should be assigned to Amidon-Bowen Elementary School.
feederpatterns_comment: We live a block away from Van Ness Elementary School.  There needs to be a proposed feeder pattern for Van Ness Elementary School
eschoicesets_comment: We live a block away from Van Ness Elementary School, so that should be included as one of our choice sets.  Also, we are physically located much closer to Brent Elementary School than we are to Amidon-Bowen Elementary School, so I believe that Brent Elementary School should be one of our choice sets.
mschoicesets_comment: We live in Ward 6, and these are the 3 Ward 6 Middle Schools, so I agree with the schools in this Choice Set
msproximity_comment: We would only send our child to Kramer Middle School if the demographics of the school changed drastically.  We will not send our child to a school with a very high FARM rate.
hslottery_comment: If we're residing in the District of Columbia when our child entering high school, we most likely will have our child at one of the test in public high schools (Banneker, Walls, etc) or have a our child attend a private school
setasides_comment: I think that low performing schools are the result of families not putting an emphasis on education.  Setting aside seats in "good" schools for students assigned to "bad" schools will only worsen the situation of the "bad" schools, since it will make people clamor to get into the "good" schools.  I think if more families made education a priority in their household across the city, you'd see successful public schools across every ward.

boundaries_comment: We live 3 blocks from Murch, our current in-boundary school. Hearst is the 3rd closest school to our house. Many days, I do not drive my car at all. If we were moved to Hearst, I would have to drive my child to school. Also, as much as Hearst is an up-and-coming schools, it is not a neighborhood school in the way that Murch is. More than half of its students come from outside the boundary. We moved to this neighborhood so that our children could attend their neighborhood school and have friends right in the neighborhood. Because many parents walk their children to Murch, the sense of community at Murch is strong.
feederpatterns_comment: I have a student at Wilson and one at Deal as well. These schools have improved dramatically in recent years as more neighborhood families have chosen to invest their time, energy -- and children's futures -- in these schools.
eschoicesets_comment: These schools are far from our home. Oyster appears in 2 choice sets in the proposal, meaning it is highly unlikely that children will be offered a slot there -- especially when you take into account the fact that Oyster maintains a 50% balance of native-speaking children.
mschoicesets_comment: Our neighborhood school is three blocks from our home. Our children walk there. It already offers 3 languages and an IB curriculum. I do not need any other choice than that.
hslottery_comment: This proposal would be the end of Wilson High School. We would likely move to Maryland if this were implemented.
setasides_comment: Allowing out-of-boundary students to have access to high-performing schools is a good goal. It also improves diversity at schools. In practice, this proposal may be unworkable because the current schools are already over-crowded. A better solution would be to double down on trying to improve lower performing schools, perhaps with a focus on schools that have begun to improve with the result that there are more options for parents who want an alternative to the low-performing schools.

hslottery_comment: It is terrible to think about having to commute the distances that would be required from the Palisades neighborhood (the corner closest to VA & MD borders) to attend any of the other high schools in the city beyond Wilson.

msproximity_comment: We would like to remain in the Deal boundary.
hslottery_comment: We would like to remain with Wilson. Clearly, if high schools and middle schools are only done geographically, there will be massive segregation by socio-economics, with little diversity. Also, I know all about "lotteries."  One of my neighbors got her kids into Horace Mann, out of boundary, by schmoozing/petitioning the principal...no lottery required. So it's chance for most people, and exceptions for those with connections.
setasides_comment: I don't understand. Where would we be getting a seat??

feederpatterns_comment: Having a neighborhood-based feeder pattern is critical for home-owners.  While all of our Mt. Pleasant neighbors go to Bancroft, it has been difficult to be the lone Mt. Pleasant St. going to HD Cooke.  Not helping matters is the current reading and math proficiency scores at HD Cooke.
eschoicesets_comment: Having no predictability in elementary schools would make us seriously consider leaving DC.  Virtually every neighbor we know feels the same way.  People all across the country make real estate decisions based on schools.  I know that there are a few cities in the US that use choice sets but we made our decision to purchase based on an improving public school system with known feeder patterns.  This option is seriously concerning to us.
mschoicesets_comment: Similar to our previous comment, we do not like the lack of predictability.  We are an out-of-bounds family in a school that we love (Hearst) that feeds into a middle school we really wanted to attend (Deal).  Once we got into Hearst we invested significantly in our home as we believed we were set with our daughter's schools.  My rating here is not based on Hardy vs Deal, per se, it is based on the lack of predictability.  We would consider moving out of the city if the middle school choice set was implemented.  Again, we are not alone in this position.  I think the implication of this choice set approach would send families fleeing to the nearby suburbs with their very good middle and high schools (again, known and predictable).
msproximity_comment: This is by far the worse option in our opinion.  It would undoubtedly result in our leaving the city.  Not only does this option have no predictability, the performance of these schools is notably below the schools in the other alternatives.  We're not willing to send our daughter to these schools.  Again, an opinion shared by many that would result in a flight of families out of the city.  Parents and families want predictability and want to raise their kids in the city.
hslottery_comment: Again, predictability is critical.  We want to stay in the city and want to send our daughter to Wilson.

eschoicesets_comment: this may actually be a headache and hard to navigate.  The reality is that there would be a lottery and that there would therefore be two lotteries to be a part of, both in boundary and out of boundary.
mschoicesets_comment: I think it should be more based on where you went to elementary school, in order to keep kids together throughout their school experiences.
msproximity_comment: just because a school is "close" does not mean that it is easy to get to.
hslottery_comment: may be a good idea
setasides_comment: I do not understand what is being set aside - needs to be more fully fleshed out before I would vote on it.

boundaries_comment: Murch is 2 block's walking distance from our house, we'd need to drive the 12 blocks to Hearst. This change makes us worse off than we were before, and contributes to more cars and traffic on the road. I thought a public policy intervention was supposed to make each of us better off? I don't see how this policy is improving in our family's welfare. Also, why is Hearst struggling to attract enough in-bound students? Is the problem with the boundary? Or is it with the school? It appears to me that our kids will have more opportunity at Murch, with music, art, and a science lab at the school. It's not clear to me that Hearst has the same offerings.
mschoicesets_comment: Again, deal is walking distance from our house.

feederpatterns_comment: This is not acceptable. Our children must be offered an equivalent or better alternative.
msproximity_comment:
These schools are unacceptable for ANY child. One has a rate of just under 30 % (DCPS SHOULD BE ASHAMED!!!) and the other hits just above 50 %

Both are abominations.
hslottery_comment: Wilson is the only public school that is a real choice for parents in Northwest. Nothing would make me happier to have options --but REAL options. I repeat, until DCPS can offer comparable or better options , DCPS should table this conversation. What will happen is that people who can afford it will either move, place kids in charter or private or leave the city. There was finally some fragile faith in the school system. These proposals have shattered this.
setasides_comment: A school performing at 30 % is not considered low performing? How is that possible? Please let us know what is low performing .

boundaries_comment: Although the boundary has been expanded it still does not change the quality of the education still available within the new boundary.  I vote for a more radical change.  Until the access to quality education is equal across the city, boundaries should be suspended.  There should be a citywide lottery to determine where each child attends school.  Only then will there be pressure put on the school system to improve all schools since children in more affluent neighbors stand a chance of being assigned to a poor performing school outside of their neighborhood.  If a parent from upper northwest had to drive their child to a poor performing school in SE or NE, the school system would change overnight.
feederpatterns_comment: The problem isn't the boundaries.  Changing boundaries and adding school choice set is merely a distraction from dealing with the real problem.  Take a hard look at the schools most parents want to send their children to...mainly schools on the Hill and Upper Northwest.  The real problem is the availability of quality education in less affluent neighborhoods.  If the schools in less affluent neighborhoods resembled the schools in more affluent neighborhoods then boundaries and school choice sets become a non-issue.
eschoicesets_comment: Within certain boundaries even with the proposed new boundaries, the access to quality education is still limited or non-existent.  Improve the schools in less affluent neighborhoods so that they are equal to the schools in more affluent neighborhoods.
hslottery_comment: I vote for a citywide lottery for Prek-3-high school.  Since the availability of quality education from Prek-3-high school is unequal across the city, they only way to give all DC a fair shot at attending a great school is to allow a citywide lottery that would not guarantee access to any child to a specific school.
setasides_comment: "Setting aside" is a bad idea for many reasons.  Should only 10-20% of the children be able to opt out of low-performing schools?  What about the remainder of the children who have been left behind?  All children deserve equal access to quality education.  Children can't choose where they live and how much money their parents make.  So if their parents are low-income and live in less affluent neighborhoods they are subject to low-performing schools unless they get lucky to be picked for a set aside.  Something is wrong with this picture.  This is taking the easy way out.  Look at the schools in the more affluent neighborhoods and the high performing schools.  See what is working there and use that data to fix the low-performing schools.  Sure it may need to be tweaked with other services that may be necessary based on the population but don't take the easy way out.

boundaries_comment: The proposed boundary change isn't fair to the families that live VERY close to Janney.  You want to be able to walk to school.  I think it would be better to expand Janney (even more than they have done.)  Besides the distance issue, Hearst is currently (and accurately, I believe) seen as overall a lesser school than Janney.  (My son attended both, so I have a pretty good sense of this.)  The risk involved here is that the families who are reassigned to Hearst will instead either move to Maryland or switch to private schools.  DC is a tricky case because the other jurisdictions are so close and have many good schools.
feederpatterns_comment: The current feeder pattern works geographically, which is important to me and many families.
eschoicesets_comment: This is dumb.  Makes kids have to travel farther, which is not good for elementary students especially.  As mentioned above, families who didn't get their choice would leave the DCPS system, which is not good for DCPS.  Actually, some wouldn't even try the lottery but would bolt as soon as their kids are toddlers, which is what used to happen.
mschoicesets_comment: Same concern as above.  DCPS would lose a lot of affluent families, who have the option to move to Maryland or go private.  This is not good for the school system.
msproximity_comment: Again, bad for DCPS because you would lose families.
hslottery_comment: While distance from home is slightly less of a problem for high school students, you still would see increased driving, which none of us need.  Also, as with my earlier comments, DCPS would lose affluent families who don't get their preferred school.
setasides_comment: This is a nice idea BUT there is zero space in many good schools at the moment, so where would those students from low-performing schools go?

boundaries_comment: Closer but still a terrible school.
feederpatterns_comment: Brookland has a greater likelihood of success, given its diversity.
eschoicesets_comment: Would rather be zoned to schools in Brookland, like Burroughs.
mschoicesets_comment: Zoning my neighborhood to Brookland will keep us in the DC school system. Zoning us southward with Eckington will drive us to private school.
msproximity_comment: My neighborhood should be zoned to Brookland, not Eckington or Edgewood.
hslottery_comment: Dunbar is terrible. But I can't support this. It is not fair. People work hard to live in specific neighborhoods and gain access to good schools. This option drives hundreds of families out of the school system.
setasides_comment: This might give us a chance to get into Wilson, but it doesn't solve the problem with other schools.

boundaries_comment: I'm happy that my daughter is going to a public charter school.  I know West is a rising school but still behind the curve.

mschoicesets_comment:
This proposal defies logic. How can parents seriously consider sending their children to a proposed new school? Concerned parents will consider choices for viable schools that demonstrate high performance and a commitment to quality educational programs. Because DCPS' credibility is lacking, parents will have great difficulty believing that a proposed new DCPS middle school would truly meet their near-term needs.  School choices need to be concrete and real options, not proposals which can be easily scuttled or defunded.
If the city is serious about attracting more families to DCPS middle schools, then the city needs to make the appropriate investments in building (or renovating) facilities and providing sufficient programming (e.g. IB, language immersion, STEM) to create attractive options. The old adage, "Build it and they will come" applies. It takes a lot of time, dedication, and energy to make a school great, and residents need to see DC putting money where its mouth is. Seeing DC make that investment would demonstrate to residents that the DME is serious which, in turn, would make residents feel it's worth their time and effort, too.
hslottery_comment: For a variety of reasons, incl poor programming and safety concerns, Roosevelt HS is not an option I would consider for my children. I expect my children to attend college and the programs at Roosevelt  High do not seem to support that goal.
setasides_comment: As a 20+ year DC resident and taxpayer, I would hope that my children automatically have access to top quality public education. It should not matter what part of the city that you live in-- all children should have access to top performing public schools. I view set-asides as a bit of a gamble, and most parents would not willingly gamble their children's education. Parents want predictability.

feederpatterns_comment: I prefer both options
eschoicesets_comment: this would just drag a good school down
setasides_comment: what would they do in a full school like Brent?

eschoicesets_comment: As a military family we are very concerned about how this proposal will deal with families that move to the area in the summer. We choose a house based on the school that is most convenient and meets our families needs. Once we find the ideal school, then we rent a house close to the school. This would leave uncertainty in the already stressful lives of military families.

feederpatterns_comment:
Not sure what this means:
"In the Advisory Committee's proposal, middle school boundaries will match those of their feeder elementary schools, which means that each address will only be zoned for a single school."

I would like my children to have a matter-of-right to go to Deal.
eschoicesets_comment: It's important to know where your children will go to school when you buy a house, not one of three possible locations.
msproximity_comment: The choice by location seems okay except my children have not studied Spanish.
hslottery_comment: Absolutely not. There are all of 50 kids going to Wilson from this area now and to take away my right to send my children there in order to give preference/lottery to a student living further away is not right.
setasides_comment: There are 50 kids out of ~1000 at Wilson coming from this area. How much more set-asides do you need? Have the kids go to school by location. Reduce the overcrowding at Wilson.

feederpatterns_comment:
We need to continue to feed to Deal until Hardy is as proficient/high quality as Deal is...
Why should Eaton move to Hardy when the current feeder schools of Hardy are not going there.  Eaton is also a World Cultures school which fits with the Deal IB program and offers Chinese.  
The demographics of Eaton is diverse and mirrors that of Deal.  Eaton has the lowest achievement gap between Blacks and Whites in the city and we should be rewarded and maintain current feeder.

If and when Hardy has the same options and extracurriculars as Deal have at it and change the boundary.  Until maintain.  Also if you have to grandfather you need everyone currently at Eaton to continue to have option to go to Deal and then if and when you make a boundary change you eed to be upfront with the incoming Pre K class.
eschoicesets_comment: This is ridiculous.  You have Eaton feeding to Hardy and Hearst to Deal and Oyster to Cardozo?  No way.  People choose elementary school and Eaton to attend Deal.
mschoicesets_comment: This might work between a high quality and proficient Deal and Hardy but it wont work anywhere else in city.
msproximity_comment: Insane.  Oyster Adams is a K-8 and not a middle school.  The choice if any needs to be Hardy or Deal. And why would bilingual be my option when Eaton does not teach Spanish?
hslottery_comment: again crazy.  feeders from Hardy and Deal to Wilson must e maintained until there are high proficient HS options and transportation.
setasides_comment: for the number of kids in low performing schools this set aside % is too damn low.

feederpatterns_comment: Eaton's current feed to Deal will be missed under this plan.
Cardozo? Never!!!! I'll move to Maryland before this crap happens. My current HS is Wilson.

boundaries_comment: I think of the streets between Ft Stevens playground and the former Walter Reed campus to be a part of the Brightwood Neighborhood. Where will those students go that has a neighborhood identity?
eschoicesets_comment: Very bad idea--what if the family lives next to the school, prefers that school, that school is preferred by many other families and then that family does not get a spot in the school based on the lottery--a very bad outcome. One school per address.

feederpatterns_comment: Middle school and high school do not seem like realistic options in terms of safety and quality.
hslottery_comment: A long way to go before it is am option

We recently moved from NYC where they had school choice. It was one of the reasons we moved as we saw friends go through applications that were worse then college, siblings attending different schools, and kids commuting long distances.
,

feederpatterns_comment: Depends on the new school.  It would have to be at least as good as Francis Stevens.
eschoicesets_comment: Would destroy all of the good work we and other parents put into our excellent neighborhood Elementary School, Ross.  Would destroy housing values in our neighborhood.  This would be a catastrophic, "nuclear" change that would cause many to loose confidence in DCPS and move out of DC, particularly those who pay the most taxes.
mschoicesets_comment: Destabilizes communities and property values and leads to lack of trust of DCPS.
msproximity_comment: Currently we have a choice of two schools that is guaranteed.  I would hate to loose that choice that we already have.
setasides_comment: 20% is way too high a percentage of seats to take away from residents who work hard to make their neighborhood schools great.  5% might be acceptable.

boundaries_comment: This makes sense and is overdue.
eschoicesets_comment: Good concept but wrong ES choices.  The additional one proposed is a LOT further from home than 2 other ESs.  And the other additional choice isn't really an addition as the grade levels offered aren't aligned.
mschoicesets_comment: Good concept but currently these additional MSs are poorer performers than our feeder MS so would never use this option, nor would others I know.  So knowing we could get "bumped" from our current choice/better MS makes it hard to get excited about the theory.
msproximity_comment: Similar concern to option above -- good in theory but in reality could result in going to poorer performing MS than current in-boundary choice for some families, like us.
hslottery_comment: This creates a lot of uncertainty and there are many HSs that I would NOT send my children to.

boundaries_comment: Doesn't affect us, would probably improve Hearst
feederpatterns_comment: Something needs to be done because of over-crowding at Deal and this disrupts things least.
eschoicesets_comment: No one should be force to do bi-lingual education. That really has to be the choice of the parents.
mschoicesets_comment: Until Hardy is improved this isn't going to sell with parents around here.
msproximity_comment: First off, I think this is incorrect. Our kids aren't suddenly going to be switched to a bi-lingual middle school after English-only K-5. I think the real choice would be Deal, which we live 1/2 a mile from, and Hardy. We moved here to be sure we were in-boundary for Deal. We paid a lot for this house. Changing the rules now is a bad idea. And we may move our kids to private school or move from the city if we can get the money we need for our home. Hardy needs to be improved as Deal was, but this will take time. Start with the physical structure and then change the admin and educational plans as needed. This is probably a 5-7 year undertaking.
hslottery_comment: This plan is basically bad in every way. Has anyone considered what this would do even to traffic patterns? How much it would disrupt people's lives? If you do this there will be a mass exodus from DCPS as you are finally making progress.

boundaries_comment: I feel bad for the families who got carved out of Key district. But overcrowding needs to be addressed.
feederpatterns_comment: Extensive work must be done to improve Hardy and increase the number of in-boundary kids who go there.
eschoicesets_comment: We moved here to go to Key. It's close by. The only choice we want is Key.
mschoicesets_comment: Would love to be able to choose Deal - but the real problem is that Hardy is not yet excellent. The top priority should be improving all middle schools.
hslottery_comment: Improve the high schools citywide.  Don't deny access to Wilson to kids in the neighborhood.
setasides_comment: All schools in the city should have a diverse population and space should be made for kids without access to high quality nearby schools - as long as there is room for all in-boundary kids.

feederpatterns_comment: How is a 'new' school going to work? I am a dcps teacher and know just because something is shiny and new doesn't mean it's good.
eschoicesets_comment: These choices are all bad or under-performing schools. Having a choice set of the same type of school is the antithesis of choice.
msproximity_comment: They are both under performing and I wouldn't send my kid there. If much rather take her elsewhere.
setasides_comment: This doesn't create more seats! It creates chaos. You need to build better schools.

feederpatterns_comment: It is incorrect to say that my feeder pattern does not change. Under this plan, kids in SW who by-right can attend Wilson are rezoned for Eastern, which is an equally distant and lower performing HS.
eschoicesets_comment: Obviously, the option of a PCS in ward 8 and a not yet created new school do not constitute reasonable alternatives to the struggling in bound school.
mschoicesets_comment: Every scenario and the proposed new boundaries offer a materially worse option for children in my area than the already suboptimal status quo. The middle school choice set is probably impractical but offers at least one slightly better option.
msproximity_comment: Stuart Hobson would be a great alternative option, although middle school is not my biggest concern in SW.
hslottery_comment: I think city-wide lottery is impractical but it would potentially give me better options.
setasides_comment: Obviously given that the new boundaries remove by right access to a high performing HS and do nothing to improve options in the very weak ES, set asides would help make this process slightly less inequitable.

feederpatterns_comment: No one in our neighborhood will ever send a kid to Cardozo, for high school or middle school, so this seems sort of pointless especially given that the "new school" is unspecified.

eschoicesets_comment: No.  People want to have at least one school to be guaranteed when they buy the house. I think the idea should be to make it so more of my immediate neighbors are going to the same school with my child.  This would make it more likely that kids within the same block will go to different schools.
mschoicesets_comment: No.  People want to have at least one school to be guaranteed when they buy the house. I think the idea should be to make it so more of my immediate neighbors are going to the same school with my child.  This would make it more likely that kids within the same block will go to different schools.
msproximity_comment: I see zero benefit to this plan!  Kids need to have the security that they will continue in school with their neighbors!  It is too hard in the last year of elementary school to say we have no idea where you will go next year or if your friends will be with you.  You are encouraging us to move out of DC.  Please stop this horrible idea.  My child needs predictability.
setasides_comment: I don't understand this.  Are you saying you would set aside spots at the high-performing schools, for students from low-performing schools?

feederpatterns_comment: I would not send my kids to a retrofitted elementary school.  Elementary students should not be exposed to middle school students.  The middle school courses offered are inadequate compared to courses offered at stand-alone middle schools.  I would not send my kids to Dunbar HS.  Instead I would try to get them in a magnet-type school or private HS in DC.
eschoicesets_comment: Charter schools remain an viable option until core standards are revised to include a more competitive curriculum such as offering science before the 5th grade.
mschoicesets_comment: If the new school is a stand-alone middle school, retrofitting an elementary school as a middle school is not an adequate choice set.
msproximity_comment: These are not stand-alone middle schools, they are elementary schools with middle school students in attendance.  This is not an option for me because neither provide the academics required to get them in a competitive high school. Kids in ward 5 should have a stand-alone middle school options in this choice set, like they do in other wards.
hslottery_comment: I would only agree to this option if there were an equal playing field to the quality of education across all of the schools.

boundaries_comment: We do not plan on attending in bounds school for a variety of reasons.
feederpatterns_comment: Again, we do not plan on attending our in bounds elementary school, so this would end up being different.
eschoicesets_comment: We would be very happy with Peabody or Maury, but my luck with the lottery has not been good and surely we would end up with Payne again.
mschoicesets_comment: Again, see my bad luck with lotteries.
msproximity_comment: It would take a huge improvement for me to consider either of those schools for my child.
hslottery_comment: Once again, I don't like having to trust my luck to a lottery.
setasides_comment: I am guessing there would be many children assigned to Payne Elementary that would qualify for this set aside.  However, I am concerned that you need to improve schools from within and not take their best students.  This whole process has soured me on the  DCPS system, and I continue to just hope we improve our luck in the lottery as time continues.  I am apparently a bit annoyed with the whole process today.

boundaries_comment: Love.
feederpatterns_comment: This would be amazing!
hslottery_comment: Makes it v diff to plan for your kid's education.

feederpatterns_comment: The Cardozo EC is a disaster.  Parents with any alternatives at all have never sent their kids there, nor will they.
eschoicesets_comment: This doesn't really affect our family directly in a negative way, but the whole idea of choice sets attempts to raise failing schools up at the expense of better performing students and schools.  In addition, the concept completely destroys the idea of neighborhood schools.  It's a cop-out instead of improving all schools.
mschoicesets_comment: There is no school as of yet, and the plan doesn't provide any details.  Also, Shaw Middle was a complete failure toward the end, as is Cardozo EC now.  There's no reason to think this will change with a new school under current DCPS leadership.
msproximity_comment: No way my kids are going to either.
hslottery_comment: This is just a silly plan.  Families deserve some type of predictability, and any plan that could include a 1 hr commute each way to school is just ridiculous.
setasides_comment: Not sure how you would do that when in-boundary kids should be guaranteed a spot.

eschoicesets_comment: What if I don't like any of the options in my choice set? I don't like the idea of not being able to apply to any school.
mschoicesets_comment: What if I don't like any of the options in my choice set? I don't like the idea of not being able to apply to any school.

boundaries_comment: Our family is not affected by elementary school boundaries.
feederpatterns_comment: This is not the current feeder pattern for our DCPS student because she is not at our inboundary middle school.  I do believe children who have already started in a feeder pattern should not be forced into another one for middle school or high school.
eschoicesets_comment: Parents cannot make decisions about staying in DC based on a lottery system.
mschoicesets_comment: Parents cannot make decisions about staying in DC based on a lottery.
msproximity_comment: Parents cannot make decisions about staying in DC without knowing for sure that their child(ren) will attend the school they believe is best for their child(ren).  Parents purchase homes based on where their children will go to school not where they hope their children will go to school.  This will be the case until all DC schools are high-performing, high-quality schools.
hslottery_comment: Parents cannot make decisions about staying in DC based on a lottery.  Until all HSs in the district are high-performing, high-quality schools, parents will have to move out of the city in order to get their child(ren) the education they need to prepare for college if they cannot get that guarantee based on where they live.
setasides_comment: This is a start but it's still no guarantee that a child assigned to a low-performing school will be able to attend a high-performing school.  Without that guarantee, many parents will not want to risk staying in DC and playing a lottery for their child's education.  The other problem with this is that it doesn't fix the root problem of the low-performing schools.  Anything that gets a child a better education is good but not if it then reduces the spaces at the better school for its neighborhood students.

feederpatterns_comment: I love the ability to attend Stuart-Hobson.  My concern has to do with the feeder vs. in-boundary challenge.  My daughter did not get into Peabody-Watkins in the 3-year-old lottery five years ago.  We had already settled into Tyler by the time we could have taken a slot at Watkins (kindergarten).  I'd like to go to Stuart-Hobson over Eliot-Hine, but may we do so directly from Tyler? If not, we'd switch to Watkins for a single year of 5th grade, but that seems ridiculous to have to do.  That said, if Jefferson were an application only middle school attracting high achieving students, we would definitely apply there.
mschoicesets_comment: This approach works well from a parent's perspective only if the students get into schools not based on lottery but on application to distinctly different program offerings.  For example, if one MS is language-immersion, one is STEM, and one is IB (or Arts focused or sports and music, or whatever), then the families could apply to go to that MS in the choice set.  Children have different strengths and interests.  Nurturing those interests helps to motivate them and help them achieve.  The school could also more efficiently direct its resources to teach at high levels in some areas, average/remedial in others.  Odds are that the students would self-select and divide the population somewhat equally across the schools (assuming that the 3 focus areas for the schools are all relatively popular but different from each other).
msproximity_comment: Given the disparities between Eliot-Hine and Stuart-Hobson, this could be great or terrible news.
hslottery_comment: Having no guaranteed access to a single high school is not a bad idea, but making the determination by lottery is absurd.  Students are tested in DC-CAS for several years, evaluated by teachers/principals/social workers.  It would take resources, but DCPS has the information to determine schools that would be the best fit for various students.  If each high school were to focus on students with specific strengths and interests and students were recommended to attend those schools, I believe the schools and students would flourish.  The educational experience of  student is based in part on that student's classmates.  Put a bunch of students at roughly the same level into the same class, and they'll all be able to advance at the same pace with less social conflict and little need for differentiated instruction.  They'll challenge each other as well.  Put students into a class based on lottery alone and each school will spend resources pulling out some students for remediation, trying to teach to the middle set of students, and failing to challenge the advanced students.  Students would surely travel across the city to access a school that felt "right" for them, that challenged their strengths, remediated in comfortable and nonjudgmental environment their weaknesses, and fed their interests to help them want to attend school every day.  It would take resources to partner students and schools correctly, but it could be done.  Heck, colleges across the country do it every year.
setasides_comment: This would be valuable if 90% of schools were high performing and the remaining 10% of school needed to provide an out to their students.  My perception of DCPS schools in the news is that a great many are low-performing.  How do we accommodate so many students who have the right to apply to a handful of strong schools? What do we say to those who want to leave but don't get reassigned and are instead left behind?

boundaries_comment: The Capitol Hill cluster should have one consistent boundary
feederpatterns_comment: Eastern is closer than Dunbar.  It didn't make sense that parts of Capitol Hill went to Dunbar.

I would very much appreciate a new middle school for the area, where Ross, Garrison, Seaton, Cleavland, and Marie Reed can feed into. I would definitely not send my children to Cardozo for middle school at this stage.
eschoicesets_comment:
This is a terrible idea. The lottery in and of itself is already stressful and pits parents against each other instead of working together to build their neighborhood school. And then where is Ross in this set? That is supposedly the highest performing school in Ward 2.
In addition, "choice" is a misnomer and dishonest. If I have to "win" a spot through a lottery that is not choice that is LUCK and parents shouldn't have to rely on luck for the basic right of having their children educated.
mschoicesets_comment: I do not like the idea of "choice sets" for middle schools but I do like the idea of a brand new Middle School for wards 1 & 2. We need a strong middle school in the neighborhood and the key to making it strong is visionary leadership, quality teachers, and commitment to programming (which includes adequate resources).
msproximity_comment: Unless there is serious improvement in either of these schools over the next 3 to 5years it will be really difficult to convince families to send their children to these schools
hslottery_comment: This is not a viable option. A lottery by the very definition is based on luck of the draw (or will have some type of weights for proximity, siblings etc). This adds a tremendous amount of stress to parents and students and does not allow families to plan ahead for their futures. Families need to have a clear feeder pattern they can visuals their children following and then focus their energy on making the schools in that pattern as strong as they can be.
setasides_comment: Another terrible idea. So only a select set of lucky students from low performing schools will have the good fortune of getting into a "better" school. This will only continue the pattern of flight from DCPS schools to either charters or parents scrambling to get their kids into a Ward 3 school.

feederpatterns_comment: The Mt Pleasant neighborhood has a longstanding relationship with Deal Middle School, and it is critically important that this relationship be maintained.  As many people have observed, including diverse neighborhoods such as Mt Pleasant in the Deal boundary is key to maintaining diversity in the school, and it will be critical to ensuring the success of Bancroft.  Many Mt Pleasant families, including mine, purchased or house with the expectation that we would have the right to attend Deal.
eschoicesets_comment: This proposal is fine.  However, my children already attend an out-of-boundary ES, and have done so for many years (in the case of my older child, this has been the case for 5 years), and my main concern is ensuring their continued ability to attend that school, for the sake of consistency in their education.  It would be extremely disruptive if they were forced to attend a different school.
msproximity_comment: Of course, this option would be unacceptable for my family, as it would be for almost all Mt Pleasant families.  We would move out of the city if we were forced to attend these under-performing schools.

boundaries_comment: My children currently go to Bancroft and we feel like it is the neighborhood school for the Mt Pleasant neighborhood. This is a common sense and very welcome change since the old boundary was down the middle of a street and divided out two streets (Irving and Hobart) that are absolutely part of the neighborhood.
feederpatterns_comment: This gives "east of park" students continued access to Deal and Wilson which is a great thing for everyone.
eschoicesets_comment: This plan creates too much uncertainty in the elementary school years, you should know that you have a right to go to a specific school if you move into certain boundaries.
mschoicesets_comment: While better than Policy Example A, I prefer the Policy B feeder system.
msproximity_comment: This is not a good choice for our neighborhood.
hslottery_comment: You should have guaranteed access to at least one school.

boundaries_comment: We purchased a home within the Powell boundary because we were attracted to the English-Spanish emersion program at Powell.

Today I would not object signing up my child in one of these schools. When I went to visit Powell ES 10 years ago while looking for a school for my daughter the teachers at the school itself were discouraging us from enrolling in there!
feederpatterns_comment: This means we will have to go to a lower performing school than the school for we are zoned currently and which is good fit for my student.
eschoicesets_comment: I find the expression "choice set" very misleading since it suggests parents can choose - albeit from limited options - the school for their child. Unfortunately it is mostly matter of "luck" as student assignment is basically subject to a lottery drawing.
mschoicesets_comment:
There is even more absurd - "choice set" with no existing school to enroll in. I have enrolled my older child to a K grade in the newly created school in past. But that was my family's choice based on the great trust we had in people who undertook that enterprise, trust in their vision. It was not an enforced decision.  
For last 2 years we were planning to enroll in one of the middle schools we are zoned for and were happy with that. That would be drastically changed with the new proposal. I feel caught up.
msproximity_comment:
Both of these schools are performing on considerably lower level than the school we are zoned for now. 

Again, I consider the word "choice" misleading.
hslottery_comment: City wide lottery is a bad idea.
setasides_comment: It seems that the current (I admit very confusing and complicated) situation actually allows more than 10-20% of students to attend OOB schools then current proposals (except an unfortunate city wide lottery).

boundaries_comment: Broadening the boundaries for These neighborhood schools, that rely on a common approach using the responsive classroom and are led by the same principal, makes sense. I would argue that the boundaries could be even more inclusive supporting Peabody and Watkins being true neighborhood schools with all the advantages that state offers-close family engagement and support, a walking to school culture, and close student ties that are reinforced in the community.
feederpatterns_comment: I would like to see the feeders for Stuart expanded to cover all neighborhood elementary schools. At present 15 percent of students at Stuart are from our neighborhood, meaning 85 percent of families in our neighborhood are bussing children across town or attending private school. This is a missed opportunity for Stuart and our community.
eschoicesets_comment: Choice sets for elementary school could work. Critical to all new options, if investing in all schools so families feel they have good choices in their neighborhood.
mschoicesets_comment: As noted above, without ensuring all schools are high quality, this is a less attractive option. We would not elect to attend Elliot or Jefferson. How does this proposal integrate charters? Are they included in the choice set for the neighborhood they are in?
hslottery_comment: I think it is destructive to communities and a drain on children and city bussing resources to send our children across town.
setasides_comment: On the fence. Why not just invest in all schools so students can attend their neighborhood school?

boundaries_comment: School administration is satisfied with status quo - they are one of the best schools east of the park and have little impetus to improve.
feederpatterns_comment: Thrilled to see this, personally, but it makes no sense. Seems mostly to be a relic of Shepherd Park's halcyon days of DC elite.
hslottery_comment: So much is put to chance for children in this city - to relegate possibilities for success to the whims of a lottery is deplorable.

boundaries_comment: Doesn't matter, my kids are already going to a different elementary school.  Ludlow-Taylor has a poor reputation in our neighborhood, due in large part to the principal who has very poor people skills and doesn't do anything to make families feel welcome.
I'm happy with our current school zone and would not want to change.  We bought our current home so we can attend Key, and our child will not be of age until next year.
feederpatterns_comment: While this makes sense, I would not be happy with a rezoning from Key.
eschoicesets_comment: Absolutely not.  This list gets further and further from our home and these are not our "neighborhood" schools!
mschoicesets_comment: This is fine.  We are currently zoned to Hardy.
msproximity_comment: This is great and makes sense.
hslottery_comment: I think the lottery system does not work.
setasides_comment: I think this should be done.

boundaries_comment: The mix of neighborhoods  tee eater safety concerns and behavior issues for the children in the school.
feederpatterns_comment: These schools continue to have safety issues as a result of school closures and neighborhood problems. Also, these schools do not offer nearly as many opportunities as other schools in dc. HD has yet to implement a STEM program. I do not believe most people follow this pattern because of the lack of programming at their neighborhood schools. Which leads to families like mine traveling to around D.C. to attend out of boundary schools.
eschoicesets_comment: Programming at this school is poor compared to schools in other parts of D.C.
