hslottery_comment: I don't think this is fair. I personally think that there is a dispariy in D.C. based on financial, social and cultural needs. It baffles me that you can consider some ones choices without giving them access to the same type of education that is being offered in other parts of the city.
setasides_comment: The committee should compare all aspects of each school. I don't think its fair for that small amount to be set aside. Should people then just be forced to attend low performing schools? I think more work needs to be done to reach out to parents in these areas. Maybe the committee should try visiting the school during the day and meeting with parents then.

boundaries_comment: The only thing appealing about Noyes is its proximity to our house. With such a low inbound participation rate, what I've read on neighborhoods listserves about older students and adults hanging out and making trouble around there, teacher and administrator scandals, and terrible ratings on LearnDC, not to mention sad DC CAS scores. Langley's more recently renovated facilities and slightly better "report card" I find more attractive. I'd like to hear about any plans to improve facilities and the school in general at Noyes.
feederpatterns_comment: I assume this will change when new Brookland Middle School opens in 2015.
eschoicesets_comment: I don't know what to think about this proposal. On the one hand, I like the idea of parents knowing one school is a sure-thing and not making lottery an obligation. On the other hand, I'd rather have chance of getting a better by-right neighborhood school than to simply get redistricted to the worst of the three.
msproximity_comment: This will change when new Brookland Middle School opens.
hslottery_comment: I think I like this because it may allow students to go to high schools best meeting their needs and interests. That could be location, access to certain vocational programs, higher level college prep or whatever. Of course, the right middle school preparation would be crucial. I am also unsure how application/test-in high schools would be maintained in the proposal.
setasides_comment: High school is too late to try to rescue kids from low-performing schools.

boundaries_comment: The proposed boundary is much better.  I live on Hobart St. and it makes sense to keep the Mt. Pleasant neighborhood together.  When my daughter was elementary school age, I deliberately chose a charter school rather than send her to HD Cooke which at the time was very low performing.   I know it has improved now.
feederpatterns_comment: The proposed feeder pattern is  great.  It's obvious that Deal and Wilson are great schools.
eschoicesets_comment: I think the choice set is an innovative method to combine "choice" with "neighborhood schools".
mschoicesets_comment: I think the choice set is an innovative method to combine "choice" with "neighborhood schools".
msproximity_comment: Given these two closest middle school,  I much prefer the middle school choice set.  At middle school,  I don't think distance is as important as quality of the school.
hslottery_comment: Too much risk at the high school level.  Could only work if the quality of the high schools was level which it is not.
setasides_comment: Definitely should do it.  Only way to get "real" diversity since neighborhoods are economically segregated.

feederpatterns_comment:
Those middle and high schools are a non-starter for me. Deal and Wilson are the only ones I'd consider now because of their ratings. I would not send my child to a school that I thought was unsafe, subpar, or potentially a poor influence.

We've chosen to settle down in the city based on the current school zones. Changing them now would cause us to consider moving... out of the city. The value of our neighborhood will go down as well. 

Improve the schools first... then consider rezoning. Otherwise, it's a non-starter for most of us.
eschoicesets_comment: Luckily, we are currently in a charter school so this (lord help us) will not apply to us.
mschoicesets_comment: Options are good.
msproximity_comment: Again... we won't go to these schools.
hslottery_comment:
Unwise proposal. The lottery processes are painful enough in the lower grades. Requiring them again in the later years will be terribly disruptive to families and friends. 

Additionally, urban planners should be consulted. The cross-city travel that occurs because of the current lottery system is ridiculous.

I would hope that more energy and funding would be used to improve neighborhood schools rather than creating an atmosphere in which everyone vies for the same school. Personally, I think our children, as DC residents, have lost an opportunity to connect and engage with their neighbors (who are the same age). We have raised a generation of children who require adult involvement for play dates with their classmates because younger elementary school aged children are clearly not going to use metro by themselves to get to a friend's house. In addition, we lose on the community involvement end because the logistics of getting to your child's school is much harder when it is not located in you neighborhood. While I'm sure there are those in central office who dismiss the community involvement, our neighborhood school has benefitted from programming that only resulted because of parent volunteers and their efforts.

feederpatterns_comment: Dunbar seems far away - I think there are other options (though specialized) closer to my house

boundaries_comment: Ross ES is quickly going to become over run in the early childhood grades, and continue attrition in the upper grades. With no decent MS or HS feeder DCPS may as well make it a PS - 3rd early childhood program only.
feederpatterns_comment: "new school" is the only seemingly viable option for academic continuity from Ross ES, but it doesn't exist. And it won't exist for year (maybe -10 years?). Clearly the DME is focusing on future generations with this boundary process, but leaving those of us currently in the system with no solutions either temporary or part of the permanent changes.
eschoicesets_comment: I can't see where this improves education in any group. Poorly performing schools will get lumped with neighboring poorly performing schools. Choice sets is like a smoke screen that makes parents feel they may have "choice", when in fact they have a lottery (no choice) and no better seats available for their kids.
mschoicesets_comment: Ironically, Ross ES and many families who attend are geographically close to both SWWFS and Hardy MS. So, why do we only get a non-existent single school as our "choice". Smoke and mirrors.
msproximity_comment: At least this MS option actually offers locations that exist! This would essentially split Ward 2 families. Those who attend SWWFS and those who DCPS loses because they won't attend Cardozo EC. At the very least, this gives one viable option to some of the Ward 2 residents and may decrease DCPS attrition slightly. It may be the best of the worst.
hslottery_comment: Seriously?!
setasides_comment: While this isn't a solution to poorly performing schools, in the short-term I do think this would increase diversity across city schools and ensure that expensive housing isn't the only way to attend a decent school. But again, the committee fails to follow through with a determination of what "low-performing" means.

boundaries_comment: We do not currently attend our in boundary school. I am in favor of trying to align catchment with school capacity to try to increase in boundary attendance percentages at schools. However, I am skeptical that expanding Miner's boundary eastward will do anything to make it more likely that in boundary families will make that school a first choice (or an option at all) for their children.
feederpatterns_comment: I think there should be a logical feeder path from school to school, increasing predictability for families and stability for schools while encouraging families to invest time and energy in the schools in their path.
eschoicesets_comment: This is phony "choice" that is really "chance." Families want good school choices that make them feel secure about their children's future. Most families I know also want to create community by attending school with their neighbors. They do not like playing the lottery for their children's education. I also don't see how this proposal does anything to strengthen any of the schools in the choice sets or provide any better guarantee than the current system that children at all schools will get a better education. Would families be provided with any opportunity for choices outside their choice set? The current system would be better than this.
mschoicesets_comment: I have zero confidence in middle school "special focus" options that have not been planned or revealed when DCPS has not followed through with promised middle school program plans and facilities improvements. Again, I think families want a good, stable path for their children, ideally something that is vertically aligned programatically. They do not want to be thrust into lottery situations with each school phase.
msproximity_comment: I don't see how this does anything to improve quality for kids or the experience for families. It is just more instability masquerading as choice.
hslottery_comment: I am torn about this, as I think students might appreciate more choice in program or specialty at high school and have the ability to independently commute to school without damaging family and community relationships. I also think it's tempting for any family who lives east of the park to be for this option. However, without more quality options at the high school level, I think this could very well drive middle class families out of DCPS and perhaps out of DC. There is no incentive for investing in your neighborhood schools with this option.
setasides_comment: Without adequate supports (ie: transportation, OST subsidies) this is really just PR or it would just suck the most engaged, affluent parents out of schools in their neighborhoods and send them to schools west of the park IF they can afford the time and expense of commuting to school. And again, it does nothing to strengthen any of the schools involved.

boundaries_comment: I live within the current boundary, and already have my child waitlisted for Pre-K because there are far more students within the boundary than seats available.  Pushing to expand the catchment area should be explored only after current in-bounds students are able to go to their neighborhood school without being waitlisted.
feederpatterns_comment: Eliot Hine needs some reinvestment and improvement.
eschoicesets_comment: This would solve some of the adverse selection problems at Payne (it's the in-bounds school for the homeless shelter at DC General, and thus, most neighborhood parents try to avoid sending their kids there), and put all of these schools on equal footing.
mschoicesets_comment: Eliot Hine and Stuart Hobson would be fine, but Jefferson is so far from us, it would be a major commute to get there.  I think it would also depend on the quality of Jefferson improving in the next few years.
msproximity_comment: Wheatley may be close, but to get there, we would have to cross three major arterial roadways and walk on narrow Florida Ave sidewalks that I don't consider safe for adults, let alone children.  I would prefer staying at Hine over this plan.
hslottery_comment: I can't fathom some of the transportation scenarios that this would lead to.  I could imagine my kid going to Eastern or Dunbar, but other schools are so far distant, that I'd be very worried about forcing myself and other parents into transporting their kids that far or sending them on long metro trips.  Also, the sense of community that a guaranteed neighborhood school leads to is what I want, so my kids can go to school with the same people they've gone to ES and MS with, and not have to find a new group of friends as soon as they are in 9th grade and are scattered across the city.
setasides_comment: I like the option of being able to apply for a different school assignment if our neighborhood HS doesn't improve performance by the time my kids are ready to go.  I have toddlers now, so I don't have to worry too much about it, but our HS is underperforming, and we would have a hard decision sending our kid there now.

hslottery_comment: every child should be guaranteed access to a school

boundaries_comment:
The boundary should run on the north to Taylor-- it makes a weird jog, but it's not necessary. That green space is the Howard School of Divinity, and no one lives there. 

But these boundaries mean that people just adjacent to Brookland @ Bunker Hill on the south won't be zoned for there, which is odd.

Overall, though, I think the boundary for Burroughs makes sense.
feederpatterns_comment:
This information is inaccurate. We will be zoned for the new Brookland Middle School. Brookland @ Bunker Hill will no longer have a middle school, and neither will Burroughs.

We will not be going to middle or high school in DCPS though. Our girls are at a DCI feeder school. 

If we were still subject to this zoning, we would not send our kids to Dunbar as it is now.
eschoicesets_comment:
We live across the street from Burroughs. If we were going to attend DCPS, it would never make sense to send our kids down the way to Brookland @ Bunker Hill. I think "choice sets," by creating uncertainty, will sap the energy out of efforts to invest in Burroughs, where momentum seems to be building. 

I'm also totally unclear on how the charter school option would work in this scenario. 
 
Also unclear- would choice sets mean that kids couldn't attend out of boundary DCPS schools? Many in the neighborhood do that now.  

For me, the choice set idea seems like an effort to redistribute kids, rather then make DCPS schools more appealing for families. For DCPS to compete in Brookland, the schools need to offer more things that families want-- language, special programs, focus on the arts, etc. DCPS needs to see itself as competing with charters, and with privates, and up its game by increasing its outreach and sophistication. It needs to start at the elementary school level. Just moving kids around won't do it.
mschoicesets_comment:
This is inaccurate. There will be a new Brookland middle school. 

But as I explained above, I'm not in favor of choice sets.
msproximity_comment: Again, this is inaccurate. There won't be a middle school at Burroughs, and I'm not sure about Langdon. We won't be attending either.
hslottery_comment: We will be sending our girls to DCI, so this doesn't affect us directly. But I don't see how this effort will improve high school quality options. Create more compelling programs, test in options, magnets, etc. that appeal to people. Simply conducting a lottery won't do it.
setasides_comment: I think people that are at low performing schools should have additional options. But I don't see how 10-20% of seats at high performing schools can be guaranteed without exacerbating crowding at them.

feederpatterns_comment: Removing access to Deal without providing a replacement of equal or superior quality is unacceptable. Like many other parents, we purchased our home many years ago based on school boundaries. I cannot imagine a greater harm that the DC government could deliberately do to our family than to simultaneously disenfranchise our children and lower the value of our single largest financial asset.
Very pleased to remain in the Stuart Hobson feeder.
mschoicesets_comment: I prefer to have a guaranteed access to Stuart Hobson.
msproximity_comment: I prefer to have a guaranteed access to Stuart Hobson.

eschoicesets_comment: I live where I live so that my kid can go to Janney and I think 1 assigned school makes more sense than 1 out of a lottery of 3. Where I could walk to school now I might have to drive which is what neighborhood assigned schools are in place to avoid. There is a sense of community living when your neighbors kids are all in the same school. This plan would be highly disruptive!

boundaries_comment: We are currently assigned to Langley Elementary School, which has some great facilities.  This plan would represent yet another shuffle, the 5th in the 13 years my son has been alive. It is difficult to trust DCPS will stick with any plan given that track record.
feederpatterns_comment: To get to Cardozo High School from our house, we have to pass Dunbar High School, Banneker and McKinley High school. This makes no sense.
eschoicesets_comment: Impossible to say what I will like because you are not telling me what I will get. I am happy that Cleveland Elementary school is in our choice set, because of the Spanish language program. However, given that we have no guarantee of getting in, it's no good. It does not represent a real return on my tax dollars or commitment to this city.
mschoicesets_comment: Again, can't trust my children to this proposed "new school," which does not exist yet. DCPS has consistently shown a contempt for the children in our community through the constant shuffling. Just because they can get away with it does not make it right or equitable for our children.
msproximity_comment: This a weak compromise and gives no guarantee of fairness or equity. McKinley Middle school is showing some promise because of the facilities. However, DCPS has not demonstrated a strong enough commitment to the families, and then that lack of trust is returned. Impossible to say what I will like because you are not telling me what I will get.
hslottery_comment: A citywide lottery is only fair if it is universally applied to each and every school in the city, starting from Pre-K, including "speciality" programs and charters. This is a cop-out and shows a lack of commitment, which is I think the real problem. You are trying to play the charter school game. Again, only fair if each and every person has the same chances. This half-way program is creating more confusion, more uncertainty, and frankly it is an appalling abnegation of the commitment to each and every child in the city.
setasides_comment: Again,  impossible to say what I will like because you are still not telling me what I will get. What about the 80 percent of the kids who have to stay? Why not focus on creating positive community culture right there in the neighborhood?

mschoicesets_comment:
Hardy is almost four (4x) farther from our homes than Deal. (3.7 miles away vs. 1.0 miles). 
Communities are about communities.  About children being able to study with their neighbors. Please do not make my children and future children in our neighborhood travel 4x farther to go to Middle school.
msproximity_comment:
Brightwood EC is almost twice as far from our home than Deal. (2.1 miles away vs. 1.0 miles). 
Communities are about communities.  About children being able to study with their neighbors. Please do not make my children and future children in our neighborhood travel 2x farther to go to Middle school.
hslottery_comment: Communities are about communities.  About children being able to study with their neighbors. Please do not make our children spend their childhoods on buses travelling all over town.
setasides_comment: Great idea.

boundaries_comment: I could live with this, so long as controlled choice sets doesn't happen (lottery to see if I get Maury or two other schools).  If access to Maury isn't a right for my address, this changes to the very angry face with horns drawn on top, steam coming out of the ears, and holding a (flaming) pitchfork.
feederpatterns_comment: Eliot Hine and Eastern would have to improve considerably for me to consider them as options for my family.
eschoicesets_comment: Over my dead body.
mschoicesets_comment: I don't know enough about this proposal to have a strong opinion.  I am interested in creative solutions to the middle school problem, but there needs to be some degree of reliability.  I suspect middle school choice sets would slow the pace of improvement of DC middle schools.
msproximity_comment: Again, there needs to be reliability.  I believe without ill-considered interventions, Eliot-Hine will eventually become a solid middle school (though I would very much like the pace of that improvement to accelerate).  Parents can't just hope they get a good school in a lottery, and will instead make choices (charters, private, moving) that offer them greater certainty.
hslottery_comment: Same comments.
setasides_comment: This seems like a reasonable way to improve access to better education for low income families.

boundaries_comment: It's not a change for us, but I would be concerned if I lived in the western area south of Hawaii Ave, for the school is not very accessible to this area.
feederpatterns_comment: Although the middle school stays the same, I am very disappointed at potentially being shifted to Dunbar from Coolidge.  I would let my child go to Dunbar.
eschoicesets_comment: This would be good for us, because Burroughs seems a better option than our direct feeder Brookland EC.  If this option existed, and my child did not get into Burroughs, I would probably remove him from DCPS.
mschoicesets_comment: Since Brookland is not a desirable middle school, having an easy way to improve upon it is good.  As above, I would not let my child go to middle school at Brookland, so failing to get into a better school would probably lead me to remove him from DCPS.
msproximity_comment: See above.
hslottery_comment: DC has only a few acceptable high schools.  I understand the argument that all students should have an opportunity to go to these; but I suspect that lotteries would cause these schools to become worse.  This concern leads to my general feeling about DCPS school reform:  that the only solution is to make every school good enough that the neighborhood will not abandon it.
setasides_comment: Same as above.

feederpatterns_comment: Wilson-->Cardozo is a terrible results for us. We would never send our child to Cardozo.
eschoicesets_comment: It used to be that Oyster was part of this choice set. Why has it been moved?
mschoicesets_comment: Need more stand-alone middle schools. Current options are education campuses and are not okay.
msproximity_comment: These two middle schools are both education campuses, and bad ones at that. I would not send my child there, and there should be a strong stand-alone middle school option for everyone.
hslottery_comment: This is a terrible idea. People should not have to travel across town to go to high school unless they choose to do so for a charter or OOB DCPS.
setasides_comment: This is a great idea. People who are in low-performing schools should have other options.

feederpatterns_comment: Children should have the right to go to a quality neighborhood school, that is a walkable distance from home.
eschoicesets_comment: This would create needless traffic with families who now walk or bike to school having to travel farther, and it would be dangerous for younger children having to cross major roads if their school was farther away.
mschoicesets_comment: Rather than making kids spend more time in transit going to/from a school that is farther away, those hours could be better spent with extra instruction or free time.
msproximity_comment: All children should have a quality middle school near their home, there is no reason to mix kids up and send them all over the place. This will cause disruption with traffic, and also with carpooling with neighborhood families for school pickup and extra curricular activities. Parents who rely on school pick up by neighbors and friends at school will have less ability to do that if their child is farther away, attending school with kids who don't live near their home.
hslottery_comment: This could require my child to travel a significant distance to get to a high school. This could therefore affect his ability to play sports and other activities as the transit time to get back home could be significant. I don't want my child spending an hour on a bus in traffic to get to a school across town, we will move to Montgomery County. Has the city considered how much this would increase costs for the additional metro and bus trips that would have to be paid for, where many kids now can simply walk. If every kid had a good school nearby, people wouldn't even be  talking about bussing kids all over. Fix the schools that are broken. And make Charter schools take neighborhood kids, so there's less cream skimming.
setasides_comment: What if the set aside pushes a school over capacity? How would DCPS handle that? Would neighborhood kids be kicked out? I can see justification for some children needing to go to a non-neighborhood school (parent works across town in that area, for example, or a specialized school with language instruction or some such thing) but if each neighborhood school is adequate, this issue of people wanting to traipse across town will likely be minimized for most kids. Who wants to spend more time traveling to get to/from school than is necessary?

boundaries_comment: It never made sense to me that the kids who live on the other side of our street (Irving St NW) go to Bancroft and the kids on our side of the street go to HD Cooke.  The new proposed boundaries make much more sense.

eschoicesets_comment: Lumping together 3 good schools with 1 that isn't doesn't address the issue of quality at that one school.
msproximity_comment: The proximity to my currently assigned middle school is the one thing that makes me willing to overlook its not being ranked very well. I would not be happy if my children had to go to a school that wasn't good and wasn't very convenient to get to either.
setasides_comment: I think low-performing schools should just be improved rather enticing good students to leave.

feederpatterns_comment: Stuart Hobson is closer to Maury than Eliot

boundaries_comment: I'd love to see the data and analysis that suggest that the child population is going to decline by 469 in 3 years.
feederpatterns_comment: Why are the data in the visualization tool of the feeder pattern from 2011-12? Surely the District has data for 2012-13? Also, the tool only showed the simple N of students moving from Lafayette to Deal. That's a big part of the story. Another important part is that it's about 95% of kids. That should suggest that over time, most kids who go to Lafayette, almost all kids, that is, will go on to Deal. (You should also note that there's very little attrition from K to 5 at Lafayette.) That matters.
eschoicesets_comment: I'm not crazy about the choice set idea generally. People want certainty and no one prefers travel to a good neighborhood school. But this case is just silly. Who is served by shuffling kids among Janney, Lafayette, and Murch? This serves absolutely no purpose. Brightwood, Shepard, and Takoma are probably about as close to most of Lafayette as Janney. (I need to check a map.) Some cluster of Lafayette and those schools and perhaps Murch would make much more sense. Or Murch, Hearst, and Eaton (which isn't much better than Lafayette, Janney, and Murch). I don't like the cluster idea, but if you're going to consider, consider one that would accomplish something beyond creating massive inefficiencies.
mschoicesets_comment: Again, think choice sets don't solve the problem. It's not a zero sum game. Create more quality schools and people will flock to them. Don't just shuffle kids around. I'd be happy to have a kid at Hardy. But why travel further to Hardy when Deal is closer? Silly choice set.
msproximity_comment: don't like choice sets, as said repeatedly above. This one makes more sense than Deal and Hardy. Does Brightwood have the capacity to take 100 kids from Lafayette? Looks small from the outside.
hslottery_comment: Great way to drive families to MD and VA. This is a monumentally bad idea. DC has an opportunity that is unique in America. We can have a thriving charter sector and great neighborhood schools. Why would anyone want to blow that up? Show me one city in which most people send their kids to their neighborhood public school? There isn't one. Except DC. Wards 2 and 4 are ripe for creating a sort of educational utopia of socio-economically and racially diverse, high quality neighborhood schools. Invest in them. Get people to bring their kids back home from across the park, save all that driving and bus time so kids can use the time more productively at great schools near home.
setasides_comment: So would this mean that the students in seats that are "set aside" will bump neighborhood kids? Or does it mean that every overcapacity neighborhood school, like Lafayette, will just be 10% larger? So instead of being at 700 kids and stuffed to the brim, it'll be 770 kids? Gotta say, I don't understand how that makes any sense. I get that kids in bounds for lousy schools need options. Rationing quality education as we do now by income/wealth is wrong. This isn't the solution. The solution is to create more quality schools.

boundaries_comment: There is likely a reason that there are low in-boundary participation rates for this school, and DCPS should be forced to consider that.

eschoicesets_comment: We live one block from Bancroft and would not want to "travel" to another school.  Could consider preference based on location from school as a factor in the lottery.

feederpatterns_comment: My daughter is currently attending Peabody (one of the cluster schools), which she won through the lottery.  My children should be allowed to attend the school as it is within our current boundary.  The opportunities at Peabody, compared to other schools the "proposed boundary" are excellent.  I want her to continue to have great opportunities.  It is clear that people who are not affected by lotteries or the boundaries feel strongly by the proposed changes.  However, my children have benefited from the lottery.
eschoicesets_comment: What are parents to do if none of the schools in the assigned choice set are desired?
mschoicesets_comment: I am interested to see how this plan will be developed.
hslottery_comment: We chose to enter the lottery for our teenage daughter so that she would have access to a high school that would challenge her.  I think giving parents a choice actually works.  Each high school in the lottery requests essays and other items from the applicants.
setasides_comment: I stated earlier, that the purpose of the lottery, allows students to apply to different schools.  Under the new guidelines, all of the schools in our proposed feeder patter are low performing, and this is not ideal for the growth of my children.  All children deserve equal access to a proper education.

eschoicesets_comment: If I wanted choice, I'd have selected a charter school.  DCPS should maintain neighborhood schools that help create strong communities, by engendering close friendships amongst students who metriculate together as well as strong ties as parents get to know each other.  A walkable school is also a key benefit of the current neighborhood feeder pattern.  This a great lifestyle choice that provides good exercise, reduces transportation costs, and is a environmental sensitive by reducing fossil fuel costs.
mschoicesets_comment: If I wanted choice, I'd have selected a charter school.  DCPS should maintain neighborhood schools that help create strong communities, by engendering close friendships amongst students who metriculate together as well as strong ties as parents get to know each other.  A walkable school is also a key benefit of the current neighborhood feeder pattern.  This a great lifestyle choice that provides good exercise, reduces transportation costs, and is a environmental sensitive by reducing fossil fuel costs.
msproximity_comment: We moved to Ward 3 at great expense to ensure that our children would be in the Deal-Wilson feeder pattern.  If we lose this certainty, we will pack up and move to Maryland.  Its that simple.
hslottery_comment: We moved to Ward 3 at great expense to ensure that our children would be in the Deal-Wilson feeder pattern.  If we lose this certainty, we will pack up and move to Maryland.  Its that simple.
setasides_comment: If set asides can be used to maintain diversity at highly sought after schools such as Deal and Wilson I think they are a good idea.  However, before adopting such an approach, DCPS must make sure that there is adequate space for the in boundary students as well as students from low performing schools.

boundaries_comment: Our child (and soon her sibling) currently attends Hearst Elementary in Ward 3 as an OOB student.  and, fingers crossed we are hoping that grandfathering will take care of our children through high school.  For families moving into Ward 5, while better than most in the area, Cleveland Elemenary is not the most optimal choice for children in terms of performance and racial/economic diversity.  For my husband and I racial AND economic diversity are very important compositions for a successful education environment.
feederpatterns_comment: First it is hard to be part of a feeder pattern that does not include a middle school.  This is hard for any parent to digest and therefore impossible for us to comment on.  Cardozo EC is currently a priority school which means it is one of the poorest performing high schools in the district.  We are not sure if words could even represent our sentiment.  For my husband and I, this is a no go and does not help us in any way as Ward 5 residents.
eschoicesets_comment: To reiterate, our options are limited because compared to the schools in other areas of the district, these schools rank very low in terms of performance and diversity.  This is a no go for us and doesn't help us in any way in terms of neighborhood shools.
mschoicesets_comment: Would anyone want to be a part of a feeder pattern that does not include a middle school? We understand that this is something that needs to be done due to the condition of existing schools, but how can we comment on this if we don't know what this holds for our chidrens' future.  But we do agree that building a good school is what is needed in our ward.  Whether that will work, it is tough for us to comment with anything but unhappiness and anxiety.
msproximity_comment: Cardozo EC is currently a priority school which means it is one of the poorest performing high schools in the district.  We are not sure if words could even represent our sentiment.  For my husband and I, this is a no go and does not help us in any way as Ward 5 residents.  We would continue to rely on the lottery to afford us a spot in a better high school.
hslottery_comment: We think equal opportunity for all is a move in the right direction.  This allows for everyone who values education a chance to get  into a great school. Economic and racial barriers are removed with a city wide lottery.  It is also a risk which we understand but we rely heavily on DCPS to make this work for all families.
setasides_comment: While we would love to send our children to our neighborhood schools, the school options provided for our children we are afraid, are not good enough and pose a high risk to their educational development.  For this reason we strongly support the option for "set aside" seats for students assigned to low performing schools.  Thank you for this opportunity. We are anxious but excited for the results. Our children are our most prized posessions so we are grateful that someone is finally listening!

boundaries_comment: Murch is 2 blocks from our building. That is why we chose to live here.
feederpatterns_comment: Murch and Deal and Wilson were what we were looking for when we looked for a place in DC. That is why we chose to live where we do.
eschoicesets_comment: All of these are too far for elementary school children to walk to.
mschoicesets_comment: Deal is a good school but Hardy has a poor reputation. This is not an equal choice. If you made first Hardy better you would inspire more trust. I would not send my daughter to Hardy as it is.
msproximity_comment: I don't know anything about West. But the map shows it is too far. We moved here to walk to Murch and Deal.
hslottery_comment: Wilson is currently the only acceptable high school for us. You would see a lot of people run from DCPS if you went to a lottery system.
setasides_comment: Letting people leave failing schools for good schools is positive. But shouldn't DCPS fix failing schools instead of admitting defeat? This seems like giving up.

boundaries_comment: It is shortsighted to argue that few public school students live in this area. Even the briefest of walks through the expanded Maury boundary reveals a large number of strollers. And if this becomes the new Maury boundary, new families will buy up the remaining seniors' houses overnight. Meanwhile, Maury ES itself is physically overcrowded and the budget for expansion has been delayed for many years. Expanding this boundary first invites many years of serious problems for this otherwise successful school. Either the boundary needs to shrink (not grow!), or DCPS needs to commit to building a bigger facility for this school.
feederpatterns_comment: This is a sensible feeder pattern. But DCPS has no vision for what Eliot Hine should be and has failed to take action on the Capitol Hill middle school proposal, so we have no incentive to follow this pattern now. The jury is out on the newly reopened Eastern High School but the first problem is keeping the kids in grades 6-8.
eschoicesets_comment: This is a decently diverse choice set but as a practical matter, it would only serve to siphon off some kids from the other three (better) schools and put them at Payne, since the other three schools are full beyond their physical capacity and Payne's space is under-utilized. This is obviously unattractive to all parents whose students are currently attending one of the other three better-performing schools.
mschoicesets_comment: This ONLY makes sense if the special focuses are clearly defined and well implemented. Otherwise, a middle school choice set takes the handful of kids willing to brave the disastrous DCPS middle school system and disperses them further.
msproximity_comment: Again, why undermine predictability without providing a clear curricular distinction between the schools? Besides, for my personal situation, this is a choice between two schools I'm not interested in unless DCPS really sinks some effort into Eliot Hine to transform it.
hslottery_comment: This is the worst in a long list of bad ideas.
setasides_comment: This is a good idea to ensure that not all students are priced out of decent neighborhood schools.

boundaries_comment: It's walking distant from our home.
feederpatterns_comment: I'm not fond of either school. NO diversity and terrible test scores. My kids will be going to a charter or private school.

msproximity_comment: There is a big difference between just driving a half a mile down Nebraska to drop off my kids at Deal than having to get through the park across to Brightwood.  Geographically they may be close but the actual distance is much greater.

eschoicesets_comment: Being able to walk to school instead of drive is extremely important to our family. One of the reasons we moved to this neighborhood is our desire to use our car as little as possible.
mschoicesets_comment: Again, we do not want to drive our kids to school, and Hardy is too far to walk. We also generally oppose the idea of school assignments by lottery. We want predictability and neighborhood schools.
msproximity_comment: See above.

boundaries_comment: Seems reasonable, although I worry about eventual crowding.

Children living within a modest distance (1,000 ft or less) of SWS should be able to attend that school.  For almost 20 years SWS has always had a geographic preference and that should be reinstated.  Reggio Emilia schools stress the importance of community and nothing says community like allowing those families that live in close proximity to the school the ability to attend.
feederpatterns_comment: Hobson is a good school and getting better.  Eastern needs a lot of work.
eschoicesets_comment: Again, students living within proximity to a school like SWS or Montessori should be able to attend there.  Community is key to a school so proximity preferences should be in place especially for schools like SWS.
hslottery_comment: School is about community and driving all over town to attend schools destroys this.  Neighbors who attend neighborhood schools have buy-in within their community.  Children should go to the schools closest to their homes.

boundaries_comment: Raymond is currently our in-bounds school but we have not considered it to be a viable option for our child (now in pre-k, OOB via lottery) due to very poor academic performance and the PS3-8th grade campus.  Neither is desirable.
feederpatterns_comment: I do not see any major differences between Cardozo and Roosevelt HS, but still do not consider either one a viable educational option for my child due to the very poor academic performance of both schools.  Again, I do not like the concept of a PS3-8 school (or grade 6-12 schools). MS is challenging, both socially and academically, and I worry that struggling MS-aged kids may set a poor example (academically and behaviorally) for ES-aged kids.  And also that vulnerable MS-aged kids will be subject to poor influences from HS-aged kids.  I don't believe educational campuses are the right answer to addressing many of the challenges facing DCPS.
eschoicesets_comment: We might consider Powell or Tubman as viable school options. Raymond is not an option; I don't know enough about Bruce Monroe to have much of an opinion on the school.  However, I suspect that many other families in the area would have the same preferences, meaning that many would be matched with the less-preferred schools.  In our case, we would move rather than send our children to Raymond.  That might even be our choice if we were matched with Powell or Tubman. This also provides absolutely no certainty about schools, which is not appealing at all.
mschoicesets_comment: It's hard to have much of a positive opinion about an imaginary new school.
msproximity_comment: I will not send my children to an educational campus ES or MS, for reasons explained above.  I do not think that the academic performance of the MS grades at either Raymond or CHEC make either one an option I would consider for my children.
hslottery_comment: Roosevelt HS is not somewhere I would send my children due to very poor academic performance.  Under current conditions, where there is really only one high-performing non-application HS in the city, I cannot support a city-wide lottery for HS.  I have doubts about DCPS' ability to create high-performing HSs from scratch.
setasides_comment: In theory, I think this is a fine idea.  But I have concerns about how low-performing schools would be defined and about parents gaming this system.

boundaries_comment: My wife and I, both DC voters, are furious by the proposed change in school boundaries.  We specifically purchased our condo so our son would be able to attend Murch.  Not only is it a teriffic school, it is only 3 blocks away from us.  It makes absolutely no sense to force us to send our kids to Hearst, which is in Cleveland Park and would take 20 minutes to get to during rush hour.  We are not alone in our frustration.  There are many, many families in our building with young children that are also frustrated.
feederpatterns_comment: We are furious about the prospect of being reassigned to Hearst.  We live only 3 blocks from Murch, and bought our condo thinking out child would attend Murch.
eschoicesets_comment: This proposal is the cruelest and dumbest one of all.  The biggest insult to us is Murch isn't even in our "proposed choice set."  We spent our life savings on a down payment for our condo.  While we could have afforded a bigger, nicer place in another part of town or the suburbs, we chose to buy a condo in Forrest Hills because it was in the Murch School district.  So we sacrificed the opportunity to own a bigger home in another part of the city or the suburbs just so our son could have a good education at a quality neighborhood school 3 blocks away.  With this plan, DCPS would take everything away from us, and we may have to bus our kid all the way across town to Oyster Adams.  That's really not fair - it reminds me of the failed bussing policies of the 1970s which lead to an exodus of middle class families to the suburbs.
mschoicesets_comment: This is a terrible idea.  Hardy MS is no where near as good a middle school as Deal.  We sacrificed so much to be able to send our child to quality schools.  Why does DCPS want to punish middle class families like ours?
msproximity_comment: Horrible idea.  Why do you want to destroy communities by forcing our kids to be bussed across town to go to school?  Do you want to return DCPS to the horrible state it was in during the 1980s?
hslottery_comment: This is another way of punishing middle class families and returning DCPS to the state it was in the 1980s and 1990s.

boundaries_comment: My family and I moved to this neighborhood particularly because of the feeder pattern.  We moved from Capitol Hill.  We relied on the current feeder patterns to make our decision.  We chose DC over the suburbs.  We have two young children, one in Pre-K and another that will be in pre-K in 3 years time.  There has been no discussion about revising Charter schools as part of this boundary process only public schools.  With 45% of DC students in charter schools, charter schools should be part of the discussion when talking about boundary revisions.  This would take pressure off of trying to blow up the strong traditional public schools that seem to be the target of of Policy Examples A and C.
feederpatterns_comment: My family and I moved to this neighborhood particularly because of the feeder pattern.  We moved from Capitol Hill.  We relied on the current feeder patterns to make our decision.  We chose DC over the suburbs.
eschoicesets_comment: My family and I moved to this neighborhood particularly because of the feeder pattern.  We moved from Capitol Hill.  We relied on the current feeder patterns to make our decision.  We chose DC over the suburbs.  A choice set of Janney, Lafayette and Murch is a waste.  There is no reason for it.  I would like a neighborhood school that is in walking distance for me and my children.
mschoicesets_comment: I oppose choice sets for my children and relied upon the current Lafayette, Deal, Wilson boundary when purchasing my home.
msproximity_comment: I oppose choice sets for my children and relied upon the current Lafayette, Deal, Wilson boundary when purchasing my home.
hslottery_comment: My family and I moved to this neighborhood particularly because of the feeder pattern.  We moved from Capitol Hill.  We relied on the current feeder patterns to make our decision.  We chose DC over the suburbs.  We have two young children, one in Pre-K and another that will be in pre-K in 3 years time.  There has been no discussion about revising Charter schools as part of this boundary process only public schools.  With 45% of DC students in charter schools, charter schools should be part of the discussion when talking about boundary revisions.  This would take pressure off of trying to blow up the strong traditional public schools that seem to be the target of of Policy Examples A and C.
setasides_comment: I am not opposed to some sort of set aside for children out of boundary, but children within a boundary should have priority.

feederpatterns_comment:
Maintaining boundaries is the BEST CHOICE presented in the DME's options.  All the other options reduce predictability.  The boundary option still needs proximity preference.  This is the one way to build neighborhood school improvement into the mix.  The proximity preference would lose its power as the neighborhood schools fill up from the neighborhood, but it still provides a way to grow quality schools organically.  Choice sets and lotteries introduce too much uncertainty and will return us to the days when it was go private or move to the suburbs.

Maury is great!  But MS is a BIG PROBLEM.  Eliot-Hine is not attractive to me.  Perhaps this is because I don't know anyone that sends their kids there.  None of my neighbors children attend Eliot-Hine.  And test scores are not good.
Maybe this will change as the crop of Maury children grow, but somehow I don't think that will happen without some incentives to get neighborhood children to attend.  It could be done, but it would take outreach and real recruitment.
eschoicesets_comment:
All but one of the schools in my 'choice set' are already filling their classes with in-boundary students.  

"Choice set" in this instance means getting a lottery ticket to the one failing school in the set.  

The remaining school, Payne, has problems that are caused by the school boundary which includes the DC General site and fills 20% of the school with students from the homeless shelter.  These students arrive throughout the year, with severe and intractable problems.  These students don't come with extra money or services.  They just come with serious needs.  This makes it very hard for the new residents (the ones paying big bucks for the newly renovated houses) to buy into the school as a neighborhood school (as they have done for Maury and Brent).  Choice sets don't look like they will work.  Instead I am afraid that it will cause more fleeing from DCPS to charters and the suburbs.
mschoicesets_comment:
There aren't enough quality MS in DC and there is (at most) one quality MS in the "Choice Set" for my location.  A choice set makes getting into that quality MS more difficult for any resident within the choice set boundary and makes the MS choice less predictable -- without increasing the number of quality seats.

We need a couple of test-in middle schools.
msproximity_comment: No predictability here either.  Stuart is the better school.  I am not in boundary for it.  One of my two closest schools means... Eliot Hine.  Get some more quality MSs.
hslottery_comment:
Wilson is the only comprehensive, non-Application HS that has an acceptable quality.  Eastern is the next best comprehensive HS but it is still not attractive at this point.  I would love it if it WAS an acceptable school for my neighborhood, but the I don't know how DCPS can make it one.  

I do know that making HS a citywide lottery will drive all the other high-SES families out of the system, since there is a presumption that the average quality school that results from a citywide lottery will be crappy.  (Wilson succeeds by taking most of their students from families that value education, either high-SES families in the neighborhood, or dedicated families that are in feeder schools or were diligent in working the system to get in.  Wilson has 12% of its 9th grade class repeating the grade.  The city-wide average from all the other non-application HS is around 20-24% repeating the grade).

Build another HS west of the park and allow out of boundary admissions using an application process to 'academies'.
setasides_comment:
The low-performing schools haven't been defined.  The scare resource of 'well functioning HS' needs to be expanded.  A 20% set-aside may be too high level, especially if a lottery is used to pull citywide without any filtering for proficient and advanced or highly-motivated parents.  

What is the target "proficient and advanced" percentage?  What is the goal?  Is it to give motivated parents from boundaries to low-performing schools an escape hatch, or is it to take in low-performing students and place them in an environment where the expectations are different and they will grow to meet the expected performance?

In order for the environment of the successful school to improve the performance of students coming from "low-performing" school zone you need to make sure that the high-quality school isn't degraded to become a not-so-high-quality school.  The mix of students already in those schools that aren't from the 'low-performing schools' may not be all that great.  Getting the mix of 'proficient' right before adding more 'not proficient' is important.

mschoicesets_comment: Choice sets for middle school should feed into the same high school so the consequences of the "choice" for the few years of middle school aren't drastic.
msproximity_comment: Again, the middle schools should feed into the same high school so the consequence of being sent to either middle school isn't drastic.
setasides_comment: This is an interesting idea. I like the possibility of kids at low-performing schools having some preference for an out-of-boundary placement, but I don't understand how EACH elementary school can have at least 10% of its seats reserved for out-of-boundary (low performing school) kids.  E.g., Lafayette is already bursting at the seams, almost entirely with in-boundary kids.  If all in-boundary kids will still have a "right" to attend their neighborhood school and then reserve 10% of seats for low-performing-designated-out-of-boundary kids, literally where do all those kids sit (let alone, what are the class sizes for the teachers and/or the money for additional teachers)?  How many trailers can one school have?  I'm not against the set-aside idea and think it is one of the better ideas in the set of proposals; I just want some of the those questions answered (satisfactorily) first.

boundaries_comment: Both Marie Reed and Oyster are doing good work.  Only BIG concern is to be feed into Cardozo at later grades.
feederpatterns_comment: Again, only concern is being feed to a below standard HS such as Cardozo.  Such a switch would likely entail a lot of neighborhood families relocating.
eschoicesets_comment: Interesting idea but would like to read more about plan and its implementation.
mschoicesets_comment: Interesting idea (really like the idea of STEM) but would like to read more about plan and its implementation.
msproximity_comment: Do not like the uncertainty considering if one of two options is not satisfactory.
hslottery_comment: Consideration of schools independent of child's home is ridiculous.  Why make families commute across the city?
setasides_comment: Interesting idea but would like to read more about plan and its implementation.  At best its a band aid to address some students stuck in a bad performing school.

feederpatterns_comment: I would like for my child to have more options for middle school especially.
I am not keen on sending my children to either of these schools, but I am more comfortable with the trajectory for change and improvement at Roosevelt than I am for Cardozo.
eschoicesets_comment: I'm not sure what all the hullabaloo is about this. As long we parents still have opportunities to participate in the broader lottery beyond these choice sets, then this seems like a relatively good solution to allowing kids to have access to a school close to home. The issue really is that quality among these schools can vary so greatly, that it makes it hard for parents to feel confident and commit to their neighborhood if they can't guarantee that their child will have access to a good school.
mschoicesets_comment: I find it remarkably sad that they schools are so poor quality in these wards that quality schools do not even exist despite masses of students in the neighborhoods.
msproximity_comment: Right now, I would not consider sending my children to either of these middle schools.
hslottery_comment: Overall, i think this is not a viable solution for this city. Neighborhoods will weaken, high SES families will flea to private, guaranteed. Let's strengthen our schools in our communities instead of throwing everyone into a single pot.
setasides_comment: Only fair.

boundaries_comment: By expanding the boundary for Oyster, I have some concerns about capacity. We were told that non-Spanish language dominant households do not stand much of a chance of taking advantage of Pre-4 and as is, I hear the school is busting at the seams. I am just skeptical about expanding the boundary at such a time when capacity seems to be a concern and the Pre-4 availability quite limited.
feederpatterns_comment: Let me say that I am not convinced that Oyster middle is an acceptable option at this time. I would greatly prefer to have the option of going to Deal for middle school, but fear that flexibility may be taken away, sadly. As for the HS, I don't think Cardozza would be acceptable at this time. Our family would likely have to move to a new home unless we were able to enter "School Without Walls" or some such stellar HS closer by.
eschoicesets_comment: I would be very, very happy with Eaton as a back-up to Oyster or even first-choice if Pre-4 were viable at Eaton. I like this flexibility considerably, and am glad to see it being taken seriously.
mschoicesets_comment: I would be in favor so long as Deal were an option. Otherwise, I would not be interested in the least.
msproximity_comment: Neither middle school is acceptable at this time. I can't say that this option is desirable in the least. Our family will require better options and more flexibility.
hslottery_comment: By moving to NW DC, I  had thought Wilson would be our HS. Cordozo is not acceptable at this time.
setasides_comment: I am not sure I understand this option. Please do better to explain clearly.

boundaries_comment: Drew is a lowest 40 school. So either way our choice is a lowest performing school. Higher capacity is a good thing if funding increases accordingly.
feederpatterns_comment: Our feeder pattern doesn't change. Again all 3 schools are low performing or lowest performing.
eschoicesets_comment: All 3 options are low performing schools. This amounts to choosing the least bad school.
hslottery_comment: This would at least give us a chance at a good HS
setasides_comment:
Access to high and middle performing schools should not be limited to wealthy and upper middle class residents. The set as side process should be easily assessable and easy to apply to. Their should also be a process to make sure kids can get to these schools. A kid in Deanwood will need to take 2-3 buses to get to a school in parts of NW.  This student may be able to get a set as side seat but not actually be able to get to school.

Additionally, their should be a way for teachers and principles to ID a student who might accel at a higher performing school but doesn't have parental interest or parental ability to apply for a set assist seat.

boundaries_comment: In order to stay in DC, our kids should attend neighborhood school of our choice, the choice that we made when we purchased our property, schools that are 4 blocks away and not 20!!
eschoicesets_comment: We could've buy a house near any of the schools above if these were our choices. Besides having a special education kid , bilingual school is not an option. Traffic, driving, parking, none sense.
mschoicesets_comment: The choice will be clear, walking distance school rather commuting and better performing as well.
hslottery_comment: That will mean for me and my family : leaving DC!

boundaries_comment: Looks reasonable, but I would worry about eventual crowding (as enrollment increases).
Looks reasonable, but I worry about eventual overcrowding (as enrollment increases).
feederpatterns_comment: I would be very disappointed if the option to attend Deal and the direct feed to Wilson was taken away from Oyster students. We purchased our home (in Woodley Park) with the understanding that our child could attend Deal and Wilson. Cardozo is in no way comparable to Wilson and also not easily accessible from Woodley Park via metro.
eschoicesets_comment: Families expect predictability. And, considering the large number of households without a car (us included), this option would place undue burden on most families.
mschoicesets_comment: Good idea in theory, but a terrible idea in practice. How do you propose that a student will get to a school that is not near their home?
msproximity_comment: Again, families expect predictability and a guarantee. Taking this away would be a terrible decision. The second closest school may not be at all convenient. What's the proposal for getting students to/from distant schools if they are forced to attend?
hslottery_comment: A huge proportion of DC families rely exclusively on public transportation. Has anybody thought about the logistics of this proposal?

boundaries_comment: Why is Seaton Elementary School not an option since it is located a few blocks from our home?
feederpatterns_comment: How is it possible that Eastern HS is the current feeder high school since there are other schools so much closer to our home?  From what I hear at neighborhood meetings, other families are NOT interested in sending their children to Cardozo.

boundaries_comment: Maury is already at capacity with almost no out of boundary students enrolled. Where would we fit the additional students? I don't see a budget plan for expansion of the building.
feederpatterns_comment: We would like access to better middle schools, or a concerted effort to attract and retain more families from the feeder schools into our neighborhood missile school.
eschoicesets_comment: It is very challenging to get very young children out of the house on time. Will need to weigh distance options.
mschoicesets_comment: Would this also include an option for broader lottery?

boundaries_comment: Love this idea.
I think that Bunker Hill and Burroughs would be superior choices to Noyes.
feederpatterns_comment: Neither high school is acceptable. But Dunbar seems even worse than Coolidge.
eschoicesets_comment: Why is Burroughs not included?
hslottery_comment: While this might improve my own options, it would be terrible for people who bought homes counting on good IB schools. I think it would really harm the city's economy. Don't do it!
setasides_comment: I would rather just see us improve all of our schools. We can do that by distributing low-income housing more fairly across the District so that poverty is less concentrated in certain areas, by trying to ensure that as many parents as possible have living wage jobs so that they can provide for their children, and by providing good role models for all students (tutors, educators, community programs, etc.) so that they can learn that staying in school is worth the trouble.

boundaries_comment: While I live directly across from Raymond and know that it will our in-boundary choice - it's not an option for us in light of the school's horrible performance!  The school needs a new principal, deputy and the building needs to be renovated.  It's not an option for many families in the area and desperately needs attention from DC School Board!
feederpatterns_comment: Cardozo will now a beautiful school doesn't seem to be improving in its performance.
eschoicesets_comment: This works in our favor since we could apply to attend one of the other schools that have made positive progress on performance in the last couple of years.  However, it doesn't help Raymond become a better school if all the parents who might be invested in the school opt to send their child to a different school.

boundaries_comment: We are currently out-of-bounds in Powell ES through the lottery. If we had to go to our in-bounds school, I would prefer Whittier as it would mean my kids would not have to cross the busy Missouri Ave/Goergia Ave intersection. This is a MUCH more walkable route to school and also accessible on the 62/62 bus route.
feederpatterns_comment: PLEASE BRING A NEW MIDDLE SCHOOL TO WARD 4!!!!
eschoicesets_comment: I like this choice set, however, I HATE the idea of choice sets.
mschoicesets_comment: There simply are no MS options in Ward 4!
msproximity_comment: This is not real choice, these are not real MSs, they are Education Campuses.
hslottery_comment: Kids should have the ability to go to their neighborhood HS and this should be guaranteed.

eschoicesets_comment: I would love to be able to send my daughter to Bruce Monroe Park View- mostly because it is 4 blocks of my house, it has a great dual language program, the principal and teachers are fabulous, the school has been making incredible academic progress the past 3 years and the school building in spite of needing the 2nd phase of renovation is beautiful.  I, along other prospective parents of toddlers have already become very involved with the school and volunteer on a regular basis.  I can say a similar thing has happened with parents at Powell.  I don't like the "sub-set" lottery proposal where my daughter could potentially be assigned to any of 4 schools (Bruce Monroe, Powell, Tubman or Raymond).  It disincentives parents who are already involved and want to be involved in the neighborhood school, it creates uncertainty--i have a 25% chance at any of those schools.  Adjust boundaries and let us have certainty that our child will have 100% chance (and a right) of going to one school.   It is not much of a choice --and is not just a nomenclature issue.
mschoicesets_comment: same comment as with the elementary school choice set. I guess i am not sure what problem will this solution address.
msproximity_comment: ok so at least the chances are now 50/50 and both schools are nearby home.
hslottery_comment:
Ok so this is the least appealing idea.  How will a kid that lives across Wilson HS get everyday to Coolidge and how will that be a choice and an improvement? Or how will my daughter who lives in Ward 4 get everyday to a school in ward 3 or Ward 8 and why should she be asked to travel 45 mins to 1 hour to get to school? Charters are already enough of a lottery, do not destroy the DCPS system improve it. There are parts of the system that work and others that don't. Instead of disrupting life for every one DCPS works on providing options for those students that are in a "bad" school. 

Also why not do the following: 

1) Implement "progressive budgeting" for schools, so the least performing schools can get more resources.  The "average' $9,800 spent per student in DC obscures the fact that schools in better off neighborhoods have higher budgets than schools in low income neighborhoods. 

2) Use the additional resources to truly attract the best talent in the school (bonus for serving in the most needy schools for principals and teachers). Use also those resources to build the capacity of PTAs and make them better advocates of quality education for their children and their communities. 

3) Ensure that all schools do not only have a "common core" but the facilities where children go to are bright, new, clean, safe, welcoming. Unfortunately, many schools in low income neighborhoods have yet to be modernized and look like prisons. 

4) Ensure extended days or after school academic and non-academic activities for all children from low income families so they can be tutored, help with homework, catch up on subjects they are falling behind, engage in arts (music, theater or other activities). 

It takes resources t to change this situation and playing musical chairs and lottery is not going to make the problem of poor schools go away. You will drive away from the city parents who are excited to have their children grow in culturally/ethnically/and socio-economically diverse schools and neighborhoods (as many of the wards are becoming). Schools like KIPP demonstrate that income does not seal your fate in academic performance--partner with KIPP to expand their schools in neighborhoods that offer a really bad option for parents--and offer that school as a right.  There are so many other ways to get at this problem that simply playing musical chairs and lottery.
setasides_comment: This will be a workable option...how do you guarantee spaces for OB students without pushing IB students out?  The OB sibbling preference over a new IB child is already a challenge for us.

boundaries_comment: Abolish school boundaries!
eschoicesets_comment: I like how this would prevent folks from segregating wealth as easily into a single in-boundary school. It could spread the positive school effects of gentrification into other schools!
msproximity_comment: This seems like a nice balance between pushing choice and preserving neighborhood community.
hslottery_comment: I wish we had a citywide lottery for elementary schools! Abolish school boundaries!

boundaries_comment: I love my current in-bounds school!
feederpatterns_comment: I am very excited to have a new stand-alone middle school proposed for my feeder pattern. The current education campus model is simply not sustainable because the critical mass of middle school students is not there to provide dedicated programming. No one from my elementary school, BMPV wants to send their children to an education campus that is embedded in a high school (Columbia Heights EC).
eschoicesets_comment:
I am committed to improving my local elementary school, BMPV, and I can do this work better when I can build a social network and sense of community around the school by working with other neighbors. This concept of community is incredibly powerful: we now have a group that includes about a dozen families who live in-bounds for BMPV but do not yet send their children to school there, who are interested in fundraising, volunteering, and organizing events at the school. We have also started to build networks with other neighborhood parents groups to push for improved middle school options. We would not be able to plan together as a community if we had no idea where our children would end up. While school choice sets are not as bad as a full lottery for undermining this sense of stability, they would still be devastating to groups like ours that work with prospective parents to build on a collective vision for the neighborhood school.

Also, I am not sure why my elementary school has an asterix by the name, please add this information to the website.
mschoicesets_comment: I am unhappy with this proposal because I oppose the idea of choice sets. That being said, there are so few DCPS middle schools in my neighborhood that our "choice set" is really just one school that hasn't been built yet. I do support building this school and having access to it by right.
msproximity_comment:
This proposal presents the same problem as a lottery or choice sets: without by-right access, there is no way to invest in a school before your are enrolled. 

Lack of by-right access at the middle school level also introduces instability in the elementary schools. At my local school, BMPV, even parents who love the school still start to get nervous as their children approach middle school, and begin playing the lottery every year long before they reach 5th grade, hoping for a good charter that goes through high school. These tend to be the most proficient students, who leave the school and are replaced by students who have not been taught at BMPV and are often not as proficient. The school then appears to be failing its students and test scores remain depressed regardless of the quality of instruction, further deterring enrollment. Parents who remain and hope to invest in the DCPS system through middle school are increasingly socially isolated. We need a stable, high-quality middle school option in our area with by-right access so that we can start building solidarity now around commitment to DCPS.
hslottery_comment: This idea is by far the most horrible, for the reasons stated above. Roosevelt is not a good school, but we can make it better if you give us a chance to invest, starting now.
setasides_comment:
I like this idea but am concerned about feasibility, particularly if set-asides are cumulative (i.e. 10-20% in middle school, plus 10-20% in high school). At schools that are already over-enrolled without set-asides, how can you make room for more students?  

Also, I would prefer if this policy focused on low-income students from low-performing schools. Students from low-income families are more deserving of an extra bump in the lottery, because they have fewer alternatives if they fail to secure a good spot (they can't move to a better neighborhood or pay for private school). Moreover, middle and high-income families are more likely to take advantage of an out-of-boundary preference, because they are more mobile (for example, they may be more likely to have a car and a work schedule that allows them to drive their children across town). We don't want a system that makes it easier for these middle and high-income families to flee their low-performing neighborhood schools into already high-performing DCPS schools (already too many are leaving for charters). Instead, we want to encourage them to stay in their neighborhoods and invest time and energy into creating high-quality, socio-economically integrated neighborhood schools.

boundaries_comment: I think this is unfortunate for the families at Janney who will be rezoned to another school; however, I do think that periodic redrawing of boundaries is normal given changes to the populations.  I hope there is grandfathering in under this proposal for students currently at Janney.
eschoicesets_comment: Why would I want to drive to another school that "looks" (in terms of student body composition) almost exactly like my child's current school looks like.  Instead of walking to school, I would have to drive my kids and get no benefit from the alternate school experience.  Plus, it would just mix the kids up from these neighborhoods and create a neighborhood where the kids don't know each other as well.
mschoicesets_comment: I do not want to have to drive my student to Hardy.  I work in Herndon, VA, so I can't take advantage of public transportation.  It would add another 30-45 minutes in the morning if I had to drive my child to Hardy.
msproximity_comment: I don't want to be forced into a bilingual school for middle school.  We do not have any Spanish speakers in our home, and this would be a hard experience to start in middle school, with no Spanish background.  Plus, see my response above about having to drive in the morning to school.  Oyster would also add another 30-45 minutes to my morning commute.
hslottery_comment: I think it is ridiculous to expect students to commute all over the city to HS.  We have a HS in walking distance (Wilson) and that's where we want our son to have a right to attend.
setasides_comment: I'm potentially fine with this idea, but for a school that is already 90-100% in-boundary, how do we make sure that the school doesn't become overcrowded if it has to set 10-20% aside for out of boundary students?
I'm concerned the choices available for my neighborhood are incomplete.  It drives home for me the need for quality, educational schools near my neighborhood (Bloomingdale/Ledroit Park) in Ward 5.

boundaries_comment: My child currently attends West and we are happy there. We believe in supporting our neighborhood school, and we are doing that. We intend to send our younger child there also.
feederpatterns_comment: I have mixed feelings about Education Campuses. It may not provide enough opportunities for middle school children. Perhaps Education Campuses can collaborate to offer different elective or sports offerings for economies of scale. Our ward needs a strong middle school, which we don't have.
eschoicesets_comment: This could work or it could create gross inequities if there are drastic differences in the schools. The city must fight against these drastic inequities as are seen in schools West of Rock Creek Park.
mschoicesets_comment: The idea to have special focuses for middle schools is great, but then people should be able to have a choice. If you have a child with interests and or skills in STEM, why would they then go to the arts focused school? By middle school, we need to foster children's interests and skills.
msproximity_comment: Only if the middle schools have equally desirable niche offerings that may appeal to different groups (e.g. different languages, STEM or arts focus, etc) and children's skills or interests. It would not make sense if the schools were drastically different in terms of performance, resources, etc. That would lead to inequities, which the city must work to fix.
hslottery_comment: No, this discourages investment in neighborhood schools, which is what should be happening. Everywhere else in the country, for the most part, kids go to the school they are zoned to go to. End of story. Unfortunately, the city has disrupted this, especially for high school, and will have to work hard to build this back into how DCPS works.
setasides_comment: This is a cop out and may result in sending advantaged children, because their parents/caregivers understand the set aside rule and can navigate accordingly, leaving the less advantaged children to deal with what they're dealt. This could facilitate inequities, which the city must fight against, as DCPS has a lot of them. A better way to do this is that the city should reserve some spaces at the "best" DCPS schools for children from economically disadvantaged neighborhoods so they can benefit from these schools, which are located generally in more wealthy, resource-rich areas, and oddly, those schools appear more resource rich than those schools in Wards 7 and 8, as well as other economically disadvantaged parts of the district.

boundaries_comment: Bancroft should be assigned for this block. Our Block has the largest growth of new DC residences starting families. This block also generates the highest taxes with the new condos built for families.
feederpatterns_comment: Our Block has the largest growth of new DC residences starting families. This block also generates the highest taxes with the new condos built for families. $ per sqft this block should be allowed to attend Deal and Wilson.
eschoicesets_comment: Our Block has the largest growth of new DC residences starting families. This block also generates the highest taxes with the new condos built for families. $ per sqft this block should be assigned to Bancroft
mschoicesets_comment: Our Block has the largest growth of new DC residences starting families. This block also generates the highest taxes with the new condos built for families. $ per sqft this block should be allowed to attend Deal and Wilson.
msproximity_comment: Our Block has the largest growth of new DC residences starting families. This block also generates the highest taxes with the new condos built for families. $ per sqft this block should be allowed to attend Deal and Wilson.
hslottery_comment: Our Block has the largest growth of new DC residences starting families. This block also generates the highest taxes with the new condos built for families. $ per sqft this block should be allowed to attend Wilson.
setasides_comment: There should be room for those exceptional students in many cases.

boundaries_comment: Oyster is a school I'd consider sending my children to even though we will also consider independent schools. After attending a Marie Reed open house, I don't think it would be a viable option for us.
feederpatterns_comment: Assuming the quality of Cardozo stays the same, we would not consider sending our children there.

boundaries_comment: Maury is already at capacity. Where would they get the space?
feederpatterns_comment: Not enough good options.
mschoicesets_comment: Would a district-wide lottery also be available?
