msproximity_comment: Not enough quality options in this proposal. Again, would this also be accompanied by a district-wide lottery?
hslottery_comment: To convince families to stay in DC more needs to be done to provide better options for all at the middle and high school levels.
setasides_comment: Interesting prospect. Is the goal to diversify the ward composition or the student population? If the end goal is a diverse, successful school community this may not be the best approach.

address: 42XX MARTIN LUTHER KING JR AVENUE SW

boundaries_comment: We are only 2-3 blocks from Janney.  We are within walking distance of Janney and can see the Janney building from our front lawn and we are being forced to get transportation to not the 2nd closest school to us, but the third!  This change is unbelievable as there are students that are 6-7 times as far from Janney as we are who will be sent there.  We would need to find transportation to an elementary school that is three times as far away.  These changes are unacceptable.
eschoicesets_comment: This is just outrageous.  JANNEY IS 2 BLOCKS FROM OUR HOUSE AND ITS NOT EVEN IN THE CHOICE SET! MURCH IS 4 BLOCKS FROM OUR HOUSE AND ITS NOT IN THE CHOICES.  WHO MAKES THIS BOUNDARIES!  Essentially we will be forced to choose not the first or second closest schools, but schools that are much much farther.  Based upon these choices my child will not be going to school with any of our neighbors.  We would have to drive to get our kids to school.  We moved to this neighborhood solely to avoid driving, get access to neighborhood schools (JANNEY).  All of these changes (choice sets and boundary changes) undermine our choices and may force us to move.
mschoicesets_comment: Deal is less than 2 blocks from our house and we may be forced to go somewhere else? To Hardy?  I've never even heard of Hardy!  How would my child get there!
msproximity_comment: This is better than the proposed choice set, but still insane.  Deal is 2 blocks from our house.  How could we be forced to have to drive far away to another middle school when Deal is 2 blocks from our house!
hslottery_comment: Wilson is 1 block from our house.  1 block.  How on earth could we have a school scheme where my child would be forced to go somewhere else.  Can I reiterate that we are 1 block from Wilson and there is a plan being considered that may send my child elsewhere!  How is this even under consideration?

boundaries_comment: It is an excellent idea to have all of Mount Pleasant feed to the same neighborhood elementary school.
feederpatterns_comment: It is an excellent idea to have all of Mount Pleasant feed to the same neighborhood elementary school.  Equally important is ensuring that that same cohort of students can move to Deal and Wilson together along a guaranteed feeder pattern.
eschoicesets_comment: Choice sets are disruptive to families and neighborhoods and weaken links between kids, schools and neighborhoods. Families need certainty that they are guaranteed a slot at a specific school.  Absent that certainty, it is difficult to plan long-term about housing and other major life choices.  Furthermore, these school choices are terrible.  Cooke and Marie Reed are both low performing so providing a choice between the two is meaningless.
mschoicesets_comment: Families need certainty that they are guaranteed a slot at a specific school.  Absent that certainty, it is difficult to plan long-term about housing and other major life choices.  The uncertainty will foster anxiety among students and parents and hasten the departure of families from DC. The uncertainty at the middle school level is also particularly bad for students -- breaking kids away from their established peer group after elementary school is bad for continuity and sense of community.  While a choice of Hardy or Deal is far better than Columbia Heights EC, the overall policy approach is asking families to take too big of a gamble.
msproximity_comment: Choice sets are disruptive to families and neighborhoods and weaken links between kids, schools and neighborhoods. Families need certainty that they are guaranteed a slot at a specific school.  Absent that certainty, it is difficult to plan long-term about housing and other major life choices.  The uncertainty will foster anxiety among students and parents and hasten the departure of families from DC. The uncertainty at the high school level is also particularly bad for students -- breaking kids away from their established peer group after elementary school is bad for continuity and sense of community.  Furthermore, these two school choices are terrible.
hslottery_comment: Families will leave the city in droves if this policy is put in place. How can a family make the commitment to buy a home if they have no certainty about their children's academic future?  This policy is disruptive to families, and will create an undesirable level of uncertainty and anxiety that will outweigh any policy benefit.
setasides_comment: Set-asides are an intriguing idea, but this is only workable if there are precautions to ensure that the schools receiving the new students are not then overcrowded. There would need to be a way to accommodate neighborhood students with guaranteed slots at the school and the set-aside students without resulting in overcrowding.

msproximity_comment: I love having a neighborhood school and nearby schools in my feeder pattern
hslottery_comment: I want guaranteed access; as is.

eschoicesets_comment:
This is all too confusing.  Isn't everyone going to pick the IB school?
Could we still enter charter school lotteries?
msproximity_comment: Isn't everyone going to pick the best school?
setasides_comment: I don't even understand what this means.

feederpatterns_comment: An EC is not a middle school and there are no other options for middle schools in ward 4. There can be no changes to our existing Deal rights until there is an equal or better alternative. West EC is not equal nor better as it has no where near the resources and capability of serving the middle school needs of our neighborhood.
eschoicesets_comment: Powell should be an option for those in 16th Street Heights. Proximity and ease of commute is important. Busing down 14th St. is very different from crossing town to get to Barnard, for example. The latter is unrealistic for most families.
mschoicesets_comment: There can be no redrawing of boundaries to a school that does not exist. This is an absurd concept, that makes parents with rising middle school others feel as if their needs have no value. This suggestion is a slap in the face to everyone in our neighborhood.
msproximity_comment: Again, an EC is not a middle school. The critical importance of a strong middle school program has been well proven in education research. The idea that our MS children should cram into a building without appropriate resources and instructional opportunities, again, is a slap in the face to everyone in the 16th St. Heights neighborhood.
setasides_comment: That percentage seems low, particularly in light of the fact that most people in the district would qualify for a set-aside.

boundaries_comment: If we get reassigned to Tubman it would be an improvement over Bruce-Monroe and it's closer walking distance for us. But initially I got conflicting information that we would be reassigned to Raymond which doesn't make sense for us as it's much farther away.
feederpatterns_comment: As for the middles schools, I do not see sending my children to either CH EC or Cardozo. We would be out of the District by then because their educational achievements are unacceptable to me.
eschoicesets_comment: The option of school sets threatens any involvement parents can have with their neighborhood schools before the kids enroll. Families like predictability and this weighs heavily when families relocate to a neighborhood.
mschoicesets_comment: same comment as above...families need predictability and assurance when they relocate to a neighborhood.
msproximity_comment: I understand the concept of narrowing the choice sets to two schools. I cannot have an opinion because I wouldn't send my children to either school.
hslottery_comment: This is a crazy proposal. Busing kids across the city to go to high school. This threatens any possibility of retaining families in DC who are currently happy with the schools, its increases the anxiety and stress of family having their children wandering off in unknown neighborhoods, and increases commuting time and stress for all. This would be a completely deal breaker for me if we decide to stay through middle school.
setasides_comment: I think this is fair for all as long as the students in boundary have guaranteed space in their school and are not sent someplace else because of the set aside students.

boundaries_comment: We live in the Mt Pleasant neighborhood and would very much like our child to be in school with other children in our neighborhood.  Therefore, we are eager to see the Bancroft boundary changed to include the southern part of Mt Pleasant.
We would very much like to stay zoned for Powell Elementary school as we are looking for a bilingual education for our children.
eschoicesets_comment: Not knowing where our children will be able to go to school leaves too many questions up in the air.  In addition, we would need a guarantee that all siblings will attend the same school.
mschoicesets_comment: If we have no set, this policy wouldn't apply to us.
msproximity_comment: Again, there would have to be some guarantee that siblings will attend the same school
hslottery_comment: Residents need to know where their children will go to school.  There must be some guarantee so that people can plan accordingly.

boundaries_comment: We have been very happy with Lafayette and will continue to support the school as it adjusts to the exponential growth in our neighborhood.
feederpatterns_comment: We are happy with this feeder pattern.
eschoicesets_comment: Our children benefitted from attending our neighborhood elementary school.  Not sure that we would have opted for another school that is close, but farther away than Lafayette.  The kids have ownership of the place - this is our school, in our neighborhood and they identify with it and love it.
mschoicesets_comment: Not sure you can get us on board about Hardy - Deal sets the bar VERY high.  I don't think I would seriously consider another MS in DC right now.
msproximity_comment: Not going across the park -  seems even less of an ideal situation than Hardy.  Again - can't see considering another MS besides Deal at this point.
hslottery_comment: I want access to Wilson for my children.

boundaries_comment: We are very happy to be in-boundary for Ross, especially since it is very close.
feederpatterns_comment: As things stand now, we would be very unlikely to send our child to Cardozo for middle or high school.  We like having the option of SWWFS, especially since it seems to be improving.  A new middle school could be good, but we would need more details before we are convinced.  Where would it be located?  What programs would it offer?  There is also concern that SWWFS will not be able to fill its middle school if Ross students don't have the option of going there.  In regard to high school, we are currently in-bounds for Wilson, and we would be very sorry to lose that option.
eschoicesets_comment: I think it's important to have predictability in regard to neighborhood elementary schools.  We would not want our child to be forced to travel more than a mile each way to go to Hyde.  If we want to go to Hyde, we will move to Georgetown.
mschoicesets_comment: Given that no information is available about the new middle school, it is hard to give an opinion on this option.  If the new school isn't great, we would likely choose a charter or try for SWWFS or Hardy.
msproximity_comment: As it stands now, I can't imagine sending my child to Cardozo for middle school.  There would have to be major improvements before we would be comfortable with the school.
hslottery_comment: I think a citywide lottery for high school is a bad idea.  We have to think about traffic patterns and the impact on the environment.  If we ended up at a school that is far away and not metro accessible, we would have to find another option.
setasides_comment: This is a fine idea in principle, but I'm not sure how it would work at schools that are already overcrowded with in-boundary kids.  If this is implemented, it should be for the school as a whole, rather than for each class or grade.  For us personally, we would be taken out of the Wilson boundary for high school and put in Cardozo, which would presumably qualify us to be considered for set aside seats.  Why not just keep us at Wilson?

hslottery_comment: Adding more commute and traffic issues into everyone's life, even people without kids since more  people will be on the roads/public transportation, is not a good thing. Feeling uncertainty about where your child will go to school could lead people to leave DC.

boundaries_comment: I recognize the overcrowding but feel this change will move some families who live barely two blocks from the school. Could Murch be expanded?
eschoicesets_comment: Three of the city's best schools. Still I would rather have one designated school
hslottery_comment: Terrible, terrible idea which would set back the progress DC has made in keeping the middle class in the school district. The schools will not improve under such a plan

feederpatterns_comment: Both feeder patterns are to sub-par schools.   I'll would send my children to any if these schools and will continue to drive to Ward 3.

boundaries_comment: The quality at Takoma is middling, so my neutral rating regarding the proposed boundary is based on this. At my address, the boundary change wouldn't affect my household.
feederpatterns_comment: There is strong demand for a quality DCPS middle school in Ward 4. However, the questions are where it would be located, how quality would be assured, and why this idea of converting the ECs wasn't implemented in order to strengthen MacFarland instead. As it stands, any rationale for a new middle school would need to account for why a new school, rather than turnaround of MacFarland, because this whole situation makes the school system seem disorganized.
eschoicesets_comment: Given that we're currently zoned for Takoma, the idea of a choice set to possibly access Shepherd is compelling. However, given that we'd prefer Takoma to LaSalle or Whittier, the idea of a mini-lottery is pretty unsettling, as there would be only a 50% chance of ending up in one of the two schools I would be willing to send my kids to among these four options. Even though we're not thrilled by Takoma, a bird in hand is better in this instance.
mschoicesets_comment: This doesn't make much sense, especially since Takoma and Whittier are both ECs. Why would I want to have to move my child in 6th grade subject to the outcome of a mini lottery?  Given the limitations of funding for ECs and the unknowns about specialized programming options, there are really only downsides here.
hslottery_comment: As it currently stands, there's no way I'd send my child to Coolidge. So on one hand, we know we're going to be navigating lotteries and applications. However, forcing all families into a citywide lottery actually decreases the chances that the families who actually care about their child's education will be able to go where they want to go. While the in boundary participation rates are low, there are some families who just want to send their kid to the nearest school.  Let them do so.
setasides_comment: While it might decrease our own chances of getting our kids into the schools we prefer, providing preferences based on low-performing schools is the right thing to do. However, we'd strongly like this to be coupled with proximity preference (within 2 miles, or within the existing elementary choice sets).  So, the idea is that if there are some set asides for low performing schools, there should also be some preferences for families who live near a school that is a better fit for them, in order to achieve the part of the vision around access to quality schools in "locations that make sense for families."

boundaries_comment: Elementary school-aged children should not have to cross large arteries such as South Capitol Street to get to school. Especially with the large amounts of construction they have planned for the roadway.
feederpatterns_comment: Bring back the old feeder pattern...Jefferson MS to Wilson HS.
eschoicesets_comment: In the proposal the 'new school' is a Ward 8 charter. Taking my child to a Ward 8 charter school is not at all convenient to my commute in the morning. Having a LOCAL NEIGHBORHOOD school is important for both the students and the community and can only strengthen them both. Also, the choice set in this case does not offer anything different between the schools. The only advantage to the plan is if the schools offered different programs (STEM, language immersion, Reggio, Montessori, IB, etc) which is not the case here.
setasides_comment: I would love to take advantage of getting my child into a better school however I feel that just because a student is enrolled in a low-performing school should not grant them that privilege. Those seats would be better used by low-income students from low-performing schools rather than families like myself.

feederpatterns_comment: Please do not ruin what is already barely working -
eschoicesets_comment: Why distrust neighborhoods to send kids to comparable schools?
mschoicesets_comment: Why? What is gained? How would it solve Deal's over crowding? How is DCPS going to ever have the capacity to offer these choices?
msproximity_comment: If you want folks to leave DCPS, good choice. Improve the schools first, maybe. Otherwise, not going to happen.
hslottery_comment:
First, there have to be other options available. If you eliminate the schools requiring admission (walls and Banneker)  is nothing close to Wilson which, has some academic holes of its own. Until there are some high quality alternatives out there, destroying Wilson makes no sense.

second, the goal has to be building quality alternatives. Otherwise it is li

feederpatterns_comment: This eliminates Crestwood's children's ability to attend Deal and Wilson. Instead of removing options and putting this neighborhood in a less favorable position, the proposal should focus on improving schools throughout the city so that those who currently have less favorable options have better ones and those who currently have favorable options can keep them. In other words, instead of moving puzzle pieces and shifting kids around, take a serious look at making excellent schools in all neighborhoods. What are the proposals for achieving that goal??
mschoicesets_comment: How can a proposal which is slated to be finalized in six months involve an as yet unnamed and presumably unbuilt school. That provides absolutely no predictability for parents. At the very least, the schools that are of the subject of the proposal should be schools that exist or the planned changes should be delayed until they do.
hslottery_comment: Why have neighborhood based assignments for middle and elementary school but not for high school?  Also, the proposal is unclear. Is there guaranteed access or not?  Educational years as important as high school should not be left up to lottery selection. There must be a less arbitrary and more predictable way to assign high schools.
setasides_comment: What happens to the kids in the low performing schools who can't take advantage of the set aside?  Again, instead of removing some students from these schools to leave others to languish, improve those schools.

boundaries_comment: As Ross is less than three blocks away this makes my husband and I thrilled that we will be able to walk our son to school.  This is a huge deal for both of us!
msproximity_comment: Although Cardozo may be the alternate closest school to us it remains quite far.  I would be hesitant about commuting there for school.

boundaries_comment: Yes, this is the most sensible.  We've purchased a home so we can be close to the school our children attend.  The school they attend is improving and getting excellent ratings because of it's proximity to the families it services.  It's proximity leads to parental participation.  Keep the boundaries the same and keep families who live close and invested hundreds of thousands of dollars into their home/school choice intact.
feederpatterns_comment: Of course, there needs to be a predictability of where our children will go. We have four and if it was reduced to a lottery or if we were displaced from a school a few blocks from us, so that a child from several miles away could 'take their place' we would seek counsel and encourage a class-action suit.  A significant, if not controlling factor in the exorbitant costs of securing a home in Washington, D.C. is the school's represented in that home's boundary.  If you change it, we, along with many other people will fight it.

We have four and if it was reduced to a lottery or if we were displaced from a school a few blocks from us, so that a child from several miles away could 'take their place' we would seek counsel and encourage a class-action suit.  A significant, if not controlling factor in the exorbitant costs of securing a home in Washington, D.C. is the school's represented in that home's boundary.  If you change it, we, along with many other people will fight it.

A significant, if not controlling factor in the exorbitant costs of securing a home in Washington, D.C. is the school's represented in that home's boundary.  If you change it, we, along with many other people will fight it.
msproximity_comment: Of course not, there needs to be a predictability of where our children will go. We have four and if it was reduced to a lottery or if we were displaced from a school a few blocks from us, so that a child from several miles away could 'take their place' we would seek counsel and encourage a class-action suit.  A significant, if not controlling factor in the exorbitant costs of securing a home in Washington, D.C. is the school's represented in that home's boundary.  If you change it, we, along with many other people will fight it.
hslottery_comment: Of course not, there needs to be a predictability of where our children will go. We have four and if it was reduced to a lottery or if we were displaced from a school a few blocks from us, so that a child from several miles away could 'take their place' we would seek counsel and encourage a class-action suit.  A significant, if not controlling factor in the exorbitant costs of securing a home in Washington, D.C. is the school's represented in that home's boundary.  If you change it, we, along with many other people will fight it.
setasides_comment: This option shows a classic gap between the understanding for underperforming schools. It's not geography, it's parental involvement.  When we first moved to our school district, it was not known as a great school. Now, after years of parental involvement, parental help and parental investments, the school is one of the best.  Each family has a right to get involved and make their child's school better.

eschoicesets_comment: I think it is important that parents have predictability about where their children would go to school. Choice sets do not provide sufficient predictability. The system should retain the right to attend one's neighborhood school. Further, I think the ability to be able to be admitted to an out of boundary school via the lottery should be preserved for all students. Some families may not feel like any of the options in their choice set are the right fit for their child(ren).
mschoicesets_comment: Once again, I think that students should be able to access out of boundary schools through the lottery, as well as have a right to attend a specific school in boundary.
msproximity_comment: I think students should have guaranteed access to a specific school and also have the ability to apply to out of boundary schools through the lottery.
hslottery_comment: I think students should have the right to have access to a specific school, as well as access to out of boundary schools through the lottery.

address: 46XX MARTIN LUTHER KING JR AVENUE SW
boundaries_comment: My child currently does not attend an in boundary school
feederpatterns_comment: So not like the high school in my boundary.

boundaries_comment: Although it appears to be a small change it impacts the diversity of the Murch community. A number of apartment buildings on Connecticut Avenue would no longer feed into Murch; effectively making the school whiter and wealthier. We purposely chose Murch for it's large Asian community with number of the embassy placed families in these apartment buildings from China and Vietnam. This change would eliminate this entire population.
hslottery_comment: We'll be moving if this happens; either private school or to the 'burbs.

boundaries_comment: Data suggesting Lafayette's population will shrink by over 400 while surrounding schools will grow is faulty at best.
msproximity_comment: Brightwood is already at capacity and the crosstown commute is not well served by transit and will double my morning time in a car if I drive.
hslottery_comment: Any change to my current HS means traveling a long distance to go to a significantly worse school.
setasides_comment: Set asides make sense if there is a safe way to move the kids to a better school.

feederpatterns_comment: Curious about a new middle school option and how it would work and we have 12 years until high school so Cardozo might be an option by then.
eschoicesets_comment: We are currently only interested in our in boundary school out of the schools in our choice set so this makes things worse for us.
mschoicesets_comment: So no actual choice as there is only one school on our list and it currently doesn't exist.
msproximity_comment: I guess adding an even more unacceptable option is technically giving me more choices.
hslottery_comment: We are 12 years out from high school.  Currently we don't see Cardozo as an option so losing a spot there isn't a concern, but in a decade things could be different.
setasides_comment: This seems like creating another lottery within certain schools and how will specific students be chosen?

boundaries_comment: Because Oyster-Adams is a specialized program, an alternative should be offered for students for whom a bilingual immersion program would not be advised. An example would be a 4th Grader new to the neighborhood.
feederpatterns_comment: An alternative should be provided for students for whom a bilingual immersion program is not advised. The change in high school assignment would take this neighborhood out of the boundary of a higher performing school and send students to a lower performing school. There also are significant transportation barriers to reaching Cardozo from Woodley Park. Wilson is easily accessible by the Metro red line (3 stops away with no change of trains) and several bus lines.
eschoicesets_comment: The proposal does not specify how siblings would be treated. Siblings should be in the same school.
mschoicesets_comment: Choice in middle school is needed but the proposal induces too much unpredictability. The city does not currently have enough strong middle schools to make this a workable option.
msproximity_comment: Hardy is a less performing school than Deal.
hslottery_comment: The city does not have enough high performing high schools to make this a viable option. The best students will go to the magnet/application schools or leave DCPS.
setasides_comment: The receiving school needs to be sure to get additional resources when it takes in lower performing students so the high performing program and students already at the school are not adversely affected.

boundaries_comment: I don't think Murch should lose some of our boundary and then take on some of Janneys.
feederpatterns_comment: I have kids in all three schools currently and am glad the feeder pattern stays the same for my family. We have worked hard in and with cur schools for years.
eschoicesets_comment: Choice sets are a bad idea. This set are all excellent schools, for which I  grateful , but you lose the walk ability, the predictability, neighborhood school.  Many choice sets in the city are either unequal or three poorly performing schools-these don't really work for anyone.
mschoicesets_comment: Choice sets at middle school  break up cohorts right when kids are insecure, emotionally unstable. I think there could be ramifications when kids move on without their cohort. I've seen it with friends in NY, which loses neighborhood schools after elementary.
msproximity_comment: My kids could walk one block, or get across the park to get to school? No thank you. Neighborhood schools please!
hslottery_comment: I am completely opposed to a citywide lottery for schools.
setasides_comment: I support set asides and out of boundary spaces, abdutely.

boundaries_comment: I live on the 3700 block of Chesapeake Street and am 2 blocks away from Murch.  This proposed plan sends me to the third closest school, a mile away and the lowest performing school out of the three closest schools.  Hearst is not my neighborhood school.  Once Hearst finishes its renovation, it will probably begin to gain enrollment from its traditional feeding pattern.  Yes, Murch is currently overcrowded but it too is awaiting renovation which will increase capacity.  If a dividing line is needed, Albemarle is a much more sensible point which does not divide the neighborhood quite as badly.
eschoicesets_comment: These schools are not in my neighborhood.  They would all entail a car ride rather than a short walk to school.  They are lower performing schools than Murch.  It is unreasonable to include Oyster with its specialized population needs for bilingual students in a choice set.
mschoicesets_comment: Again, I am 2 blocks from Deal and at least 2 miles away from Hardy.  I would like to have guaranteed access to a general middle school in my neighborhood.  The performing arts curricula at Hardy never appealed to any of my kids and I would not want to be forced to accept it.  Choice sets would also add to the disruption of the transition from elementary school to middle school.  While a family might choose to place their student in a school with fewer of their elementary school peers, I believe that it is helpful for most students to be accompanied by their classmates as they make the transition to a new school and the middle school curricula.  It is also very important for the parents to have a community of peers as their kids move on.  It is very helpful to know who you can reach out to to compare notes and check on progress.  This is much harder if elementary school groups are jumbled and sent to different schools.
msproximity_comment: This is a false choice.  The choice presented between Deal and Oyster is not a reasonable option.  Oyster has a very specialized program that would be harmed by the influx of students who have not been studying Spanish.  It is also a very small program.  I do not know which campus the middle schoolers would be sent to, but this option is even farther away.  Choice sets would need to include 2 schools with similar curricula and extra curricular activities.  There is no comparison between Deal and Oyster for families who want a general and not a language-centric program.
hslottery_comment: This option would be disastrous for both DCPS and DC.  First, let me say that every family and student deserves a high quality option in their own neighborhood.  It is unfortunate that those options do not currently exist right now.  I believe that a city wide lottery and no guaranteed access to a neighborhood school would cause flight from both DCPS and DC in general.  Families have bought or rented houses on the basis of the existing school feeding pattern.  If guaranteed access disappears, more families will move out of the district or find other school options than DCPS.  It will cause more students to be spending hours a day getting to and from their schools.  It will destroy school communities and PTAs because the networks of parents from the feeder schools will be disrupted. If this option is adopted, it will probably result in more applications to the magnet school programs from high achieving white students.  The likely result is the displacement of black/brown students from those schools and a lessening of options for those very students who are trying to find more demanding school options.

boundaries_comment: I don't understand where they're getting their data. Why is Lafayette the ONLY school in DC predicted to decrease in population? It is one of the top elem. schools in one of the most desirable neighborhoods. There is no way the school age population is decreasing in this neighborhood.

eschoicesets_comment: How ironic to call this nonsense "choice sets" when you don't actually have a choice. The commute to two of these schools is inconvenient and irrational.
mschoicesets_comment: Again, more stupidity. There is no "choice" in a lottery system. Kids should go to school in their neighborhood.

boundaries_comment: Please please please don't rezone the apartment buildings on Connecticut out of Murch.  Those students, including many international families, add so much to the school.
feederpatterns_comment: If it ain't broke don't fix it should be a fundamental principle in all this.
eschoicesets_comment: This particular choice set might be the only one in the entire city that would actually work (because all 3 schools are about the same, people would generally choose the school closest to their homes and it would generally give people and actual choice).  But this is a really terrible idea with a dishonest name (it's a mini-lottery not a choice).
mschoicesets_comment: I live 3 blocks from Deal.  Everyone is going to want to go to Deal but not everyone will be able to.  We would potentially be forced from a better school to a worse school.  Plus the traffic on Wisconsin Ave is bad enough, this would make it worse.
msproximity_comment: See above
hslottery_comment: Less crazy at the high school level, but still a really bad idea.
setasides_comment: But for the overcrowding problems, I would be in favor of this.  But DCPS does not give our school enough resources for the teachers to effectively differentiate as it is and some kids could get really hurt by this.  My kids would benefit from the added diversity.

eschoicesets_comment: I want to know where my kids will go to school and I want it to be easy for them to get there.
mschoicesets_comment: I want to know where my kids will go to school and I want it to be easy for them to get there.
msproximity_comment: I want to know where my kids will go to school and I want it to be easy for them to get there.  I also want to understand how the city will guarantee the quality of experience, academically and socially (eg sports, after school activities, etc) at Brightwood as is currently offered at Deal.
hslottery_comment: I want to know where my kids will go to school and I want it to be easy for them to get there.
setasides_comment: It is not clear what is meant here.  Would set asides basically do the same thing as the current lottery, only save space for lottery kids?  Don't Lafayette, Deal, and Wilson already have somewhere around 15% out of boundary kids?  Seems like this is not a bad interim idea, but does not address the problem of why are there under performing schools in the first place.

feederpatterns_comment: I do not want to lose the opportunity for Eaton to feed to Deal. If you do decide to do this please grandfather all existing students.
eschoicesets_comment: This is a VERY BAD idea. It removes all predictability for parents and students and makes deciding to buy a home much harder. For my neighborhood the choices are all good, but for many neighborhoods that's not the case at all.
mschoicesets_comment: Not a good idea. You remove all predictability of the current system, which is a major factor when deciding where to live and buy a house. Just the fact that DCPS is reorganizing the boundaries has made me delay purchasing a house so I have to option to move or leave the District if necessary for my child's education.
msproximity_comment: Bad idea. This remove predictability of the current system, which is a major factor when deciding where to live and buy a house. Just the fact that DCPS is reorganizing the boundaries has made me delay purchasing a house so I have to option to move or leave the District if necessary for my child's education.
hslottery_comment: This is the WORST of all the very bad ideas. There's NO predictability at all for where a student will go or that they will go to a school that's any good. You'd have students shuttling all over the city, which is a huge waste of time for kids who are already stressed out and overburdened with the pressure of high school. Their friends would be scattered geographically. The opportunities for problematic behavior expand massively it's difficult to believe the Advisory Committee is even floating this idea. If there were a frown face that was even less happy than the most unhappy one shown above, I would click on that one.
setasides_comment: First of all, this does nothing for the kids in the mass of substandard schools that aren't at the very bottom. Second, this pushes out neighborhood kids in the oversubscribed schools. All you're doing is playing musical chairs to create the illusion that people with crappy neighborhood schools may have a shot at getting into a better one, but for every seat to offer to a student of a low-performing school, you push out another kid. It's a zero sum game. You're not improving schools: it's just a magician's illusion, a three-card monte.

boundaries_comment:
Maury (where my son is currently enrolled) is much closer than Miner.

Please don't create boundaries down the middle of roads. This splits communities.
eschoicesets_comment: This would turn a household that relies on one car into a two-car household. It would also take away the neighborhood school as a focal point of the community.
hslottery_comment: Horrible.

boundaries_comment: Kids should go to school in their neighborhood.
eschoicesets_comment: No "choice" in a lottery. Are they serious?
mschoicesets_comment: This is ridiculous. Hardy is not as high performing as Deal. And would be a commuting nightmare. Kids should go to school in their neighborhood. Fix the lower performing schools instead!
msproximity_comment: Again, no choice in "choice sets."  It's a lottery!!!! How ironic.
hslottery_comment: Complete insanity. And stupidity.  Are they smoking crack?
setasides_comment: Fix the lower performing schools instead. What makes Lafayette and Deal high performing are the parents in the neighborhood. Fire the low performing teachers. They are everywhere.

feederpatterns_comment: Predictable schools are a must for a strong school and strong community.

feederpatterns_comment: I like neighborhood schools.

eschoicesets_comment: I do not support "choice sets".  If we live within walking distance of a school, my children should be guaranteed placement at that school.  For us, that's Janney.
mschoicesets_comment: I do not support "choice sets".  If we live within walking distance of a school, my children should be guaranteed placement at that school.  For us, that's Deal.
msproximity_comment: I do not support "choice sets".  If we live within walking distance of a school, my children should be guaranteed placement at that school.
hslottery_comment: This is unbelievably horrible idea, for more reasons that I can include in this survey.  If other schools are underperforming, they should be fixed.  Wilson is a good school for many reasons, but one of those reasons is because parents are actively involved in the school.  Dispersing to all corners of the City the neighborhood kids who now attend Wilson will destroy that community involvement and leave Wilson far worse than it is now.  If this policy is enacted, we will move, with our two daughters, across Western Ave. to Montgomery County.
setasides_comment: I have no problem with this policy provided it does not negatively affect our neighborhood schools or result in displacement of any students currently assigned to those schools.

mschoicesets_comment: prefer to keep our middle school as Deal

feederpatterns_comment: All students should be able to go to their neighborhood school. Make all DC schools high achieving so that children don't have to leave their neighborhoods.

mschoicesets_comment: Hardy would take too long to get to by public transportation and does not have a comparable reputation to Deal.
msproximity_comment: Again, would want to be assured of comparable programs at both schools. That might not be realistic.

boundaries_comment: It's why we bought a house in this neighborhood!
feederpatterns_comment: Once again, we bought our house last year to be part of this feeder pattern.

msproximity_comment: Traveling across town to underperforming schools is a horrible thought.

eschoicesets_comment: The choices are all good schools, but I believe spreading out students from a single neighborhood across 3 schools is unnecessary and harmful. Nextdoor neighbors could be in different schools and community bonding would suffer.

hslottery_comment: Idiotic. It does nothing to improve schools.

boundaries_comment: Good school, close to home, neighborhood stays intact.  What is not to like?

eschoicesets_comment: While the schools themselves are all good schools, the benefits of a neighborhood community would be lost.  It is really special to know kids at the park and ball teams from the neighborhood, to know who your children's friends are and know their parents, to let the kids walk to playdates, etc.  We also need to minimize commuting - DC roads are a nightmare already.
mschoicesets_comment: The benefits of a neighborhood community would be lost.  It is really special to know kids at the park and ball teams from the neighborhood, to know who your children's friends are and know their parents, to let the kids walk to playdates, etc.  We also need to minimize commuting - DC roads are a nightmare already and getting to and from Georgetown at school drop off time would add about 1.5 hours of travelling to our family's day.
msproximity_comment: A difficult commute - adding about 1.5 hours of travel time to our family's day - with a significant drop in test scores, and loss of neighborhood community -  make that unappealing in every way.

setasides_comment: What happens when schools are overcrowded or at capacity already?  I would also want to see the students involved in any set-aside or out-of-boundary placement held to a commitment to be assets to the school to which they want to go.  They need to 1) attend regularly, 2) stay out of disciplinary trouble, and 3) be willing and able to stay for extra academic help (which the school should be willing and able to provide) if they are struggling.  Any student who cannot commit (and whose parents cannot commit) to these 3 things could be a potential drain on the school to which the student wants to go and should not be eligible for the set-aside.

boundaries_comment: I will move out of DC before I will go to Noyes. I would send my kids to Burroughs, though, currently in-boundary for us.

mschoicesets_comment: My "choice set" has one school in it?
msproximity_comment: I'd do Burroughs.

setasides_comment: I don't understand how this would work. Meaning, I would be able to choose a different school in the city-wide lottery?

boundaries_comment: This is very good for us because we will remain in walking distance of our school and can send our children to our NEIGHBORHOOD school.
feederpatterns_comment: This is very good because we can send our children to the middle and high schools that are closest to our home and require the shortest commute.
eschoicesets_comment: Although all the schools in this proposed choice set are strong, I am opposed to choice sets. Parents and students want predictability not illusions of choice. DCPS should put its resources toward bettering schools across the city rather than creating more bureaucracy through lotteries, choice sets, etc. This increase in "choice" will create more anxiety, decrease in trust of the system, and could cause more families to leave the city.
mschoicesets_comment: See above comment.
hslottery_comment: All families from all parts of the city want predictability NOT stress and anxiety related to public schooling. Improve all high schools across the city. Yet these schools systems are making it work without resorting to market-based education reforms, without an increasing reliance on charter schools, without relying on under-qualified Teacher for America teachers. Why can't DCPS follow suit?
setasides_comment: This is very  important but should create a situation where students might not be able to attend their neighborhood school.

boundaries_comment: I am worried that with the popularity of Ross and the number of families with young children moving to the neighborhood that Ross will NOT be able to handle the inbound children.
feederpatterns_comment: Some schools are better than others, so you may with or lose this one.
eschoicesets_comment: MAny of us move in order for our children to attend a specific school, this new plan would make that pointless since a lottery would ultimately be the decider due to such descrepencies in quality of schools.
setasides_comment: Unfair to the other 80%.

mschoicesets_comment: We are very happy with this option.

boundaries_comment: This is a horrible proposal and would only cause further decline of our neighborhood school.  Also, currently the Bloomingdale neighborhood is part of the boundary for Langley Elementary (I'm not sure why the current boundary map does not reflect this).  Bloomingdale and Eckington share a large, common boundary along North Capitol street that serves as a strong tie between these communities.  This proposal would split those communities.
eschoicesets_comment: These are ridiculous "choices" for our neighborhood.  They are geographically incredibly inaccessible to our neighborhood, thereby, no real choice.
mschoicesets_comment: Again, a horrible suggestion.  Brookland EC is nowhere near or at all accessible to the Eckington community.

boundaries_comment: The combination of Crestwood and Petworth is dynamic.  It is working for Powell and generating results for diverse populations.  Why would you mess with that?!?!?!  However I am happy to stay in Powell.
feederpatterns_comment: I am excited about the possibility of a new neighborhood middle school.
eschoicesets_comment: This is absolutely crazy.  I will lodge a sit in to stop this.  We live on the SAME BLOCK as Powell.  How are you going to stop someone from sending their kids to the school ON THEIR BLOCK.  this is outrageous.  Absolutely outrageous.
mschoicesets_comment: If there are going to be choice sets, at least please give us the option of seeing which is better between two schools.  But I oppose choice sets so ok with this I guess.
msproximity_comment: I highly prefer the new neighborhood middle school.
hslottery_comment: Once it is time for high school and being close to home matters less for a child's development, I think equality should triumph!  For the lower years, this does not make sense, but for HS it seems okay.

boundaries_comment: This change seems reasonable.  Others in my neighborhood wonder why our in-bound school is not closer to our address.
feederpatterns_comment: A new middle school and an updated Roosevelt High School will be great for Ward 4.
eschoicesets_comment: I think this works against the goal of establishing a community through your neighborhood school and is unnecessary since any family can attempt to lottery into schools outside of their boundary.
mschoicesets_comment: I think this works against the goal of establishing a community through your neighborhood school and is unnecessary since any family can attempt to lottery into schools outside of their boundary.
msproximity_comment: I need to look into this more.
hslottery_comment: It is important to have neighborhood options for many reasons.

Can low-performing applicants still lottery in or are they excluded beyond the required quota?

boundaries_comment: Luckily it doesn't affect me, but I wouldn't be happy to change to Hearst. And I know people that moved to a certain house because of the school they were getting and they are really unhappy with this change.
We like being in the Janney catchment area.
feederpatterns_comment: We like this feeder pattern very much.
eschoicesets_comment: These are all good schools, but we prefer knowing for certain that our children will attend Janney.
mschoicesets_comment: We prefer knowing for certain that our children will attend Deal.
msproximity_comment: These are both good schools, but we prefer Deal.
hslottery_comment: This makes no sense in terms of building community spirit and will cause many people to move out of the District to Maryland and Virginia.
setasides_comment: D.C. should make these low-performing schools better.

boundaries_comment: It would really bring the neighborhood together.

feederpatterns_comment: Since my child currently does not attend Ludlow Taylor, the additional zoning of Walker Jones is upsetting. eschoicesets_comment: This is awful. While I do not love my IB school, at least it is walking distance from home, which is so important, and many members of my immediate community attend. mschoicesets_comment: Same as above.
msproximity_comment: This will only mean that the better school will fill up, often with families who live rather far away, and the rest will go elsewhere. If we don't have neighborhood schools here I am concerned that we are going to see more school decline.

feederpatterns_comment: In favor of this new feeder pattern
