feederpatterns_comment: It totally depends on the quality and facilities of the new middle school envisioned.
eschoicesets_comment: We live a block and a half (less than 2/10 of a mile) from Ross Elementary...I don't understand how it could not be considered a part of our proposed choice set.
mschoicesets_comment: Depends on the quality of the new middle school.
hslottery_comment: completely eliminating the connection between neighborhood and school seems weird and unhelpful

feederpatterns_comment: There's no information here for me to compare - it's all missing.
mschoicesets_comment: There's no school to comment on - it just says "new school."

boundaries_comment: I am ecstatic.  Both of our children currently go to Marie Reed, but only got in via out-of-boundary lottery.  Many of our neighbors also go to Reed, so this redrawn boundary makes sense to me.  Plus I would LOVE to be in-bounds for Reed -- I think it would raise the value of my home!
feederpatterns_comment: Both the old and revised feeder pattern for our middle and high school is bleak.  We will almost certainly bail out of the DCPS system and into charters/private schools after 5th grade.
eschoicesets_comment: Better than just being in-bounds for a substandard school and taking your chances with everyone else in the lottery for one of the nearby options.  But we much prefer the redrawn school boundary that gives us a guaranteed seat at Reed.
mschoicesets_comment: Would need MUCH more information regarding the "planned new middle school."
msproximity_comment: Neither of these is an acceptable option for my children.  We would go charter/private instead.
hslottery_comment: I kind of like this because it means the EOTP and SE/NE kids would have as much chance as anyone at getting into the few good high schools.
setasides_comment: Sounds great!  Anything that extends our years in DCPS is a good change from our perspective.  The only better option would be to elevate our assigned school (Cardozo) from terrifying to excellent, but I'm not going to be the one who sacrifices my children during that transition.

boundaries_comment: The boundaries for Tyler are somewhat meaningless since it houses a magnet program (Spanish immersion) that draws students from all over the city.
feederpatterns_comment: of the current in-boundary students attending Tyler now, most of them would be challenged to walk or take public transportation to Jefferson in SW. Eliot-Hine is reachable on foot or bike by a middle schooler.  Jefferson is not.
eschoicesets_comment: This would create a very interesting dynamic - but again, the families seeking Tyler do so for Spanish Immersion instruction. It is not a fair swap to trade a seat in an all-Spanish language classroom for a seat in English-only Friendship or Brent.
mschoicesets_comment: This could be an interesting idea in terms of letting families make some decisions about middle school nearby. It does not address the transportation issues facing Jefferson from SE DC.
msproximity_comment: I've never heard of Kramer. It wouldn't be an option for my kids.
hslottery_comment: The city already runs application-only high schools.  Kids who cannot get into those schools should have a solid, reachable, high school in their neighborhood. It seems disruptive to tell a child living near Eastern that they were assigned to go to Cardozo or some other high school on the other side of town.
setasides_comment: Seems like a fair option for those students who can't get into the application-only high schools but face an undesirable in-boundary high school assignment.

boundaries_comment: I am only concerned that Maury, which is over capacity now in the lower grades would not be able to handle the additional students in the new boundaries no matter how few, even 5-6 more kids in kindergarten would be an impact on limited resources at Maury and our expected school renovation/ addition keeps being delayed.
mschoicesets_comment: This type of choice set would make more sense to me at this age rather than elementary school.  It would be hard though given the big distance between Elliott Hine and Jefferson to feel like a neighborhood/community school.  Also it feels strange to have to try to figure out your child's focus by the time they are in 5th grade and what happens if you really wanted science but don't get in and you are placed in the two language school and it is a really bad academic fit?
msproximity_comment: I feel like this world continue to create the same problem.  More people would continue to choose Stuart Hobson because Hine hasn't been given the resources to be a better school.  More people would be allowed to attempt to go to Stuart Hobson who are not able to now (like us) but I feel like those who didn't get on would go the charter route or private and you are back to the same issue of having the struggling school on the edge if the neighborhood be considered not an option by many.  I do like that we would get a shot at Stuart Hobson though.
hslottery_comment: I have a hard time understanding how this would work but am indifferent to loosing preferential treatment at Eastern as I currently don't consider this an option for my daughters.
setasides_comment:
Not enough seats at high(er) performing schools to make a difference.  Need to make more school better rather than "busing" students in to higher performing schools.  I feel like there would be more losers in this option. And not enough attention to getting better choices close to people's homes.

I have a final comment which is not specific to a question.  Why are charter middle schools allowed to start in 5th grade??? This makes parents feel like they have to leave their neighborhood school early and not really feel like they can wait to see if they can get into a decent dcps middle school.  I think this undermines the parental influence necessary to create good middle schools.  This would be exacerbated  by the choice group option because if you are afraid you won't get into the specialty you want you will focus on getting your child into a charter like basis or Latin rather than waiting until the lottery for 6th grade.

boundaries_comment: Mine does not change
eschoicesets_comment: I would prefer avoiding a lottery.
mschoicesets_comment:
I don't want my children to go to a school not performing at top level,  as is Deal.
I don't want lottery. It is not fair. It took everything we could pull together to move here to guarantee our children get good schools to go to. We live in a house too small but are willing to sacrifice space for right of school.

boundaries_comment: We have invested in Powell and specifically choose this neighborhood house and school.
eschoicesets_comment: Too much uncertainty. These schools need a lot of work and investment and all the uncertainty makes it hard for a community to make change.
mschoicesets_comment: We need to IMPROVE schools not always create new ones that have the same problems after their first 5 years..

boundaries_comment: Boundary change doesn't affect me.
feederpatterns_comment: None of these schools are attractive to me.
eschoicesets_comment: None of these schools are attractive to me.
mschoicesets_comment: I'm not familiar with this school.
msproximity_comment: Neither of these schools is attractive to me.
hslottery_comment: While I would never attend my in-bounds school, were I to move to a neighborhood with a good high school, I would be furious to not have access to that school.
setasides_comment:
Set-asides are a great idea as long as they don't force out in-bounds students.
Set-asides are a great way to ensure that all schools share the burden of out-of-bounds students, in order to cope with low-performing schools. It is not fair that some schools currently have out-of-bounds enrollment under 5%.

hslottery_comment: Terrible idea. We need to keep neighborhood schools.

feederpatterns_comment: I like the fact that we will now feed to Burroughs since it is so close and doing well.  But the feeding to Dunbar makes no sense to me.  Brookland Middle School is still being built and hopefully the programs and solid teachers will draw families but it is an unknown.  I think under enrolled Roosevelt with some new programs and support could be a much better option  or even Coolidge.  But Dunbar has done nothing to make itself attractive to families in Brookland.
eschoicesets_comment:
there don't seem to be any real 'choices' in this set.   and if it's just  lottery anyway it's not really a 'choice set' to begin with.

Nothing stands out as different between the campuses yet. Burroughs is a STEM school and this might be good however, STEM should really be a part of every school so how will the schools differentiate themselves? What will make parents want to choose one over the other?  Will there be special programs at each school? These are not yet identified.
mschoicesets_comment: again, no real choices have been identified. There's just one school on this list.  While it will be new, it's not a proven entity yet.
hslottery_comment: could make for a very interesting city experiment but also cause some families to leave because of too much uncertainty_sort of what we have now anyway given the current lottery for charters and out of boundary students or the magnets such as Walls and Ellington.  I like this idea given that I don't think Dunbar is a good option but I could end up in an even worse one_so it's a gamble.
setasides_comment: obviously yes. Because I don't think Dunbar is a good fit for my kid.  She'll be going to Walls in the fall and would not consider Dunbar.

feederpatterns_comment: Cardozo remains a problem but the possibility of a new middle school is encouraging. having middle school kids in Cardozo is a non-starter with most (if not all) parents in the neighborhood who are invested in their kids education.
eschoicesets_comment: For some neighborhoods where one school is overcrowded and others are not (for example Ross and the surrounding schools or Hearst and the surrounding schools) this could make sense, but in our neighborhood it seems like a solution in search of a problem. None of the elementary schools are overcrowded with neighborhood kids and the uncertainty around which school one's kids might attend would likely discourage people from investing in their neighborhood school early on.  Plus one inducement to take a chance on a Title 1 school is a short commute.  THat short commute could not be guaranteed under choice sets.
mschoicesets_comment: If they made one of these options a test-in middle school with advanced coursework, I would support this.
msproximity_comment: This seems like a reasonable way to deal with overcrowding at Deal, but I;m not sure why it is necessary in my neighborhood.
hslottery_comment: This seems crazy. DC does not have good enough public transportation to make this work.
setasides_comment: I think this is a good policy in terms of encouraging diversity, but you would have to make it clear how you would make room for these kids at schools in Ward 3 that are already totally overcrowded.

boundaries_comment: As stated, these are already the boundaries in practice.
feederpatterns_comment: We would welcome the change to our high school- more consistent and more familiar to us.
eschoicesets_comment: No thanks. I want my kids in the same school that our next door neighbors' kids go to. It fosters community, and makes it easier for families to support one another.
mschoicesets_comment: Again, I want a true neighborhood school for my kids where they are with children they went to elementary school with. I think the opportunity too have our kids together at least through eighth grade is part of creating a supportive and effective learning environment.
msproximity_comment: The alternate school in this scenario is not part of the neighborhood I live in. Again, I don't like the choice set idea. Right now I feel connected to the middle school that my kids should feed into in a few years. We frequently participate in activities to support Stuart - Hobson. I don't think we'd feel as committed to DCPS or to staying in DC if this level of uncertainty were introduced.
hslottery_comment: Unless my kid gets into an application only high school, I'm not very interested in having them travel to get to school.
setasides_comment: The real solution is to fix these low performing schools that no one wants to go to. The only non-application high school anyone is interested in seems to be Wilson. My best option should be the high school in my neighborhood. This "choice" b.s. only obscures the obvious issue. We wouldn't be talking about choice sets and set asides if DCPS functioned as it should.

eschoicesets_comment: Assuming the ultimate goal is to create stronger schools overall (i.e. more of them), I believe that creating balanced diversity (economic, ethnic, etc) rather than unbalanced "diversity" (i.e. 70% free and reduced lunch compared with 50% free and reduced lunch, or 70% Latino, 20% African American, 10% Caucasion compared with 35% Latino, 30% African American, 25% Caucasion, 10% other - the latter choices considered "balanced") is one major factor contributing to inequality across schools. In most neighborhoods, the choice set only perpetuates the current problem and provides kids at low performing schools the option of 3 low-performing schools, or kids at high performing schools, the option of 3 high-performing schools. It does not address the underlying issues.
mschoicesets_comment:
Somewhat similar to my comment above for elementary choice sets, but more likely to create balanced diversity over the longer-term given there are fewer schools to choose between, thus strongly encouraging people who were less likely to choose a school perceived as low-performing to actually choose it, hopefully increasing the positive balance in diversity. But if my only choices were two low-performing schools (not the case for me personally) I would not be happy.

And, short term, and from a personal, not macro-education perspective, Deal is a much better school than Hardy, although the latter has potential, and one presumably wants the best education for their child.
msproximity_comment: The closest schools to me are not strong schools, and do not have a balance of diversity. On a macro level, that is likely true for many DC neighborhoods, thus giving people the choice between two low-performing schools, which isn't much choice really at all.
hslottery_comment:
1. Positive - Potential to create more balanced diversity at the already "strong" schools, drawing from people across the city.
2. Negative - Will not create more balanced diversity at the low-performing schools as many people (myself included) would find another option, although who knows what that would be, rather than send my child to a low performing school.
3. Negative - I don't want my child going to a school in Anacostia or similar neighborhood, just because it is the one he got in the lottery.
setasides_comment: I believe "set asides" could help create more balanced diversity in schools over the long term. However it ultimately depends which option it is paired with, i.e. choice sets, closest, lottery, etc.
Yes, please!! There are no tenable middle or high school options where we live.

boundaries_comment: We love Lafayette and it's why we purchased our house in this neighborhood (along with the Avalon Theater and the E bus line).  Our daughter is thriving at this school, and we love being a part of the Lafayette neighborhood community.
feederpatterns_comment: We are looking forward to sending our child to Deal and Wilson.  If this were to change, we would likely move to Maryland.  We do not want to leave Washington DC, but having our daughter attend a public neighborhood school is our top priority.
eschoicesets_comment: We want to remain in the Lafayette boundary.  We want our child to go to school with other neighborhood kids.   The lack of predictability offered by the choice set plan would drive us to Maryland.
mschoicesets_comment: We want to remain in the Lafayette/Deal feeder  pattern.  We want our child to go to school with the neighborhood kids.   The lack of predictability offered by the choice set plan would drive us to Maryland.
msproximity_comment: We would not drive our child across Rock Creek park in traffic every morning when Deal is so close to our house.  Guaranteed access to a close neighborhood public school is the most important factor in our decision about where we live.  If we cannot have this right in Washington DC, we will have to move to Maryland so we could send our daughter to school without uncertainty and anxiety.
hslottery_comment: The citywide lottery would be the worst possible thing that could happen to our child, our family, and Washington DC.  It would create anxiety-provoking uncertainty, snarling traffic as children criss-cross the city to schools that are farther from their houses, and plummeting housing prices as families scrambled to escape the city.  This plan would also eliminate any sort of neighborhood communities, which develop around schools.  Anyone who cares about our city would not force us to live in this confusing system that would destroy communities that are now working.
setasides_comment: low performing schools should be improved.  we would support any plan that involved allocating more of our taxes to this purpose.

feederpatterns_comment: This is what we have now and what we want going forward. We want to live in the District. We want our children to attend public school. We value neighborhood schools and predictability. We also don't want anything less than what we signed up for when we moved here.
eschoicesets_comment: All three of these schools are good elementary schools, but we want our children to attend the school in our neighborhood. It is why we moved here.
mschoicesets_comment: Again, we moved here so our children could attend school in our neighborhood and so our children could attend Deal MS. The other MS in the proposed choice set is not at all close and is inferior to Deal. Why would we stay if our children could end up with something much less desirable than what we have now? Moreover, the idea of the "special focus" schools appears not to have been fully fleshed out and at this point seems like just that, "an idea."  There should be far more discussion about the benefits (and drawbacks) of having a special focus for each school, and what it would mean in practice.  It's also not clear how the "special focus" would work in a lottery system - what if you want a STEM focus but get the language focus school in the lottery?
msproximity_comment: Again, we moved here so our children could attend the school IN OUR NEIGHBORHOOD and so our children could attend Deal MS. Moreover, the other "closest" MS is not close and is vastly inferior to Deal. Why would we stay in the District if our children have a 50/50 chance of ending up there?
hslottery_comment: It's hard to even respond to this proposal. First of all, we moved here because Wilson is the public high school so we would be hard pressed to consider staying if that was not guaranteed. But beyond that, is there any evidence that a citywide lottery would result in improvement? What is the educational argument for this approach? All I can come up with are the negatives -- lack of cohesion, zero predictability, increased logistical challenges and costs (for the city, for families and kids). You now have families opting out at middle school because they don't like their options - you would even more opting out (or moving out) with this approach.

boundaries_comment: Although we are pleased that our home school remains the same as it was when we bought our home, since Murch was one of the reasons we purchased it, we remain concerned that there is no plan to address 1) structural and technological upgrades needed at Murch and 2) structural, technological and instructional upgrades needed at low-achieving schools throughout the City.
feederpatterns_comment: Although we are pleased that our home school feeder pattern remains the same as it was when we bought our home, we remain concerned that there is no plan to address 1) structural and technological upgrades needed at Murch, 2) structural, technological and instructional upgrades needed at low-achieving schools throughout the City and 3) there is no plan to increase and strengthen engagement of each community at ALL schools in DCPS.
eschoicesets_comment: We are interested in increasing the diversity in our school, to reflect the diversity in the City, while maintaining the high engagement of all stakeholders: the staff, students, parents and community.
mschoicesets_comment: No one wants to have their child be part of an experiment, when it comes to education. Middle school is a critical period, academically, socially and emotionally in a child's life that requires academic rigor with appropriate supports and creative, compassionate and committed staff members. Do Hardy and Deal have those required components?
msproximity_comment: Brightwood EC is not close to our home. We purchased our home, with the current feeder pattern in mind.
hslottery_comment: We purchased our home, with the current feeder pattern in mind.
setasides_comment: Why should a child go to school far away from his or her neighborhood? Doesn't every child have the right to an academically rigorous, safe, engaging and thriving school in their own neighborhood? Where is the plan for that?

boundaries_comment: There are many advantages to maintaining lower class sizes in schools were students are struggling academically.  Efforts need to be made to maintain this in order to boost an 85%+ number of students who are falling far below the proficiency rate in math and reading.
feederpatterns_comment: Being a middle school administrator, I find that developmentally elementary students and middle schoolers should be separated period!
eschoicesets_comment: I support the choice process based on an identified program for example language immersion, math, science or technology or the arts.  Choice for the sake of the perception of a better school means the system does not value rigorous academic instruction at all schools.
mschoicesets_comment: Totally support this initiative!  Same should be for elementary.
msproximity_comment: Again middle school students should have their own school. Do away with the K-8 model.
hslottery_comment: Based upon current data, Coolidge HS needs significant restructuring.  A solid academic program including remedial preparation is desperately needed. It appears that currently the same under-performing students are getting passed through from ES, MS (LaSalle)to HS with the same deficits.
setasides_comment: Address the issue of low performing schools within the schools.  The problems will continue to exists if these types of transitions are allowed. Transfers should be based upon an identified family hardship, moves or special programs.

mschoicesets_comment: Just build another middle school.

boundaries_comment: Likely Decreases the model for 50/50 English Spanish speaking homes by including a higher % of English speaking families
feederpatterns_comment: Removing options of deal ms
eschoicesets_comment: Lottery takes away certainty
hslottery_comment: Decreases certainty

boundaries_comment: I think students in my neighborhood should continue to be able to walk to school.  Hearst is not in easy walking distance for the very young.  Why should our children be taken out of their neighborhood school? In addition, parents dropping their children off at school on their way to work would have to walk well over a mile to get to the Metro since the school is in one direction and the  Metro is in the opposite direction.
eschoicesets_comment: Eaton and Oyster Adams are no where near my home.  Janney is much closer than Hearst.  Murch is closer than Hearst.

boundaries_comment: We have been active with other Brent parents and our neighbors for many years to support Brent and turn it into an attractive school.  This whole-community effort has involved everything from independent fund raising to effective leadership through the PTA and LSAT committees to re-landscaping the school ourselves.  The fact that families are moving into the area is a sign of the Brent community's success.  It is also proof positive that a school community can make a difference, and that local schools cannot succeed without hard work and a lot of hours from its families and neighbors.  DCPS alone cannot make a school into a strong institution; it takes everyone.  We are proud of what has been accomplished at Brent and we are pleased to be able to remain in-bounds for it.
feederpatterns_comment:
Our plan is to remain with our chosen charter school for middle and high school.  We spent several years looking at the public school options.  Although we have great confidence in the principal at Jefferson, it will take a great deal of effort to make it into an attractive school, both physically (DCPS' promised funding was significantly reduced for Jefferson school improvements a couple years ago) and in terms of student performance. 

The charter we have chosen also has challenges, but the basic foundations for success, we believe, are there.  The school management is good, the teachers are excellent, the school sets reasonably high expectations for its students, and students (and their families) are held accountable for their performance.  Families that join this charter are motivated.  We simply were not seeing all these factors come together in our local DCPS options, so we opted out.  Had the charter not been there for us, we would have moved out of the district.
eschoicesets_comment: Strong school performance requires the involvement of the whole community - school administration, teachers, families, students, and the neighborhood.  As both a member of our school's community and as close neighbors of the school, we invested a lot in turning our local school around.  If it is considered a good school now, it's because the school community has earned it, and that has taken a great deal of work and dedication.  It would be unfair if our family were displaced from this school in a random lottery.  The unpredictability that this proposal introduces would certainly reduce our motivation to invest in our local school.
mschoicesets_comment: As noted above, this proposal would not change our plan to stick with the charter school option we have chosen.  If DCPS wants families to stick with its system, it has to give them real choices.  Giving them one or two or three ... or four or five ... unacceptable options is not going to change the game.  Motivated families will simply find a way to opt out of DCPS and seek other options.  If DCPS wants motivated families and students to participate in its system, it needs to understand what they want to achieve, and then find ways to help them achieve it.
msproximity_comment: Motivated students and their families will seek real options - not just the "best available" option - for school.  It does not matter how many schools DCPS offers a student, if they all are poor options.  If DCPS wants motivated families and students to participate in its system, it needs to understand what they want to achieve, and then find ways to help them achieve it.
hslottery_comment: So nobody would be able to predict where their student might go for high school, one of the most important and formative periods of their lives?  How is this a good choice?  It would simply de-motivate those living near a good high school from investing in the continued strength of that institution.  At the same time, no family would invest ahead in any high school because they would be completely unable to predict where their kid would go.

boundaries_comment: We are young DC homeowners in Mount Pleasant, and are much more likely to stay in the city if our children have guaranteed access to Bancroft ES, the traditional Mt Pleasant school. This would be a very positive change and we strongly support this proposal.
feederpatterns_comment: We live in Mount Pleasant, and having access to the traditional Mount Pleasant schools will have a big impact on whether we move out to the suburbs when our children reach school age. Like many young couples, we love the city and our neighborhood and want to stay, but will not likely do so due to the current school boundaries. If we can send our kids to Bancroft, Deal and Wilson, staying in the city is a much more viable and attractive option.

boundaries_comment: Hearst is a great local school.  It makes sense to even out the local populations between Murch and Hearst.  Our kids are now inbound from Murch but were attending Hearst, we opted to keep them at Hearst due to a great principal, teachers, smaller community and newly renovated building.
feederpatterns_comment: People have made enormous financial and life decisions based on these feeder patterns.  They also create a cohesive community.  It should not change.  If it does, it will cause many families to abandon DCPS or leave the district altogether.  It will not achieve everyone's goals of better schools for more kids.
eschoicesets_comment: Families want and need certainty.  We should create more excellent schools not more uncertainty.
mschoicesets_comment: Families want and need certainty.  We should create more excellent schools not more uncertainty.
msproximity_comment: Families want and need certainty.  We should create more excellent schools not more uncertainty.  In addition, this creates a burden on families that is totally unnecessary.  Currently my children plan to walk or ride bikes to school, if we were forced to attend the other school we would have to drive them everyday across the park.
hslottery_comment: Families want and need certainty.  We should create more excellent schools not more uncertainty.  People have made enormous financial and life decisions based on these feeder patterns.  They also create a cohesive community.  It should not change.  If it does, it will cause many families to abandon DCPS or leave the district altogether.  It will not achieve everyone's goals of better schools for more kids.
setasides_comment: I fully support finding more opportunities to attend good schools for those children who are currently feeding into poor performance schools, as well as investing more in those schools.  Creating set asides that don't displace inbound/neighbor children is a one good tool.

boundaries_comment: I am much closer to Langley Elementary.
feederpatterns_comment: I would much rather go to Dunbar. It is also just as close and it has college themed academies.
eschoicesets_comment: I am much closer to Langley Elementary.
mschoicesets_comment: There is McKinley Middle School nearby. Why am I not assigned to that?

eschoicesets_comment: Choice sets are a horrible idea.  They'll do nothing to improve weak schools, and will severely damage good schools.

boundaries_comment: Middle income families are going to leave Mt. Pleasant if the boundaries are redrawn to shut them out of current school choices.
feederpatterns_comment: We would want Wilson
eschoicesets_comment: We would want Bancroft
msproximity_comment: Those aren't good choices

feederpatterns_comment: My understanding is that was our existing feeder pattern.

boundaries_comment: I would be very happy to be zoned in Bancroft. My family needs a bilingual school
eschoicesets_comment: Schools should be assigned based on distance, not on lottery

boundaries_comment: I completely agree with this boundary change (although I am no affected by it). It adds a couple of streets that people consider as part of the Mount Pleasant neighbourhood and therefore helps define Bancroft as our neighbourhood school.
feederpatterns_comment: This feeder pattern is favourable. (I am not sure that the current feeder pattern is correct - I think that the feeder pattern includes CHEC and Deal/ Wilson).

Bancroft should keep its feeder status to Deal and Wilson. The reason Bancroft has improved significantly over the past several years is that the parents in the neighbourhood invested in their school and became more involved. One of the main reasons for the parental involvement is promise of entry to Deal and Wilson. If that changes, many families who moved into the neighbourhood will move to the suburbs with guaranteed access to good schools.
eschoicesets_comment: Parents want certainty when it comes to the most important choice they make. School choice and housing investment are two very important decisions a household makes. If my child does not have guaranteed access to our neighbourhood school, I am less likely to invest in the school and I am much more likely to start making plans to move out of the neighbourhood to the suburbs where I have guaranteed access to a very good school. Any plan that involves a lottery is a terrible choice for the city- especially given the past experiences of other cities that experimented with this dangerous policy tool.
mschoicesets_comment: Again- certainty is key for parents. If my child has 50% probability of attending a good school, i will chose a neighbourhood (likely outside DC) that gives my child access to a good school with 100% probability.
msproximity_comment: Again- certainty is key for parents. If my child has 50% probability of attending a good school, i will chose a neighbourhood (likely outside DC) that gives my child access to a good school with 100% probability.
hslottery_comment: Lottery will mean that the quality of EVERY school in DC will decrease. This has not worked in any city that has implemented it and its surprising that this idea is even entertained in DC. We should work on increasing the number of high quality schools. Lottery will decrease parental involvement in schools which has been a key positive ingredient in improving neighbourhood schools.

boundaries_comment: The problem at Cooke is with an administration that does not want to engage with parents. I do not think it will improve until there is a new principal, unfortunately, even though is has an amazing new building and a strong international baccalaureate curriculum.
feederpatterns_comment:
This is really terrible. First, Cooke is not dual language. Why would it feed to CHEC, which is entirely dual language. Cooke is IB so if anything a feed to Deal makes the most sense, which would also contribute to increased economic and racial diversity at Deal. Also, a feed to Deal and a new principal at Cooke would fundamentally change Cooke and make it more desirable.

The loss of Wilson is awful. I would not send my child to Cardozo. Wilson is the only thing that is keeping middle-class families in the neighborhood. Remove that and they will shift to charters, privates, or move.
eschoicesets_comment: I think this could really help in my neighborhood.
mschoicesets_comment: I really can't comment on this, not knowing what middle schools would be in a choice set. I agree that everyone should have the right to attend at least one stand-alone middle-school. The "education campus" model (with middle schools attached as an after-thought to either elementary schools or high schools) does not work.
msproximity_comment: The two middle schools in our choice set are education campuses and not stand alone middle schools. I would not send my child to either.
hslottery_comment: I really don't understand the thought behind this. A city-wide lottery would force kids from one side of the city to potentially go to schools on the other side of the city and remove all certainty from the process. This would certainly engender a middle-class exodus from the city, which would be bad for those who remain.
setasides_comment: Set-asides seem to be a great idea. If you are attending a failing school and don't have a choice set, then you should have a preference in getting into a school that can meet your children's need. This seems like a no-brainer if there are no elementary choice sets.

feederpatterns_comment: I would like to have the inclusion of inbound for PS3 for all residents.

eschoicesets_comment: There will be a lot of gaming and holding seats post-lottery for those that don't get into the preferred school in the choice set.
hslottery_comment: Not very inspiring, but guessing this is a red herring option anyway.

boundaries_comment: My kids do/did not attend this ES, rather were included as edge of boundary for Oyster. Would not change the enrollment of current ES student, particularly given the resource/space issue.
This makes sense and keeps the neighborhood together. Very sensible.
feederpatterns_comment: Most of Mt Pleasant is in boundary for Deal and Wilson. Many people, including myself, made long-term family decisions based on that and I fully support keeping access to those schools. Since we are in boundary anyway, it is sensible that the feeder pattern would match.
eschoicesets_comment: Access to a neighborhood elementary school is crucial. Introducing uncertainty only discourages parents from investing in their school.
mschoicesets_comment: The lack of predictability is very difficult in a system that has such uneven quality. If my kid will get a low performing school, I need to know about that well in advance so I can try to improve that school or make arrangements to send him elsewhere.
msproximity_comment: Proximity to home is not so important at the middle school level. Quality matters far more.
hslottery_comment: Seems like a bad idea to me. What does one get in exchange for the tremendous uncertainty? A lot of headaches over uncertainty, maybe travel time, and school quality. This option only prevents advance investments by parents. Why do that?
setasides_comment: Here the negative rating means the question is poorly specified. What is set aside for whom? Why not just improve school quality instead of playing games with lotteries and patterns?

boundaries_comment: I am pleased with the proposed new boundaries-- id be happier sending my child to my new proposed in boundary elementary school.
feederpatterns_comment: West used to feed into Deal.  We don't have--and need--a great middle school in our area.  Let alone any middle school

eschoicesets_comment: I'd rather have my children attend their neighborhood school that is within walking distance and is the school that the neighborhood children also attend. Splitting neighborhood children would lose some of the community sense we currently have going to our neighborhood school. Also, the proposed choice set would make it difficult to actively participate as a parent in the school b/c the school is farther from home/commute to work.
mschoicesets_comment: Again, would not want to split my children up from their neighborhood friends and the community they have built. Also, the school is not within the neighborhood making for a longer commute for my child to get to school.
msproximity_comment: How would my child get to school?
hslottery_comment: A city-wide lottery is ridiculous. How is this effective? Though there would be diversity across the city in these schools but we would lose our sense of community.

feederpatterns_comment: I think  PLAN B IS THE BEST PLAN - PLEASE IMPLEMENT THIS FEEDER PATTERN
I vote for this proposed feeder pattern!

mschoicesets_comment: hate the idea of MS and HS in Cardozo
hslottery_comment: High School students can travel.

boundaries_comment: Brookland EC at Bunker Hill rates much higher than Noyes and LaSalle.  Brookland EC has a rich array of supplemental programs.  Brookland EC rates at 81% for highly qualified instructors (HQI) which is dramatically greater than Noyes at 66% and LaSalle at 50%.  LaSalle is listed as needing intense support.  Noyes and LaSalle are not schools that I would want to send my 17 month old to.  I am currently zoned for Brookland EC but would be removed under the proposed zoning.  I oppose the new zoning.  I suggest instead that the old zoning be lowered along the southern line across Girard to North Capital on the West and 14th Street on the East.
feederpatterns_comment: Dunbar is in need of intense support.  It is not a school I would want my son to attend.  I am currently zoned for Coolidge HS and I oppose the proposed school boundary.
eschoicesets_comment: This will not solve the problem with our schools.  It will just create a long waiting list for the better schools.  This is not a proper focus and is a waste of time and resources.  I oppose the school choice set.
mschoicesets_comment: This will not solve the problem with our schools.  It will just create a long waiting list for the better schools.  This is not a proper focus and is a waste of time and resources.  I oppose the school choice set.
msproximity_comment: This will not solve the problem with our schools.  It will just create a long waiting list for the better schools.  This is not a proper focus and is a waste of time and resources.  I oppose the school choice set.
hslottery_comment: A lottery system will not solve the problem with our schools.  It will just create a long waiting list for the better schools.  We see this already with the current lottery system for charter schools.  This is not a proper focus and is a waste of time and resources.  I oppose totally eliminating a guarantee to a child's local school to be replaced only by a lotter.
setasides_comment: I am in favor of exploring options to help children in lower performing schools but this option would only help 10-20% of the children.  What about the remaining children?  It is not fair to only help a small percentage of the children in the low-performing schools.  Instead I suggest improving the performance of the low-performing schools.

boundaries_comment: We are currently zoned for Garrison.  While I am apprehensive, as a neighborhood I understand the immediate vicinity more than I do the areas surrounding Marie Reed
eschoicesets_comment: Bancroft is much too far from us to be a reasonable choice.  We have many closer more reasonable options.  How would the PCS schools figure in this.  The city keeps selling off the school lands in Ward 1 instead of letting promising PCSs that start in ward 1 find permanent spaces in Ward 1. Having every reasonable school option transplant to NE is ridiculous
mschoicesets_comment: A choice set of 1 untested school is no choice at all
hslottery_comment: At the moment I would like a chance to potty into Wilson.  High school kids are best able to travel for school, so this is reasonable.  From the perspective of current in boundary parents, this change would dramatically impact property rates, so I understand the dilemma
setasides_comment: Anything is better than what we have

feederpatterns_comment: Clearly the feeder to Cardozo is an unhappy situation.  The loss of the ability to go to Wilson is a big loss.
eschoicesets_comment: all great schools -- though FS-SWW needs some improvement in the elem/middle school years
msproximity_comment: Look I'm beginning to see how reasonable-sounding but bad-in-reality the choice set is, given that a number of schools in DC are sub-par. This is such a rough policy juncture because some schools are still tough nuts to crack.
hslottery_comment: I guess all families would be ok with this, except those currently zoned for Wilson
setasides_comment: Sorry i don't have time right now to understand this caveat fully.  But my gut says, this is a rough fix overall. Great we'd be eligible to apply for this, but it wouldn't be assured.  If my family were to consider relocating out of DC for high school, this potential of getting a set-aside might not be a sure-enough bet to stop us from relocating given the advance efforts needed to relocate.  It also creates a new form of randomness and uncertainty (and competition possibly?) within the system.

boundaries_comment: As new homeowner and parent in Mt. Pleasant, I strongly support the revised school boundary. The current school zoning map is out of date and doesn't reflect the geography of the neighborhood. This issue is very important to me and will have important implications for my long-term residency.

feederpatterns_comment: Cardozo EC is bad.

boundaries_comment: It doesn't make sense for my children to go to school close to where I live, as I work clear across town by GWU and would rather they be close to my place of work in case I have to get to them quickly.
feederpatterns_comment: All of these schools are underperforming.  Only schools in affluent areas of the city have acceptable feeder patterns with high-performing schools.
eschoicesets_comment: I appreciate the increased choice, but they are still all underperforming schools.  Until you fix the performance of these schools, you are asking parents to choose between bad schools and worse schools.
mschoicesets_comment: See Elementary School Choice Sets comments.
msproximity_comment: See Elementary School Choice Sets comments.
hslottery_comment: This is a slightly better option, though any parent who is paying attention will indicate School Without Walls, Banneker, McKinley Tech, or Wilson.  No parent will want their child in Ballou or Anacostia and what is the option for children who don't get into their preferred school.  Will you have 14 year olds schleping across this dangerous city to underperforming schools?
setasides_comment: All of the schools in my area are underperforming, so my children go to school in Ward 3.  It is also closer to where I work, since it doesn't make sense for my children to be so far away from me during the day when I am at work (not at home).  You are already jeopardizing my children's education in that I participated in the lottery so my children could go to Eaton and then Deal.  With the proposed change, Eaton will no longer feed into Deal and will feed into underperforming Hardy, a school that doesn't even continue the Chinese language they are taking at Eaton.  I will have two children at Deal next year and will have to apply my 3rd child to a private school to avoid that Hardy debacle.  Messing with people's educational plans for their children is precisely why you are losing children to charter schools and the suburbs.

eschoicesets_comment: Choice sets are a terrible idea, as is any kind of lottery system.
mschoicesets_comment: Again, not a good idea.
msproximity_comment: Anything that eliminates certain access to the neighborhood school is a terrible option.

setasides_comment: So they will push the neighborhood children to a different school so they can bring out of bounds students into the school.  Terrible option!

boundaries_comment: Raymond is currently not a very school.  I doubt it will change.  I wish I'd bought property elsewhere.
setasides_comment: my child will at least have a shot at going to a school that is not substantially under performing.

boundaries_comment: This proposal does not affect my children.
feederpatterns_comment: Ideally, we want our children to go to the school closest to our home.  Children should not have to commute to school.
eschoicesets_comment: All three schools are a tolerable distance from our house for transport.
mschoicesets_comment: Both schools are a tolerable distance from our house.
msproximity_comment: Both schools are a tolerable distance to our home.
hslottery_comment: I'm concerned that forcing children to commute to school take up too much time in their day that could be devoted to family time, studying and extra-curricular activities.  Ideally, children should have access to a good education that is close to home.
setasides_comment: Children who do no have access to a good education that is close to home deserve better.  We need a program in place to equalize opportunities for those students who seek the best education available.  This program should be voluntary and should be differentiated from forcing children to commute across town.

boundaries_comment: We love this proposal. Tubman is only two blocks from our house and on the same side of Georgia Ave. It is a more convenient school and much more in our neighborhood as people actually live than Bruce Monroe.
eschoicesets_comment: In order for parents to make decisions on where to live, they should be able to count on at least one school. The lottery is fine...but not for virtually the entire system.

boundaries_comment: Terrible idea. We moved to this neighborhood so that our children can go to Murch. It is insane to change the boundary in this way. I oppose it in the strongest possible terms. eschoicesets_comment: Bad idea. Those of us who put our trust in the DC public school system need predictability. My family moved to this neighborhood because we want our children to go to Murch (not Hearst. Not Eaton. Not Oyster. Oyster is a good school but I am not interested in Spanish immersion, and it is very far away from my home) and because we want to walk to school. If this proposal goes through we would move or pull our children out of DCPS.
mschoicesets_comment: Bad idea. Once again, we want predictability, and we want to send our children to a school with a proven record of achievement. Moreover, we want our children to walk to school. And that school is Deal. This is not a real choice.
msproximity_comment: Deal is 4 blocks away from where we live. It is an excellent school.  We would not send our child to West. This is not a real choice.
hslottery_comment:
I have no comment on this.  I am sure the committee and the DME understand that this will completely eliminate any gains made by DCPS as all the parents living west of the park and many of the ones east of the park would simply pull their kids out. This is unacceptable for reasons too many to enumerate.

As a general comment: I hope all dc schools improve; but you don't achieve it by reshuffling the kids and scattering them throughout the city. You need to invest significant resources (excellent teachers, special programs, longer school days) and address the deep socio-economic issues in this city to improve education throughout the city. One way to do this is to create a pool of affordable housing in high SES areas. The three proposals achieve none of that.
setasides_comment: I believe our current schools already have a similar percentage of OOB students.
Need more details.  Would support 10%

boundaries_comment: Why would I want my child to attend a school that is farther away from my house?  That's ridiculous.  Did Kafka write these proposals?
feederpatterns_comment: Why would I want my child to attend a school that is farther away from my house?  That's ridiculous.  Did Kafka write these proposals?
eschoicesets_comment: Why would I want my child to attend a school that is farther away from my house?  That's ridiculous.  Did Kafka write these proposals?
mschoicesets_comment: The choice between nothing (current situation) and imaginary ("future new school") is no choice at all.
msproximity_comment: Why would I want my child to attend a school that is farther away from my house?  That's ridiculous.  Did Kafka write these proposals?

boundaries_comment: As a parent with 4 children, 2 in high school, 1 middle, 1 elementary, it's not the feeder pattern, but the quality of the education provided at the schools listed that is an issue.
feederpatterns_comment:
I do not think students follow these patterns. As a parent with 4 children, 2 in high school, 1 middle, 1 elementary, it's not the feeder pattern, but the quality of the education provided at the schools listed. Also, I think all children should have the opportunity to attend a traditional middle school (6,7,8).  There is something lost when the aforementioned grades are not seperated with specialized instruction & training for faculty; the opportunity to change classes; 
and sports, clubs and other opportunities for this special student population. Also, the students in this area do not have access to a neighborhood high school.  Students will have to travel to a different quadrant to attend high school.  It may not be that far, but does put a student at a disadvantage.  A student may have to wake-up earlier to commute and arrive home later.  This has been my experience and as a parent I do not want to put my kids through the commute anymore for a high quality school.  Every student deserves high quality schools at all levels in their neighborhood if they chose to attend.  I like Dunbar as a choice better than Coolidge or Roosevelt, but the school is not close.  With the up and coming Brookland Middle School in Ward 5, this is a great choice for parents.  I am considering this option for my youngest.  However, the biggest concern is where do they go from here (Brookland Middle School)?  Away from the Ward/neighborhood.  So this makes it a hard choice for parents when considering staying in the neighborhood.  Most will continue to jockey to position kids in schools where the end result is a quality high school with great test scores.
eschoicesets_comment: If you are blocks from a specific school and you have to enter a lottery to enter the school, that could propose a problem.  I like to have choices, but the possibility of not being able to go to the closest school is an issue.  Once the selections are made, a lottery should factor in distance. Would the charter school be part of the rank?  How will DCPS have control over that selection?  Charter schools have a sperate process.
mschoicesets_comment: I like the possibility of the "new school"; a dedicated middle school in Ward 5.
msproximity_comment: Distance should be a variable in the lottery, and the type of school.  If I live closest to Brookland Middle School, and get a K-8/EC as my first choice, I would not be happy!  In this case you are offering apples and oranges, not apples and apples. Most parents want a dedicated middle school so most will select that option.  DCPS can argue that they are equal, but they are not for some and parents should have the right to select which is best for them and their child.
hslottery_comment: Just not sure how this would play-out.  Will this option be equal?  Will you have just as many students traveling from NW to SE as you do the reverse?  If all involved play be the rules and their is a balance than yes and this could be a model for other cities the size and demographic make-up of DC.  Inclusion is another factor for kids with disabilities.  What are the implications?
setasides_comment: I like, but will a set aside provide a balance at all schools?

boundaries_comment: I wouldn't mind in conjunction with one of the policy change proposals.
feederpatterns_comment: If these schools do not improve in quality, I cannot envision sending my children to them.

mschoicesets_comment: I think this is an excellent idea and I believe it would result in improving the quality of the lower performing schools in the set.
hslottery_comment: I think high schools would improve citywide.  I am concerned that it might result in some flight from DCPS.  But I don't think that should impact the adoption of this policy.

eschoicesets_comment: We love Key school

eschoicesets_comment: I think this choice set makes a level of sense.  It mixes kids demographically.  I suppose trying to fit Tyler with Watkins and say Payne would make it awkward to group Brent.  Did people take into account the future opening of Van Ness when making this rating?  I think the adjoining neighborhood's affluent residents overlook friendship charter.

But then this city has so many kids that lucked into a bad lot in life.......

boundaries_comment: This is a much larger area that the school must absorb.  Also seems like the furthest reaches of the boundary are very far from the school and would not be at all convenient for those folks.
eschoicesets_comment: Much prefer current system where you're guaranteed a spot at the neighborhood school and then can apply out of boundary if not satisfied.  Provides much more predictability.  This proposal makes me extremely nervous and unsettled feeling.
msproximity_comment: Would prefer to know which school you are guaranteed a spot in, and then go from there.  The idea that you will always be part of a lottery no matter what is extremely unsettling.  I would feel much better knowing that at least one option is established, but that I can also apply out of boundary.
hslottery_comment: High schools across the city need to be improved, and I will be living somewhere without a good high school currently, but I still think that there needs to be more predictability and that students would want to stay with kids they have already been with in school rather than having those networks broken up at the high school stage.
setasides_comment: Yes, consider even a higher percentage.  Until the neighborhood schools are performing better, parents and children need more quality options.

boundaries_comment: THE BOUNDARY IS TOO BIG
Moved to this apartment because we can walk to Murch. We don't have a car. A lot of people in our building moved here for the same reason.
feederpatterns_comment: We moved here to have our children go to Murch Deal Wilson.
setasides_comment: No. You should make all neighborhood schools better.

boundaries_comment: It makes no sense that my daughter's classmate on Connecticut and Albemarle will be rezoned out of Murch, but streets that are closer to Lafayette will stay in Murch. The Murch renovation has been delayed for too long. Cutting families off from the school that are only 3 blocks away is a poor way to make up for an overdue renovation.
feederpatterns_comment: Predictable feeder patters for schools are important to keep bringing families in our neighborhood back to DCPS.
eschoicesets_comment: People here want neighborhood schools - knowing where your kids will go when you buy a house. Uncertainty will not be good for neighborhoods.
mschoicesets_comment: We don't really think of Hardy as in our neighborhood. We want a neighborhood middle school.

hslottery_comment: Parents want predictability for their children's schools. A lottery would undermine this.
setasides_comment: I don't think setting aside places in "high-performing schools" is a way to improve low performing schools. DC should encourage strong neighborhood schools in every neighborhood.

eschoicesets_comment: Odd that this pattern skips Maury but adds Miner. Would make more sense to include Maury.
mschoicesets_comment: Would not send my kid to any of those schools. Would "choose" to opt out of dcps if those were my only choices.
msproximity_comment: Wheatley??

boundaries_comment: I don't understand this change because Peabody is only PK3-K and Watkins is 1st-5th.  Both school are part of the Capitol Hill Cluster School.
eschoicesets_comment: i don't support choice sets
mschoicesets_comment: i do not support choice sets
msproximity_comment:
i do not support choice sets 
i believe in neighborhood schools of right
hslottery_comment: i support neighborhood schools of right
setasides_comment: i support neighborhood schools of right

boundaries_comment: I support the boundary change.
feederpatterns_comment: I support the proposed feeder pattern.
eschoicesets_comment: I support guaranteed access to neighborhood schools.
mschoicesets_comment: I support guaranteed access to middle schools in feeder pattern.
msproximity_comment: I support guaranteed access to middle schools in feeder pattern.
hslottery_comment: I oppose the lottery and support guaranteed access to neighborhood schools based on feeder patterns.
setasides_comment: I support improving the "low-performing" schools, not transferring the students.

boundaries_comment: My child is a lotteried 3rd grader at John Eaton Elementary in Ward 3. We were told she would be able to remain with her class and attend Deal and Wilson.  If any of the proposals go through, that may not be the case.  We have no middle school in Ward 4.  We have financially supported John Eaton throughout the years.  If this proposal goes through we may be forced to:  pull our child out of Eaton to give her a better chance to attend a middle school in another part of the city, or we may move out of DC.  Takoma will not have the capacity to provide the education we seek for our child  when she enters 6th grade.
feederpatterns_comment: How can she feed into a school that doesn't even exist?
mschoicesets_comment: Takoma schools have a lot of work to do if they are to attract  students whose parents set  high standards for their kids' education.
msproximity_comment: We need better schools in Takoma.
hslottery_comment: Coolidge students walk by my house every day on the way to school.  At least I don't see as many drug deals going down as I used to.  I still hear the swearing,  and pick up their trash.  One set of girls smashed my car windows for the fun of it.  My child will not go that school.

boundaries_comment: This change is long overdue.
eschoicesets_comment: Terrible idea. People who you WANT in DCPS would flee the system in droves. They would either sell their houses and move to the suburbs, or send their kids to private school or charter school. You would diminish the value of properties in good school districts. Please don't do this to loyal, involved DC residents. Please don't destroy our property values. I am not rich, I sent my kids to DC public schools K-12. I love this city, please don't screw me by diminishing the value of my house.
mschoicesets_comment: Those are both good schools, but I am philosophically opposed to "choice sets." People should have defined feeder patterns attached to their address. Anything less would be damaging to property values.
msproximity_comment: Terrible idea. I would not send my child to either school. My address should entitle me to send my children to a specific school - currently Deal Junior High. Please don't harm DCPS by creating choice sets. You will destroy what works in DCPS.
hslottery_comment: You need a category that's worse than the scowling face. This is absolute total armageddon suicide. People buy houses in specific neighborhoods so they can send their children to specific schools. Anything that's left up to chance - a lottery - would damage property values, and send people fleeing to the suburbs. The quality of DCPS would plummet. There are lots of schools in DCPS that work, more than there used to be. Why mess with a positive trend? Are you out of your minds? Another thing: assigning schools by lottery across the board would make rush-house traffic even worse than it already is. Why take a child who can walk to his/her neighborhood school, and have him/her go to another school that requires being driven there? Again, this makes no sense on a number of levels. The people who dreamt up this scheme must not have children, must not be driving DC streets during rush hour, and must not own property in DC, because an entirely lottery-based system would be terrible for all three.
setasides_comment: I don't understand what this is saying. If a child is in a low-performing school, FIX THAT SCHOOL. Have a lottery to allow extra space in better-performing schools to take kids from low-performing schools, but the top priority must be to improve low-performing schools. "Alice Deal For All" should not mean that every middle school kid literally gets to go to Alice Deal. It means, make all the schools as good as Deal.

hslottery_comment: Anything to avoid Cardozo.

boundaries_comment: Cook is much further away and to get there would require passing through many unsafe neighborhoods.  Further, Cook has much lower performance scores.
feederpatterns_comment: Cook is not a preferred elementary school.
eschoicesets_comment: This does not include the closest school, H. Tubman.
mschoicesets_comment: A new school would be welcomed.
msproximity_comment: Better than having to go to Cardozo.
hslottery_comment: Impartial

boundaries_comment: Tubman is already a substandard school. Increasing the enrollment doesn't do anything to fix the problem.
feederpatterns_comment: My feeder pattern stays the same but the reality is my child will not attend any of these schools because of their poor performance. In general, changing how the feeder program works will not change the fact that children are being pushed into schools that are not performing well. I don't think the movement of children across schools is the big issue that needs to be addressed. You should be addressing the dismal state of the schools system in the district
hslottery_comment: As with every other proposal under this initiative, it aims at solving the wrong problem. Giving more children "possible" access to the only high school in DC worth going to does not help improve the horrible state of high school in the district. Your focus should be on improving education across all schools not opening up a lottery system. Additionally, I would recommend creating specialized high schools, similar to NYC, that would focus on high level academics and be open to all district residents through an entrance exam.
setasides_comment: Once again, this does not fix the low performing schools and displaces residents who moved to neighborhoods specifically for the school district.

feederpatterns_comment: Many, many people (myself included) bought houses with school districts high on the priority list. Many of us paid more money to ensure that our children would be able to attend certain schools. I do not agree with changing set school boundaries at this point.
eschoicesets_comment: Many, many people (myself included) bought houses with school districts high on the priority list. Many of us paid more money to ensure that our children would be able to attend certain schools. I do not agree with changing set school boundaries at this point.
hslottery_comment: Many, many people (myself included) bought houses with school districts high on the priority list. Many of us paid more money to ensure that our children would be able to attend certain schools. I do not agree with changing set school boundaries at this point.

boundaries_comment: This is really a terrible idea.  If you move the school boundary to a worse school that's farther away, we'll either put our kids in private school or leave the District altogether.  So will a lot of other families.
hslottery_comment: Cardozo has a nice new building, but I won't send my kids there unless the academics improve enormously.  Graduation and literacy rates are far below anything approaching acceptable.
setasides_comment: This would be more useful if the question explained in any meaningful way what a "set aside" means in practice.  Simply placing the term "setting aside" in quotations while offering nothing in the way of substantive explanation is a near useless effort.

feederpatterns_comment: Most critical is that all families that have children currently attending a DCPS school should be grandfathered in to be able to attend the feeder school(s) from the school they attend regardless of whether the school they attend is in or out of their boundary.
eschoicesets_comment: Parents need and should have greater predictability than "choice sets."
mschoicesets_comment: See above.
msproximity_comment: See above.
hslottery_comment: See above.  This would be detrimental in numerous ways.  Bad for neighborhoods and for socialization of children, and bad in terms of predictability.

boundaries_comment: I am fine with this as long as I am zoned for Van Ness, as a neighborhood school, when it opens.
feederpatterns_comment: I hope these high schools will be better performing by the time  my children get to them...
eschoicesets_comment: I want to have the right to attend my neighborhood school, Van Ness.
mschoicesets_comment: Interesting idea, if they are all performing well...
hslottery_comment: This leaves your child's education completely up to chance, degrades neighborhood schools, does not contribute to community building in neighborhoods, and could mean long commutes for students and parents across the city.

boundaries_comment: It is wrong and isolating to perforate our neighborhood in half. All of Mt. Pleasant belongs in the same district.
feederpatterns_comment: Bancroft is part of the Mt. Pleasant community - we already play there, have soccer there, and support its fund raisers, Christmas tress sales, etc.  We have no nexus or connection to HD Cooke and hear absolutely nothing about it.  I actually think it's physically farther away. We STRONGLY support inclusion in the Mt. Pleasant Bancroft district.
eschoicesets_comment: I agree only if you weighted to your own community school in the lottery (i.e., one of the four has greater weight for you).
mschoicesets_comment: Once children start school together, there should be ongoing consistency.  I don't like school sets for middle and high school.
msproximity_comment: People moved to the area because of access to Deale and Wilson.  It is unfair to take that away.
hslottery_comment: I have now participated in the elementary school lottery twice and it's a nightmare.  There must be certainty and consistency at the middle and high school level.
setasides_comment: This seems like a good idea for those with underserving schools, but the follow-on effect of how that impacts both departed schools and those schools the set-asides elect to attend alternately will be difficult to manage and create a host of domino problems.  I favor racially and economically blended school communities but would like to see a more detailed plan.

boundaries_comment: This represents no change for me.
feederpatterns_comment: This feeder pattern is more predictable than my current feeder pattern.  Currently, if my child chose not to attend Stuart Hobson, I would lose access to Eastern.
eschoicesets_comment: My choice set is good.  But I'm not marking the highest approval option because I know other choice sets are not equal.  A few are fantastic, and some are not good at all.
mschoicesets_comment: No strong feelings on my own choice set, but concerned about equity district-wide.
msproximity_comment: Not a terrible idea in theory, but I do not like my odds here.  Doesn't make sense to have kids feed to an EC who haven't completed PS-5 there.
hslottery_comment: I think the city-wide lottery with no neighborhood preference would be the best chance at achieving equity system wide, but only if nobody could opt out.  With charters, private schooling, and moving to the suburbs all (relatively) readily available options for families, it doesn't seem likely to be successful.
setasides_comment: Makes sense to me.

boundaries_comment: I don't mind being in-boundary for LaSalle-Backus if it becomes an elementary school.  The K-8 model there has not been successful and we need a stand alone middle school.

I still have concerns about the continued reliance on out of boundary set-asides as a band-aid for low performing schools in other wards. Overcrowding will not be resolved until this issue is properly addressed.

My children currently attend Murch Elementary as OOB students, life, family and job decisions  were made by my family based on this assignment and its feeder pattern to Deal and Wilson,  (We have already suffered through several lotteries). Redirecting my children to Brightwood and out of Deal and Wilson would force us out of the city.
feederpatterns_comment: same comment as above:  these schools are much lower performing than the current OOB award and feeder patterns my children and I worked hard for.  We are active in our current OOB schools and worked hard to bring them to their current levels.  We won't start over.  We will have to leave the city :(
eschoicesets_comment: this is a toddler choice : asking us to pick one from all bad options
mschoicesets_comment: all bad choices
msproximity_comment: these are not middle schools and not what we signed up for
hslottery_comment: awful school
setasides_comment: we already worked hard for a lottery placement at a good school:  you will be making us start over or leave the city.  Brightwood is NOT a good school, compared to what we already worked for.

boundaries_comment: While I am happy our school boundaries would not change, I still have concerns about the continued reliance on out of boundary set-asides as a band-aid solution to the low performing schools in other wards. The issue of overcrowding, especially at Wilson HS, will not be resolved until this issue is properly addressed.
feederpatterns_comment: See comment above.
eschoicesets_comment: I am satisfied with my specific choice set, however I am completely opposed to the idea of choice sets which are, in fact, mini-lotteries, and would be unpredictable at best for the majority of families across the city and devastating for many others based on the poor choices available in most parts of the city. This option also continues to rely too heavily on the out of boundary set asides, which in my opinion, should be phased out in favor of a city-wide neighborhood school model to be implemented in concert with concrete and realistic plan for improving our worst schools, which DME, DCPS and the Charter School Board have failed to create.
mschoicesets_comment: We haven't even been able to provide a quality general education at any of the three school divisions, what makes us think we could specialize (with no additional resources at our disposal) and do any better? We spend more per student than any other city in the US and our test scores are worse than Detroit. We need to simplify, not further complicate, our school system.
msproximity_comment: I will only support the traditional neighborhood school model.
hslottery_comment: This would only increase the number of losers in the DCPS system and ensure that no one had any predictability whatsoever. It would also make it extremely difficult if not impossible to keep, track and analyze student data in a comprehensive manner which would prevent us from being able to rate and therefore improve our schools in any meaningful way.
setasides_comment: It makes sense that we would not be eligible for a set-aside. However, I am vehemently opposed to this model for the reasons already stated in my previous comments. In addition, it is my understanding that these percentages are based on the respective total student population of each school. Based on this model, with varied total student populations, it is not mathematically possible to remain within the limits of the percentages as students move through their assigned feeder patterns unless there is a process established to "kick out" the necessary number of previously assigned students in cases where the limits have been exceeded based on the numbers in the feeder schools.

boundaries_comment: Not a strong opinion or strongly upset, but this school does not have a good reputation as being neighborhood-oriented from what I have heard from others. My children are not yet school-aged, but I have heard negative comments from other parents in the neighborhood that the school is dismissive of the neighborhood itself (and has a low in-boundary rate, which does seem to bear out what others may be saying) - perhaps something DCPS should be made aware of, if it is not already, and work to address. A school is located within a neighborhood and it isn't very fair to its community if it isn't interested in engaging with it.
eschoicesets_comment: That seems like a great idea to give parents some flexibility.
mschoicesets_comment: Not as excited about this idea because the middle school could end up being quite far from the student's home. This seems more problematic.
msproximity_comment: Not a huge fan of this idea either, again partly because of the distance from home for the additional middle school option.
hslottery_comment: Seems like a good idea, since the high schools aren't that close to home anyway, and I'd feel more comfortable with a high schooler getting around the city. I assume that each child would have access to some high school, though, even if not the original one.
setasides_comment: I think that seems like a good idea, as a way to keep folks in DCPS in high school if the local school is not performing well.

boundaries_comment: It incorporates the huge homeless shelter, that's actually now part of ward 7
msproximity_comment: By middle school, students should have the option of taking a standardized test which tracks them with other similar children
hslottery_comment: Eastern is dreadful.  My goal is to ensure that my child goes to a challenging school with other smart children.

msproximity_comment: My current zoned school is much more high performing than these other 2 options.
hslottery_comment: I want access to my neighborhood school.
setasides_comment: If set asides are limited to 5 - 10% I would be in favor of this but unfortunately all most all of DC's high schools are eligible for set asides as they are underperforming schools.

feederpatterns_comment: I am for Eastern becoming the neighborhood High School for Capitol Hill. I am also in favor of feeder patterns becoming more consistent. Currently, our elementary school has 3 separate feeder patterns within 4 blocks.
eschoicesets_comment: Totally against choice sets.
mschoicesets_comment: No choice sets
hslottery_comment: The citywide lottery would force us to leave DCPS.

boundaries_comment: Having two choices for elementary kind of means 2 choices for middle. Currently the Ross Middle School feeder is terrible, if it were great I would not care about other so callled choices. And actually I thought one of the proposals was to have more than one school as an option, the cluster concept, so I don't understand why this question is about reducing/eliminating choice.
feederpatterns_comment: Middle school is only 3 years, we would be unlikely to remain in our house or neighborhood just for a proposed decent middle school when the high school is not going to be anywhere near satisfactory.  A new high school is needed that serves high preforming kids in these neighborhoods, then a middle school will have a better chance.
eschoicesets_comment: I did not read the policy details, but on a personal level this could be very annoying for people with very close proximity, but it could also be good from an administrative point of view if one day overcrowding becomes an issue in these schools.
mschoicesets_comment: New can be good, it depends who goes, I am very concerned about student performance so if the student outcomes are high and the facilities good then I would be happy - the the high school situations is still terrible so I may chose to move.
msproximity_comment: Not great student outcomes at either school, the Francis administration seems to be a bit of a mess, but has the physical space and a growing number of middle class families which gives it potential to be a great middle school.  But the uncertainty of high school would really make people think twice about investing three years here.
hslottery_comment: I am not interested in Cardozo, so the "would not" have guaranteed access suits me fine, but then where do my kids go to high school? I think I need to move to Maryland or start saving for private school.
setasides_comment: Please articulate the purpose of this policy. It reduces the number of proximity families that can attend the school so I do not support it, even if it would offer my children a remote chance of going to a better high school.  It does not look like smart school assignment planning, it looks like you are just throwing a bone to people who are zoned to low-performing schools so they feel like they have a chance of getting out of their crap local school where in reality that chance is really low.
