boundaries_comment: The public elementary school, Anne Goding, was closed in 1989.  It is right next to my house.  It just reopened with a new name, SWS.   SWS was part of Peabody Elementary, so it shared that boundary.  When the parents in the old boundary made a fuss about the boundary moving, DC made SWS a lottery school!  Now, instead creating a community hub, it is tearing our families apart, as now tensions are high between families who 'won' the lottery, and those who lost.  By far the majority of families lost, as the school is one of the highest rated schools in the District.
feederpatterns_comment: Although this feeder pattern makes sense for proximity, all three of these schools have some of the lowest test scores in the entire United States.  The real issue here is: When DC will be changing out the administration in these failing schools?
eschoicesets_comment: This is a terrible idea; we need community schools to boost family involvement.  How will neighborhood families meet and interact?  How will neighborhood kids meet and become friends for life?   How easy will it be to get my 3 year old to school in pouring rain?  This concept, if realized, will create splintered communities all across DC.
mschoicesets_comment: At this age, kids can walk to school without a parent, or take public transportation, so proximity is not an issue.  However, I would never be able to sell my house.  What parent would buy a house, not knowing exactly what schools their kids will go to?
msproximity_comment: Wow this concept will send us right back to Montgomery County.
hslottery_comment: This is not fair to those families who purchased homes in order to be in-bounds for excellent schools. Why should we leach onto their schools?    This is also a logistical nightmare, with kids taking buses for hours each day, just to commute.
setasides_comment: The emphasis should be to hire better teachers and to get rid of ineffective administrations at low performing schools.

feederpatterns_comment: All of the highly favorable high school and middle schools have enormous numbers feeding into them where the underperforming schools have very little if any change in the enrollment.  This still doesn't solve the problem of how to gain access to a better performing school. Oh, I know why not, put the resources, time and $ into bringing this schools up to par instead of changing the boundaries, cause if the school was doing better, then why would I care about sending my kids to an out of boundary school.
eschoicesets_comment: This plan doesn't offer valuable solutions for students east of the river to gain access to better performing schools, programs or options.
mschoicesets_comment: Again, this plan doesn't offer valuable solutions for students east of the river to gain access to better performing schools, programs and options.  My family would still apply to the lottery to find a school that provided better option.  I'm only hearing about the change in boundary (or lack of it) and not a change in curriculum.  Yes, STEM is mentioned, but there are other schools that provide access to access to considerably more options and extracurricular activities, then just STEM.
msproximity_comment: Again, this plan doesn't offer valuable solutions for students east of the river to gain access to better performing schools, programs and options.  Where are the solutions to providing a more rigorous academic experience.  My family would still apply to the lottery to find a school that provided better options.
hslottery_comment: This plan offers no recourse (or doesn't explain) what the recourse would be if families did not get into the school of their choice.  The number of available seats now are so limited, what would it look like if it were city-wide.
setasides_comment: Although this is some type of recourse, the percentage is a too low.  10 out of 100 or 20 out of 200. This feels like a crab-shoot.

boundaries_comment: I think DCPS should account for Van Ness in these boundaries since the school is scheduled to open at the same times as the new boundaries will become effective.

msproximity_comment:
Mamie D. Lee isn't a real options for most folks - since it caters to special ed and I believe is closing? 

Also is LaSalle a mid school?

boundaries_comment: we can see Janney from our house and it is less than 100 yards away. now we'd have to drive our kids to school. i'm not sure how this makes sense.

I think that Ludlow-Taylor is a fine school. However, I would point out that there is another DC Public school 1 1/2 blocks from our house, SWS, which we have no preference for. I find this frustrating as this is the closest and the "in our neighborhood" school.
feederpatterns_comment: I support this feeder pattern.
eschoicesets_comment: I think there is too much variation in these choice sets. SWS and Logan are top draws throughout the city; Ludlow and Wilson are improving; I would not consider sending my child to Miner due to safety concerns and the complete lack of diversity. If forced, I would drop out of DCPS.
mschoicesets_comment: I've never even heard of Jefferson and which means its a) far from my home; and b) doesn't have a reputation that warrants travel. That my children would have a 1/3 probability of attending is troubling.
msproximity_comment: The committee hasn't taken into account "closest" well. Wheatley involves crossing several dangerous streets and is over a mile from our house. I would not consider sending my children there and would opt out of DCPS.
hslottery_comment: I support attending neighborhood schools. A large reason why we live in the city is because of its walkability and to avoid driving. A city-wide lottery completely violates this. If you wanted to increase diversity you should require a percentage at each school devoted to free and reduced lunch and give separate lottery preference for that if a school can't meet the percent using inbounds. City wide lotteries would be a disaster and result in large opt-outs.
setasides_comment: I'm concerned that the committee has yet to decide how they would determine "low-performing." Our child's school lost funding because of the way DCPS determined Title IX status (the one day they took attendance, a few free and reduced lunch students were absent pushing our share just below 40% but not changing the actual population attending our school.

boundaries_comment: We will not cooperate if pushed to low-performing Tyler Traditional and don't want Spanish Immersion.  Please do keep Brent's boundaries the same.  We're already involved in the PTA, although our children are not old enough for K yet.
feederpatterns_comment: Jefferson Academy?  Short of of serious honors classes (where almost every child tested advanced on the 5th grade DCAS), not interested.  We're saving for parochial middle school.   If DCPS insists on dividing the Maury and Brent families again, the critical mass of strong students won't emerge to attract most of us to any DCPS MS, at least not in the next 15 years.  Dream on, DCPS.
eschoicesets_comment: Horrible idea.  Expect no cooperation from us.
mschoicesets_comment: All crummy choices for our advanced learners.  You're just rearranging deck chairs on the Titanic here.
msproximity_comment: I want a serious MS test-in program.  Won't touch either of these choices without one.
hslottery_comment: Eastern does not appeal to us now, it will be bad in 10 years, in 15, in 20.  Reality check time, folks.  No test-in program at Eastern, or at least an International Baccalaureate program (where the majority of candidates earn the full diploma), count us out.
setasides_comment: You said it yourself, Brent is already nearing capacity.  Where are you going to put the kids coming in via set asides.  The roof of Brent?

feederpatterns_comment: have significant concerns about the viability of Eastern as an effective college preparatory vehicle. also have concerns about the lack of "neighborhood" commitment in Watkins as a neighborhood school.
eschoicesets_comment: Worry that we're creating effectively another complicated lottery process that establishes the desirables and the undesirables, which results in inconsistent learning.
mschoicesets_comment: see above
hslottery_comment: would prefer a lottery to our current assignment but wonder how this will impact investments in low performing schools if we don't land in a stronger facility.

feederpatterns_comment: I am currently in bounds for Deal Middle School.  There is no middle school in ward four, and certainly no middle school that provides the same quality of education as deal.   It would be a great loss to me to no longer have access to Deal, and for the neighborhood in general.
mschoicesets_comment: It is ludicrous to have us judge an option that is non-existant.  The city is clearly doing us a disservice.
msproximity_comment: Definitely worse than what our current option is.  I thought this was suppose to improve things?

boundaries_comment: In fairness to the folks in the former Adams boundary, there is an argument for this.  But it is absolute folly to think that the enrollment response will not be a problem for the school.  There are tons of young families in that neighborhood who will stay instead of moving, and choose public instead of private school, if they can go to Oyster-Adams.  Even if you make the (highly advisable) investments needed to expand capacity at the school, there will be no preserving the language balance that the program depends on.  This school needs about 40% out-of-boundary enrollment at the kinder level to achieve language balance in the student body.  We're already below that, and the Adams neighborhood has the potential to more than double our in-boundary enrollment.
feederpatterns_comment: Nobody who currently has rights for a decent high school is going to be happy about being sent to Cardozo.  I don't think I need to explain that you need to create an acceptable academic program first, before you can get parents to risk their kids' educations on investing in it.  But for Oyster, the mere possibility of reassignment is destructive, because right now we have grandfather rights to Deal.  People will bail on the Oyster-Adams middle school to preserve their feeder rights.  I am really excited about keeping my kids in the O-A program through 8th grade, because it's a great program, but if that means we are not going to have a high school, even my family might desert. This change could destroy our school.  On the bright side (this is totally sarcastic), if we don't have a middle school, then there might be room for the Adams boundary kids to have their building back.
eschoicesets_comment:
Eaton and Hearst are not neighborhood schools for us.  They are not walkable/bikable for us (up a big hill and miles away).  If our kids had to go there, we'd be in our cars all the time, and for that we might as well move to the suburbs where there's less traffic.  Of course, our family is already in school, so this would not affect where we attend school--just wreck our property values.
I'm not going to waste too much time beating this dead horse, though.  The bigger problem is that people expect to get in DC what they would get in nearly every other jurisdiction in the country, which is to pick where your kids go to school by where you choose to live.  
Let me also object to the Orwellian double speak in this nomenclature.  "Choice set" has a technical meaning in economics and choice theory, which is a set of things among which one is in a position to choose.  In your usage, it is the opposite, a set of possibilities among which you may not choose, but rather get one foisted on you at random.  If neighborhood schools are not in the choice set for DC families, they can still choose suburban life, or private schools, or charter schools.  You don't have the power to take those out of our choice set.
mschoicesets_comment: This part of the proposal is really unclear to me.  Our middle school of right is a specialized program.  I think it makes sense for us to have a backup for kids who get to middle school and want out of the dual language thing. My kids are very science-oriented, and a great science-focus program might be better for us.  My first choice would be for science to be strengthened at our own school.  Right now our backup is Deal, and there are several good charter schools, too.  I don't know what alternative is proposed.
msproximity_comment: I don't really understand the CHEC program. It's supposed to be an IB program, but I haven't heard that student performance is any good.  And sort of bilingual, but has inappropriate levels of language instruction for kids who are already bilingual.  Anyway, I don't like the idea of my kids getting split up from their friends and cohort against their will.  Even if both schools/programs were equally good (a big if), the cohesion and continuity of a small program staying together seems compelling.
hslottery_comment: This is terrible.  If my kids had to travel more than half an hour each way to get to school by transit, if they couldn't get there by bike, it would be a non-starter.  You can ask a high school kid to get to school on his own, but you can't tell him he has to go all the way across the city to some school in a distant neighborhood where he doesn't know anyone and might not be safe.  If you put really strong geographic preferences into the lottery, so that the results minimized travel distances, there might be an argument for it.  But not as proposed.  It's important for the schools to be connected to their communities, too.  The community and the school have a symbiotic relationship.
setasides_comment: First of all, if a school is overcrowded, the so-called "set aside" is just going to crowd it more. You can't actually set seats aside when there is by-right admission.  That would be absolutely indefensible.  Second, kids in boundary at crowded schools benefit their classmates as well as themselves if they go to an out of boundary school, so they should get higher priority in the lottery.  And everyone should have the best chance possible to go to school near home, so higher lottery priority should go to kids from nearby.  Within geographic distance classes, there might be an argument for giving kids from low-performing schools priority over those from better-performing schools, but I am not sure that that is either fair to everyone else or constructive to the low-performing schools, which are harmed by flight.  I can think of a lot of better ways to help kids at low performing schools. Start with putting in the resources to make the schools better.

feederpatterns_comment: If the necessary investments and support are provided to new middle school is good, with dual language immersion.
eschoicesets_comment: We are one block from Ross Elementary school, why don't we get to be in a choice set with them? How will the choice sets be determined? Who is going to develop the schools within a choice set to make sure the right programming and quality is available? how is this a solution?
mschoicesets_comment: One option is not a choice set!
hslottery_comment: NO way will this improve my access to quality education.

boundaries_comment: Murch is way beyond capacity and needs to be modernized/expanded ASAP.
eschoicesets_comment: It would be ridiculous to force families to drive when they could walk to school. Traffic and childcare arrangements would be even more of a nightmare.
mschoicesets_comment: Same comment as above - this would be a nightmare for traffic, childcare arrangements, etc.
msproximity_comment: Same comment as above - traffic and childcare arrangements would be a mess.
hslottery_comment: Completely ridiculous and impractical, for so many reasons - traffic, childcare arrangements, etc.
setasides_comment: What about all the kids who remain in the low-performing schools? And what about the already overcrowded high-performing schools? Seems like a nice idea in theory but not practical/sustainable and not addressing the larger problem.

feederpatterns_comment: Cardozo is a NO choice for us therefore we will have to move or apply for a charter.
eschoicesets_comment: All three schools indicated above are OK for Elementary. My expectation is that this option may work if all the schools in a choice set are excellent. If however, there is one bad apple, this can create serious issues for people who may end up there via lottery but would have otherwise been in bounds for the better school in the pool
mschoicesets_comment: Well...hard to rate something I don't know. From what middle schools I know could go into this choice set, none sound good. Maybe one, but everyone will want that, so....lottery mercy
msproximity_comment: I am sorry but I don't want Cardozo, not in its current state, or immediate future state
setasides_comment: This sounds ok, but what will the application be? Academic testing? However, I am truly hoping that by when I will be looking for high schools, there will be significant improvement at middle and high schools in DC. In any case,  I loved this survey and appreciate what a tough job the Advisory Committee has and I thank you for that.

eschoicesets_comment: As most people would agree, walking to school is a convenience and an integral part of being part of a neighborhood. Additionally, it is the greenest choice putting no additional burdens on the city's transportation system or traffic levels.

feederpatterns_comment: We bought our house in part because it fed into Deal
mschoicesets_comment: What are the boundaries of this "new school" Where would it be located?
setasides_comment: This is too little too late as an option. I suspect the set asides would be highly competitive.

feederpatterns_comment: We will need an option for non-Spanish speaking children for middle school.  Also, Cardozo is not an acceptable option.  We would move to Montgomery County or send our children to private school.
eschoicesets_comment: I think this could hurt the neighborhood feel of the neighborhood schools.  My response is also slightly skewed b/c Oyster-Adams is a specialized program that families in our neighborhood have specifically chosen when purchasing a home.
mschoicesets_comment: We will need an option for kids who can't go to Oyster-Adams since they didn't come up through the elementary school.  Also, this is getting to the age where kids who live on the same street could walk/bus/metro together to school and this would disrupt that plan.
hslottery_comment: Kids might have to travel long time and distance to go to school.  It would also break up friendships.
setasides_comment: There should be ways for students who can't afford to move to areas with better performing schools to attend those schools.

boundaries_comment: While I understand the concern of parents whose school boundaries are changing the reality is that some of the schools in Ward 3 are seriously overcrowded. Something needs to be done and changing the boundaries seems like the only solution at least until the schools (like Murch) are renovated.
We don't feel that HD Cooke is a useable school for our family.
These schools are the worst my daughter goes to school inward 3 and I want her to stay there.
setasides_comment: Let's keep the lottery system we have. ..no one that has an education wants their kids in these suggested schools.

hslottery_comment: I would hope that I would continue to have a right to go to Wilson unless the rest of DC public high schools improve.

boundaries_comment: Since I'm near the border I'd like the option to go to other schools that have better test scores that are on the other side of 6th Street NW.  I also believe that my street typically associates with the schools and activities to the West of us,
feederpatterns_comment: I think these are terrible schools, and I would rather move than send my child to any of these schools.
eschoicesets_comment: I like the idea of having choices, but if the schools in the choice set are not better than those in the boundary, then I do not think it is a real choice.
msproximity_comment: I like the idea of a choice set but note that the "neighborhood" school is not within walking distance, but I believe it is of better quality than my existing school.
hslottery_comment: I have mixed views on the lottery.  Having kids trek across the city for their schools is not ideal. I'd love to have a quality, neighborhood school option -- either public or charter.
setasides_comment: This would be very helpful and would allow us to actually have a chance at another school.  Again, the down side is that we would  not be in neighborhood schools and this would increase the family commute.  The big advantage of being in the city is to live close to where we work, play and go to school. If the school option is on the other side of the city, it makes us feel that we are better off in the suburbs rather than in the city.

eschoicesets_comment: One of the best aspects of neighborhood elementary schools is being able to walk or bike to school.

boundaries_comment: The main reason we moved this neighborhood is to send our child to Lafayette and the reason Lafayette is as good as it is, is because of parent involvement! Get the parents on board in other wards to improve their schools! Do not overcrowd our school with out of bound students! Modern day busing is not the answer to receive a good education for all. Fix the other neighborhoods with everything we work so hard to have. We are a duel working household that pays taxes and we do everything we can to make sure our son has a safe environment to receive a good education.
feederpatterns_comment: See above comment.
eschoicesets_comment: Unacceptable! Fix the bigger problem! The reason Lafayette is overcrowded is because we have to take out of bound in order to receive money from the government!
mschoicesets_comment: See above comment!
msproximity_comment: Absolutely unacceptable!!
hslottery_comment: Are you kidding?! Unacceptable!
setasides_comment: Good! Because this is ridiculous! Do not take our right to go to our neighborhood school!

feederpatterns_comment: This is rather poor.  The feeder patterns are supposed to change in another year or two.  There is no chance that the "New School" will be built, up and running by then.  Is there a location decided?  And, Cardozo is a nonstarter.
eschoicesets_comment: This is an unacceptable terrible idea.  Period.
mschoicesets_comment: How can it be a choice set if there is only one school?  Nevertheless, it is impossible to plan for the future in this way.
hslottery_comment: Is this a joke?  No serious person would accept this.

boundaries_comment: Why can't we send our children to Goding like our family did for the first couple decades we lived here?
feederpatterns_comment: Eastern is our neighborhood High School and should be the one we have rights to.
eschoicesets_comment: There are some good schools in there, but I'm unsure if I would have a have a right to one of them or if I would have to go to one that's further from home, if I didn't want to.
mschoicesets_comment: Prefer to keep our rights to Stuart Hobson

boundaries_comment: I applaud the idea of bringing these new areas into the Oyster boundary - giving these people access to a great school. But, I think DCPS is vastly underestimating the potential new enrollment. Current enrollment in public school is low due to poor access to good neighborhood school. Changing that will possibly dramatically increase the potential enrollees from this neighborhood.  Oyster would have to be expanded to accommodate this. The proposal could explode the school if this is not taken into account.
feederpatterns_comment: Proposing to send Oyster students to Cardozo (in its current form) would be a disaster for Oyster, and for anyone who owns property in this area. Cardozo is in a completely different league from Oyster (and Wilson). With DC-CAS scores near the bottom, and a 40% graduation rate, Cardozo is extremely unlikely to be seen as an attractive destination for Oyster students who as a group rank among the top in the City.  Loss of the feeder pattern to a reasonably successful high-school will undoubtedly unravel Oyster as parents move their high-performing children to other districts, or shift their kids to private alternatives. This in turn will have a direct and substantial effect on property values - amounting to a tax on all owners of property in this school district regardless of whether they have kids. In short, this is a disaster.
eschoicesets_comment: Although rationing may be necessary given the scarcity of good schools, this idea is idiotic. Besides being arbitrary, it is probably going to cause a total mess. In the abstract, if everyone votes to put their kids in the best performing school, then almost by definition, all families will be dumped into a lottery.  It's just random.
mschoicesets_comment: Dumb idea here too.
msproximity_comment: Sort of makes sense, other than that these schools have very different performance statistics, so that makes one of the two pretty irrelevant.  Putting everyone in a lottery would mean large numbers are going to randomly assigned to a school that they almost certainly view as a poor choice.  This is almost as unlikely to unravel Oyster as the Cardozo feeder pattern.
hslottery_comment: This is quite possibly the worst of several quite bad ideas.  The effect of such a lottery will be asymmetric. All high performing students will leave for the suburbs or go to private schools because.
setasides_comment:
A band aid solution. Whose seats in the neighborhoods with the "good" schools are being taken away for these set-asides?  Doesn't that just strain the already capacity strained schools more?  For those hoping to get into one of these set asides - especially at high school level - this really would be just like winning the lottery given how much competition there is likely to be over a few scarce spots.  I just don't seen any winners here - except random ones.

All of these plans have a rearranging deck chairs on the Titanic feeling to them.  Focusing on creating even just one more high-quality high school and a few decent middle schools would alleviate almost all of the opposition the city is likely to face regarding the feeder pattern proposals. 

Fix the capacity/quality problem first.  These proposals put the cart before the horse. 

I have two kids at Oyster and one about to start. For the first time since moving to this district ten years ago, I am beginning to doubt whether we should stay given the high school options it seems the city wants to offer.

boundaries_comment: Our kids go to charter schools and these old vs. new boundaries aren't that different, so this doesn't affect me.
feederpatterns_comment: Middle school at Cardozo is a terrible terrible idea, so glad they're working to fix it.
eschoicesets_comment: Not sure why both Garrison and Seaton need to survive. Those schools duplicate each other and they're right near each other. I'm indifferent among these schools, which my kids won't attned anyway.
hslottery_comment: If they expand supply in good schools, then a lottery is best, so this is a conditional response.
setasides_comment: Better yet: give them greater weight/priority to low-income families in an unrestricted choice system, so instead of set-asides per school, poor kids get more choice, in case they all want the same school.

boundaries_comment: Why change something that seems to be working?! Additionally, where is the funding to address the modernization and the growth that school will experience?
feederpatterns_comment: We moved to Crestwood because of Deal and Wilson. It would be better for them to first prove he other schools before shifting students around. Moving students is not the soliton. Providing each equal resources to all schools is a better start. Equal schools is what DC needs.
eschoicesets_comment: Please see my previous comments. Better and equal schools for all. Shift resources in order to improve the schools and not the students.
mschoicesets_comment: These schools and the programs do not even currently exist. How are they going to address the students that are going to middle school in the next year?!
msproximity_comment: Please previous comments re: elementary schools.
hslottery_comment: The thought that a student may have to travel across town to get to school is absurd. Moving the students around is not the answer.
setasides_comment: See comments above. Equal schools, better schools.

eschoicesets_comment: Maury Elementary School is closer to our house than every school in this list except Miner. Seems like it should be one of our options.

hslottery_comment: It's a neighborhood high school and ridiculous to have to travel to another HS.

feederpatterns_comment: No school options on this side of the city
eschoicesets_comment: We have to factor in "driving time" for these "neighborhood schools"  I might as well travel to an out of boundary school
mschoicesets_comment: Could work well for wards that have more than one school option.  Makes no difference in Ward 7
hslottery_comment: I'm alright with that
setasides_comment: 10-20% of the total population or each grade or each classroom?  Those kids who are able to get into HeadStart would have an advantage over families who were not able to get in?

boundaries_comment: Ms. Scott does an OK job with what she has, but there has been no true investment in this school.
feederpatterns_comment: you ignored community input, shutting down Eastern willy-nilly, without a plan for athletics and other programs as they diminished in enrollment; then did the renovation without first planning a curriculum, which we'd been promised would drive the design; then re-opened having completely destroyed community trust. And now, that's the great big new choice for residents here? I don't think so.
eschoicesets_comment: every school needs to be equally safe, welcoming and excellent before you pull this nonsense. OTOH, while everyone around here clamors to get into Peabody, it's more than 12 blocks from here and not a viable option as any kind of "neighborhood" school IMO
mschoicesets_comment: unless and until all three schools are well ordered and well endowed, this is ugly nonsense
msproximity_comment: again, more uncertainty is not helping, and you must be allowing apples to apples choices, not some kids get into an apple and some are stuck with starved out raisin.
hslottery_comment: I expected the boundary process to take a good hard look at our racial and income situation in this city and try to find some ways of equalizing or encouraging attendance at different schools to create some diversity. Instead, I am seeing complete abdication of the necessary work. Meanwhile, who honestly truly thinks that one single solitary kid from Spring Valley is going to shlep to Ballou if assigned there? Really? If you can find me one, I will consider this plan. And what about the cost in time and stress and money for the kids who have to travel the length and breadth of the city? This is either clueless or cruel. And given that it's your responsibility to take this seriously and buy a clue if you must, I'm going with cruel.
setasides_comment: this is the most amazingly annoying idea yet. This GUARANTEES that the "low-performing schools" remain low-performing by labeling them and encouraging people to move away from them, but of course not guaranteeing any stable, community-building access to a good neighborhood school. So, proximity to Eastern would make me eligible for a set-aside? The school that Michelle Rhee and Tommy Wells insisted they were turning into a showcase. Yeah, this whole thing is working real well.

eschoicesets_comment: This is a terrible idea. It completely disregards the notion of a neighborhood school, which is why many families choose DCPS over charters,

mschoicesets_comment: Interesting pros and cons, in terms of balancing location with curricular focus.
hslottery_comment: My response is somewhat selfish, in that the only public, non-charter HS we'd consider is Wilson. If we weren't able to send our child to Wilson, I think we'd have to look at other school options (and it's possible it would have affected our decision to buy in the District). I do recognize, though, that part of what's needed is for more parents to be committed to the improvement of other schools in the District.

msproximity_comment: I worry that sending a child who has not had bilingual opportunities before middle school would struggle during middle school. More research would be needed

boundaries_comment: currently OOB and do not believe Tubman or Cooke are reasonable choices: we would have to move to VA
feederpatterns_comment: would move to VA:  children OOB to a school we are happy with
eschoicesets_comment: all bad choices
msproximity_comment: these are not middle schools: we would lose feeder to Deal and Wilson under current OOB promise
hslottery_comment: no changes until all schools are high performing
setasides_comment: "best guess" not good enough: we have ALREADY suffered through the lottery so that we could stay in DC

boundaries_comment: Watkins and Peabody are currently combined under the Capitol Hill Cluster School (CHCS). We have been very happy at CHCS and would not like to see anything about this successful school change - except for it to keep getting better and better!
feederpatterns_comment: We would prefer the Student Hobson feeder pattern .
eschoicesets_comment: I think we should have one school that all neighbors have in common and work together towards making it great.
mschoicesets_comment: Let's offer STEM and other specialty focuses at ALL schools. Don't all kids deserve it?
msproximity_comment: Let's keep our neighborhood kids together!
hslottery_comment: What does this have to offer over the current system?

boundaries_comment: I believe that the environment that I choose to put my children reflects their ability to learn as well as their over all behavior.
feederpatterns_comment: I also believe in quality over convenience. Even though the schools are in walking to our home it is not safe nor up to my standards in raising 3 boys in a great environment.
eschoicesets_comment: Again, these schools are not up to standard. The kids are walking around the neighborhood cursing, fighting, stealing, and the parents are even dropping their kids off in pajamas, due rags, and I think it sets the tone on how well the child will do in school.
mschoicesets_comment: My son who is in middle receives special education and thrives off of a calm environment. He owuld not do well if he had to worry about fighting, cursing, just negative things all around. I want him in an  environment that is conducive to him getting the best education that he deserves.
msproximity_comment: I think that this is absurd! The only options that I'm being given are all on the same level. Test scores are low, the environment is unsafe, and the quality is terrible. Why are rights being denied to ensuring that my sons have the best education possible. Even if the schools are being renovated, the same people are still attending. If anything the parents need training and need to be taught how to become an effective parents in their child's lives.
hslottery_comment: My sons have been going to schools in Ward 3 since they started. I do not want their school districts to change. I want them to attend Wilson HS. My children have been going to their feeder schools since the age of 5. I think that it will totally disrupt their education if I put them in a different environment where they have to worry about so many other things and be able to focus on their education. These options do make any sense!!!
setasides_comment: These options are not to my liking. My kids have been in these schools(Ward 3) for far too long to have their rights stripped from them. This is unacceptable! I can understand it more if, that moving all new students who wanted to apply for out of boundary was not given that option anymore but, to take it away from families that have did this for over 10 years is so unfair. My kids will be devastated and completely torn in these schools. I will not just be dealing with moving anxiety but I will have to deal with quality and their safety.

boundaries_comment: I don't understand the purpose of expanding the boundaries of an over-crowded campus, even if it has low in-boundary participation rates.  I do not like k-8 education campuses for my kids, and would leverage school choice if possible to avoid sending my 3 or 4 year old to the same school as 13 year olds.  I don't believe education campuses provide middle school students with the unique services they require, and short-change nearly all students on enriching resources (e.g., advanced math instruction doesn't often happen in education campuses because so many resources go to ECE).
feederpatterns_comment: I don't know how anyone can be happy about the "new middle school" without knowing what that program will look like.  And, I don't think that any DCPS high schools that are not the application-based programs (e.g., SWW, Banneker, etc) are truly college preparatory, so I cannot be excited about Roosevelt until I see how the school program improves at Roosevelt and other neighborhood high schools.
eschoicesets_comment: as stated above, I don't want Education Campuses for my children.  And, we are currently enrolled at a bilingual DCPS - none of these schools include a bilingual option which is a high priority for our family.
mschoicesets_comment: as noted above, I need to learn more about the possible programming available at the new middle school before forming an opinion.  I am hopeful that the community mobilization for this new school will garner specialized programming such as an IB curriculum and/or dual language.
msproximity_comment: I do not like education campuses.  middle school students need and deserve specialized programming and resources that meet their unique needs.
hslottery_comment: while I am not currently thrilled about our in-boundary school due to its low performance, I think it is important for folks to have access to neighborhood schools in which they can become truly invested.  As my children get older I am looking forward to opportunities to work with Roosevelt leadership to ensure that it is a strong option for anyone who chooses it, from within the neighborhood or beyond.
setasides_comment: we need to improve the quality of schools across the city.  None of these proposals do anything to do that.

boundaries_comment: Demographically, I worry that this change would make it more difficult to maintain the English/Spanish balance.
feederpatterns_comment: I am not opposed to eliminating Deal from the feeder pattern. It makes sense from a bilingual perspective (and we would be sending our kids to Adams anyway), but I suspect it will drive some parents away. If we had to send our kids to Cardozo, though, we would almost certainly move to MD or switch to private school.
eschoicesets_comment: We love the neighborhood school model for so many reasons - walkability, predictability, the sense of community - plus so many people, including us, choose to live where we do for its access to Oyster. I hate this proposal more than anything.
mschoicesets_comment: I don't fully understand the impact of this.
msproximity_comment: See above re: commitment to Oyster and neighborhood school model.
hslottery_comment: The traffic impact alone gives me nightmares, but this has all the downsides as other proposals above - a lack of walkability, predictability, community feel, etc.
setasides_comment: I don't understand the impact of this proposal.

boundaries_comment: consern with quality as parents we need more choice
feederpatterns_comment: consern with quality
eschoicesets_comment: consern with quality
setasides_comment: no sucess in education  no long term chance

boundaries_comment: It's close to home so it's convenient, but not concerned about the environment, because I have witnessed the principal arguing with the students.
feederpatterns_comment: I've witnessed Ballou students consistently fighting after school, and being disruptive.
All three of these schools are subpar, and force us into the lottery to try to get into a charter or a better performing DCPS that is not in our neighborhood. We want better neighborhood schools.
eschoicesets_comment: At least this gives us a chance to get into Oyster or Bancraft, better performing schools than Cooke or Marie Reed. But the reality is that demand for those schools outstrip supply, again forcing us into the lottery for better performing charters.
mschoicesets_comment: This is a complete unknown, so it is difficult to judge what it would mean for our family.
msproximity_comment: Again, neither of these middle schools are acceptable to us, forcing us into the charter system.
hslottery_comment: This is a surefire way to push higher income families out of DCPS, if not out of the city.
setasides_comment: This is more acceptable than a city wide lottery for high school. But, again, demand outstrips supply for seats in quality programs. A better idea is to create quality magnet programs in underutilized high schools.

boundaries_comment: I would like my child to be able to attend the public SWS elementary school one block from our residence.
feederpatterns_comment: A planned feeder pattern based on proximity is a smart community decision.
eschoicesets_comment: I want my child to be able to attend the SWS public elementary school one block from my residence.
mschoicesets_comment: Families need to have a known school they are guaranteed to get into.  Without a known guaranteed path for my child's education through 12th grade there is too much uncertainty.  I would leave the district and move elsewhere.
msproximity_comment: Families need a known path of guaranteed schools for their children.
hslottery_comment: In order to raise my family in DC I need to know the guaranteed school path through 12th grade for my children.

feederpatterns_comment: The Cluster is a good model and is working.  Gives certainty and keeps parents involved at all schools in  Cluster.
eschoicesets_comment:
Only works if all schools are good.  Payne is a disaster.  With this choice set, no one would choose Payne and if sent there by lottery, would leave the system.  Fix Payne and this could work. (For starters, need to address the transient population from the shelter--concentrating these kids in Payne is de facto segregation.  Why not spread them out in other schools and DC neighborhoods?)

Also, all schools in the choice set should feed into the same middle school so their is parity among schools and cohesiveness within the neighborhood.
mschoicesets_comment: Terrible idea.  If you don't link an elementary school with a middle school, the curricula will not be coordinated, you won't have elementary parents working to improve their feeder middle school.  Creates too much uncertainty, dilutes resources and parents will leave.
msproximity_comment: Terrible for the same reasons as above .  Proximity for middle school is less important because kids are more independent .  Need an elementary with a feeder.
hslottery_comment: Need neighborhood/community commitment to a high school AND need certainty.  Parents are not comfortable leaving the choice of a high school to chance.  Need feeders throughout the system and a lottery to supplement.  Also,  must commit to the IB program at Eastern.  So many families want to stay--DCPS is missing a real opportunity with Eastern.
setasides_comment: This lets DCPS off easy and punishes everyone else.  Underperforming schools should be fixed.  Period.

boundaries_comment: The redrawn boundary for Powell arbitrarily forces many families in very close proximity to Powell to travel much farther for West, i.e., going from a school they can walk to, to a school they must drive to.  This is particularly egregious given that Powell is an elementary school, which is when proximity is at its most important.  Arkansas Avenue, which is a mere block from Powell Elementary, is simply not an appropriate cut off for Powell's in-boundary zone.
feederpatterns_comment: Roosevelt, as it currently is, and without significant academic improvement, is simply NOT a school we would send our children to.  We would move or be forced to somehow send our children to private school.
eschoicesets_comment: I don't think choice sets are appropriate at the elementary school level.  Neighborhood and community involvement is key to building good schools. In addition, as mentioned before, proximity is very important at the elementary school level.  A set of four schools would necessarily mean that a substantial number of them are farther than I think is appropriate to travel to school in a city.  Moreover, our particular choice set does NOT include the closest elementary school to us (Powell), which is 2 blocks away.  It's illogical!!
mschoicesets_comment: While I am not generally-speaking opposed to choice sets at the middle school level, I cannot possibly support a proposal that leaves us with a "choice" of a single, as-yet unplanned, to-be-created-out-of-thin-air middle school.  I applaud the efforts being made here, but to think that Mayor Gray could or should "announce" his decision on the proposals within a few months' time, with implementation in 2015, is incredibly naive.  How can you decide on a proposal that includes a situation such as this one, where your option is a "new school"?  Also, I don't understand why every school within a choice set would be given a particular focus without giving kids (and their families) the ability to choose what school, and therefore what focus, they want to pursue?
msproximity_comment: I'm neutral on this because it's not clear that there will be a sibling preference.  If so, I'm happier with this proposal; if not, I'm not happy with this proposal.
hslottery_comment: While Roosevelt (as it is now) is a not a school that we would ever send our kids to, I am not in favor of a city-wide lottery.  It makes no sense whatsoever to shuffle kids all over the city based on a lottery system.  Neighborhood and community involvement are important to school success.  But maybe just as important, the DC metro system is simply not capable of handling this traffic, and I have no faith that it will be so capable anytime in the near or foreseeable future.
setasides_comment:
I'm neutral on this because I don't think any intelligent choice can be made based on the information given, i.e., how low-performing schools will be determined.  I'm generally not opposed to set-asides, I'm skeptical that in practice they can be implemented fairly and as envisioned.  What if a school is at-capacity with in-boundary children?  Would in-boundary children be turned away in order to preserve the set-asides? Where would those children turned away go?  

I understand that many, many details will need to be worked out and that these proposals are just a first step in a process.  And, I applaud the attempt at a process.  But, I keep coming back to the pronouncement that Mayor Gray will decide on a proposal within a few months and wonder how can that possibly be (especially if these proposals were always meant to be just a first step).  I think DME Smith will gain more support and traction if Mayor Gray relinquishes any naive attempt to "come to a decision" about these proposals.  Let the process take its natural course.  I'm sure all of the feedback the DME is getting can only help the process; use it, don't impede it.

boundaries_comment: I don't have an opinion about the elementary school boundary either way.
feederpatterns_comment: We bought our home with the intention of attending Deal MS and Wilson HS.  I would say that if our neighborhood were to be rezoned, it would need to be for an equal or better opportunity, neither of which I have seen proposed by DCPS to date.
mschoicesets_comment: It's hard to be excited about something new that has no track record and NO explanation as to what will come, what the vision is for new schools, how parents should and could buy into the success of that model, etc.
msproximity_comment: It's hard to be excited about something new that has no track record and NO explanation as to what will come, what the vision is for new schools, how parents should and could buy into the success of that model, etc.
hslottery_comment: While this seems like the most equitable choice for all DC residents, if the current situation of Wilson vs Non-Wilson is the choice, I think it is a false choice.  It has no predictability which will drive people away from the district in droves.  It also reinforces the thinking that DCPS has no vision for providing new, quality schools in the future, if we are forced to go with the model of "new schools for Ward 4"

mschoicesets_comment: Would like to keep Deal as an option
msproximity_comment: These are failing schools. Unacceptable!
hslottery_comment: At least with the city wide lottery we have a small chance in attending the only non failing middle school in town, Deal.

boundaries_comment: I have no problem with iterative changes to zone borders that are needed as populations shift. (Changes shouldn't be every 20 years, however. Every couple of years things should automatically adjust to keep enrollment at maximum efficiency.)
hslottery_comment: A lottery, without regard to home address, is the only fair way to allocate seats.

boundaries_comment: It is important for families and students to have predictability about their choices.  I support each family have a school to which they have a right to attend.  If more than one school fits this profile, that would be acceptable, although it reduces predictability for the schools perhaps.  I do not support the proposal to create choice sets that would eliminate a right to a specific school.
feederpatterns_comment: Ward 4 currently has no stand-alone middle school and I agree that establishing one should be a priority for DCPS.
eschoicesets_comment: Frankly this option would provide our family with a bigger selection of appealing choices for elementary school.
mschoicesets_comment: The idea of developing a special focus for middle schools is a useful one that should be explored separate from the issue of choice sets.
hslottery_comment: Although we don't see our current zoned high school as a clear choice, I absolutely disagree with a citywide lottery system which would provide NOONE with predictability.

boundaries_comment:
We rely on walking and public transportation to get around which is the primary reason we bought our house.
The proposed changes would force us to seriously consider moving.

We can see Janney from our home.  We walk there everyday. Hearst is not our neighborhood school and it would force us to drive to school creating increased traffic or take the bus which includes crossing a main thoroughfare three times a day and costs the city money.   We want walkability and neighborhood schools. We want Janney not Hearst.  This data from the committee doesn't even apply to us--it applies to Murch_
feederpatterns_comment: Hearst is not our neighborhood elementary school--it is 2 neighborhoods away from ours.
eschoicesets_comment: That is insane. It would move our kids to schools vastly underperforming the schools we are in.
mschoicesets_comment: We live one block from Deal. WHy wouldn't we go there.. oh yeah because the DME has no idea what they are doing.
msproximity_comment: AGAIN---WE LIVE A BLOCK FROM DEAL WHY WOULDN'T WE GO THERE?
hslottery_comment: WE LIVE HALF A BLOCK FROM WILSON WHY WOULDN'T WE GO THERE?
setasides_comment: We are at a high-performing school and will be moved to a lower performing school.  It's nonsense. We need a half-mile geographic set aside to preserve walkability to neighborhood schools.

eschoicesets_comment: I believe that a single neighborhood school option fosters community in and out of school. Being able to walk to my local school is something I would not want to give up, especially if it meant a commute up to Tenleytown.
mschoicesets_comment: I hope that attending Deal would continue to be an option for students who enter Oyster in the later years without knowing Spanish.

feederpatterns_comment: While I like having rights to a STEM school, it's not easily walkable/ accessible by public transport for my family.
eschoicesets_comment: I like being able to lottery for the best schools in the neighborhood, and my choice set doesn't include them.
mschoicesets_comment: Would ECs also have a focus in middle school?  I think I would support this more if the specialized programs were already in place.

boundaries_comment: These schools have to get themselves together before they can attract a diverse population.
msproximity_comment: These middle schools have not established themselves as safe and effective places of learning. Therefore I would not send my children there despite their convenient location.
hslottery_comment: The schools have to put together programming attractive to a range of students and establish a reputation as a safe place to attend. This offering could start small as a school within a school and then have a phase in to become the mission or theme for the entire campus. With each school, proven ability to deliver a quality program, effectively administered is key to attracting a diverse and stable student body.

boundaries_comment: We live very close to Murch elementary - it is less than a five minute walk. Hearst Elementary will mean a significant commute for us.
feederpatterns_comment: We chose this neighborhood for its high-quality public schools.
eschoicesets_comment: The choice set would provide some options within the changes. The choices also might increase the quality of all of these schools as they compete for students. However, not having a right to attend a specific school is a downside.
mschoicesets_comment: Part of the attraction of this neighborhood for us is Deal MS. Without a right to attend Deal, we may move to Montgomery County.
msproximity_comment: We live much closer to Deal than to West EC. And as noted above, Deal MS was one of the reasons we chose to live in this neighborhood. Without a right to attend it, we may move to Montgomery County.
setasides_comment: It would be useful to explore this option more. My biggest concern is that the high-performing schools are over-crowded already. How will they be forced to accept 10-20% of students from low-performing schools? Other than that concern, this seems like a useful proposal.

feederpatterns_comment: With the new proposal, there is no stand alone middle school in my boundary period.  Additionally, there are no schools in the new proposed boundary that are as good are better than the schools current boundary.  The proposed zoning puts my children going to low performing schools.
mschoicesets_comment: This is an unknown.
msproximity_comment: Not a fan of the education campus.  Isn't DCPS phasing this out?
hslottery_comment: With the large amount of under performing schools, this is a disaster.  Not every student in DC can go to the few high performing schools.  First, DCPS should focus on improving the schools, replicating programs that are working in high performing schools to low performing schools.  If schools are performing, re-drawing the boundaries would be less of an issue.
setasides_comment: This only increases the educational gap.

boundaries_comment: I don't have a problem with the decision to leave Thomson's boundaries alone.  I don't really see a need to change that.
feederpatterns_comment: I would send my kids to SWW@FS but not Jefferson.  Currently my children do not attend Thomson but we are thinking about SWW@FS. I would also NOT send my kids to Cardozo.  (We would go private before that would happen.) I am open to Eastern but there are at least 3 schools closer to us than Eastern so it just does not make sense logistically.
eschoicesets_comment: I don't like the idea of choice sets.  I also am not sure how a charter would become part of the choice sets.  There are a few charters that I would never send my children to (Kipp, CAPCS, CCPCS,etc.). Note:  My children have attended charter schools in the past so I am open to them.
mschoicesets_comment: Very confusing. Currently we're zoned for SWW@FS and that would not be an option in the set? Again,  I don't really like the choice sets idea and I have no info on the " new middle " school.
msproximity_comment: I prefer SWW@FS.  Not sure how Walker Jones is closer but I'd have to map it.  As previously stated, I would go private before I would send my kids to Cardozo.
hslottery_comment: This is a non starter for me as is Cardozo.  I love DC but I this would could drive me out to one of the surrounding counties.
setasides_comment: I don't really have an opinion on set asides.

feederpatterns_comment: What would the middle school be? And how close physically would it be to the elementary feeder school?

boundaries_comment: We love Janney and live less than 3 blocks from the school. In addition, we drop our kids off at Janney and then immediately catch the Red Line. If we go to Hearst, it is nearly a mile away. Plus we will likely have to drive to work.
feederpatterns_comment: I'm happy we would stay in Deal/Wilson. Not happy about switching to Hearst.
eschoicesets_comment: This is ridiculous. We are less than 3 blocks from Janney and about 5 blocks from Murch. but these choice sets place us in schools that could be several miles away.
mschoicesets_comment: We simply would not attend Hardy. It's performance is much lower than Deal and we live about two blocks from Deal. We would instead send our kids to private school.
msproximity_comment: We live 2 blocks from Deal. We are some of the closest families to that school. We would not attend any middle school other than Deal.
hslottery_comment: This is so ridiculous of a proposal that it's hard to know where to start. We live nearly across the street from Wilson. It's football field lights shine into our windows every night. There is no way I'm sending my kids across town to attend a different high school.
setasides_comment: I agree with 10% set asides. I think 20% is much too high and simply is a way for DC Schools to avoid improving poor performing schools.

boundaries_comment: Eaton is a wonderful, academically rich and diverse elementary school.
feederpatterns_comment: I would like my child to attend Deal. I chose to accept our placement at Eaton and not choose another Ward 3 school with the intent that my child attend Deal and then Wilson. To take away that predictability and place students at a lower performing middle school is unacceptable.
mschoicesets_comment: It should remain the families' choice to send their child to Deal or Hardy.
msproximity_comment: I would not like my child to be moved to a bilingual middle school, further from my home, when they have attended a single language elementary school.
hslottery_comment: Completely unacceptable. Wilson is the highest performing high school in the city. My real estate cost is tied to my right to Wilson. Shuttling students all over the city is not a good option. Forcing students who previously fed into high performing schools into lower performing school jeopardizes their ultimate academic achievement and future success.

feederpatterns_comment: If we can go to deal that is fine, but we are not sending  our child to Hardy middle school.
eschoicesets_comment: Neutral as we can still go to our current school.
msproximity_comment: If we don't maintain Deal as our middle school our child will not be going to public school
hslottery_comment: This is a bad idea. It will drive people from the city if they don't know where their kids are going to go to school.
setasides_comment: As long as kids in boundary get in, it is fine to set aside a percentage of seat.

boundaries_comment: School is too discipline focused, poorly managed, and I will never send my children there.
feederpatterns_comment: Deal and Wilson are quality schools and I support those as our feeders.
eschoicesets_comment: My child attends eaton now and I want her to remain there.  None of these elementary schools listed are strong schools.

setasides_comment:
We bought our house partly because we wanted our son to go to Deal on day and continue
with programs etc that he was getting at Eaton.   If you change things it is unfair to do so unless
you grandfather all students into what they expected when they bought/rented their home.

boundaries_comment: I strongly support the proposed pattern to include Hobart and Irving streets, in the mount pleasant feeder for Bancroft elem, Deal middle and Wilson HS feeders.
eschoicesets_comment: I support Bancroft proposal
mschoicesets_comment: I support Deal MS feeder
hslottery_comment: I support having Wilson be the designated feeder pattern school

feederpatterns_comment: We will have to do a lot of work to get Hardy to where it needs to be for our needs. This work will be much more acrimonious than the current work being done. But it will be done. Wait and read.
eschoicesets_comment: Oyster Adams is a nice little distance from here and won't feed into Wilson. Non-starter for many but won't effect me.
mschoicesets_comment: See comment on Hardy above.
hslottery_comment: Insipid idea with much negative potential for NW elected officials should it go through.
setasides_comment: I would rather fix those schools.

boundaries_comment: this is a poorly constructed survey.  Here, the question "what do you think" is vague.  There is a lot of information in the text above.  What do I think about WHAT, exactly?  What are you asking people about, exactly?
feederpatterns_comment: I have the same comment here as the above comment.  What are you asking me about?  The proposed feeder pattern?  It's not explicit.
mschoicesets_comment: are you asking me what I think about the proposed choice set?  "What do you think" is rather open-ended--maybe you also want to know what I think about the idea of giving every middle school a special focus.  I can "like" that idea but still "not like" the proposed choice set.  Poorly constructed survey.
msproximity_comment: The map shown in this survey question about middle schools shows Oyster Bilingual at 2801 Calvert St.  My understanding is that is the address for the elementary school, NOT the middle school.  I thought the Oyster middle school was in Adam's Morgan, on a different campus/building.  Is Oyster's middle school really the second closest middle school for my address?
hslottery_comment: Again, what do I think about WHAT?  that "I may or may not have guaranteed access to Wilson HS"?  What kind of question is THAT?  As for a citywide lottery, can you imagine the additional traffic that would be generated by this idea?  What a nightmare.  We already have horrible traffic, let's make it worse.  Not to mention the pollution, additional greenhouse gases, etc.

boundaries_comment: One of the main reasons we purchased our home is that it was within the Tubman school district rather than Raymond.  Now it looks like we're going to be forced to send our children to a school with a dismal record rather than the best public elementary school in the city.  I'm also concerned this will affect property values.

feederpatterns_comment: While I would prefer to send my children to higher performing middle and high schools. I understand if the current pattern is unsustainable. The only way DC will have multiple viable public School options is to make much needed improvements in the under-performing schools. It is my hope that this will occur at Roosevelt.
mschoicesets_comment: This is where removing Deal is unacceptable.
msproximity_comment: Not crazy about either option.
